HEADLINE: New York City Can Do Better With Underused Industrial Areas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The New York City Planning Department is seeking new uses for industrial areas, you report Jan. 15. By this proposal Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration acknowledges its failure in industrial development; reaffirms its promotion of business services and information at the expense of industry, and advocates rezoning to reduce the city's stock of industrial land and buildings, and allow massive discount retail warehouses and supermarket use in them. 
 This is a prescription for disaster and must be prevented. It would preclude future large-scale industrial development; use up irreplaceable low rent large industrial buildings and reduce their job-producing potential. And it would destroy small-business entrepreneurship in minority areas, undermining one of the high priorities of the Dinkins administration.
A New York City Controller's Office study shows that since the late 1950's, 800,000 manufacturing jobs have left the city. Moreover, between April 1989 and June 1992, employment in the city fell by 370,000 jobs. This represents 10.2 percent of the city's work force (the largest proportion in the private sector) and 20 percent of the jobs lost nationally during the recession. These were primarily service jobs, illustrating this sector's increasing vulnerability.
For the city to throw all its eggs in one basket would be suicidal and preclude employment of most of its dependent population, who have no interest in or skills for office work. Local government must abandon its misconception that the city's future lies exclusively in the service sector.
If New York City is to solve its fiscal and social crisis, stem the migration of business and the middle class, and attract new jobs on a scale in proportion to need, it needs an increase in industrial land and building resources and an independent industrial and economic development strategy. That strategy would use the city's assets and resources (such as extensive waterfront, vacant piers, the Brooklyn Army Terminal, the Brooklyn Navy Yard and numerous vacant city blocks in all boroughs), train its work force and make doing business here cheaper and easier than elsewhere.
For more than 25 years, New York City has been sitting on a high-tech export tax-free zone light industrial development proposal that can do this without reducing revenues, creating unfair competition or requiring major capital investment. It would do for New York City what it has done for such places as Hong Kong, Taiwan and Shannon, Ireland.
This city has the ability and resources to solve its problems through its own efforts.
 
HARRY L. LANGER
New York, Jan. 18, 1993
 
The writer heads a real estate organization bearing his name.

HEADLINE: Shareholders Exercise New Power With Nation's Biggest Companies

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Only a week ago, James D. Robinson 3d appeared to have won the battle of the board room at the American Express Company, persuading the company's directors to keep him on as chairman. But within days, large shareholders began to sell stock or meet with the board and top executives, seeking his ouster. Friday night, Mr. Robinson gave in and resigned.
The news provided a dramatic end to a remarkable week in American corporate history. I.B.M. and Westinghouse, two very large corporations with many unhappy shareholders, announced that their chief executives would be leaving. And Sears, Roebuck & Company, also the object of shareholder criticism, said it would close its historic catalogue operations, lay off 50,000 workers and close 113 stores in an effort to increase profits and its stock price. 
 At all these companies, the changes were a sign of a shift in power, with shareholders gaining more leverage over the executives and managers of the corporate world. The shareholder rights movement, once a theoretical concept pushed by a band of academicians in the 1980's, is now reshaping the corporate landscape.
At American Express, for example, the largest shareholder, the J. P. Morgan bank, which owns 13.2 million, or 2.77 percent, of the company's shares, met with top executives to lobby against Mr. Robinson. So did other large stockholders, including Alliance Capital and Putnam Management.
 
'Many Companies Vulnerable'
 At Westinghouse, large shareholders began to meet with top executives in October, pressing for the sale of the company's troubled financial services subsidiary. The executives agreed, but the subsidiary was not sold. So the large shareholders pressed for a new management team, and the directors agreed.
"Shareholders have suddenly pulled together as a power base," said John Wilcox, chairman at Georgeson & Company, which helps companies manage shareholder votes by soliciting proxies from holders who cannot attend meetings. "They are talking about the real stuff of corporate performance, not just theoretical things. The economic problems at many companies combined with this increased power of shareholders have left many companies vulnerable."
The movement's leader is the California Public Employees' Retirement System. With $72 billion to invest, the fund owns stock in more than 1,000 companies. The state pension funds of New York, Massachusetts and Wisconsin are also very active.
The movement is based in the belief that the shareholders, either as individuals or collectively as mutual funds, pension funds or other institutions, should exercise power as influential owners of a corporation. Rather than accepting that the corporation is the fief of a chief executive and his hand-picked board, these investors say the corporation must respond to their demands for better performance and higher profits.
The blows struck by these shareholders have already been felt throughout America's executive suites and have brought about significant changes in companies' strategies and leadership. The movement has also forced corporate boards into a new stance that has turned them into tough overseers rather than silent partners.
"There's been a huge shift in power within companies," said Ralph Whitworth, president of United Shareholders Association, an investors' advocacy group in Washington. "We're seeing things move in the direction of major structural and managerial changes."
 
'Boards Have No Choice'
 Institutional shareholders, concerned about lagging corporate performance, were behind I.B.M.'s decision to seek a replacement for John F. Akers, its chairman and chief executive. And it was shareholders who successfully sought the ouster of Paul E. Lego at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Earlier, shareholder pressure had been instrumental in galvanizing General Motors' directors to seek the resignation of Robert C. Stempel as chief executive.
"In these cases, boards have no choice but to act," said James E. Heard, president of Institutional Shareholder Services, a consultant to pension funds on shareholder issues. "How can they say to their largest shareholders, who are not quick-buck artists, they they have no right to raise questions about corporate performance? The ripple effect of what happened at I.B.M. and G.M. at other companies is bound to be significant."
As recently as three years ago, the shareholders rights movement was largely an academic exercise, as some pension funds led generally unsuccessful proxy fights against leading corporations. In many battles, shareholder advocates sought to gain board seats or to change rules so that it would be easier for those outside the company to be elected to corporate boards and their key committees.
The movement was born amid the takeover battles of the 1980's, as some institutional shareholders became dismayed that corporations erected elaborate defenses to avoid being taken over, in some cases denying large shareholders the chance to accept a would-be acquirer's top dollar for their holdings. And they were frustrated that some companies would pay "greenmail" -- a premium above market price for the shares of a corporate raider -- to halt a raid, while the large shareholders were never offered that price.
In the last few years, shareholders have focused on other issues, like executive compensation and whether it is tied to performance. And they have won some important battles at the Securities and Exchange Commission. In October, for instance, the commission made it easier for large shareholder groups to talk among themselves and take collective actions against corporations without violating proxy rules. The agency has also validated the attacks on executive compensation by requiring corporations to increase public reporting of executive pay packages.
Equally important, large shareholders have taken to meeting regularly with top corporate managers and discussing once-privileged business matters, like corporate strategy covering which divisions to sell or buy, and what businesses to enter.
The California pension fund, popularly known as Calpers, is so big that it cannot easily or quickly sell the stocks of companies it is unhappy with. So, as with many other institutional investors, it is trying to improve the performance of the companies it invests in.
"We are investors, and we are owners," said Dale Hanson, chief executive of the California fund. "Our focus is basically on the board of directors and making sure they understand they are responsive to the owners and providing oversight of management. So many are captive of the chief executive and, unless an outside force comes along to shake them up, there's not much oversight."
To do that, the big investors have been meeting with corporate executives and boards. And Calpers annually draws up a list of 12 underperforming companies and meets with them to devise ways to improve profits.
"There's been a culture change and a change in attitude and a change in the concept of the role of the board and large shareholders," said Ira Millstein, a partner at the law firm of Weil Gotshal & Manges and outside counsel to the Westinghouse and G.M. boards. "That's the big important thing happening now. In the future, boards will be there on their own without having to be pushed by shareholders."
The shareholder activity has drawn some complaints. Some executives worry that such shareholders could go too far -- using corporations, for instance, as a way to promote a social agenda or making business decisions in areas where they have little expertise. "Shareholders are here to stay; whether that's good or bad is not the question," said Mr. Wilcox, the proxy solicitor. "Will the power of the shareholders be too great, and will they want to make business decisions? You don't want shareholders running the company. And so far, they don't seem to want to."
Still, it is clear that corporations and shareholders are engaging in dialogues that two or three years ago would have been unthinkable. It is now fairly common for management and boards to negotiate quietly with the California fund and other groups to avert situations like those at G.M. or I.B.M.
"This has been an evolutionary process rather than a revolutionary one," Mr. Hanson said. "But the gains could be categorized as revolutionary." Among the companies that Mr. Hanson said have made changes as a result of discussions with shareholders are Avon, ITT, Lockheed, TRW, Champion International, Time Warner and Westinghouse.
 
Clear Thinking
 Many of these companies have eliminated anti-takeover measures, added more outside directors to their boards, limited executive pay and consulted with large shareholders before deciding whether to buy or sell a business.
One company involved in such discussions is the Ceridian Corporation, a Minneapolis-based information company created from the wreckage of the former Control Data Corporation. After meeting with Mr. Hanson's group, the company eliminated its anti-takeover measure, began changing the way votes are counted in proxy battles and reviewed corporate strategy and executive compensation.
Larry Perlman, chief executive of Ceridian, said many chief executives were becoming more responsive to shareholders because they are afraid of their power: "It's like what Dr. Johnson said: There's nothing so clear as the mind of a man who will hang in the morning."

HEADLINE: After the Deluge, Life in Tijuana Is Grimmer

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico

 BODY:
From the muddy hillside to which his tar-paper shack just barely holds, Ambrosio Castro can look up at a vision of Mexico's economic future. Behind him, American and Japanese assembly plants spread over the landscaped terraces of a busy industrial park, their mirrored windows glinting in the sun.
But for miles below the tiny home that Mr. Castro shares with his wife and three children, the view is crowded with the sort of frail lives that were broken and lost when it rained hard here over 12 days in January. 
 Nearly 10 years after Mr. Castro and other squatters began to invade the valley seeking a place to live, it bears no sign of sewers, storm drains or running water. Junked cars and old tires are everywhere, remnants of the garbage that dammed up natural drains and then burst, causing more severe flooding below. Hundreds of ramshackle homes like Mr. Castro's have been torn open by the waters or carpeted with mud.
"We thought it would be a little easier to get by here, but so many people came," said Mr. Castro, 41, who brought his family from a farm town in the central state of Guanajuato and has found work off and on as a laborer and taxicab driver.
In the aftermath of the mudslides and floods, the gap between the attraction of Tijuana for poor, ambitious immigrants like Mr. Castro and its failure to provide them with basic services has opened like a chasm before the city's hopes of booming again as a gateway for free trade between Mexico and the United States.
The problem is duplicated to varying degrees in other Mexican border cities. In almost all, the rapid growth of light assembly plants and other industries since the 1970's has transformed their economic base. But with minor exceptions, that change has taken place without corresponding investment in housing, sewers, roads and social services.
In Tijuana, the image of a seedy frontier town has worn away, replaced by that of a vital, if chaotic, metropolis on the forefront of Mexican economic and political change. Yet years of corruption, populist politics, environmental degradation and an utter lack of urban planning have also left a place in which many experts say disaster was only a matter of time.
"Tijuana is really at a crossroads," said Roberto Sanchez, an urban planning expert at the Colegio de la Frontera Norte, a research institute just south of the city. "Either it imposes dramatic measures to order its growth or it condemns itself to chaos."
 
Flood Damage in San Diego
 The havoc caused by the rains was by no means Tijuana's alone.
Just across the border in San Diego, the floodwaters caused $10.5 million in damage, said Dan McAllister, a city spokesman. At least 12 homes and 17 mobile homes were destroyed, and 23 other homes were badly damaged.
Across San Diego County, Mr. McAllister said, the flooding claimed three lives. In all of Southern California, the rough estimates are $100 million in damages, most of it to crops and homes.
Tijuana, with a fraction of the region's people and wealth, was left with more than 5,000 homeless and perhaps $40 million in damage, the city's new Mayor, Hector Osuna, said. (Some federal officials and nongovernmental experts rejected those figures as too conservative.) According to the counts of various government agencies, 30 to 35 people were killed.
In the 30-odd canyons that make up much of the watershed of the Tijuana River, squatter settlements and unregulated, upscale housing developments blocked the waters' natural course. Hillsides cut up for subdivisions gave way in sheets of mud. In the vast areas where storm drainage was inadequate or nonexistent, dams of garbage stopped up the waters temporarily and then burst, flooding areas below with torrents of muck.
Tens of thousands of homes were damaged. Poorly built roads and bridges washed away, leaving people stranded. Streets turned to rivers of mud or, where not paved, were carved up by the flows.
 
'Not a Single Service'
 In the working-class Gavilondo neighborhood, Jose Antonio Bernal, a 30-year-old waiter, looked out over the remains of a bridge that residents had been pressing local officials to repair for months.
"They always said they were going to do something about it, but they never did," he said.
Nor did residents seem pleased with the speed and scope of the governmental response to the disaster.
"This is just the latest of our problems," said Socorro Vidrios, 53, a housewife whose modest home was left knee-deep in mud. "There is not a single service here -- no water, no sewer. We need all sorts of things."
For the time being, Mrs. Vidrios, her husband and nine children are living in the empty warehouse of one of the city's 550 maquiladoras, or light assembly plants.
The plant manager, Jeffrey R. Gain, said that after 20 years of profitable business in Tijuana, he wanted to help out neighbors in a time of need.
A brochure for Mr. Gain's company, which assembles everything from computer components to pregnancy testing kits, describes Mexico as "a land of dynamic people and extreme labor savings."
Its skilled workers earn $1.40 an hour, he said.
 
Foundation for Development
 The rush of foreign manufacturers to take advantage of the inexpensive labor, tax exemptions and lax environmental regulation in the maquiladora program helped Tijuana to sell much of Mexico a shimmering image of economic well-being a stone's throw from the United States.
In the 1970's, Tijuana's population grew by almost 8 percent a year, according to Government figures. Although the annual growth rate has officially dropped to 4.5 percent, estimates of the city's population vary widely.
According to the 1990 national census, the municipality is home to 747,381 people, but city and state officials and academic experts say many of Tijuana's poor and transient residents went uncounted; some of them estimate its real population as high as 1.5 million. Its unemployment rate remains one of the country's lowest.
As early as the 1960's, when the national Government modified its inward-looking economic strategy to incorporate border areas, it sought to lay a foundation for development: big highways, industrial parks, a big thermoelectrical generating station.
 
Leading Squatter Invasions
 "They tried to invest so as to create an economic dynamism to the city," Dr. Sanchez, the urban planning expert, said. "But they left aside the social needs that this created."
Manufacturers were given no direct responsibility for their workers' housing. The tax they paid to finance the federal housing authority was largely squandered, Government officials say, by an agency that for years was rife with corruption. (The agency was finally stripped of its construction responsibilities last year.)
But as in other cities, local politicians of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party found that they could build constituencies almost overnight by leading squatter invasions of public and private lands.
 
Big Projects Needed
 Though illegal, colonias, or colonies, like the sprawling Camino Verde settlement to which Mr. Castro moved were tolerated as a matter of policy; they simply were not given running water, sewers or electricity. In poorer areas, diarrhea, hepatitis and other illnesses became endemic.
Until 1984, an urban master plan for Tijuana did not exist, and even after that zoning regulations were not enforced. So developers of more upscale housing projects built first and checked regulations later, paying bribes as necessary, according to officials. The city spread wildly over an area that is geologically unstable and in past years has flooded intermittently.
"It is an incredibly unrealistic place to build a city for two million people," said Lawrence A. Herzog, a professor of urban studies at San Diego State University. "It almost has biblical proportions."
In the late 1970's, a single engineering feat became the fulcrum of Tijuana's makeover. At a cost of about $100 million, a channel was built for part of the Tijuana River, freeing up acres of prime land for glitzy new development.
Yet as the 35-year-old Mayor, Mr. Osuna, ponders the oversized map in his office, the completion of the channel at a cost estimated at $80 million appears as only one of many big projects the city needs urgently and cannot afford. Traffic is often paralyzed because of a shortage of roads and bridges across the river. Because the city has no truck stops, 5,000 trucks park each night on its streets.
 
Vows to Control Growth
 The city government has direct responsibility for filling its potholes and building its bridges. Yet, as in other relatively prosperous areas along the border, Tijuana and Baja California Norte State are beholden to Mexico City for most of the money to pay for such investments. With the national Government giving back only about one-third of the tax revenue that the state generates, Tijuana's public works budget will be about $30 million this year, Mr. Osuna said.
"The rain we got here was unusual, but it was not so much more than other cities get," he said. "The fundamental problem is infrastructure. And on that, they have tied our hands."
As Tijuana began to dry out after the 12 days of rain that ended on Jan. 18, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari came promising new federal attention to its longer-term needs.
At the same time, the city and state governments, both led by the opposition National Action Party, vowed a tougher regulation of Tijuana's growth and a greater role for private business in building needed roads, bridges and drainage canals.
In what is the country's most important experiment in multiparty rule, the state administration of Gov. Ernesto Ruffo and that of Mr. Salinas have already been competing to provide Baja residents with some basic services.
But their focus has largely been on the sort of projects that residents most frequently demand: pavement, sewer lines, potable water and electricity. Until now, storm drains have been well down the list.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Ambrosio Castro and his son, Raymundo Castro Rivas, walking in their neighborhood in the Camino Verde settlement in Tijuana, Mexico. HEADLINE: A Texas-Size Scandal Seems to Blossom in Bonn

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 31

 BODY:
This is such a small town that even political scandals don't usually meet the international standards set by Washington, London and Paris.
A few weeks ago the German Economics Minister had to resign over a letter he wrote on behalf of a cousin's company, which made plastic tokens to spring shopping carts loose in supermarket chains. 
 The Housing Minister was accused of writing letters she should not have penned for a big real estate investment company.
 
Big Spending, Lavish Trips
 But an affair is brewing that has all the ingredients of a major scandal: European-American aerospace rivalry, charges of bribery reaching high up into the German ruling party, big-spending contractors, lavish trips to South America -- everything, so far, except sex.
The world, with bigger things to think about, has scarcely noticed, nor has it paid much attention yet, to the charges centering on a $1-billion contract for a high-altitude electronic reconnaissance system. An American company, E-Systems of Greenville, Tex., is the prime contractor for the reconnaissance system, known as Lapas.
The German Defense Ministry has already spent more than $500 million on the project, but temporarily halted the next phase, worth $220 million, last month after German prosecutors raised charges of bribery against the main German subcontractor here.
According to the prosecutors and to German press reports, the owner of Grob Air and Space Travel G.m.b.H. of Mindelheim, the German company, was generous to officials who were in a position to see to it that he got the contract.
 
The Aircraft Maker
 The German company makes the high-flying, nonmetallic turboprop aircraft, called the "Egrett D-500," that carries the airborne part of the system to heights above 50,000 feet. The Defense Ministry has ordered ten of them, plus the extensive air- and ground-based electronic equipment that goes with them.
The system, according to the authoritative Jane's Defense Review in London, can be used for everything from environmental monitoring to disarmament verification.
The prosecutors and press say the owner of the company invited a four-star general in the German Air Force, now retired, as well as the Premier of Bavaria, where the factory is, to lavish parties at an estate in Brazil in the late 1980's.
The retired general, Eberhard Eimler, and Premier Max Streibl of Bavaria have vigorously denied that they took any money from the company.
"I am not bribable, and I have never been bribed," Mr. Streibl said on Thursday in a tumultuous session of the Bavarian state parliament during which he was repeatedly called upon to resign.
 
Defended Their Visits
 General Eimler, formerly the senior officer in the German Air Force, said he saw nothing wrong with accepting Burkhart Grob's invitation to visit Brazil at his expense in the late 1980's, before the general retired in 1990.
And Mr. Streibl said on Thursday that he had gone to Brazil twice at Mr. Grob's invitation, which he said he regarded as completely private.
Mr. Streibl also acknowledged that he had taken a trip to Kenya at Mr. Grob's expense in 1985.
General Eimler told the Bild am Sonntag newspaper that he had never had anything to do with the German decision to procure the system, but that Mr. Grob was an old friend whose invitation he had accepted with pleasure.
General Eimler could not be reached on Friday, and the Grob company said it was not yet making any statements about the reported charges.
 
A Trip to Texas
 German newspaper reports have also said that E-Systems paid for a trip to Texas by a former official of the Defense Ministry, Norbert Gilles, in 1988.
Klaus Meyer, the E-Systems vice president in charge of the project in Bonn, said that the trip had taken place after Mr. Gilles's retirement.
Mr. Grob's companies also contributed 105,000 marks, more than $65,000, to Mr. Streibl's Christian Social Union Party in 1990, according to documents filed by the party with the national Parliament in Bonn.
Mr. Meyer of E-Systems said on Friday, "We are not aware of any investigation of us, and we have never been contacted by the prosecutors." He said that his company fully expected to continue with the contract after the German authorities resolved their problems with it, which he said he hoped would be soon.
But with the opposition Social Democrats raising charges that unfair methods had steered the contract into American hands and away from big German companies such as Dornier, also in Bavaria, the affair seemed, as Der Spiegel magazine pointed out last week, to be destined for a long run.

HEADLINE: Bigger Battle Expected on Spy Budget

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials say they expect to be drawn soon into a fractious high-stakes debate about how to reshape the nation's intelligence community and how much to spend on espionage now that the Soviet Union has collapsed.
Although President Clinton would like to postpone major decisions about the issue, the officials said it would be difficult to do so because the intelligence community's budget is one of the most tempting targets for those eager to cut Government spending to help trim the deficit. 
 The United States now spends nearly $18 billion a year to sustain the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister agencies; an additional $11 billion goes to the Defense Department for its intelligence operations. All of the agencies were originally fashioned to deal with a bipolar world that no longer exists.
 
'Information Is Easier to Get'
 One of those leading the charge to explore ways to find savings is Senator Dennis DeConcini, the Arizona Democrat who is the new chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.
"Common sense tells me that intelligence shouldn't cost as much as it once did," Mr. DeConcini said in a recent interview. "I'm aware that the world may be no less a dangerous place than it once was, but to me that means information is easier to get now."
Mr. DeConcini was the moving force behind the efforts in Congress last year that resulted in $1.6 billion being slashed from the intelligence budget, an action that alarmed some national security officials. The Senator said that he favored additional cuts this year but that he had no figure in mind.
In a more telling sign of his approach, Senator DeConcini said he believed that the collapse of the Soviet threat meant that the United States espionage activity no longer needed to be on the cutting edge. "We don't have to be ahead of the curve as we once were," he said.
Mr. DeConcini's approach would seem to fit with Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to cut $7.5 billion in intelligence spending over the next five years. The person who will be the White House's principal adviser on how to reshape the C.I.A. and the rest of the intelligence agencies is R. James Woolsey, a retired admiral who is Mr. Clinton's nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence. But Mr. Woolsey has not yet been confirmed and, Administration officials say, is thus unable to take on the problem.
Mr. Woolsey is viewed by White House officials as someone who will be innovative in finding ways to save money. But he is certain to face formidable obstacles from an entrenched intelligence community.
Those views are best represented by Robert M. Gates, the man Mr. Woolsey would succeed as Director and who has become the most outspoken defender of the intelligence community's budget. Before leaving office earlier this month, Mr. Gates began a campaign to resist further budget cuts.
"If I'm on a crusade," Mr. Gates said in a recent interview, "it's to prevent a sharp cut in the budget similar to the one we took last year."
Mr. Gates, who is to become a consultant and writer on intelligence matters, argued that if Mr. DeConcini and the Clinton Administration slashed the intelligence budget by an amount similar to last year's cut the result would be catastrophic.
"A similarly sharp cut this year would do real damage to the intelligence capability of this country because many people would have to be laid off and real capabilities would be cut back," he said.
Mr. Gates has also criticized members of the Congressional committees who oversee intelligence operations for not doing their jobs well. "Very few members appear to devote much time to their intelligence oversight responsibilities," he said in a speech a few days before he left office, a parting shot that underlines the tension in the battle over the future of the intelligence budget.
Mr. DeConcini responded by tossing a few criticisms of his own. He said the C.I.A. had been woefully mistaken on two of the most important intelligence matters of recent years, the strength of the Soviet economy and the Iraqi Army.
"They told us the Soviets had a world-class economy," he said. "That was absurd, and I question whether that was really professional intelligence or something put together at the behest of higher-ups to build public support for our foreign policy." Mr. DeConcini said the agency also provided a misleading estimate of Saddam Hussein's army at the time of the Persian Gulf war, wrongly predicting tens of thousands of American casualties.
 
'Still a Dangerous World'
 "I hope Admiral Woolsey takes a sharp look at what's going on over there," Mr. Deconcini said.
Bobby Ray Inman, a retired admiral who has held several senior intelligence posts, said Congress and the Clinton Administration should delay seeking cuts in the budget until they first decided what kind of intelligence they needed to operate in the newly shaped world.
"It's still a dangerous world out there," Mr. Inman said.
"If the policy makers make a conscious decision that they can live without some of this, then fine," he said. But if they trim back the intelligence gathering capabilities, Mr. Inman added, they should no longer complain that the C.I.A. failed to serve them well.
Mr. Gates has argued that resources once devoted to the Soviet threat now have to be devoted to other problems like the proliferation of nuclear weapons among smaller countries, drug trafficking and economic intelligence that affects national security.
Roy Godson, a Georgetown University professor and an authority on intelligence matters, said the United States could get more accurate and cheaper economic intelligence from banks or financial consultants, rather than from the C.I.A.
Professor Godson favors narrowing the C.I.A.'s role in gathering secrets, particularly in areas where other parts of the Government have access to freely available information.
The C.I.A., he said, is currently the repository of all kinds of arcane information, like global warming and the wool crop yield in Mongolia.
"If there is to be savings and efficiency, the first thing to do is distinguish between intelligence and information," he said. "Intelligence should be concerned with secrets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Dennis DeConcini, who is among those leading the charge to find way to trim the intelligence community's budget. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Security Council Expected to Threaten Tougher Belgrade Sanctions

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
In an effort to press the warring factions in Bosnia to accept a peace plan, the Security Council is expected to threaten what remains of Yugoslavia with tougher economic sanctions that could include severing all transport links with the outside world, diplomats said today .
After talks in Geneva ended on Saturday without agreement among the three main factions -- Serbs, Croats and Muslims -- negotiations on the three-part plan were moved to United Nations headquarters in New York. The plan, drawn up by Cyrus R. Vance, former Secretary of State and Lord Owen of Britain, would divide Bosnia and Herzegovina into ten areas with only a loose central Government.
 
A Lesser Evil
 Britain and France, which have both sent substantial peacekeeping forces to Bosnia and lost troops in the fighting, believe that tightening the strictures of the embargo would force the Belgrade Government to put a stop to aggression by Bosnia's ethnic Serbs. The current Yugoslav federation includes only Serbia and tiny Montenegro. Such a tightening could involve cutting any remaining road, rail or river links and suspending Yugoslavia's membership in international bodies. 
 Their strategy also includes convincing the Bosnian factions that the peace plan, despite their objections to parts of it, is better than continued bloodshed or economic sanctions. Britain and France want the Security Council to endorse the plan and send the factions back to Geneva for further talks.
For this strategy to work, the United States must also convince Bosnia's Muslims that it is not planning to rescue them by military force.
 
Review of U.S. Policy
 Pressure to provide more military aid to the beleaguered Muslims is growing, and on Friday Islamic countries formally asked for an emergency Security Council meeting this week to lift the arms embargo on Bosnia so its forces could acquire the weapons they need to recapture territory seized by the Serbs.
It remains unclear whether the Clinton Administration is ready to throw its full support behind the peace plan. "We are very worried that the Americans might stab Vance and Owen in the back," a European diplomat said today.
The Administration indicated last week that it plans a thorough review of American policy toward the crisis in the former Yugoslav federation, but events are moving faster than expected and the decision to bring in the Security Council means the United States may need to formulate its policy by the end of the week.
Warren Christopher, the new Secretary of State, has criticized the Vance-Owen plan as unfair to Bosnia's Muslims. He and Madeleine K. Albright, the new United States chief delegate to the United Nations, will discuss the matter with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Monday. They will meet Mr. Vance and Lord Owen.
European diplomats here argue that while the Geneva peace talks have become bogged down, they are nevertheless at an advanced stage.
Bosnia's Croats, lead by Mate Boban, have signed all three parts of the accord: a statement of the general principles; a detailed map of the partitioning, and a cease-fire.
 
Issue of U.S. Visa
 In the talks in Geneva, Radovan Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs, refused to accept the map; President Izetbegovic would sign neither the map nor the cease-fire agreement.
Lord Owen and Mr. Vance said leaders of the three factions would all come to New York this week to settle their differences, but it remained unclear today whether the United States, which has placed Mr. Karadzic's name on a list of potential war criminals accused of atrocities, will give him a visa to attend the United Nations meeting.
France and Britain are also discussing sending NATO warplanes to enforce the ban on flights over Bosnia by shooting down violators.
While such a move would be of scant military value, it is seen as a further warning that the Security Council intends to compel the enemies to make peace.
 
Protection for Sarajevo
 France has suggested throwing a military cordon around the beleaguered Bosnian capital of Sarajevo to protect it from the encircling Serbian gunners.
But something very similar would happen anyway under the Vance-Owen plan, which requires the withdrawal of all armed forces from Sarajevo province and their replacement by new peacekeeping forces to ensure freedom of movement.
One remaining problem is the new fighting in Croatia. The Security Council must still deal with the Croatian attack on the United Nations-protected Serbian enclave of Krajina last week, which has raised the specter of a new war between Serbs and Croats.

HEADLINE: Jobs Promised in '91 Bill Have Yet to Be Realized

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Viewed as a stimulus for an economy in the doldrums, a $151 billion transportation bill was quickly approved by Congress and signed into law by President George Bush in November 1991. The bill, the President promised, would quickly translate into "jobs building roads, jobs building bridges and jobs building railways."
But more than 13 months later, transportation planners say, the law has neither stimulated the economy nor created many jobs. It will take another year or two, they say, to produce concrete results. 
 "The legislation's total effect is underwhelming," said Representative Bob Carr, a Michigan Democrat who is vice chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation.
What happened? One important reason is that Congress, facing a growing Federal deficit, provided states with only 70 percent of the money authorized by the law, the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. That was just a modest increase over transportation financing in previous years.
 
More Planning Required
 In addition, the law itself has slowed the process. It requires more planning and sets standards for meeting new Federal requirements on air quality and access for the disabled. It also requires more public participation in determining which projects should be built and whether they should be mass transit or highway projects. State agencies, which used to make most transportation decisions, must now consult with local and regional groups.
But perhaps the biggest reason for the delay is simply that transportation projects, by virtue of their size, take years to plan and build.
And that may be the bill's biggest lesson for the new Clinton Administration, which is considering a plan to spend an additional $15 billion to $20 billion this year on public works, including highway and rail projects.
"The experience with the Surface Transportation Act provides some cautionary flags about expecting fast results," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany.
The 1991 transportation bill was heralded by all sides. Even Mr. Bush, who once opposed its mass-transit provisions, enthusiastically endorsed it as a symbol of his Administration's efforts to breathe life into a weak economy.
The measure increased transportation spending by 25 percent, to a total of $151 billion in the fiscal years 1992 to 1997. But Congress appropriated an increase of only 9 percent, to an average of $21.5 billion in the 1992 and 1993 fiscal years.
Still, the transportation law represents the first significant shift in national transportation policy since the Interstate System of highways was begun 35 years ago.
For years, that policy was defined simply as where to build new highways. But the new law forces the states to develop long-range regional plans that reduce traffic without increasing air pollution.
And in recent interviews, three dozen planners and government experts said the law seemed to be generally doing what it was intended to do: promote the wisest investment of Federal money, whether it is spent on highways, transit systems, bicycle paths or pedestrian bridges.
Jon A. Bloom, director of highway and area planning for the Minnesota Department of Transportation, said the law was promoting good policy. "The changes in the law are beneficial to the state," he said. "But we're not getting any more money than we used to get."
If the law had been fully financed, Mr. Bloom said, Minnesota would have received $86 million a year for highway repair projects. Instead, it will get only $47 million.
Because the law provides new Federal grants for projects to reduce congestion and improve air quality, some projects that would have remained on drawing boards are actually being built.
In San Jose, Calif., for example, the Santa Clara County Transportation Agency obtained a $500,000 Federal grant to build a children's day-care center next to a downtown train station. If the not-for-profit center for 150 children can attract more parents to the county transit system, which serves 200,000 passengers a day, the county plans to apply for grants to build centers at 24 other stations.
"Without the new law, the child-care center wouldn't have happened because we had no local funds for it," said Rod Diridon, a member of the Board of Supervisors of Santa Clara County, which includes San Jose and operates the local transit system.
In Boston, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority received $3.2 million to start restoring commuter rail service between Boston and 32 southeastern communities that was discontinued in 1959. The agency proposed the restoration two years ago, when Federal grants would have covered half of the project's $480 million cost. But now that transit and highway projects receive equal treatment, the transit agency expects the Government to pay 80 percent of the cost.
The new law often gives transit projects an edge over highway projects because the law incorporates provisions of the Clean Air Act of 1990, forcing states to consider the environmental costs of competing transportation proposals.
Although transit systems appear to get the most benefit from the new law, many transit officials are not ready to pass judgment.
"Like people in most communities and regions, we in New York are trying to figure out how to adapt ourselves to the new rules of the game," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman and chief executive of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The agency is looking to the Federal Government for a significant part of its five-year, $9.6 billion capital improvement program. It received only $200 million last year, and Mr. Stangl said, "The test will be how well we do over the next four years."

HEADLINE: Governors Ask U.S. to Set Standards on Health Care

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
In a sweeping new policy statement, the National Governors' Association said today that the Federal Government should set nationwide standards for health insurance and should limit the tax deductibility of health insurance for both employers and employees.
But in a rebuff to President Clinton, the governors rejected his proposal to impose a national limit on all health spending, public and private. 
 The governors said all Americans should have access to health care. Such universal access is "both a moral imperative and an invaluable cost-containment tool," they said. More than 35 million Americans have no health insurance coverage.
The governors' position is important because the states will have a big role in carrying out any major changes in the health-care system approved by Congress. Mr. Clinton, a former chairman of the association, has invited all governors to a White House meeting on Monday and plans to address them at their winter meeting here on Tuesday.
 
Call for Definitions
 In their policy statement, adopted by voice vote without dissent, the governors demand "Federal minimum standards for the regulation of health insurance," which has historically been regulated by the states. The Federal standards should limit variation in insurance premiums and prohibit insurers from denying coverage to people with a history or a high risk of medical problems, they said.
The governors said the Federal Government should define a standard minimum package of health benefits, comparable to those now provided by the most efficient health maintenance organizations. Under the proposal, employers could not take a tax deduction for contributions to employee health benefits exceeding the value of the standard package. And employees would have to pay income tax on such excess contributions.
Under current law, there is no limit on an employer's tax deductions for employee health benefits, and none of the benefits are counted as taxable income to employees. Economists contend that this arrangement encourages overuse of health care because employees are shielded from the true cost.
Governors said they hoped that, by limiting tax breaks for health insurance, the nation could slow the growth of health spending, expected to total $940 billion this year, up $100 billion from 1992. People would still be free to buy coverage beyond the basic benefits, but the Government would no longer subsidize the extra coverage through the tax code.
 
Health Budget Opposed
 The governors did not specify how the unemployed or their families should be covered. But they said states should organize cooperatives through which individuals and small businesses could buy coverage.
In his campaign manifesto, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to "establish an annual health budget for the nation to limit both public and private expenditures."
But in their policy statement today, the governors said, "It is unrealistic to immediately enforce strict budget limits on health-care spending, since available data are not sufficient to set accurate spending ceilings."
At the White House on Monday, governors said, they will plead with Mr. Clinton to allow maximum flexibility to states, both in Medicaid and in any new national health-care program.
Mr. Clinton has endorsed the idea of "managed competition," in which large groups of consumers seek the most efficient providers from competing networks of doctors and hospitals. In general, the governors support this approach. But they warned that Mr. Clinton and Congress must pay special attention to the needs of rural areas.
Gov. George S. Mickelson of South Dakota, a Republican, said, "Managed competition is not relevant in 55 percent of my state, which is classified as frontier." In such rural areas, he said, there are not enough doctors or hospitals to have meaningful competition.
The governors' policy allows states to require employers to provide health insurance to their employees. But it does not endorse Mr. Clinton's proposal for a Federal law to impose such a requirement nationwide.
"I would not sign on to a policy that said we were going to have an employer mandate," said Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, a Republican, who is vice chairman of the association.
The governors' meeting is dominated by talk of health care. "If we're to reduce the deficit and get some fiscal sanity in this nation and in our individual states, we must attack our health-care costs," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat who is chairman of the association.
Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas, a Democrat, proposed an amendment to the health-policy statement that said, "National and state-level spending targets should be set," and cost-control techniques should be adopted as quickly as possible.
Mr. Campbell recommended that the first half of the amendment be deleted, to eliminate the idea of spending targets, and the other governors agreed. Mr. Campbell said he feared that such targets would be set unwisely and enforced rigidly by "Federal bureaucrats."
Doctors, hospitals, drug makers and manufacturers of medical equipment also oppose national limits on health spending. "If you can put a cap on illness, then we'll talk about a cap on expenditures," said Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 investor-owned hospitals.
In a separate statement adopted today, the governors asked the Clinton Administration for immediate relief from the crushing burden of Medicaid costs. They proposed changes in Medicaid rules to give state officials more discretion in managing costs, especially the costs of long-term care for elderly people and for children who are disabled or mentally retarded.
The governors also called for a change in Federal law to increase Medicaid payments to hospitals serving "a disproportionate number of low-income patients." The governors themselves agreed to limits on such payments, under pressure from the Bush Administration, in November 1991.

Mr. Clinton has invited all governors to the White House today as part of the National Governors Association's conference. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Iran's Leader Challenges U.S. And Talks of Re-election Bid

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 31

 BODY:
President Hashemi Rafsanjani confirmed today that he was ready to run for a second term in June and warned the Clinton Administration in unusually dismissive terms that it was up to Washington to improve relations with his country.
At a rare news conference to which more than 70 foreign journalists were invited, Mr. Rafsanjani accused the United States of a bias against Muslims and urged the Clinton Administration to release Iranian assets that have been frozen since the country's Islamic revolution in 1979. 
 "The West does not want independence and freedom based on Islamic thoughts for Islamic countries," the President said. "They are confronting an important movement and they do not like it."
 
A Harsher Tone
 The news conference was apparently scheduled to draw international attention to two weeks of celebrations commemorating the 14th anniversary of the Iranian revolution. The tone was unusually harsh for Mr. Rafsanjani, who has steered Iran toward greater economic and political liberalization over the last three years.
"We have always said that the United States must reconsider its policies toward Muslims and particularly the Islamic Republic," he said. "Why are they still holding our assets and giving unfair assistance to Israel or adopting a double standard on Iraq -- taking action so quickly there but not taking the disaster in Bosnia seriously?"
Mr. Rafsanjani emphasized that the resumption of relations with Washington "would not be in contradiction with Iran's objectives" if American policies were "truly corrected." The United States severed relations with Iran after militants seized hostages at the American Embassy in Teheran in 1979.
But the Iranian President rejected the assumption that growing trade relations with the United States, a development criticized by the country's hard-line press, would pave the way for diplomatic relations.
Mr. Rafsanjani implicitly confirmed his candidacy for the June presidential elections by saying that he had dedicated his life to the revolution. "If there is a need for me to remain in my responsibility, I will do so," he said.
He denied that Iran was challenging the influence of its oil-producing Arab neighbors or developing nuclear weapons, insisting that reports to that effect in the Western press were "utterly untrue" and "politically motivated."
Mr. Rafsanjani's appeal on the rights of Muslims and his vow to fight "imperialism" anywhere and uphold the principles of the revolution are viewed by political analysts here as themes for his election campaign, which he is beginning at a time of renewed anti-Western sentiment in the Iranian press and Parliament.
One sign that Mr. Rafsanjani is taking an increasingly militant tone was his repeated denunciation of Israel today as the "illegitimate state."
"All this mischief in the foreign press that presents Iran as a threat is intended to spread fear among the Arabs, diverting their attention from Israel," he said. "We believe that Israel should be rejected by all countries until the rights of the oppressed Palestinians have been returned."
Mr. Rafsanjani brushed aside questions on the fate of an American businessman, Milton Meier, 58, who was arrested in Teheran last October on charges of corruption and links with "foreign intelligence" agents. "In Iran, this was a legal matter, not a political one," he said. He did not say when or where Mr. Meier had been convicted. No details of a trial or conviction have appeared in the state-run press.

HEADLINE: Two Surveys Show Split On Clinton's Performance

 BODY:
Two new polls indicate that Americans are deeply divided over President Clinton's job performance so far, and are almost evenly split over the first major issue his Administration has tackled, the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces.
A poll conducted by the Gallup Organization for Newsweek magazine showed that although 51 percent of those surveyed approved of Mr. Clinton's job performance 32 percent disapproved. It is the highest disapproval rating for any new President since such surveys were begun in the 1950's. 
 For most other Presidents, disapproval ratings this early in their first term were in single digits. The only exception -- and the previous high -- was a 13 percent disapproval rating for Ronald Reagan after the first week of his Presidency in January 1981, Newsweek reported.
The latest poll, based on 774 telephone interviews conducted last Thursday and Friday, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
The same poll also indicated that Americans are divided over whether it is a good idea that the military will stop asking prospective recruits about their sexual preference, which is part of the compromise plan announced by Mr. Clinton on Friday. Forty-eight percent did not approve of halting the practice, while 44 percent approved.
In another poll, by Yankelovich Inc. for Time magazine and CNN, 68 percent of those surveyed said they had a favorable impression of Mr. Clinton.
The Time/CNN poll also showed close division over the new President's plan to allow homosexuals to serve in the military. Forty-eight percent said they opposed the plan, while 43 percent supported it.
For the Time/CNN poll, 1,800 adults were surveyed on Jan. 22-25. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

HEADLINE: Surprising Governor Keeps State Guessing

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md.

 BODY:
In 1988, when Gov. William Donald Schaefer was in his second year on the job, a member of the Maryland House of Delegates took the floor one day to offer a brief prayer.
"Good Lord," he pleaded, "help us to understand our Governor." 
 Five years later, halfway through Mr. Schaefer's second term, many state legislators, and many Marylanders in general, still await the answer to that prayer.
The 71-year-old Governor, who first came to national attention as the aggressive, innovative Mayor of Baltimore, is one of the country's most enigmatic elected officials, and seemingly growing more enigmatic by the day.
He is a politician of serious purpose and achievement. But lately he seems to be expending more and more of his time and energy on petty issues and squabbles, even venting his ire at times on private individuals. When a Baltimore man wrote to take issue with the Governor's handling of state affairs, for instance, Mr. Schaefer went to the critic's house and berated the man in person.
Some of his political friends say they now find him testily unpredictable, generous one moment and vindictive the next. His opponents say they can no longer predict whether he is going to crack a joke or a political skull.
 
At Odds With Lawmakers
 He is constantly at odds with the State Legislature, engaging in stinging public arguments with some members and flatly refusing to talk to others.
"Well, I've never been a predictable politics-as-usual politician," he said in his defense. "I don't mind going against the grain."
Certainly that is what he did when he delivered his 1993 State of the State message recently. The many governmental improvements and programs he proposed went all but unnoticed because he also chose to insert a suggestion that Maryland consider mandatory birth control for welfare recipients who have several children out of wedlock. He suggested using Norplant, the contraceptive implant for women, and vasectomies.
His suggestion shocked many elected officials and civil rights advocates. Some warned of clumsy, racist social engineering.
 
Birth- Control Plan Assailed
 "It's a ludicrous plan," said Carl Snowden, an Annapolis City Councilman. "The government trying to be Big Brother in people's bedrooms."
The Governor saw his suggestion as bold, not ludicrous, which is often the way the debate shapes up these days when there is a Schaefer brouhaha.
"I just threw that out to be provocative, to get some serious debate going about a problem that's costing the country millions and millions," the Governor said. "Sometimes you have to be bold in politics. I've never hesitated to be that way in 40 years or so of public life, and if I do say so, I've been pretty successful."
As the Mayor of Baltimore for 15 years, from 1971 through 1986, Mr. Schaefer won national fame and repeated re-election because of his tireless, "Do It Now!" efforts to revitalize the city's decrepit downtown waterfront and grim slums, and for his enviable ability to attract industry.
He was often hailed as the best mayor in America. And in that time and place he just might have been, even on that day when, ever willing to promote his beloved hometown with a bit of public buffoonery, he struggled into a striped Gay Nineties-style bathing suit and, rubber duck in hand, plunged in among the honking seals in a showman's attempt to promote Baltimore's new aquarium.
 
Change in Personality
 But some change in persona or political approach seems to have come over Mr. Schaefer since he moved to Annapolis.
As Governor, he has been no less eccentric than when he was Mayor, donning every crazy hat and pair of funky sunglasses proffered. But there has been much less applause for his achievements in Annapolis than in Baltimore, and those successes he has enjoyed have often been lost or submerged in unrelated squalls.
In his six years in the Governor's office, he has managed to persuade the Legislature to approve important education and transportation measures, and he has been a leader in efforts to clean up Chesapeake Bay and to limit and guide development on its shores. He has also pushed through an overhaul of the state's legal code and its workers' compensation system.
But to a large degree these achievements have been overshadowed by his vitriolic squabbles with legislators, state and national officials and voters.
 
Puzzling Kind of Disputes
 They are the kinds of disputes he generally avoided while Mayor. And they are especially puzzling given Mr. Schaefer's undisguised yearningfor public approval if not adoration; he once lamented that he had been politically "destroyed" when he won an election by a hefty 20 points.
Among the most recent Schaefer headline-making events are these:
*Though a lifelong mainstream Democrat, he came out in support of President George Bush in last fall's election, angering Maryland Democratic leaders. "George Bush has been good to me," the Governor explained.
*He outraged residents of Maryland's Eastern Shore by referring to that rural but politically important part of the state as an outhouse. "Just jesting," he insisted when a caravan of protesting Shoremen showed up at the Executive Mansion here.
*After his Lieutenant Governor, Melvin A. Steinberg, twice his running mate, objected to a tax increase, he kicked Mr. Steinberg off several committees, stripped him of some of his aides and then stopped talking to him.
"The Governor's a hard man to fathom," said Thomas V. Mike Miller, the president of the State Senate. "He's gotten to be more and more difficult, and there's no reason to be that way."
Another top State Senator, Laurence Levitan, the chairman of the Budget and Taxation Committee, says Mr. Schaefer has been less successful as a Governor than as a Mayor because the State Legislature is much more independent-minded than the Baltimore City Council.
"He ran Baltimore with an iron hand, had everybody and everything in his pocket," Mr. Levitan said. "But when he got to Annapolis, he found he couldn't control us, couldn't put us in his pocket. He's had a hard and frustrating time getting used to that cold fact, and it shows. It's a constant tug of war with him."
Mr. Schaefer's view is that the Legislature has "too many people who worry more about political consequences than about what needs to be done." He also makes the point that he, like governors all over the country, has spent a good part of his tenure contending with a recession that has left the state treasury sorely short of money.
 
When the Money Stopped
 Bob DiPietro, a Maryland developer who was among the first to urge Mr. Schaefer to run for Governor, also sees the recession and the resulting shortage of money as the main cause of the Governor's problems.
"Things went well for him in the first four years and he was enjoying the same kind of success he knew as Mayor," Mr. DiPietro said. "Then, suddenly, the money stopped coming in and the job didn't seem so rewarding, and there was the fear that people would remember only the second four years. It's that simple."
Mr. DiPietro, who worked as an aide to the Governor during the first term, contends that Mr. Schaefer is basically unchanged except for being frustrated.
"He's not all that complex," Mr. DiPietro said. "Sooner or later, if you're around him long enough, everybody -- friend and foe -- has a good argument and fight with him. I certainly did. But I'm still his friend, and I'll back him whatever he does and wherever he goes."
And where might Mr. Schaefer go next, since under Maryland law he can serve only two consecutive terms in Annapolis?
"I'm concentrating only on finishing my work as Governor," he replied.
But there is much speculation in state political circles that he is considering another run for Mayor of Baltimore. He still maintains a home there and visits often.
In a recent address to the Maryland Chamber of Commerce, he devoted a good part of his time discussing the city and its problems, which by most assessments have mounted since he left for Annapolis.
"I don't think the Baltimore business community has moved hard enough to push the economy in the city," he said at one point, his voice taking on the timbre of a disappointed parent scolding a naughty child.

"I've never been a predictable politics-as-usual politician," he said. "I don't mind going against the grain." (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gay Issue Mobilizes Conservatives Against Clinton

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Emboldened by the furor over President Clinton's proposal to allow homosexuals in the military, conservative and evangelical Christian groups are furiously organizing, raising money and looking ahead to the battles to come against the first Democratic President in 12 years.
"It's a bonanza for building organizations and raising money; the fund-raising letters are already in the mail," said John Green, a professor at the University of Akron who is an expert on the Christian right. "I've been talking to several of these people, and they all say that they could not have scripted Bill Clinton's first weeks any better." 
 Some of these groups have made homosexual issues their main focus for organizing and fund-raising over the past year. For moral traditionalists, many of them evangelical Christians, homosexuality is a more clear-cut issue even than abortion, Professor Green said, because it is explicitly forbidden in the Bible. And when the issue was fused to conservative views on the military and the objections of the nation's military leadership, it attained extraordinary emotional power, both for committed conservatives and for Americans in the political mainstream.
The issue is so potent that some conservatives, like Randall Terry, the anti-abortion crusader, are expanding their activities to become part of it.
"Clinton has done us a great favor," said Mr. Terry, who calls his efforts to mobilize opinion on the issue "the resistance." "This is going to help us mobilize people to take action for the next four years."
Because the question of homosexuals in the military is so volatile, some experts doubt that last week's furor is indicative of broader problems Mr. Clinton could face. Todd Gitlin, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley, said the current furor was a reminder of how split Americans were on social issues, but he added that he did not expect cultural issues to overwhelm economic ones.
"I wouldn't exaggerate the degree to which he's landed in a storm here," he said. "These may be just gusts."
Still, even liberal groups like People for the American Way concede the public opinion often flows toward the conservative side on issues like homosexual rights. No one doubts that Mr. Clinton won by focusing on the economy and by coming across as a moderate, bus-riding new-style Democrat rather than because voters endorsed liberal social policies.
And some experts say the intensity of the feelings last week reflects the depth of the cultural divide in America and the perils it raises for Democratic Presidents, in an era when no Democrat from north of the Mason-Dixon line has been elected President since 1960.
Professor Green, who is director of the Ray Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron, said: "This is a very conservative country, and cultural liberalism is a loser in American politics. There are more cultural conservatives than cultural liberals, and their ability to mobilize should not be underestimated. You've got 300,000 to 400,000 churches out there, and there's nothing like that on the left."
 
Strong Conservative Instincts
 As the departing Republican national chairman, Richard N. Bond, made clear last week when he warned his party against zealotry, the kind of strident conservatism that many saw at the Republican Convention last year can be as unpopular as liberal excesses. But poll results indicate just how strong the conservative instincts of the American people remain.
When voters leaving polling booths in November were asked whether it was more important for government to encourage traditional family values or tolerance for nontraditional families, 70 percent said traditional families. Although most Americans oppose efforts to ban abortion, a New York Times/CBS News poll in October found that only 43 percent of respondents felt abortion should be generally available to all who want it. Thirty-seven percent favored stricter limits than are in effect now, and 16 percent favored an abortion ban.
Although polls show Americans feel homosexuals should not be discriminated against in hiring, they show a majority of Americans say homosexuality is not an acceptable life style and more Americans feel homosexual relations should be illegal than think they should be legal. Other polls have indicated that more than three-quarters of Americans favor prayer in school and the death penalty.
"Democrats make a mistake in thinking that because the social issues won't hurt the Democrats when there's a failed Republican economic manager in the White House, that those same issues can be ignored when you've got a Democrat in the White House," said Kevin Phillips, the maverick Republican political analyst. "What you've got working now calls up the ghosts of 1972 and of things that don't resonate in the subdivisions and malls."
 
A Promise of More to Come
 Conservative groups are looking toward similar cultural issues they say could come up repeatedly during the Clinton Presidency, as the gay issue did last week. "This is a train wreck for Bill Clinton, and there will be more to come," said the Rev. Louis Sheldon, chairman of the conservative Traditional Values Coalition, based in Anaheim, Calif., which includes 25,000 churches.
Conservatives cite the coming debate over extending the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which is likely to include proposals to protect homosexuals; curriculum disputes around the country like the one in New York City over the Children of the Rainbow curriculum; National Endowment for the Arts financing for controversial artists; fetal tissue research and other issues as ones with the potential to polarize Americans on value-laden issues.
Not everyone, including some Republicans, is convinced that such issues need be losers for the Democrats. Vince Breglio, a Republican poll taker, said that despite the uproar over the military ban, the divide in American life had narrowed sharply since the 1960's. With their emphasis on meeting the social and economic needs of families, jobs, health care and education, the Democrats may be more in touch with the values people really care about than the Republicans, he said.
"If you limit it to a more restrictive set of social values, I would say the Republicans come out looking pretty good," he said. "But on the broader cross-section of cultural and economic values, I would have to say the Democrats strike a more resonating chord."
Even the most ardent conservatives say it's dangerous to read too much into a President's first two weeks. But many also say this week's uproar was neither manufactured nor a fluke.
"I think these cultural issues have an enormous opportunity to divide Clinton from this country, deeply and perhaps irretrievably," said Karl Rove, a Republican political consultant in Texas. "It's a marathon, and he can make a couple of mistakes. One would be to start too fast. He didn't do that. Another would be to start running in the wrong direction. I think he's making that mistake."

HEADLINE: When Good Will Is Not Enough;
Desegregation Project at Heart of Hartford School Suit

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 29

 BODY:
Twenty-six years ago, hundreds of black children from Hartford stepped onto buses to go to schools in five nearby towns. They were pioneers, the first to take part in Project Concern, one of the nation's earliest voluntary desegregation programs between a city and its suburbs.
The buses still run, yet Hartford's schools are far more racially segregated today. And so Project Concern finds itself at the heart of a lawsuit challenging the racial and economic segregation dividing Hartford from its suburbs, asking a judge to order what good will has not accomplished. 
 The suit, known as Sheff v. O'Neill, contends that the concentration of poor and minority children in Hartford denies them educational opportunities equal to those in neighboring towns. Project Concern's goal was to promote integration and to provide those opportunities by busing children out of the city.
It is the smallest of many ironies that the suit is being heard in a courtroom in a former school, long ago converted to other uses, that welcomed some of Project Concern's first pupils in 1966. For in that courtroom, Project Concern is being held up by the plaintiffs as proof that integration benefits children, and by the state as evidence that it does not.
Even so, the state, doubting its benefits, offers Project Concern as proof that Connecticut has actively encouraged integration. The plaintiffs, praising its benefits, hold the program up as ineffectual, as evidence of token intentions. The product of 1960's hopes and the victim of 70's and 80's realities, Project Concern has come to embody the entire contradictory record of school desegregation. It has produced successes and failures that can be seized upon by any partisan.
"It just doesn't cut it any more," testified John Allison, the director of the Capital Region Education Council, a regional agency that has sought unsuccessfully to expand Project Concern.
 
Analyses Questioned
 In court, the state has sharply questioned statistical analyses of the higher education and job choices of Project Concern's first graduates. Sociologists have used them as the basis of a "perpetuation theory": People who grow up amid segregation tend to accept segregation as adults, but those who grow up in integrated settings tend to work and raise their families in integrated settings.
A larger question, however, is whether the one-way busing program ever produced anything resembling integration, and whether it ever benefited Hartford.
Critics say that too few children have taken part to create meaningful integration outside the city -- in June, the 930th Project Concern student will graduate from a suburban high school -- or to halt the growing segregation in Hartford's schools, which are 90 percent black and Puerto Rican.
The strongest critics suggest that the program has had adverse effects, creating a false impression that the state and suburbs were acting against segregation, and allowing many of Hartford's most motivated parents to avoid the city's schools.
"The name of the game was 'jockey to get your kids in Project Concern,' " said Rudolph Arnold, a former Deputy Mayor of Hartford. "The more sophisticated, assertive parents would do that, and so they didn't have to worry about Hartford.
"It was also allowing suburban communities to say, 'We're doing something, we've got Project Concern, we've got X number of students in Project Concern,' which was not really doing anything to change the fundamentals of the situation," he continued. "So while Project Concern had some benefits, it really is just window-dressing. It's 25 years old now, it's gotten lots of accolades, but it hasn't changed anything. It's the easy way."
Project Concern arose from a 1965 study of Hartford's schools, which were segregated by neighborhoods into black and white schools. The study proposed integrating by building new middle schools across the city. Opposition from the white South End blocked the plan.
 
Began as Small Study
 The proposal to bus black children to suburbs also met opposition. So Project Concern began as a small two-year study, involving only 266 children in 1966.
"The concerns on the part of suburban people were: is this the beginning of the end of our local autonomy, and what effect will these youngsters have on our school systems?" said Project Concern's administrator, Mary Carroll.
Set up so researchers could measure its effects, Project Concern selected children randomly from schools in the largely black North End; a control group of children who remained in those schools was also identified. Parents had to give their approval, but the program sent counselors to answer their questions. Most said yes. By 1968, 690 children were involved.
But Project Concern, started with state, Federal and foundation grants, quickly ran into financial problems. By 1970, said Robert L. Crain, who has studied Project Concern's first graduates, outreach efforts were limited to the initial letters sent to parents, and only 25 percent were responding.
 
'Mom Pushed and Pushed'
 That ended the project's research value, he testified, because the children were, in effect, volunteers as opposed to a random sample. For Hartford, it began opening the program to parents who sought out Project Concern as a way to avoid the city schools.
"My mom pushed and pushed," said Antonio Champion, a Hartford police officer who entered Project Concern in the sixth grade. He graduated from Hall High School in West Hartford in 1981. "In her wisdom she realized there was a problem with the Hartford school system."
Alfred Lindseth, an Atlanta lawyer representing the state, who has helped several states and cities contest desegregation lawsuits, labored to have Professor Crain concede that Project Concern was a rare instance of a state voluntarily encouraging school integration.
But Mr. Lindseth also cast doubt on Professor Crain's research on the positive effects of Project Concern by suggesting that its students were unusually motivated.
The number of Project Concern students fell sharply in the 1980's as Hartford cut its support to spend the money on the children in its own schools. More recently, suburbs have encountered budget problems and growing enrollments, and so have accepted fewer children. From a peak of 1,175 children in 12 grades in 1978, Project Concern is down to 680.
