HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Staten Island Packs One-Two Punch

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
IF AT FIRST you don't secede try, try again.
That could become the motto of Staten Island, whose voters may wield an ironic double wallop next November: In the very same election, they may choose the next mayor for the rest of New York City and then decide to form a separate city themselves. 
 This week, the New York State Charter Commission for Staten Island will report these two significant conclusions to the Governor and to the Legislature:
A City of Staten Island would have a revenue base strong enough to provide municipal services "without major dislocations"; and the preferred form of government for New York State's newest city would be a mayor, a 15-member common council with an elected speaker but no council president, a comptroller, a planning director and a five-member zoning appeals board, a nine-member elected school board, and a provision allowing voters to petition the council to act on legislation.
Ninety-five years ago, a referendum proposing the consolidation of greater New York into what are now the five boroughs got more support in Richmond, as it was known, than in any other county -- 79 percent.
Almost from the beginning, Staten Islanders had second thoughts. In 1947, after New York City decided that Fresh Kills would be just the spot to dump garbage from the other boroughs, a secession movement was begun, but it failed in the Legislature.
The nascent movement was galvanized again in 1989 when a charter commission, responding to court rulings, abolished the Board of Estimate, on which each of the five borough presidents had equal votes. Theoretically, that pretense of equality actually benefited Staten Island, which had fewer residents. Following the most fundamental restructuring of city government since consolidation, Staten Island was left with three representatives on an expanded 51-member City Council -- and the Fresh Kills dump.
By 1990, after the Governor and the Legislature gave a tentative go-ahead, Staten Islanders voted by 83 percent -- even more than the percentage for consolidation -- to begin the secession process again.
With State Senator John J. Marchi as its chairman and Dr. Joseph P. Viteritti, who heads the Center for Management at New York University's Wagner School of Public Service, as its director, the charter commission held hearings, conducted polls and finally concluded that a mayor-council form of government would be "consistent with the local tradition of Staten Islanders, but it additionally allows the government of the Island to provide maximum representation for its diverse population."
That the population is less racially diverse than the city's is not coincidental, either to the challenge by the other boroughs to the Board of Estimate or to the possibilities for ethnic cleansing that secession represents for some Staten Islanders.
One issue looms even largerthan diversity, though: taxes. The commission decided that a City of Staten Island could provide services with current revenues, but that secession could cost the remaining four boroughs about $300 million, or 1 percent of the current citywide expense budget. Garbage may have traveled a one-way street, but for years New York City subsidized Staten Island commuters going both ways by, among other things, maintaining the nickel fare on the ferry.
The commission estimated that as things stand, revenues associated with Staten Island totaled $955 million during the 1991 fiscal year and expenditures $1.13 billion -- suggesting that the borough may get more than it gives, and not just garbage (which is scheduled to go elsewhere eventually after making Fresh Kills the highest point on the eastern seaboard).
"It shouldn't be interpreted as saying that because this would be economically feasible, do it," Dr. Viteritti said.
Plenty of other transition issues would have to be resolved if Staten Islanders approve a second secession referendum in November and leave the final decision with the Governor and with state legislators, who passed the buck in the first place.
But at the same time that they are voting on secession, Staten Islanders may choose their former mayor. Four years ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani defeated David N. Dinkins by better than 4 to 1 on Staten Island. Voters there may prove pivotal if there is a rematch next November.
Kevin Simmons, the 6-foot-8 Tilden High School basketball star from Brooklyn, has won off the court as well as on. Mr. Simmons, the subject of a recent Metro Matters column, had been barred by the Public School Athletic League from playing for Tilden after he transferred there last September from a Virginia high school that he had attended for a few months after switching from Christ the King High School in Queens.
The question was whether Mr. Simmons was circumventing Board of Education rules that bar transfers "for the purpose of participating in athletics at the receiving school." Peter Parcher, a lawyer who had sued on Mr. Simmons's behalf, said on Friday that after several favorable rulings for Mr. Simmons, city lawyers have agreed that he is eligible.

HEADLINE: Congressional Brief;
Amid Calls for 'Change,' Senate Stays the Course

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
When the rest of Washington hums a mantra of "change," count on the United States Senate to stand fast against the kind of loose thinking abroad in the land that suggests the venerable Congressional way of doing business is, well, not quite adequate to the nation's needs.
The faint breath of reform in the Senate was stilled almost before it could be noticed last week when the minority leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, dismissed a series of very modest suggestions for speeding up the chamber's arcane ways. It was not that Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, proposed anything really radical, like requiring amendments to have something to do with the bill they amend, or even something painful, like a five-day, or even a four-day week. 
 Mr. Mitchell's most dramatic proposal would have reduced to 2 hours, from the current maximum of 78, the time the Senate can spend before it gets to vote on whether to consider a particular bill. He said the change "could enhance the Senate's efficiency as well as its ability to act in a responsible manner in a changing world."
But Mr. Dole, whose own most radical proposal was limiting Senate sessions, which sometimes last until Christmas, to six months -- he didn't say how many days a week -- was unmoved. "Minority rights are precious in the Senate," he proclaimed, and should not be abridged in the name of reform. Since it takes 67 votes to end a filibuster over rules changes, there is no chance Mr. Dole can be beaten.
 
Stand By Your Man? Not These Democrats
 It is not only the Republicans who find the old ways comforting. For years some Democrats have been at odds with the leadership of their party, considering it out of touch and elitist. Eight years ago they founded the Democratic Leadership Council to try to have a greater voice in party affairs. And by the surest political measure of all, they succeeded; one of them, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, was elected President.
But the habit of fighting their party's leadership lives on. In Mr. Clinton's first two problems with Congress, the fights over the Zoe Baird nomination and over homosexuals in the armed services, it was Democrats from his own D.L.C. who complained first. Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, a founder of the organization, led Democrats in opposition to Mr. Clinton over gay troops, and Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, another prominent member, fired one of the first Democratic attacks on Ms. Baird.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, one of several non-D.L.C. candidates whom Mr. Clinton defeated for the Democratic nomination last year, chided Mr. Breaux for not standing by his old chum. Another Senator reported that Mr. Breaux replied that he was, selflessly, only trying to make it easier for Mr. Clinton to withdraw the nomination.
 
Public Calls In With Requests and Advice
 It is doubtless too early for the public to have a fixed opinion of the new Congress. But if there is any early trend, lawmakers point out, it is that along with telling Congress what to do about Ms. Baird or homosexual soldiers, the voters are telling them not to be spending their time on such issues. "We sent you back to cut the deficit and fix the economy," Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas reported one constituent told him on the phone, before offering advice on the military issue.
But before Congress got around to these problems, there was some clear evidence that the public was even feeling hopeful about Capitol Hill. The New York Times/CBS News Poll, completed just before Inauguration Day, showed that 48 percent of Americans thought the influx of new members would enable Congress to do a better job, while only 4 percent thought it would do worse.
And 72 percent said they thought the Government would "work better" now that one party controlled both Congress and the White House. Of course, the last time that question was asked, 74 percent said so. That was in 1977. The Carter years ended with those hopes unfulfilled.
 
New Legislation, Same Compromises
 Nobody plans to cut the deficit or fix the economy any time soon. The Democrats are still waiting for Mr. Clinton's proposals. But as legislative batting practice, each house plans to pass two bills next week. The Senate plans to pass a health research authorization bill, the House plans to adopt a measure to ease voter registration, and both intend to pass the family-leave bill.
The timing is pure theatrics, intended to prove that now that George Bush is gone, progress can be made. But the legislation itself may carry a message for the future, because all the compromises put into those bills to woo Republican lawmakers in 1992, with the hope of overriding a veto, remain in 1993. Democrats thought of toughening them up, but they decided the long-range interest of good relations with moderate Republicans was worth the price of slightly weaker versions of these bills.

HEADLINE: Stalled Tobacco Suit Is Revived by Ruling

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
After winning a five-year battle to remove a Federal judge from sitting on their cases, cigarette companies defending against smokers' lawsuits found scant reason last week to cheer a ruling by the judge's successor.
The ruling by Judge Alfred J. Lechner Jr. of Federal District Court in Newark breathed new life into a stalled lawsuit contending that cigarette makers knowingly marketed unsafe products and conspired to conceal the dangers of smoking. 
 In his ruling, the judge said that the lawsuit, brought by a Philadelphia woman over the death of her father, was of "high public interest" and had brought to light "damaging" industry documents and that to allow her to be driven out of the case by the superior spending power of the tobacco companies would be "intolerable."
Judge Lechner thus rejected the application of lawyers for the woman, Susan Haines, to be let out of the case, which was filed in 1984 and has cost millions of dollars. While Ms. Haines -- whose father, Peter F. Rossi, died of lung cancer in 1982 -- voiced delight with the ruling, neither her lawyers from the firm of Budd Larner Gross Rosenbaum Greenberg & Sade of Short Hills, N.J., nor lawyers representing tobacco companies returned telephone calls seeking comment.
 
Viewed as a Setback
 Following by less than five months the removal of his predecessor, Judge H. Lee Sarokin, on the ground of an appearance of bias against the cigarette companies, Judge Lechner's action seemed to mark a setback in the industry's efforts to sustain a virtually unbroken record of success in the face of mounting liability lawsuits to which the Supreme Court opened the door last summer.
The Court ruled that while warning labels on cigarette packs shielded companies from some liability, smokers had grounds for action if they could show that companies concealed or misrepresented the risks. Internal documents produced by the companies under duress in the lawsuits are giving credence to such allegations.
But in a significant victory by the industry on Friday, a state circuit court jury in Belleville, Ill., rejected the claims of a 51-year-old lung-cancer patient and longtime Winston smoker, Charles Kueper, who was suing R. J. Reynolds and the Tobacco Institute for $48 million in damages for his illness. After a 10-week trial, the jury found his smoking, despite the known risks, a matter of free choice.
Only one plaintiff, Rose Cipollone of New Jersey, has ever won a damage award from a cigarette company, but the $400,000 verdict after her death in 1984 was later overturned and the case was never retried.
In Brooklyn, meanwhile, Federal prosecutors have been conducting what lawyers described as the nation's first criminal investigation of possible conspiracy and fraud by tobacco companies. In an extraordinary effort to seize confidential industry documents being held under seal in Judge Sarokin's court, prosecutors last year sought to obtain a search warrant for the material but were turned down at a higher level, said a lawyer familiar with the matter. The interim United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Mary Jo White, declined to comment.
Judge Lechner's decision in New Jersey on Tuesday revived a case that had lain dormant since shortly after Judge Sarokin's disqualification based on an opinion in which Judge Sarokin said "the tobacco industry may be the king of concealment and disinformation" and cited internal company documents that he said should be made public under "crime-fraud exceptions" to the lawyer-client confidentiality privilege.
Yet last November, his successor, Judge Lechner, was petitioned by Ms. Haines's lawyers to be allowed to drop the arduous and costly litigation, stalling the case. The lawyers had argued that the case, taken on a contingency-fee basis, was unlikely to yield anything close to the millions of dollars it had cost and that the lawsuit had already raised crucial public issues. The defendants -- the Liggett Group; Loews, the parent company of Lorillard; R. J. Reynolds, a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco, and Philip Morris -- took no position on the motion, although forcing Ms. Haines to drop the case or start all over with new lawyers could scarcely have been an unwelcome prospect.
 
'Burdensome and Expensive'
 But Judge Lechner ruled it was not in the interest of justice to allow that. Twice, he quoted a statement by an R. J. Reynolds lawyer, J. Michael Jordan, who had credited cigarette companies' courtroom victories to a strategy of making the lawsuits "extremely burdensome and expensive" for plaintiffs.
The Jordan statement as cited in the judge's opinion went on: "To paraphrase General Patton, the way we won these cases was not by spending [RJR's] money, but by making that other son of a bitch spend all of his."
To which Judge Lechner responded: "To the extent Jordan's paraphrase of General Patton correctly reflects the attitude of defendants, it is at odds with the purposes of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and is intolerable." He took note of the extensive depositions sought by the defendant companies.
Taking issue with a contention by Ms. Haines's laywers that it was not in the public interest to pursue a lawsuit lacking "economic viability," Judge Lechner said, "There is a high public interest in cases such as this."
Ms. Haines lauded the ruling. "I'm very happy," she said, although she acknowledged that there was a chance that Budd Larner might yet appeal. Calls to two of the firm's lawyers, Marc Z. Edell and Cynthia A. Walters, were not returned.
Repeated calls on Friday to lawyers for Liggett, Loews and R. J. Reynolds were also not returned.
Richard A. Daynard, a professor at Northeastern University Law School and chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Project that tracks smoker lawsuits around the nation, said the ruling showed Judge Lechner was "tougher than Sarokin" and had no patience for delaying tactics. "They're going to be sorry they got this guy," he said of the defendants.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Investors Now Expect Inflation to Remain Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Inflation is down. That is documented in Government statistics. But what was not so sure until last week's bond rally is that investors and traders -- long known for their skepticism -- are actually beginning to believe that inflation will stay low for some time.
Some analysts and investors are citing that growing confidence about the inflationary outlook to explain the surprising rally that has dropped the interest rate on the 30-year bond to its lowest level in six and a half years. The yield on the 30-year bond ended Friday at 7.19 percent. 
 "We think that growth is going to be reasonable, but not spectacular, and that inflation is not coming back soon," John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said. "And if that is the consensus that is forming, it should lead to lower long-term interest rates."
 
 
'I Believe'
 Glenn E. Murphy, the chief investment officer at Travelers Asset Management International in Hartford, said, "I believe the inflation story." And because of that he has been buying long-term Treasury securities since autumn, and made especially sure that he "hopped on the freight train as it left the station in January."
Mr. Murphy's confidence reflects a shift in attitude that could open the way to the lower long-term interest rates that economists from the smallest of banks to the chairman of the Federal Reserve have said are needed to keep the economy on a sure-footed growth path. Lower long-term rates will give a boost to construction, to housing and home buyers and to businesses.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said last week that long-term rates could be two percentage points lower -- that is, around 5 percent -- given current inflation levels of 3 percent and a credible effort by the Clinton Administration to reduce the record Federal budget deficit.
But while Mr. Lipsky and Mr. Murphy said the inflation story should continue to bring rates lower over the year, they warned that the markets' adherence to this new low-inflation dogma would be tested in coming weeks. This means that trading is likely to remain volatile whether investors and traders decide to push yields lower or not.
 
 
'Real Challenge'
 Investors and traders seemed to dismiss a signal of strong growth in Friday's report of a sharp 9.1 percent increase in orders for durable goods in December. "That is a real challenge to our fundamental outlook of 2.5 percent sideways growth," Mr. Murphy said .
But several of the economic reports due out this week could disturb traders by forcing them to conclude that the economy is not growing more slowly at the start of 1993 than at the end of 1992. A belief that growth has slowed has contributed to the rally because slow growth increases the odds that inflation will stay low or even fall further.
These reports include the index of leading economic indicators on Tuesday and the January employment report on Friday. The jobs report will be watched especially closely because it will be the first detailed economic barometer of the year.
President Clinton will introduce his economic program before a joint session of Congress on Feb. 17. Mr. Lipsky said the market could be unnerved if the Administration did not come through with the kind of tough deficit-reduction policies that it had been talking about. It was that talk -- starting with comments from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen about new taxes and reducing the deficit -- that started the rally last week.
 
 
Concerns About Policy
 "What will determine the speed of the rate decline is what will diminish the concerns about policy" disrupting the low-inflation outlook, Mr. Lipsky said. But he said the market had already anticipated positive developments before seeing any actual policy from the Administration or reaction from Congress. "I would have thought that investors might have been somewhat more cautious until the policy consensus of the new Administration was clear," he said.
Mr. Murphy is sure enough that the Clinton economic plan "will disappoint the optimists" that he is beginning to sell some of his long-term Treasuries to take profits. But he emphasized that because he believes inflation will remain tame, he is just cutting back a little and is still, on balance, betting that interest rates move lower.
"An awful lot of the juice has been squeezed out of the market in the first part of the year," he said. "We think that rates will work their way lower, but that the market will be fighting all the way."
Several other obstacles could trip up the market. One is the Treasury's quarterly auction of 30-year bonds and 10-year and 3-year notes in the second week of February. This auction can disrupt a rally if the new supply is hard to digest. And the auction could be a little more uncertain because it comes a week before Mr. Clinton announces his economic program. But well-orchestrated leaks could make much of the program known before then.
 
 
Size of Bond Auction
 Then there is the question of whether the Administration will reduce the size of the 30-year bond auction in an effort to reduce costs by shifting the borrowing to Treasury bills, which have a lower interest rate. Such a move could also help to lower long-term rates.
While there is debate over the precise benefits of such a change in borrowing, speculation about a cut in the issuance of the 30-year bond has already played a role in pushing the yield to six-and-a-half-year lows. A disappointment this week when the size of the refunding is announced could push prices lower and yields higher.
Even bond market bulls like Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, who forecasts a 30-year bond yield below 7 percent by the end of the year, are a little worried that the market could be undermined in the weeks ahead.
"There might be a lot of wishful thinking that could be built into the bond market that could get blown away in February," he said. But he is still not wavering in his long-term view. He said he just has to look at the Commodity Research Bureau futures index, a close-in barometer of prices, where he sees inflation remaining low. And in the end, he said, that will be enough to pull long-term interest rates lower.
 
 
Corporate Record
 With just a few million to spare, the corporate bond market managed to set a record for new issues in January. Total issues for the month, including sales by corporations and government agencies totaled about $37.1 billion, just over the record of $36.8 billion set a year ago.

HEADLINE: Greenspan the Politician

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the habitually cautious chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, appeared to have read the election returns when he gave a surprisingly strong endorsement last week to President Clinton's plans to stimulate the economy.
In suggesting that the President's stimulus package was not too large and his longer-term deficit reduction plan not too small, Mr. Greenspan seemed to signal an era of camaraderie with the new President. This should make life easier for Mr. Clinton by reducing the chances of interest rate increases and for Mr. Greenspan by reducing the criticism he faces. The harmony might also head off Congressional efforts to exert more control over the Fed. 
 The public clearly voted for faster economic growth in November. And if Mr. Greenspan had signaled that he would rain on their hopes by opposing an economic stimulus plan, he would have antagonized a new President as well as Congressional Democrats, who are already busy bashing him.
Indeed, if Mr. Greenspan had said an economic stimulus plan was unnecessary because it would overheat the economy, many members of Congress, and perhaps the Clinton Administration, would have read that as a declaration of war.
In his Congressional appearances last week, Mr. Greenspan faced the withering ire of several Senators who gave the Federal Reserve an "F" for its role in fighting the recession. These Senators blamed the central bank for the weakness of the recovery, saying it cut interest rates too little and too late.
By showing a pro-growth, pro-Clinton tilt, Mr. Greenspan, a long-time Washington insider who likes to be liked, probably hoped to defuse criticism from Congress and elsewhere. And perhaps he hoped a pro-growth posture might help protect his place in history from assaults by economic legends like Paul A. Samuelson, a liberal, and Milton Friedman, a conservative, who have lambasted the Greenspan Fed for hampering the recovery.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan all but told the financial markets to trust the new President. He said that if Mr. Clinton put together a credible deficit-cutting plan, then long-term interest rates might fall sharply, something that would stimulate growth and make Congress, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan happy.
With this statement, Mr. Greenspan simultaneously dangled a carrot in front of the President to get serious about deficit reduction and, at the same time, jawboned financial market players. No one respects financial markets more than the Fed chairman, but he seems frustrated that long-term interest rates remain so high.
 
Symbolic Stances
 Still, Mr. Greenspan maintained his anti-inflation credentials. In giving his seal of approval to Mr. Clinton's plan to stimulate the economy with about $20 billion in increased deficit spending this year, he made clear that he did not believe a $20 billion package would cause the economy to overheat and eventually force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to fight inflation. In fact, many economists say such a package would be so small that it would be mere public relations aimed at showing that the Administration was doing something to spur the economy.
Similarly, the Fed chairman gave away nothing when he promised that if a large deficit-reduction package were to slow growth, the Fed would take that into account in setting interest rates. This meant that the Fed could cut rates -- not necessarily that it would.
Mr. Greenspan's pro-growth remarks had an additional agenda: to derail Congressional proposals intended to reduce the independence of the Federal Reserve.
 
Looking Out for the Fed
 Henry A. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, has proposed having the President rather than local bankers select the Federal Reserve's 12 regional bank presidents, who sit on the central bank's main policy-setting committee. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, wants to deny the regional bank presidents a vote on that committee, known as the Federal Open Market Committee. Nineteen people sit on that Committee -- the Federal Reserve's 7 governors and the 12 regional bank presidents, 5 of whom are allowed to vote.
These proposals went nowhere in the last Administration because of rifts between President George Bush and Capitol Hill. But with Democrats in control of the White House and Congress, some Federal Reserve officials fear that these bills could move forward, especially if the Fed is seen as opposing faster growth.
The Fed's predicament is analogous to that of the Supreme Court in the 1930's when President Franklin D. Roosevelt tried to expand the Court, and fill it with his allies, after the Court kept overturning New Deal legislation. Facing the President's wrath and having read the election returns, the Court suddenly began to throw its weight behind the New Deal.
Explaining the Court's about-face, commentators quipped, "A switch in time saves nine." This time, Mr. Greenspan may hope that a switch in time saves 19.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Media King With Much to Prove

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 27

 BODY:
For someone who has just lost more than $640 million, Jean-Luc Lagardere looks singularly sprightly. The eyes of the ebullient chairman of Matra-Hachette still twinkle, and he remains a man with a ready smile.
But Mr. Lagardere, a flamboyant businessman, has changed after making a disastrous attempt to take Hachette into the television business. In place of the fast-talking entrepreneur of a few years ago who was busy buying magazines in the United States and planning a worldwide media empire, a quieter man now fiddles occasionally with worry beads on his desk, and says: 
 "When one has had an accident, one becomes more prudent. I have not changed in my desire to do things, but I recognize that I made a mistake, and my approach now is a careful one suited to the business atmosphere of the 90's."
Mr. Lagardere has much to prove. He has just completed the unlikely merger of Matra, the military contractor he controlled, with Hachette, the publishing house he acquired in 1980. In the face of skeptics who say that the merger was essentially a way to save Hachette after its failure in television, the 64-year-old executive must now make a success of this magazines-to-missiles monster, one with annual revenue of about $10 billion.
Jean Borjeix, an analyst at the Jean-Pierre Pinatton brokerage firm here, remarked: "The merger was an operation designed to use Matra's strength to cover the difficulties of Hachette. Mr. Lagardere is an expert in such financial acrobatics, but the market is still not sure what to make of him."
 
Ample Energy
 After a 30-year career, nobody doubts Mr. Lagardere's drive or creativity. But while he has built a vast business organization, his judgment is sometimes questioned. Forays into sectors like automobile equipment, personal computers and television sets have failed. His decision in 1990 to invest in a private French television channel, La Cinq, proved disastrous.
By the time the station collapsed last April, afflicted mostly by plunging ad revenue and costly regulatory restrictions on its programming, it had cost Hachette 3.54 billion francs, or $643 million. The loss effectively crushed Hachette's ambition to compete with the likes of the News Corporation, Bertelsmann and Time Warner as a stand-alone media company of world stature.
"I take 100 percent of the blame for this error," Mr. Lagardere said. "But the idea of trying to get into television was not wrong, and I refuse to become one of those businessmen you find so often these days who take pride in the risks they did not take."
Mr. Lagardere has always been known as a risk taker. John Veronis, of Veronis, Suhler & Associates, a New York investment bank specializing in media properties, calls him "one of the world's true entrepreneurs, a man who is bold and imaginative."
Certainly, his style has been forthright. Before the debacle at La Cinq, Hachette had embarked on a major expansion into the United States, paying $670 million in 1988 for Grolier encyclopedias and magazines, including Woman's Day and Road & Track. Unfortunately, the investment was made just as advertising weakened.
Having taken on close to $2 billion in debt, in part to make those acquisitions, Hachette had already been weakened when the television station closed. Some analysts question whether the company, which lost $550 million in 1991, could have survived on its own.
But Mr. Lagardere has long had two strings to his bow. An engineer by training, he made his fortune at Matra's military and electronics group, which makes missiles, telecommunications equipment, automatic subway systems, cars and space modules.
Matra suddenly appeared as a savior for Hachette. After long negotiations, during which the original offer to Matra stockholders had to be improved because of Hachette's worsening plight, the merger was completed last month. Matra stockholders received 13 Hachette shares for every 5 shares they held in Matra. A $509 million recapitalization of Hachette is nearing completion.
 
Facing Some Limits
 Mr. Lagardere is still in charge. But his position has been altered. New investors have required him to set up a holding company, Lagardere Group, under an unusual corporate statute that makes him liable, to the extent of his entire personal fortune, if Matra-Hachette fails. Although he controls Lagardere Group, the new shareholders, including Credit Lyonnais and Banque Nationale de Paris, will be looking over his shoulder.
"The fact that Lagardere has now engaged his personal fortune in the success of Matra-Hachette is seen positively by the market," Mr. Borjeix said.
But doubts remain about the very different natures of the merged companies' businesses. "In terms of their activities, the one company brought nothing to the other," said Jean-Paul Pierret, analyst at J. P. Morgan & Company in Paris.
Mr. Lagardere replies: "People say you have to have a single business -- tires or cars or food. But I believe that today, an industrial group has to be widely diversified. That is the best way to guard against the impact of business cycles."
As for synergy, he scoffed, "Synergy does not exist, not even between books and newspapers."
Analysts see some positive signs for the merged company. As the American economy improves, Hachette Magazines Inc., with its 17 titles, is beginning to pick up. This follows a very difficult few years, during which Woman's Day was put up for sale before being withdrawn because the offers were too low.
Last year, revenue for Hachette Magazines grew to $636 million from $587 million the year before, mainly on a 26 percent surge in ad revenue at a revamped Woman's Day. David Pecker, chief executive of the group, said that only Elle continues to present problems, with the number of advertising pages dropping 13 percent last year from 1991. He added that the group's profit margin on sales was slightly above the American industry average of 10 percent.
Mr. Veronis said it now appeared that the acquisition of the magazines, which include Metropolitan Home and Popular Photography, "will prove to have been a good strategic move for Hachette."
And Mr. Lagardere suggested that Hachette would like to increase the share of its American business, to rise to 50 percent over the next decade, from about 30 percent now.
Still, he said that no new debts would be incurred. And while conceding that Hachette needed a television business to complement its print activities, he said his experience with La Cinq had made him wary.
"This is a big hole, and one day we need to fill it," he said, "but I've been burned once, and I'd look very carefully before making any new television venture."
 
Optimism on New Company
 As for Matra, which accounts for about 45 percent of the group's sales, analysts see encouraging signs. A $265 million investment last year by Northern Telecom Ltd. in the company's telecommunications business has strengthened that sector, particularly in cellular phones.
"We knew about the losses at La Cinq," said Paul G. Stern, Northern Telecom's chief executive, "but what impressed us were our complementary businesses in telecommunications and their highly capable management team. Lagardere is straight talking, quick to make decisions, and not risk averse. I liked him immediately."
The military unit has benefited from Matra's share of a $3.5 billion order to sell 60 Mirage jets to Taiwan, and its order book had risen to $3.62 billion at the end of 1992, from $1.99 billion at the end of the previous year. And the company's auto sector, long in the doldrums, is riding high on the extraordinary success of the Espace mini-van it designed and makes for Renault.
As for Mr. Lagardere, he has already predicted "a very significant improvement" in 1993 on the merged company's 1992 results, which are expected to show a profit between $63 million and $82 million. He shrugs off suggestions of retirement, saying he still has much to do.
"I am a man of the land, a good Gascon peasant, and when a peasant is 80 or 85 he is still planting trees," he said. "The trees are his heritage, even if he knows he will never see them fully grown."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Middle-Class Rage: Like in History, Only Different

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Boiling Point
Republicans, Democrats and the Decline of Middle-Class Prosperity
By Kevin Phillips
Illustrated. 307 pages. Random House. $23. 
 As he takes pains to remind us at least half a dozen times in his disturbing new study, "Boiling Point: Republicans, Democrats and the Decline of Middle-Class Prosperity," Kevin Phillips is the political analyst who in his 1969 book, "The Emerging Republican Majority," predicted that the worn-out New Deal Democratic coalition was breaking up in favor a new Republican Presidential majority based on a new middle-class populism and a new Southern-Western alignment, which he called the Sun Belt.
More than two decades later, his sixth book, "The Politics of Rich and Poor," became what was described as a "founding document" of the 1992 Presidential campaign. So when Mr. Phillips talks about the mood of American voters we had better pay attention.
But in his new book, "Boiling Point," he is not so much concerned with predicting the behavior of voters as he is with analyzing what their present feelings are and the reasons for those feelings. Taking off from "The Politics of Rich and Poor," which portrayed the very rich as the major beneficiaries of the Reagan and Bush eras and the very poor as the losers, Mr. Phillips turns to the people between these extremes, or the middle class, which he believes to be the engine of great financial empires. As he writes, "Outbursts of bourgeois spirit and inventiveness, the triumph of middle-class values over those of established elites, have often prodded countries toward peaks of economic and political achievement."
What he finds is not too surprising. In the years of the Reagan and Bush Presidencies, the middle classes of America declined precipitately. No group has been hurt more by rising taxes, declining real income, escalating expenses, a shrinking job market, deteriorating public services, falling home values, growing health costs, weakening safety nets, the loss of savings and the threat of collapsing pension and insurance funds.
Near the bottom of the middle class, people were dropping out as a result of the loss of jobs in the industrial sector of the market. Near the top, people were running faster to stay in place on a treadmill. "For young Americans, those under 30 or 35," Mr. Phillips concludes, "two decades of polarization had brought a special, though widely unappreciated, irony: not only were they (and those younger) in danger of being the first generation of Americans to suffer a lower standard of living than their parents, but they would be the first generation to receive -- or not receive -- much of their economic opportunity from family inheritance, not personal achievement."
Now, the idea that middle-class prosperity is declining may not be a very exciting thesis, given its obviousness to most readers and the somewhat repetitive, helter-skelter way that Mr. Phillips marshals his extensive evidence. But he lends his theory considerable excitement by pointing out that America's present situation mirrors "those of history's two previous bourgeois zeniths -- 17th-century Holland and late-19th-century England."
Those empires, Mr. Phillips writes, "had also fallen from their middle-class zeniths when manufacturing, trade, nationalism and bourgeois spirit gave way to 'financialization' -- the cumulating influence of finance, government debt, unearned income, rentiers, overseas investment, domestic economic polarization and social stratification."
This implies that given its present conditions, especially its national debt and trade deficit, the United States is about to suffer the fate of the Netherlands and Britain. So we thrash our way eagerly through Mr. Phillips's thickets of tables and statistics to see what if anything can be done to save the country.
But near the end of his book, Mr. Phillips shifts his ground somewhat. For one thing, he writes that there is cause for optimism after all. "Unlike Holland and Britain in their heydays, the United States was not a relatively small maritime power lacking great natural resources or a large domestic market and thereby vulnerable. On the contrary, because of its size, resources and the possibility of a larger North American economic union, the United States had no reason to expect the Dutch and British fate, provided its policy makers learned from earlier downturns that imperial overreach, mushrooming debt and increased emphasis on finance, money and the interests of rentiers rather than on manufacturing were more than a source of great-power decline." Now he tells us, you want to cry out.
For another thing, he writes as if what really interested him all along is the behavior of the frustrated middle-class voter, which historically has involved "a mixture of cultural conservatism, apprehension about economic status, nativism and anger at the new rich." For a while there, he observes, it looked as if this voter were turning to candidates like Patrick Buchanan, David Duke and Ross Perot. But then Bill Clinton made all the right promises and rode away with the brass ring. It now remains to be seen if the President will refrain from further burdening the distressed middle class and succeed in rebuilding our diminishing industrial base. If he fails, we can expect to see the revival of voter frustration and the continued rise of a broadly based third party. In short, Ross Perot lives.
But this is not exactly stunning news. So while "Boiling Point" may analyze our immediate past with exhaustiveness and acuity, it really doesn't tell us much about the prospects of America that we couldn't have figured out for ourselves by reading the front page of our daily newspaper. And while it may constitute a dire warning, it does not compare to Mr. Phillips's earlier books as a herald of what is to come.

HEADLINE: The Talk of Sundance;
The Winners and Notable Losers at Sundance

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARK CITY, Utah, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Mainstream was once a derisive word at the Sundance Film Festival.
Only a few years ago, audiences and judges at the nation's major showcase for independent films embraced arty, esoteric movies and snubbed those dreaded Hollywood-style products. But the increasing influx of the Hollywood crowd -- coupled with changing styles of film makers -- was evident on Saturday night when audience awards were presented to films that are -- let's face it -- mainstream.
"El Mariachi," a comedy-drama by Richard Rodriguez, a 24-year-old Texas film maker, won the Audience Award for a feature film, which is given on a vote by the festival's 5,000 filmgoers and is a good gauge of a film's commercial prospects. The film, about a mariachi musician who enters a Mexican border town at the same time as a hit man, was made by Mr. Rodriguez and his friends for only $7,000. Initially made as a quickie for the Spanish-language video market, it is about as arty as "Lethal Weapon." But much funnier.
(Not as funny, and overlooked in the awards, but still the most talked about film, was "Boxing Helena," about obsessive love gone haywire. Audiences reacted in two ways: they loved it or they hated it.)
Mr. Rodriguez, an engaging, coolly confident film maker whose movie is to be released by Columbia Pictures in January, said on Saturday night, "I just hope this inspires people to make their own movies, no matter who they are, no matter how rich or poor."
 
A Winning Documentary
 The Audience Award for a documentary was given to "Something Within Me," an affectionate portrait of St. Augustine's School of the Arts in the South Bronx. This unusual elementary school uses music and other forms of artistic expression to nurture a sense of responsibility and pride among its poor, minority students. The movie won two other awards: the Film Makers Trophy and a Special Jury Award for Merit.
The documentary's producer, Jerret Engle, a former editor at the Dutton publishing house, initially heard about the school on the evening news in New York City about five years ago. Since then, she has worked at part-time jobs and spent years raising $250,000 to make the film.
"I'm just floored," she said on Saturday night. "I love these kids and their teachers, but I didn't know anyone else would be interested." The film, set for a modest commercial release, has already drawn the interest of the Public Broadcasting Service and Home Box Office.
 
Four Grand Prizes
 In presenting the awards, the audience was somewhat out of sync with the more traditional Sundance jury. The panel split the Grand Jury prizes among two dramas and two documentaries.
The dramas are "Ruby in Paradise," Victor Nunez's rambling film about a young woman who flees her Tennessee town to find her sense of self on the Florida coast, and Bryan J. Singer's "Public Access." The latter is about a slick, slightly eerie newcomer to a fictional Midwestern town, Brewster, who takes over the public-access cable network and asks the question: "What's wrong with Brewster?" The result is nothing less than paranoia.
The jury's documentary awards were given to two powerful works: "Children of Fate: Life and Death in a Sicilian Family," a heart-wrenching portrait of three generations of a Sicilian family, and "Silverlake Life: The View From Here," a harrowing film about AIDS.
(Other prize-winners included Steve Gomer's "Fly By Night," a drama about New York rappers; Tony Chan's "Combination Platter," about illegal Chinese immigrants; Everett Lewis's "Ambush of Ghosts," about a dysfunctional family; Leslie Harris's "Just Another Girl on the IRT," about a black Brooklyn teen-ager, and "Lillian," about the struggles of a black woman. A documentary prize also went to "Earth and the American Dream," about the destruction of the nation's environment).
"Silverlake Life" traces the final journey of a film teacher, Tom Joslin, and his companion of 22 years, Mark Maasi, both of whom had AIDS. The two men lived in the Silverlake area of Los Angeles, and both videotaped the film themselves. The graphic film, which includes a hard-to-watch death scene, was completed by a friend, Peter Friedman, a documentary director.
Mr. Friedman, 34, a former student of Mr. Joslin's at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., said he culled 40 hours of videotapes to produce the 99-minute film. "It is a direct and a difficult film which shows the realities of day-to-day life with AIDS," Mr. Friedman said after the awards. "The whole spirit of the film is to confront the pain and the love shared by these two men." In recent days, he said, television and theatrical distributors have expressed interest in the documentary.
 
A Few Words From the Founder
 Sundance is plainly going a bit Hollywood; at least six agents from United Talent Agency, one of the festival's numerous sponsors and more aggressive agencies, were seeking new clients. Still, the awards ceremony hardly resembled the Oscars.
Robert Redford, the founder of the festival, was welcomed onstage with applause and whistles. He wore boots, jeans, a leather jacket and a striped sweat shirt.
Mr. Redford, one of the few millionaire movie stars who have actually paid back the industry by nurturing new film makers, told the packed crowd in a converted basketball gym in this ski resort town: "Nobody can understand the blood, the sweat, the dedication it takes to make these films. Nobody can understand that except the film maker."
He said the festival stands for "innovation, for the avant-garde." But other film makers and executives say it was virtually unavoidable for Sundance to turn, unwittingly, into a hunting ground for Hollywood. In many ways, Hollywood is less interested in the films shown here -- which often flounder at the box office -- than in new film makers with commercial potential.
"It really is a festival of agents," said Jonathan Dana, the president of Triton Pictures, an independent film company, who has been visiting the festival for several years. "It's a barter economy. Everyone's trading information. But it's a tricky conversion from the narrow world of independent films to the market place."
Mr. Dana speaks from personal experience. Last year, Triton bought two of the big prize-winners at Sundance: the comedy, "In the Soup," whose star, Seymour Cassel, was master of ceremonies at this year's awards, and the documentary "A Brief History of Time."
Mr. Dana, standing outside a movie theater in Park City, said simply, "One worked; one didn't."
Like another big favorite last year, "The Waterdance," "In the Soup" failed at the box office. But "A Brief History" succeeded. Mr. Dana shrugged and voiced the oft-heard Hollywood complaint: "Who knows what works?"
 
'Orlando' and 'Helena'
 Curiously, the two pictures that were most widely discussed at Sundance went unmentioned last night.
One of them, "Orlando," an adaptation of the Virginia Woolf novel by an English film maker, Sally Potter, had its United States premiere at the festival but was not in competition for prizes. (The festival divides films into two major categories, those in competition and those having premieres.) By virtual consensus, "Orlando" was the most dazzling film at the festival.
And then there was "Boxing Helena."
No film at the festival provoked as much rage, hisses, applause and debate as this one. The film was directed and written by Jennifer Chambers Lynch, the daughter of David Lynch. Even before it was shown here, the movie created an unusual amount of talk because of the last-minute withdrawals of Madonna and then Kim Basinger from the lead role. Helena is now played by Sherilyn Fenn.
The film deals with a lunatic surgeon (Julian Sands) obsessed by an elusive, beautiful woman named Helena. To keep her, he transforms her into his own Venus de Milo by cutting off her arms and legs and placing her on a pedestal. Hard to believe, but the film is a comedy, albeit very dark.
Ms. Lynch, like many of the twentysomething directors here, is a very confident, assured film maker, without a hint of self-doubt.
Sipping coffee and chain-smoking the other morning in a hotel dining room, Ms. Lynch said she was startled by the almost violent reaction to her film. The film has been called anti-feminist, anti-male and exploitative.
"People want the film abolished," she said. "They scream at us. I wish they would talk to me. I want to hear them. They don't want to have a discussion. They just get up and leave."
Ms. Lynch, who never went to college, grew up in Los Angeles and attended Interlochen Arts Academy in Interlochen, Mich. Upon graduation, she said, she went on a "fairly extensive hike with my boyfriend," lived in Baltimore for several months, and then moved to Los Angeles at 19 to work for her father and write the movie. She's now 24. The movie is awaiting a distributor in the United States
"My whole intent was to parody and to show seriously what we do to each other in relationships," she said. "It's about how we try to change each other. We are equally vulnerable to self-hatred, to obsession, and we try and change each other. It's about how we try to break each other down and control each other -- the thievery that goes on in obsessive relationships."
Although other film makers here find it hard to believe, Ms. Lynch said being her father's daughter was not a blessing.
"Believe me, people wanted nothing to do with me," she said. "I was 19; it was a risky script; I was some big director's daughter and female. There's something about being a daughter. You would think it gives you some credibility. It doesn't."
At least, Ms. Lynch had no trouble getting through the doors of agents and executives.
 
A Long Island Story
 At the other end of the spectrum is Rob Weiss, 26, whose father, Carl, runs a touring business for gamblers in Cedarhurst, L.I. To raise money for his son's film, "Amongst Friends," which turned out to be one of the strongest at the festival, Mr. Weiss sent out letters to his customers.
Rob Weiss, who wears his cap backwards and speaks with an unmistakable New York accent, said: "My dad's friends are pretty much high rollers. The letter wasn't done in a schlock manner. It was classy. It said, like: 'Hey, if you're going to bet on ball games your entire life, if you're going to bet on horses, do something good with the money for a change. Bet it on the kid."
The bet on the kid seems to be paying off.
The movie is a gritty exploration of a group of wealthy high-school graduates, most of them Jewish or Italian, from the Five Towns of Long Island who drift into boredom, drugs, petty crime and tragedy. The director, who grew up on Long Island and attended the Parsons School of Design for about a year, said this was the world in which he grew up. Mr. Weiss said he owed a great deal to the works of Martin Scorsese, Francis Ford Coppola and Oliver Stone. He said he had seen Phillip Kaufman's "Wanderers," about 40 times. (Mr. Kaufman was honored at this year's Sundance Film Festival.)
Mr. Weiss now has an agent, a lawyer, a manager and a publicity agent. Studios are beckoning. But he's not going Hollywood, he insisted. "You've got to know where you came from," he said. "I live in South-Central L.A., by U.S.C., with my girlfriend. The neighborhood is predominantly African-American and Mexican. It's reality. That's what I want. That's what I need. Nothing's going to change."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Reuther, The Big 3 And Days Of Sit-Ins

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The gritty pictures from the 1930's, the union tunes and the reminiscences of United Automobile Workers old-timers bring back the organizing battles of what became America's biggest industrial union. But the hero of tonight's hourlong documentary, "Sit Down and Fight: Walter Reuther and the Rise of the Auto Worker's Union," remains a distant figure.
The sit-downs and sit-ins that Reuther improvised became powerful weapons in the workers' Depression-era assaults on their industry's big three, General Motors, Chrysler and Ford. As tonight's narrator says, "By doing nothing they achieved everything." 
 With a respectful narration that offers only sketchy historical context, the program is thin by the standards of "The American Experience" series. But it does capture exciting moments from the 1936 worker takeovers of General Motors suppliers. When the police attacked with tear gas and guns, they were driven back with door hinges fired from slingshots. You can see the boyish National Guardsmen being faced down by the determined strikers.
The strikebreakers used by Harry Bennett, the hard-boiled Ford security chief who became famous for setting goons on union leaders (beating up Walter Reuther among others), are seen skulking around like B-movie heavies. But by 1941, the automobile industry was organized and the workers' lot had improved dramatically.
"Sit Down and Fight" tells in passing of Reuther's fights against Communist elements within the union. His social vision, untypically broad for a union leader, comes through best in a recording of a talk he gave long after he was established as president of the United Automobile Workers. He asked his members, "What good is a dollar an hour more in wages if your neighborhood is burning down?"
When he died in an air crash in 1970, the movement he had done so much to build was already facing changes in the American economy that would prove even more formidable than the automobile barons of the 1930's. Sketchy though it is, the program leaves the impression that Reuther was so special a labor leader that he might have foreseen and confronted those, too.
 
'Back to Africa'
 PBS, tonight at 8
 (Channel 13 in New York)
Toward the end of his journey to Nigeria in an effort to reclaim his heritage, Ferdinand Dennis finds himself at a pageant put on by the Africa Reparation Movement. As the players re-enact the beating of a slave, the camera focuses on the wide-eyed reactions of a few children in the audience. It is a strong moment, the only one in this installment of "Travels."
The rest of the hour is given to a mildly interesting 625-mile trip from Kano south to Lagos. Mr. Dennis, a sociologist who was born in Jamaica and grew up in London, makes a pleasant companion as he bargains with taxi drivers, talks with an American student at Ahmadu Bello University, takes a boat down the Niger River, meets a politician and a king and reflects on the relevance of it all to himself. He is too honest to pretend that he is making dramatic connections with an ancestral past, but without such connections the trip does not have much punch. Still, he earns an Emmy nomination for never using the word "roots."

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Ads Down, Los Angeles Times Again Cuts Staff

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Under pressure to cut costs amid a severe advertising slump, The Los Angeles Times is carrying out a voluntary buyout program, its second in 18 months. The program will trim the staff by 9 percent, but also strip The Times, the nation's largest metropolitan daily newspaper, of some of its most respected reporters.
The paper, flagship of the Times Mirror Company, announced on Thursday that 668 of its 7,500 employees had accepted the buyout, which is considered generous. It provides as much as two years' salary and 18 months of medical benefits for employees and their dependents. 
 This buyout, the previous one, and other recent measures like the closing in November of the paper's San Diego edition, are expected to save The Times a total of about $16 million.
 
Blues in the Sun
 Every dollar will help. The Times is published in what is now one of the country's weakest economic regions. Recovery is slow in Southern California, and newspaper ad revenues remain depressed. Classified advertising has fallen 16.5 percent since 1991, national advertising 15.8 percent and retail advertising 3 percent, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulation.
The paper planned to eliminate 500 jobs through attrition and the severance program, which was offered to 5,200 employees. Editors and reporters familiar with the process, and who spoke on condition of anonymity, said 800 to 850 had signed up for it.
So popular was the buyout that many high-profile reporters subscribed, prompting top editors to hold private meetings with several reporters and editors and persuade some of them not to accept. Some other employees who signed up for the buyout did not qualify.
In typical buyout arrangements, newspapers seek to persuade older, higher-paid employees to retire early, which can result in large savings.
But The Times is losing some outstanding journalists. Of 88 news and editorial-page employees who took the buyout, some names stand out: Paul Conrad, its political cartoonist, who has won the Pulitzer Prize three times; Bella Stumbo, a highly regarded writer known for her profiles; Laurie Becklund, a top metropolitan reporter, and Robert Scheer, who writes special articles.
In addition, three of the five reporters who made up the investigative-reporting team took the buyout.
Laura Morgan, a spokeswoman for the newspaper, said that despite the loss of some talented reporters, The Times retained considerable talent, including one of the largest news staffs of any American newspaper.
Many writers and editors who are taking the buyout said in interviews that they had decided to do so because the offer was so generous that it would allow them to pursue other projects, like writing books and starting private ventures. Those interviewed said they would receive between $100,000 and $200,000.
But some said they were leaving The Times because they were dissatisfied with the working environment and the policies of the current management, mentioning David Laventhol, the publisher, and Shelby Coffey 3d, the editor.
 
Pay Discrimination Charged
 Ms. Stumbo said she was leaving because she learned when discussing the buyout with other reporters that male counterparts were making $10,000 to $30,000 more than she did.
"I make the same as some entry-level reporters, and I find it degrading, and I won't do it anymore," said Ms. Stumbo, 49, who has been at The Times for 21 years and is paid $67,000 a year. "I can do better slinging hash down at Denny's and certainly with more dignity."
Mr. Coffey declined to respond directly to Ms. Stumbo, but said that since he had become editor in 1989, The Times had often examined the salaries of women and members of ethnic minorities and made adjustments in individual cases.
Speaking more generally of the buyouts, he said, "It's not an easy process, but it certainly speaks to the quality of the company that we are doing it with buyouts and not layoffs."
He indicated that The Times would be pursuing various ways of replacing those who accepted buyouts -- including some new hiring and some transfers within departments. Efforts would be made to keep the hiring at a minimum, Mr. Coffey said.
Some reporters had mixed feelings about leaving. Tracy Wood, a member of the investigative reporting team, said she had been treated well by the paper. "It was a difficult decision for me to leave," she said, "but right now it's the perfect opportunity for me to do something different." She plans to write a book.
Times Mirror plans to take an accounting charge against earnings in the fourth quarter to pay for the employee-reduction program. It declined to say how much that would be, but indicated that it would release fourth-quarter earnings this week.
In addition to The Los Angeles Times, Times Mirror's big dailies are Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant. The Times and Newsday are its two largest operating companies and together account for $1.5 billion in revenue.
"Theoretically these cuts will have little impact on the news side," Edward J. Atorino of Salomon Brothers said, "but if at some point the consumer or reader notices that a certain columnist is gone or that the quality and sophistication of the reporting has declined, it could begin to affect circulation. If they are cutting fat no one will notice, but if they cut some muscle they certainly won't be as strong, and we all know that it takes time to rebuild strength."

HEADLINE: Fund-Raising Efforts Reveal Mayoral Candidates' Strategies

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The angry sound bites of the New York City mayoral election are months away, but for more than a year a quiet campaign has been busily afoot: the race for millions of dollars to make it all possible. The candidates' cash says much about them and their strategies for winning.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, though scarred by three tumultuous years in City Hall, is also flush with the powers of incumbency, and it shows in his most recent fund-raising reports, released last month. 
 Not only has the Democratic Mayor collected money from the municipal unions that long supported him but he has also drawn tens of thousands of dollars from Wall Street bankers who were not always his friends but now want the city's bond business, which he helps dispense.
City Council President Andrew J. Stein, who has said he intends to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary in September, is relying on a relative handful of large contributions from old friends. His parents have given him $200,000 -- one-sixth of all the money he raised in the last six months.
 
Countering an Advantage
 Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican former Federal prosecutor who lost to Mr. Dinkins by just two percentage points in 1989 and who plans a rematch this November, has tried to show he can counter the Democrats' huge advantage in registered voters with grass-roots fund raising that has produced thousands of smaller contributions. His contributors include scores of Korean-Americans still smarting at Mr. Dinkins's handling of a black-led boycott of two Korean-owned groceries in Brooklyn in 1990, though many are undoubtedly new immigrants and ineligible to vote.
"Everybody starts with their strengths, and then you move out," said Norman Adler, a Brooklyn-based political consultant and a veteran of many city campaigns. "My mother likes to say that in the winter there are three ingredients for success in the fall. The first is raising money. The second is raising money. And the third is raising money."
By the end, all the candidates will have scoured every corner, and Mr. Dinkins can count on hundreds of small contributions from his supporters in black churches and community organizations.
But for the moment, the contrasts among the candidates' coffers are striking. In the last six months, Mr. Giuliani raised just over $1 million from 2,100 contributors, for an average gift of about $485. Mr. Dinkins took in just over $1 million from 847 contributors, or an average of nearly $1,200 each. Mr. Stein raised just under $1.3 million from only 212 contributors, or an average of more than $6,000 per giver.
A fourth potential candidate, Herman Badillo, a Democrat and former Bronx borough president who hopes to lure enough Hispanic and Jewish voters to hold Mayor Dinkins to less than 40 percent of the primary vote and force a runoff, says he is only now beginning his fund raising. Mr. Badillo, a lawyer, has taken in $112,000 -- $100,000 of it as a loan from a friend, Raymond Greenwald, a Manhattan landlord.
Altogether, Mr. Stein has raised the most in absolute terms, $4.7 million, compared with about $3 million for Mr. Dinkins and $2.25 million for Mr. Giuliani, but he has also had the highest expenses, for fancy parties and high-priced consultants. The three major candidates all have roughly comparable amounts on hand -- around $2 million, including the matching public funds for which Mr. Giuliani and the Mayor are eligible because they have agreed to abide by voluntary limits on contributions and spending. In the end, the race will cost more than $20 million.
 
Leading in Polls
 Recent polls have shown Mr. Dinkins leading Mr. Stein by double-digit margins, and slightly ahead of Mr. Giuliani. That is an improvement from his standing at the height of the city's fiscal troubles 18 months ago, but the race remains volatile.
Television advertising will be the biggest expense, and Mr. Stein has made clear that he wants to be first on the air, probably by early March, with a series of Perot-like "infomercials" stressing his as yet unspecified prescriptions for fixing the city's ills.
The Mayor's aides believe that Mr. Stein will broadcast the commercials and then see how they alter his standing in the polls, and that if he does not like what he finds, will bow out.
"Wishful thinking in the extreme," said Mr. Stein, who twice defeated Mr. Dinkins in Manhattan borough president races a decade ago. "I am in the race and will be in the race and will beat Dinkins. I beat him twice, I know the guy and there's no doubt in my mind that I can do a better job."
But so far Mr. Stein's fund raising reflects his status as a not entirely welcome challenger in his own party. Mr. Dinkins has more or less of a lock on municipal unions and other Democratic regulars, and Mr. Stein is relying on rich businessmen and longtime friends of his family. His supporters are led by his father, Jerry Finkelstein, a former publisher of The New York Law Journal who is now a majority owner of a company that owns several community newspapers.
 
Limits on Contributions
 Alone among the candidates, Mr. Stein has declined to join the city's public campaign finance program, which limits individual contributions to $6,500 for the primary and general election combined, and a candidate's spending to $4 million in each election. Under state law, he may accept contributions of up to $50,000 each in the primary and general elections and has no limits on overall spending.
His rivals and many civic groups have criticized this, but he counters that the public opposes taxpayer-financed campaigns. "If your parents aren't your biggest supporters, who's going to be?" Mr. Stein asked. "Nobody's going to buy the election. The election's going to be decided on positive ideas."
But Mr. Stein acknowledged that "I haven't crystallized as a really strong alternative yet."
By contrast, Mr. Giuliani, a lawyer, has labored to show he is a credible alternative in a strongly Democratic city. He has held small house parties throughout the five boroughs, starting at $125 a person, and offered a choice of $500 or $1,000 tickets at his two major hotel banquets. One result of that is a campaign ledger littered with $50 and $75 contributions.
 
'Much More Difficult'
 "I think that may be a better indication than any poll of the depth of his potential," said David Garth, the media consultant who led both John V. Lindsay and Edward I. Koch to mayoral victories and is now helping Mr. Giuliani. "It's not everything, but it points in the direction of how many people across this city are willing to support him. For some of these people, it's a much more difficult contribution to make in terms of their income."
Perhaps most significantly, it maximizes Mr. Giuliani's potential to win matching public funds since the city matches contributions from city residents dollar per dollar only up to the first $1,000 of any contribution.
In fact, since Mr. Stein is not participating in the public system, Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Badillo will probably each be eligible to receive matching money at twice the usual rate -- $2 in public funds for every $1 they raise -- though still only to the limit of $2 million in matching funds for each.
"In terms of the Rudy-Stein competition for who's going to be the Mayor's opponent, it's a significant symbol," Hank Morris, a Democratic consultant not tied to any of the candidates, said of Mr. Giuliani's efforts.
For his part, the Mayor is not only depending on his solid base of support among black voters -- who account for as much as one-third of the primary electorate. He is also taking advantage of incumbency, raising tens of thousands of dollars from concerns that must do business with the city.
Like his predecessors, Mr. Dinkins has had particular success among investment banking houses competing to share in the city's lucrative bond underwriting business, for which new contracts are to be awarded this spring under bid proposals that are now circulating. Mr. Dinkins and Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman make the awards jointly.
Determining how much Mr. Dinkins has raised from Wall Street is difficult because the state financial disclosure forms his campaign has filed do not list the business addresses of givers, so it is not clear when individual partners at a single firm "bundle" gifts together. The city forms, to be required when Mr. Dinkins applies for matching funds this summer, are more detailed.
Mr. Dinkins's aides are happy to acknowledge his advantages.
"I think the Mayor is comfortable," said his press secretary, Leland T. Jones. "The basic fact of political life that both Stein and Giuliani and Badillo and anyone who runs against him is going to have to face is the comfort curve."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Ads Down, Los Angeles Times Again Cuts Staff

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Under pressure to cut costs amid a severe advertising slump, The Los Angeles Times is carrying out a voluntary buyout program, its second in 18 months. The program will trim the staff by 9 percent, but also strip The Times, the nation's largest metropolitan daily newspaper, of some of its most respected reporters.
The paper, flagship of the Times Mirror Company, announced on Thursday that 668 of its 7,500 employees had accepted the buyout, which is considered generous. It provides as much as two years' salary and 18 months of medical benefits for employees and their dependents. 
 This buyout, the previous one, and other recent measures like the closing in November of the paper's San Diego edition, are expected to save The Times a total of about $16 million.
 
Blues in the Sun
 Every dollar will help. The Times is published in what is now one of the country's weakest economic regions. Recovery is slow in Southern California, and newspaper ad revenues remain depressed. Classified advertising has fallen 16.5 percent since 1991, national advertising 15.8 percent and retail advertising 3 percent, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulation.
The paper planned to eliminate 500 jobs through attrition and the severance program, which was offered to 5,200 employees. Editors and reporters familiar with the process, and who spoke on condition of anonymity, said 800 to 850 had signed up for it.
So popular was the buyout that many high-profile reporters subscribed, prompting top editors to hold private meetings with several reporters and editors and persuade some of them not to accept. Some other employees who signed up for the buyout did not qualify.
In typical buyout arrangements, newspapers seek to persuade older, higher-paid employees to retire early, which can result in large savings.
But The Times is losing some outstanding journalists. Of 88 news and editorial-page employees who took the buyout, some names stand out: Paul Conrad, its political cartoonist, who has won the Pulitzer Prize three times; Bella Stumbo, a highly regarded writer known for her profiles; Laurie Becklund, a top metropolitan reporter, and Robert Scheer, who writes special articles.
In addition, three of the five reporters who made up the investigative-reporting team took the buyout.
Laura Morgan, a spokeswoman for the newspaper, said that despite the loss of some talented reporters, The Times retained considerable talent, including one of the largest news staffs of any American newspaper.
Many writers and editors who are taking the buyout said in interviews that they had decided to do so because the offer was so generous that it would allow them to pursue other projects, like writing books and starting private ventures. Those interviewed said they would receive between $100,000 and $200,000.
But some said they were leaving The Times because they were dissatisfied with the working environment and the policies of the current management, mentioning David Laventhol, the publisher, and Shelby Coffey 3d, the editor.
 
Pay Discrimination Charged
 Ms. Stumbo said she was leaving because she learned when discussing the buyout with other reporters that male counterparts were making $10,000 to $30,000 more than she did.
"I make the same as some entry-level reporters, and I find it degrading, and I won't do it anymore," said Ms. Stumbo, 49, who has been at The Times for 21 years and is paid $67,000 a year. "I can do better slinging hash down at Denny's and certainly with more dignity."
Mr. Coffey declined to respond directly to Ms. Stumbo, but said that since he had become editor in 1989, The Times had often examined the salaries of women and members of ethnic minorities and made adjustments in individual cases.
Speaking more generally of the buyouts, he said, "It's not an easy process, but it certainly speaks to the quality of the company that we are doing it with buyouts and not layoffs."
He indicated that The Times would be pursuing various ways of replacing those who accepted buyouts -- including some new hiring and some transfers within departments. Efforts would be made to keep the hiring at a minimum, Mr. Coffey said.
Some reporters had mixed feelings about leaving. Tracy Wood, a member of the investigative reporting team, said she had been treated well by the paper. "It was a difficult decision for me to leave," she said, "but right now it's the perfect opportunity for me to do something different." She plans to write a book.
Times Mirror plans to take an accounting charge against earnings in the fourth quarter to pay for the employee-reduction program. It declined to say how much that would be, but indicated that it would release fourth-quarter earnings this week.
In addition to The Los Angeles Times, Times Mirror's big dailies are Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant. The Times and Newsday are its two largest operating companies and together account for $1.5 billion in revenue.
"Theoretically these cuts will have little impact on the news side," Edward J. Atorino of Salomon Brothers said, "but if at some point the consumer or reader notices that a certain columnist is gone or that the quality and sophistication of the reporting has declined, it could begin to affect circulation. If they are cutting fat no one will notice, but if they cut some muscle they certainly won't be as strong, and we all know that it takes time to rebuild strength."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 1993, Tuesday / February 3, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on the Media Business page of Business Day yesterday with an article about staff reductions at The Los Angeles Times carried incorrect dates in some copies for quarterly operating income of the newspaper group of the parent company, Times Mirror. A corrected chart appears today on page D20.
An article on the Media Business page of Business Day on Monday about cost-cutting programs at The Los Angeles Times misstated the expected saving. The combined annual saving from an early-retirement program in 1991 and the closing of the San Diego edition last December is $24 million. The Times expects the saving from a recent voluntary employee buyout program to be at least another $24 million.
Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the source for the paper's advertising figures. They were provided by the newspaper, not by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
