HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ALLOWS STATES FLEXIBILITY ON MEDICAID FUNDS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton today ordered the Federal Government to make it easier for states to use Medicaid funds to introduce new health-care programs for the poor. His goal is to add much greater flexibility to a health-care system often constrained by Federal regulations.
The red tape Mr. Clinton seeks to loosen has hindered states seeking to experiment and innovate, making it difficult, for example, to take money earmarked for nursing-home care or for care in state mental institutions and spend it instead on home care for the same patients. Many patients prefer to be treated at home, and such care is usually less expensive.
 
Chance to Tailor Programs
 Mr. Clinton obtained approval for such a shift in spending when he was Governor of Arkansas. 
 The change in regulations ordered by President Clinton will not by itself automatically save any money for either the states or the Federal Government, except by reducing paperwork. But White House officials and governors said the increased flexibility would allow them to better cover the growing number of Medicaid applicants by tailoring programs to meet a state's particular needs.
For instance, a growing number of states have gained or sought waivers allowing them to enlist Medicaid recipients in health maintenance organizations, so they will go there for primary care instead of costly emergency rooms, and be seen by the same doctor or group of doctors to provide continuity. Such an experimental program begun in southwest Brooklyn recently is scheduled to be extended throughout New York City within five years.
 
First in Series of Moves
 Medicaid waivers have also been granted to states that have wanted to experiment with novel ways of paying hospitals, doctors and nursing homes. Not every application has been approved: for instance, Oregon's proposal to expand health care for the poor through a system of rationing was rejected. Oregon is in the process of renewing its application for a modified system.
Mr. Clinton made the announcement at a meeting of the nation's governors, who are in Washington for their annual conference and had planned to seek such an easing of controls on states. The initiative is the first of a series that the President plans this week to try to refocus attention away from contentious issues, like the military's ban of homosexuals, that have dominated his Administration's opening days. He is seeking to turn attention instead to the core issues on which he ran for office: affordable health care, changes in the welfare system and economic recovery.
In a speech on Tuesday to the conference of the National Governors' Association, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to sketch out his ideas on welfare reform. During the campaign he said he would press for programs to increase education, training and child care for welfare recipients, in return for stricter requirements for them to obtain work in a set amount of time.
In a speech tonight, Mr. Clinton told a fund-raising dinner of the Democratic Governors Association that he did not think a few rough moments had tarnished "a pretty good start" in office. "If you just wanted me to do things that are easy you should have elected somebody else President," he said.
The Medicaid program, through which the Federal Government and states pay for health care for 30 million low-income Americans, welfare recipients and blind or disabled people, Medicaid is the fourth-largest item in the Federal budget, but the money is sent to states under a set of tightly defined rules established by Congress and monitored by the Department of Health and Human Services.
The Federal share of Medicaid last year was $67.8 billion, while states spent more than $50 billion.
 
'Byzantine' Paperwork
 States frequently apply for exemptions from the rules to introduce innovations they expect to save money or allow them to adapt to new health-care demands, while still covering all Medicaid applicants. But obtaining such exemptions has required bureaucratic paperwork that Mr. Clinton called "Byzantine and counterproductive." As a result, the programs covered by waivers account for only a small portion of the total spent on Medicaid.
Mr. Clinton told the governors in their two hours of talks today that he was ordering the Health and Human Services Department to streamline the process in two ways immediately.
To begin with, the department and its health-care financing agency, will no longer be allowed to make numerous requests for information and clarifications on a state's waiver application. From now on, Mr. Clinton said, the department and its regional centers "will have only one opportunity to ask for additional information and clarifications on a state's waiver requests."
The President also said he was ordering the Health Care Financing Administration to develop a list of state programs that have already been approved, so other states seeking to start similar programs could adopt them immediately without having to go through the paperwork themselves.
In addition, the President said he was ordering the agency to consult with the National Governors' Association to conduct a "rapid review of the entire waiver process," which will come up with more streamlining methods within 60 days.
"If I could put it in simple terms," said Mr. Clinton, summing up his announcement today, "it amounts to this. The Federal Government requires the states to provide a certain number of health services in a certain way to people who are poor enough to qualify for Medicaid. The states very often believe that they can provide more services at lower costs if we don't impose our rules and regulations upon them.
"For years and years and years, governors have been screaming for relief from a cumbersome process by which the Federal Government has micromanaged the health-care system affecting poor Americans," added Mr. Clinton, who labored under these restrictions in his five terms as Governor of Arkansas. "We are going to try to give them that relief."
 
Negotiations on Taxes
 He also said his Administration would reopen negotiations with the governors over taxes that some states charge doctors and hospitals. Many states use the taxes to gain Federal matching money for Medicaid, then return the taxes back to doctors and hospitals by increasing the fees they receive, while using the Federal matching money to expand their Medicaid programs. In 1991 Congress restricted such tax maneuvers, a restriction many states opposed.
Assessing the proposed changes on waivers, Trish Riley, director of the National Academy for State Health Policy, a nonprofit research unit for state health issues, said: "It is an important step. It will save untold administrative dollars, because anyone who has had the unpleasant experience of writing a waiver application knows they are long, tedious and time-consuming."
Welcoming Mr. Clinton's moves today, Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas said: "At last, the states are going to be given an opportunity to deliver health care." That sentiment was shared by the governors at the White House session, as well as important members of Congress.

HEADLINE: ISRAEL TO RETURN 100 PALESTINIANS IT HAD DEPORTED

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Yielding to international pressure and convinced that its relations with the Clinton Administration are at stake, Israel agreed Monday night to send home immediately about 100 of the Palestinians it had deported to Lebanon and to cut the exile period for the remaining 300 in half, to a year.
In return, the Israelis said, they had assurances from the United States that it would block United Nations sanctions, which have been threatened because Israel defied a Security Council resolution demanding that all the deportees be brought back to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. 
 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin announced that the Americans had also promised to try to breathe new life into the stalled Middle East peace talks. The future of the negotiations has been uncertain since the Dec. 17 expulsions of 415 Palestinians accused of being militant Islamic fundamentalists and threats to Israeli security.
 
'Not Salami Tactics'
 "These are not salami tactics -- it's a package deal," Mr. Rabin said at a late-night news conference. Israel also agreed to let helicopters deliver relief shipments to the deportees who remain, he said.
It was far from clear early today, however, if the banished Palestinians would accept an arrangement that brings some of them back but leaves most still sitting in a makeshift tent camp on frozen ground between Israeli and Lebanese Army checkpoints. Initial signs were that their answer would be no, even though 19 of them have come home in the last few weeks because they fell ill or were found to have been deported by mistake.
 
A Hamas Leader Rejects Offer
 After hearing unofficial reports of the compromise as it was being submitted to the Rabin Cabinet but before it was approved unanimously, the group's spokesman, Abdul Aziz al-Rantisi, a Gazan leader of the Hamas Islamic movement, rejected the idea of allowing only some of the deportees to return home.
Although she was in no position to speak for the deportees, Hanan Ashrawi, spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation to the peace talks, also insisted that the Security Council require that Resolution 799, calling for the exiles' return, be carried out in full.
"If this is a deal with the United States, it is obviously in violation of its own vote at the United Nations," she said.
But Mr. Rabin said that his bargain was with the Americans and that its enforcement "does not depend on whether the Hamas deportees respond to it."
If the 100 or so men being offered a chance to go home do not accept the offer, "then that's their problem," a senior official said.
 
Details Remain Unsettled
 Officials said early today that the mechanics of selecting these deportees, not to mention how they will physically be brought back, still had to be worked out. Just about all would probably wind up in detention camps or prisons, they said.
The Palestinians eligible to be brought back right away are those who were expelled for up to 18 months, a group comprising roughly 100 men. The other 300 or so were deported for two years. They will now have that period sliced to a year, although some reports said they could be gradually taken back even sooner.
According to officials, all the cases are to be studied as part of a review of security files being conducted by special military committees established last week under conditions outlined by the Israeli High Court of Justice. Mr. Rabin said that the United States had promised to try to find a third country to receive the remaining Palestinians, since Lebanon has refused to accept them, but the likelihood of quick success on this score seemed small.
For Mr. Rabin, there were two dominant considerations for backing down on the expulsion of hundreds of Hamas leaders and sympathizers accused of responsibility for anti-Israeli violence.
One was the threat of United Nations sanctions, which Mr. Rabin warned would "wipe out the chances for peace in the Middle East." The other was his desire to start off on the right foot with the new American Administration. The Administration advised him that while it opposed sanctions, it also expected Israeli help in avoiding the point where it would feel compelled to use its Security Council veto.
"We should have prepared ourselves for the struggle in the international arena with the reality of a new Administration in the United States," Mr. Rabin acknowledged.
In addition, support for a hard line had begun to wane within his own Cabinet as it became increasingly clear that the crisis was not about to disappear and that Israel's diplomatic standing would suffer. An anonymous poll of 18 Cabinet ministers conducted recently by Israel Television showed that a majority supported an early return of the deportees.
 
Talks With U.S. Officials
 Finally, after a series of weekend discussions with American officials, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Mr. Rabin agreed to the "package deal."
"I don't pretend to present this as an easy decision," he said.
Moshe Katsav, parliamentary leader of the opposition Likud Party, denounced the arrangement as "a surrender to terrorist organizations," but Government officials rejected that characterization.
"Retreat? Certainly not," said Gad Ben-Ari, the Prime Minister's spokesman. "Compromise? Yes."
Environment Minister Yossi Sarid said after the Cabinet vote Monday night that "whoever thought the whole issue could end without a compromise, without a contribution by Israel, was being either naive or disingenuous."
"We are getting full backing from the United States," he said. "There is no more fear that sanctions will be imposed."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Christopher Backs Move
 UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the Israeli formula to resolve the status of the Palestinian deportees was a "breakthrough" consistent with a Security Council resolution demanding their immediate return to Israel.
As a result, Mr. Christopher said, there would be no need for Security Council sanctions against Israel.
"As a consequence of the steps that Israel will take, we believe that further action by the Security Council is unnecessary and could even undercut the process which is under way," he said.
The United States consulted with allies and other Council members, and will continue to, he said, but repeated the message that sanctions against Israel were not warranted.
In Brussels tonight, Niels Helvig Petersen, the Danish Foreign Minister and chairman of the European Council, called Israel's actions "very helpful in improving relations." But he did not say whether negotiations would open on extending the European Community's economic cooperation agreement with Israel.
Shimon Peres, the Israeli Foreign Minister, had appeared at the monthly meeting of the community's foreign ministers to discuss updating Israel's 1975 economic agreement. The foreign ministers had implied that the economic agreement would not be discussed until Israel changed its policy. To Israel, the agreement means about $20 million a year in development loans and access to the lucrative European produce market.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
President's Early Troubles Rooted in Party's Old Strains

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton was a candidate, his electoral promise was that he could straddle the gulf between populism and elitism, between the concerns of the middle classes that provide the Democratic Party's electoral muscle and those of the more liberal academic theorists who provide its ideology.
But so far, Mr. Clinton has appeared to embody that struggle rather than resolve it, sending signals late in his transition and in his first two weeks in office that blended the suburban populist concerns of his campaign with the special interests of the party elite.
 
Seeking a New Focus
 With the President's political advisers concerned over the perception thus wrought, the Administration is trying aggressively this week to refocus its image as a Government of broad middle-class interests. 
 Today, in the first of a week's worth of gestures intended to showcase such an image, Mr. Clinton ordered Federal bureaucrats to make it easier for states to administer their health-care programs. Tuesday, he plans to deliver a speech to the National Governors' Association reprising the promises of welfare changes that helped win him support among working-class Democrats who had voted Republican in recent Presidential races.
The shift in attention is crucial to the Administration after a week dominated by the politically unwelcome fight over whether homosexuals should be allowed to serve in the armed forces.
"It was unfortunate that gays in the military was the President's first major issue," said one White House official. "The danger is that people around the country are saying to themselves: 'Oh, My God. So this is why this guy sought office.' It was an accident. It wasn't like Clinton said 'O.K., it's Day 1 and I want to put down my marker on this Presidency, and I want that marker to be gays in the military.' "
And so Mr. Clinton will work to remind middle-class voters that he is one with them, stressing his commitment to a welfare overhaul, even though he has nothing much to say on the subject that he did not say a thousand times last year.
"This is not a substance speech," said the White House aide, speaking on a condition of anonymity. "This is not the legislative package. This is the President saying: 'This is important to me. These are my goals. Work with me.' "
The sudden imperative for Mr. Clinton to remind middle-class voters that he shares their concerns grows directly out of a tension that has long strained his party.
Nowhere is this tension more perfectly embodied than in Mr. Clinton. He is the son of a working-class family and a low-rent state, a man whose tastes are as naturally middle-brow as Harry Truman's. A founding member of the Democratic Leadership Council, set up to counter what some saw as the party's overly liberal tilt,he has succeeded in the past as a political middle-of-the-roader.
 
Which Clinton Ran?
 But Mr. Clinton is also a member in excellent standing of the intellectual elite, at least as at home in the academy as he is in a bowling alley. He is the product of Georgetown, Oxford and Yale, a lawyer and a career politician and a longstanding participant in the endlessly running liberal policy debate the political writer Sidney Blumenthal calls "the Conversation."
It was the middle-class Mr. Clinton who ran for President, and his ability to define himself as the quintessential candidate of suburban populism won the election. "I am the one person in this race who really comes from the great American middle class and understands the American dream," Mr. Clinton said.
He would use the White House, he said, to build "a plan for America's renewal," to cut middle-class taxes, to "end welfare as we know it," to make the streets safer and the schools better, to provide "basic health care to all Americans." He would soak the rich and put the poor to work. He would protect Social Security and Medicare recipients from Washington budget cutters. He would do away with the sleazy, bloated "business as usual" in Washington.
Now, some of Mr. Clinton's supporters are wondering what happened to that candidate.
 
Both Wrong and Stupid?
 "Here he is 10 days into his Administration, and all the signals he is sending are to the opposite of what he conveyed in the campaign," said Ben J. Wattenberg, a political analyst and neo-conservative Democrat who endorsed Mr. Clinton but now says he is seriously reconsidering. "It's worse than wrong; it's stupid."
Over the course of his transition and first days in office, Mr. Clinton moved in a number of ways that went sharply against the middle-class concerns and values he championed as a candidate, but were perfectly attuned to the party elite.
He filled 13 of his 18 Cabinet seats with well-heeled lawyers, giving the important business seats of Commerce and Trade Representative to, respectively, the lawyer-lobbyists Ronald H. Brown and Mickey Kantor, men who had made their riches doing the bidding of corporate clients.
He abandoned the campaign pretense that his wife was more cookie baker than policy maker, and Hillary Rodham Clinton moved into the West Wing as the President's most important adviser.
 
Whither the Tax Cut?
 He seemed to abandon as well the old campaign promise of a middle-class tax cut, as Administration officials floated the possibilities of consumption taxes, energy taxes and even cuts in Social Security benefits.
Ahead of the economic concerns on which he had promised to "focus like a laser," he allowed his Adminisration to focus first on the divisive issue of homosexuals in the military.
"He ran as a populist, and now he has surrounded himself with the intellectual elite of his party, and is devoting himself to their concerns." said one Democratic consultant. "I don't think anyone ever expected that gays in the military -- which is a classic example of an issue of great concern to the intellectuals but not what the middle class wants to focus on at all -- would be the primary focus of the first week of a Clinton Administration. There never was a sign on the wall in Little Rock, Ark., that said, 'It's the gays in the military, stupid.' "
 
An Act of Brilliance?
 Robert Borosage, a former adviser to the Rev. Jesse Jackson and a policy maven at the liberal Campaign for New Priorities, sees Mr. Clinton's dichotomy as an act of political brilliance, in which the agenda of the left-leaning intellectual elite of the party was protected, and to some degree hidden, by Mr. Clinton's skill at keeping the attention focused on himself as a populist on economic issues.
"What Clinton did was combine a populist economic agenda on jobs, re-investment and health care with a remarkably liberal agenda on social concerns, such as choice, feminism and gays and lesbians" he said.
"What has happened now is that the populist economic agenda has gotten submerged, which is bad. It's not the emphasis on gay and lesbian issues lately that has hurt Clinton; it's the lack of attention at the same time to the economic agenda."

HEADLINE: Governors Praise Ex-Colleague in the White House

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton spent 12 years building good will with the nation's governors, and today they went to work to pay him back.
Clearly pleased to have one of their own back in the White House, the governors were not as quick as many members of Congress or the news media to write off his first days in office. They were encouraged, both Democrats and Republicans said, by Mr. Clinton's announcement today that the Administration will give them greater leeway on health care. 
 "It was simply unbelievable to have the opportunity to exchange ideas with someone who understood what we were talking about," Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas said after leaving the White House with members of the National Governors' Association, which Mr. Clinton led in 1987.
But the Texas Democrat said that, sadly, the President's honeymoon was already over. "I don't think anyone allowed him what is customarily the honeymoon period," she said. "They didn't give Clinton that. And it is a gift. And I think he's very upbeat, and he has, fortunately for the country, a long-term view of the things he needs to do. He's pretty focused on that."
 
Advice on News Media
 Gov. Ben Nelson of Nebraska, a Democrat, was not about to characterize Mr. Clinton's first days in office as stumbling. His harshest appraisal was that the Administration may be off to "a very public start."
Mr. Nelson went on to say: "If you look at what we're talking about in deficit reduction and health care, there isn't stumbling. It's appropriate that everything's on the table right now rather than having him to come to us with 'Here's my 21-point plan.' He's continuing his style of doing what he does best and in the manner he does best."
Mr. Nelson also offered unsolicited advice for reporters: "My belief is that if the media and everybody else would give him a break on some of this, and adapt to his style rather than try to put him into a pigeonhole or some other category, things would be O.K."
Perhaps because they had worked closely with Mr. Clinton, or perhaps because they wanted the new President to look kindly upon their states, many Republican governors also praised him.
"I don't fault him," said Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts. "I think it may take away some momentum when the press writes about what they've been writing about instead of the economic plan. But I can tell you he focused with laserlike intensity on the economy in the three-hour session this morning. He's thinking about the right things." (Last summer, Mr. Weld did not offer such kind words; he traveled to Little Rock, Ark., on behalf of the Bush campaign to attack Mr. Clinton's record as Governor.)
Even Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, an outspoken Republican, sounded encouraged after meeting with Mr. Clinton. "This President came in as a governor having been on the front line with the practical experience," he said, "and that may increase sensitivity to the specifics of what we talked about."
Mr. Clinton made it plain to the governors today that he expected to continue to turn to them for support. "The day before my inauguration, on one of the last days people called me Governor, I had lunch with many of the Governors here and many others with whom I had served over the past 14 years," he said. "I pledged to them a partnership between the country's governors and this Administration, rooted in our common experience on the front lines of people's lives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The nation's governors meeting yesterday with President Clinton in the East Room of the White House. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dallas Journal;
Big Victory In Football Encourages Wider Hope

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The venerable, fedora-topped Tom Landry was revered as the coach of America's Team, as the Dallas Cowboys were called in the 1970's. But what about Jimmy Johnson, his helmet-haired, ice-water-in-the-veins successor?
The Cowboys are back, and it was Mr. Johnson who masterminded a remarkable turnaround in the fortunes of a team that had not made it to the Super Bowl since 1979. As fans here wildly celebrated the team's 52-17 trouncing of the Buffalo Bills in Pasadena on Sunday, they readily proclaimed a new era of Cowboy dominance, and some even saw the victory as a harbinger of a much-needed economic resurgence for their city. 
 But many seemed much less sure about elevating Mr. Johnson to the mythic stature accorded Mr. Landry.
"I don't know," said Donna Eddins, a nurse who had driven 90 miles from the North Texas town of Honey Grove this morning to be among the first to buy an official "Cowboys -- Super Bowl Champions" shirt at the team's official licensed-products store here.
"You are talking about two very different personalities," Ms. Eddins said. "I mean, Landry was kind of a national hero. Somehow, I just can't imagine any of his players doing a Gatorade dunk on Tom Landry."
Mr. Johnson, his stern demeanor notwithstanding, was drenched Sunday night, perhaps the only time all season that a strand of his hair could be seen out of place.
But even if sports-obsessed Dallasites have not yet come to revere Mr. Johnson, they seem immensely grateful for his success. With a baseball team that has never made it to the playoffs, and a basketball team that is on course this season to set an N.B.A. record for losses, this city found the Cowboys' world championship particularly welcome.
And it sure seems to have salved the anger at Mr. Landry's unceremonious dismissal by the Cowboys' new owner four years ago.
Even though many felt the time had arrived for Mr. Landry to be eased out gracefully, there was near-mutiny when he had to learn from a radio report that he was out of a job and when the new owner, an Arkansas natural-gas baron named Jerry Jones, hired Mr. Johnson, his fellow lineman on the 1964 University of Arkansas squad, as coach. Tens of thousands turned out in the streets for a thank-you procession that basically martyrized Mr. Landry, and the new leadership was both vilified and ridiculed when the team finished 1-15 in the 1989 season.
Mr. Jones was even jeered by Texans as "the Hillbilly of Valley Ranch," a reference to his Arkansas roots and the name of the Cowboys' training camp.
But as people here came to find out, some Arkansans know a thing or two about how to win. "These guys may come from Arkansas, but they didn't come into town on a wagon load of hay," said Tom Blackstone, a fan from Richardson, a Dallas suburb.
"Nobody liked the way they did it," Mr. Blackstone said of the dismissal of Mr. Landry. "But the other side of the coin is, they're winning again."
Beyond the sweet satisfaction of winning a 60-minute football game, some people in Dallas think their team's triumph after a decade of frustration could mirror a rebound for Dallas after a decade of rising crime and unemployment.
"We both went into the same tank and stayed there for the same period of time, said Mayor Steve Bartlett. "Now America's team rebounded, and in many ways Dallas is on the road to becoming America's city again." He cited slight job growth in recent months and the fact that 40 big companies had relocated or expanded operations here last year.
Whether a sports team can engender profound social or economic shifts remains to be seen, of course. But it is clear that the Cowboys have proved a short-term boon to some segments of the local economy.
Still, not everybody here, it should be noted, is a Cowboys' fan. Tammy DeMarco moved to Dallas from Niagara Falls, N.Y., six years ago only because her employer, the Occidental Chemical Corporation, moved some of its offices here.
"I'm still a Bills fan and proud of it," said Ms. DeMarco, a customer service representative. "I'm not going to just jump on some bandwagon because I live here now.
"I don't think you can find any fan truer than a Bills fan. If you haven't sat through a game in sleet, snow and freezing rain, you're not a fan."

HEADLINE: Missouri Senator Won't Seek 4th Term

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Senator John C. Danforth, an influential Republican moderate from Missouri, announced today that he would retire rather than seek a fourth term in 1994.
The 56-year-old Mr. Danforth, an Episcopal priest and a lawyer, said in an interview that he was looking into the possibility of working for the church and might also become associated with a law firm. 
 He said he would retire because he did not "want to end my days in government, and I didn't want the claim of government, the claim of politics, to be total."
Instead of running again, he said, he would "rather go back and start the next phase of my life."
He said his departure was not out of frustration with the Senate or his party. Speaking of his 24 years in public office, which began as state attorney general in 1969, he said, "It's been more interesting, more exciting, more challenging than anything I would have expected."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, expressed regret when he heard of Mr. Danforth's plans to retire, saying in a statement, "Whether it's taking on the tough issue, making the tough votes, or moving us with his rare eloquence, Senator Danforth has earned the lasting respect of Republicans and Democrats."
 
One Moderate Voice
 Mr. Dole may miss Mr. Danforth's voice in the Republican conference, where there is increasing pressure from exponents of harder-edged conservatism. Mr. Danforth tangled with that side of his party repeatedly in 1991, when he led Republican efforts to agree on a civil rights bill that wouldundo several Supreme Court decisions making it harder to sue in job discrimination cases. His efforts, which Mr. Dole did not join but sometimes encouraged, forced President Bush's Administration to retreat and deal with Democrats led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
Just a few days before the civil rights struggle, Mr. Danforth had prevailed in one of the toughest fights of his career as the Senate narrowly voted to confirm Clarence Thomas as a Supreme Court Justice. Justice Thomas was a protege and former aide of Mr. Danforth's in both the Senate and the Missouri attorney general's office.
He also led efforts last fall to override Mr. Bush's veto of legislation to reimpose some regulation on the cable television industry -- the only one of Mr. Bush's 35 vetoes to be overridden.
 
Candidate Emerges
 Representative Alan Wheat, a Democrat from Kansas City, put out the word that he was considering running for the seat. Mr. Wheat, a black who represents a district with a white majority, may be only the first of many Democratic hopefuls.
Of the 34 Senate seats up for election in 1994, Democrats are expected to be on the defensive, because they now hold 22 of them. But Mr. Danforth's retirement will give them a better chance of picking up the Missouri seat than they would have had if he had run again. There are now 57 Democrats and 43 Republicans in the Senate.
Mr. Danforth, an heir to the Ralston-Purina fortune, announced his retirement at a news conference at the airport in St. Louis, saying he and his wife were "overjoyed by the thought of starting a new phase of our lives with our family and friends" in St. Louis.
 
Work for Church
 In the telephone interview later, he said, "I want to make a better contribution to the church than I have to date." While he said he did not believe the parish ministry was his role, he said, "I have talked to my bishop about some kind of contribution to the church beyond what I've done."
But he also stressed, both in St. Louis and again in the interview, that he looked forward to a final two years in the Senate, where the Finance Committee will deal with the economy and health care. He has been an increasingly insistent advocate of shifting the basis of the tax system from taxing income to broad-based taxes on consumption, arguing that this change was essential to investment.
On the Commerce Committee, where he is the senior Republican, he said he would push efforts to bolster the nation's airplane manufacturers and airlines.

HEADLINE: 1,000 SAID TO DIE IN MUTINY IN ZAIRE

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Tuesday, Feb. 2

 BODY:
A spokesman for the Prime Minister said today that at least 1,000 people had been killed in several days of fighting between rebellious soldiers and forces loyal to Zaire's authoritarian President.
Forces supporting President Mobutu Sese Seko sealed off the center of the capital on Monday as both foreigners and Zairians packed riverboats and roads to flee the widening battles. 
 "The estimates that we have allow us to confirm there were at least 1,000 dead, mostly soldiers," said Jean-Joseph Mukendi, a spokesman for Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi.
There was no way to verify the toll. But Western diplomats said Monday that hundreds of people had died over the last few days as Mr. Mobutu's presidential guard put down a mutiny.
 
The Lineup of Power
 In Brussels, Foreign Minister Willy Claes said Monday that at least 300 people were believed to have been killed since Mr. Mobutu sent in special forces to suppress army riots.
Mr. Tshisekedi is the chief rival to President Mobutu, who has ruled the country for more than 27 years, and the violence has become a power struggle between the two men.
Mr. Mobutu has accused Mr. Tshisekedi of causing the violence by urging soldiers to refuse to accept newly printed 5-million-zaire bank notes as pay. A statement read on state television Monday night said that anyone refusing to accept the new zaire notes would be guilty of treason, and that 10-million-zaire notes (worth about $4) would soon be introduced.
Zaire's economy has collapsed, but Mr. Mobutu has refused to cede control of the treasury to the transitional Government led by Mr. Tshisekedi. Mr. Mobutu named the Government under pressure from the United States, France and other aid donors.
France and Belgium sent troops over the weekend to Brazzaville, Congo, across the Congo River from Kinshasa, to evacuate foreigners; the French Ambassador to Zaire and six other foreigners were shot dead last week.
Presidential guards blocked off the Gombe district, where hundreds of foreigners have sought refuge, on Monday, when about 500 Belgian, French and Italian refugees left for Brazzaville, escorted by presidential guards. More than 1,000 foreigners had been evacuated earlier.
The unrest is the worst since Belgium and France sent soldiers in September 1991 after riots by unpaid troops triggered the evacuation of 20,000 foreigners.
There were reports Monday that the riots had spread to eastern Zaire. North of Goma, on the border with Rwanda, about 600 refugees fled to Uganda over the weekend, a spokesman for the the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said. The agency's representative in Uganda said Zairian troops were harassing the refugees and stealing their belongings.

HEADLINE: Cambridge Edges Out Chicago

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In the realm of economics, the arrival of President Clinton means that the liberals from Cambridge have been anointed and the conservatives from Chicago have been banished.
In making several sages with M.I.T. doctorates the new suzerains of economic affairs, the Clinton Administration has endorsed the Cambridge school's prevailing view that government has a powerful role to play in building a stronger economy. 
 That ends the reign of the free-market Chicago school -- under the influence of the University of Chicago -- which infused the Reagan and Bush Administrations with the notion that whenever government sticks its nose into economic affairs it is bound to mess them up.
"The Clinton Government promises to do exactly the kind of economics that M.I.T. is all about," said Rudiger Dornbusch, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "That means a lot of belief in the market, but determined government intervention when there is a need for it."
For example, with the wages of more and more full-time workers falling below the poverty line, the Cambridge approach would be for the Government to help low-wage workers get training for high-wage jobs.
So many economists with M.I.T. doctorates have been funneled into the new Administration that the economics department there might well replace its placement office with a direct pipeline to Washington.
Consider this. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and the chairman-designee of the Council of Economic Advisers, received a doctorate in economics from M.I.T. in 1974. Alan Blinder, chosen for a second council seat, earned his M.I.T. doctorate in 1971 before becoming a professor at Princeton. Creating a possible hat trick for M.I.T., Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Stanford professor with a 1966 M.I.T. doctorate, is being considered for the council's third seat.
Lawrence F. Katz, a Harvard professor selected to be the Labor Department's chief economist, received his M.I.T. doctorate in 1985, while David M. Cutler, a Harvard professor expected to work for the National Economic Council, received an M.I.T. doctorate in 1991. And that's not to mention Secretary of Defense Les Aspin, who received an economics doctorate from M.I.T. in 1965.
"We feel very good about all this," said Peter Temin, the chairman of M.I.T's economics department. While faculty members are not breaking out champagne, they hope M.I.T.'s success will help attract top-notch students the way an N.C.A.A. basketball championship helps a college woo high school all-stars.
Describing the M.I.T. economics philosophy, Mr. Temin said, "We believe the market is good for most things, but not for everything, as opposed to a more Chicago view where they think the market is good for everything."
The Chicago school gets its name from the University of Chicago, whose faculty included several seminal free-market theorists, including Milton Friedman and George Stigler.
"I worry about their activism," William A. Niskanen, a University of Chicago Ph.D., said of the arrivistes from M.I.T. He is chairman of the Cato Institute, a free-market research group in Washington, and was a member of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Contrasting Views
 How will the Cambridge approach translate into policy? While many Chicago adherents support vouchers that would subsidize students to go to public or private school, the Cambridge approach would focus on education as a government function that needs to be improved. Cambridge folks are far more likely than their Cook County colleagues to favor increased deficit spending to pull the nation out of recession.
Chicago schoolers back lower income taxes and capital gains taxes, saying such taxes discourage work and investment. The M.I.T.-Cambridge people are not reflexively negative toward taxes. They are more open to raising taxes on the rich as a matter of equity, but many support an investment tax credit to encourage investing.
It should come as no surprise that these Cambridge views sound similar to Bill Clinton's campaign proposals: many of these M.I.T. people advised him during the campaign.
 
Partisan Differences
 "As President Clinton looks around for eminent people he would feel comfortable with, it's not surprising that he would go to M.I.T." said Gary S. Becker, a University of Chicago professor who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in economics last year. "There has always been more of an association with the Democratic Party than the Republican Party in Cambridge."
As M.I.T. people see it, their department is to economics what Mr. Clinton's law school alma mater, Yale, is to law -- each has a heavy focus on public policy. One professor said M.I.T.'s brand of economics was "technobabble with a heart."
To be sure, M.I.T.'s professors and students toss around highfalutin terms and complex econometric equations as effortlessly as anyone. The M.I.T. faculty boasts three Nobel laureates -- Paul Samuelson, Robert M. Solow and Franco Modigliani.
From the early 1960's through 1985 or so, these three attracted -- and churned out -- the best economics students in the nation, most economists agree. But with the Republicans in power for the last 12 years, M.I.T. produced an excess supply of Democratic economists yearning for their day in the Washington sun.
Then came Bill Clinton. Explaining why Mr. Clinton has plucked so much fruit off M.I.T.'s tree, Professor Samuelson said, "We're seeing the lagged harvest of M.I.T.'s being a crack world economics department."
Mr. Temin, the department head, insists that M.I.T.'s success in Washington shows that it still has the nation's best economics department. His colleagues across town at Harvard disagree, noting that two young stars with Harvard doctorates have received high-level economics posts.
 
The Harvard Contingent
 Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard professor, has been nominated Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, while Alicia Munnell, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston, has been chosen to be the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Economic Policy. Harvard boosters note that despite all the M.I.T. doctorates, three of the new economics officials teach at Harvard.
But M.I.T. also claims Mr. Summers because he received his bachelor's degree from there, taught there for four years, and took graduate courses there while studying for his Harvard doctorate. Not only that, Professor Samuelson is his uncle.
"You'd have to cut up Larry Summers two ways," Professor Samuelson said. "His gizzard is M.I.T. and his liver is Harvard."
Mr. Katz, a Harvard professor with an M.I.T. doctorate, tries to play Solomon in assessing the two economics departments, saying, "Right now, M.I.T. and Harvard would be viewed as fairly even."
The new appointees deny that having the same pedigree means they are an insular, like-thinking clique. "Believe me, we're not a monolithic group," Mr. Katz said.
Still, Mr. Katz once studied with Ms. Tyson; Mr. Summers was an adviser to Mr. Cutler, and many of them wrote economics papers together. What is more, they all studied at the feet of Mr. Solow.
Proof that not everyone with an M.I.T. degree thinks alike is another M.I.T. product in Washington: David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Mullins, who received an M.I.T. doctorate in economics and finance in 1974, is a well-known conservative and could use his position to dampen the liberal activism of Mr. Clinton's Cambridge crew.
Conservatives are criticizing Mr. Clinton's economic choices, contending they do not have enough faith in free markets and will build a mountain of regulations.
 
Praise With Reservations
 Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate and professor emeritus at the University of Chicago, said he was uneasy about the invasion from Cambridge, even though he said several of the nominees were technically superb as economists. "It's a great mistake obviously to have an interventionist government," he said.
His Chicago colleague, Mr. Becker, was more optimistic, suggesting that the new crowd might not do things so differently from the Chicagoans because they would be smart enough to know what does and does not make good economic sense. Mr. Becker and other economists note that the 1990's brand of Cambridge economics is less liberal than the 1960's variety.
Mr. Blinder, the choice for the Council of Economic Advisers, sought to reassure conservatives, saying, "I think there are precious few in the group that can be called lefties, but certainly we're more liberal than the people leaving Washington."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chaus Hires Ex-President Of Esprit

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Richard Baker, who left the post of president of Esprit de Corp Womenswear in November, yesterday was named president of Bernard Chaus Inc., the women's clothing manufacturer based in New York.
Mr. Baker, 46, will report to Josephine Chaus, who became chairman and chief executive following the death of her husband, Bernard Chaus, the company's founder, in July 1991. She will now relinquish the post of president, which she held before her husband's death. 
 After joining Esprit de Corp in 1986, Mr. Baker became president of its Womenswear division in December 1987. He entered the retailing business in 1971 through the Bullock's division of Federated Department Stores. In 1984, he became chief executive and president of the Izod Lacoste division of General Mills, and participated in the spinoff of that and other labels into a new public company, Crystal Brands, in November 1985.
Mr. Baker, who now lives in San Francisco with his wife and son, will be moving his family to New York to take on his new duties, a company spokesman said.
Bernard Chaus Inc. was founded in April 1975, and was a pioneer in marketing stylish sportswear at moderate prices. The death of its founder, which followed a monthlong illness, came at the end of a very difficult period for the company. Hurt by the retailing recession, the company posted a loss of $12.8 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1991. That compared with a profit of $1.52 million, or 8 cents a share, the previous fiscal year.
 
Back in the Black
 But the company's prospects brightened in the first fiscal year of Mrs. Chaus's tenure, during which it made $5.5 million, or 30 cents a share. The first quarter of its current fiscal year was also very strong, with profits of 13 cents a share, triple those of the period a year earlier.
Mr. Baker, nevertheless, has his work cut out for him. Industry analysts report that retailers' demands for discounts on prices have turned fierce, and Chaus is expected to report quarterly profits that are essentially flat. Estimates for the current fiscal year's profits range from 35 to 45 cents a share.

HEADLINE: 3 Top Editors and Columnist Leave Post for Daily News

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
At least three top editors and the columnist Mike McAlary left The New York Post yesterday to work for The Daily News amid growing anger toward the man who aspires to be The Post's next owner.
The moves came as The Post, struggling to remain afloat, took the highly unusual step of offering free classified advertising to people looking for either jobs or employees. The paper also announced plans to base advertising rates on how successful the sales advertised turned out to be. 
 As the changes were announced, those who quit The Post sharply criticized Steven Hoffenberg, the controversial investor brought in to give The Post a quick shot of cash.
"He is totally untenable as a newspaper publisher," said Richard Gooding, the former metropolitan editor of The Post, who said he will assume a similar position at The News today. "He totally lacks credibility. I think in the end he's going to do a lot of damage to the paper."
Mr. Hoffenberg is still negotiating his purchase of The Post from Peter S. Kalikow. By the end of this week, he said he hoped to clarify when the sale would be final. In the meantime, he has assumed management control and the title of publisher.
"No matter what they say about me, they say one thing," Mr. Hoffenberg said. "I'm not afraid to fight."
In a news conference yesterday afternoon, Mr. Hoffenberg confirmed that Mr. McAlary and the editors, who he did not name, were going to The News. Later in the day, The News announced that Lou Colasuonno, currently The Post's top editor, would become its editor. The News made no announcement regarding its current editor, James P. Willse or any of its other top editors.
Sources at both papers confirmed that another Post editor going to The News was James C. Lynch, one of two managing editors at The Post.
 
Rumors of More Departures
 Newsrooms across the city sizzled with rumors yesterday. The columnist Amy Pagnozzi declined to comment on whether she was leaving The Post. The sports columnist Mark Kriegel, another name frequently mentioned, could not be reached.
In a speech to staff members after the news conference, Mr. Hoffenberg announced replacements for those leaving. He said Gerard Bray, The Post's financial editor, would be the editor; Mark Kalech, an assistant city editor, would be the metropolitan editor, and Steve Cuozzo would remain in his post as managing editor.
At the staff meeting, employees said, Mr. Hoffenberg allowed Mr. Colasuonno to speak, but repeatedly interrupted him. After protests from the audience, the editor was permitted to finish.
Mr. Gooding said that yesterday morning, he and the two other editors told Mr. Hoffenberg that they had discussed going to The News with Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the paper's new owner.
"His response was to walk out of the office and then come back in with Bray and say, 'This is my new editor,' " he said. "He looked at me and said, 'I'm ordering you not to talk to the staff anymore.' "
 
Considering Suing
 The Daily News, which is protected from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, cut 170 employees on Jan. 7. At the time of the dismissals, The News said it hoped to use the money saved to hire new people.
Mr. Hoffenberg said at the news conference that his lawyers were investigating the possibility of suing Mr. Zuckerman, for pirating his staff. Mr. Zuckerman did not return calls for comment.
Mr. Hoffenberg called an article in The New York Times yesterday about his litigious financial history "baloney." He said an investigation of his dealings by the Securities and Exchange Commission was only to give Federal employees "something to do during the day."
 
New Advertising Policies
 Expressing concern about unemployment, he said The Post would begin to offer free classified advertising space to any company or individual looking to hire employees, as well as any individuals wanting to advertise their availability for work. He said The Post was willing to publish as many as 20 such pages indefinitely, at a cost of $900 a page. "We feel terrible that these people are unemployed," he said.
Mr. Hoffenberg's new plans for charging for advertisements reflected his previous suggestion that he be would open to barter. He said The Post would become a buyer of close-out or marked-down merchandise, paying for the merchandise with ad space.
In other comments, Mr. Hoffenberg said he hoped to avoid having The Post formally file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. He said he would restore 10 percent of the 20 percent pay cut that the staff agreed to last week. He said this Friday's paper, like last Friday's, would be 100 pages, a level not reached even during the December holiday season, when advertising increases.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 22.15 After Foreign Markets Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks moved higher in heavy trading yesterday, led by blue-chip issues and aided by the tempo set earlier overseas. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 22.15 points, to 3,332.18.
Advances yesterday in overseas markets -- The Financial Times-Stock Index of 100 leading issues in London gained 44.40 points, and the Nikkei index of 225 issues in Tokyo rose 109.86 points -- helped create a positive tone in New York. 
 American Express, up 1 3/8, to 24 5/8, led the Dow, accounting for 16 percent of its rise. The company's chairman stepped down over the weekend and a replacement was named yesterday.
Several other blue chips were up a point or more, including Philip Morris up 1 1/8, to 75 7/8; A.T& T. 1 1/8, to 54; Chevron 1 1/8, to 73 7/8; Goodyear Tire and Rubber 1, to 69; United Technologies 1, to 47 7/8, and I.B.M. 1 1/8, to 52 5/8.
Traders described volume as heavy at 238.6 million shares, but investors moved cautiously ahead of the employment report for January, which is scheduled on Friday. Some market strategists expect the figure to show weakness in the economy, a feeling they said might have limited the size of yesterday's advances.
Yesterday's purchasing agents' index for January suggested, however, that the recovery was gathering steam. The index rose to a four-year high, paced by healthy new orders and production.
The numbers, analysts said, were in line with the similarly robust January readings of the regional indexes reported recently by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank.
"Yesterday's purchasing managers' index numbers bode well for the economy," said Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst at MMS International, an economics research firm. "I think the market's focus will now shift to the employment number."
He said yesterday's market was helped by technology stocks, which were "underproducing the last few days."
Intel rose 4 1/2, to 111 1/4; Motorola 2 3/4, to 53 3/4; Texas Instruments 2 3/8, to 56 3/8; Apple Computer 1 3/4, to 61 1/4; Compaq Computer 2 3/8, to 53 1/2, and Microsoft 1, to 87 1/2.
RJR Nabisco rose 5/8, to 8 7/8, on heavy volume of 6.9 million shares. An Illinois jury ruled unanimously for the tobacco company and the industry trade association in a suit filed by a smoker with lung cancer. In addition, an article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday said that the company was considering creating a class of stock linked to its foods unit.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index added 1.89 points, to 243.81. Advancing issues led declining stocks almost 2 to 1 on the Big Board.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.74, to 442.52, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 5.43, to 701.77. The American Stock Exchange composite index advanced 0.55 point, to 411.63.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Shrug Off Report

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday, holding up well in the face of another report showing that the economy may be moving spritely into the new year.
The closely watched index of the nation's purchasing managers jumped to 58 percent in January from 55.4 percent in December. This was the index's highest level since the summer of 1988. 
 "What was good about the report was that it was broad-based," Stuart G. Hoffman, the chief economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh, said.
While such news would normally disturb the bond market because economic growth can lead to higher inflation, yesterday's report came as investor confidence was growing that the rate of inflation will remain low this year and into next year.
 
Long Bond Yield Rises Slightly
 After the morning release of the purchasing managers' report, the price of the 30-year bond fell almost half a point. But by late afternoon, the price was off just 3/32 to yield 7.20 percent, up from 7.19 percent Friday. At 7.19, the yield on the 30-year bond had been at its lowest level since August 1986.
Prices of Treasury notes were also little changed. At the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the three-month bill had an average discount rate of 2.97 percent, down from 2.98 percent last week, and the six-month bill had an average discount rate of 3.10 percent, up from 3.09 percent a week ago.
The White House said yesterday that President Clinton was considering a fiscal stimulus package of around $30 billion. But while the estimate was slightly higher than the $20 billion that many analysts have been using, it did not seem to bother the market.
 
M-2 Growth Debate
 The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, is meeting today and tomorrow to set its policy course for the year. But Fed watchers do not expect any policy change that should affect short-term interest rates.
Darwin L. Beck, director of the economics department at the First Boston Corporation, said he expected the Federal Reserve's target for the Federal funds rate to stay "stable through most of the year." The Fed funds rate, the interest rate charged on overnight loans between banks, is the short-term rate that the Fed uses to enact its monetary policy goals. The current target is 3 percent.
The only thing that would change the Fed's mind, Mr. Beck said, would be a significant change in the performance of the economy. But he said that if economic growth held in a 2 percent to 4 percent range there should be no need for the Fed to shift short-term interest rates.
The big Fed debate will concern the annual growth range for M-2, the key money supply barometer that includes currency in circulation, checking accounts, money market accounts, savings accounts and certificates of deposit.
Fed officials say the decision would not have an impact on maintaining the Federal funds rate at 3 percent.
But a change could have political consequences. Under discussion will be a proposal to lower the M-2 growth range from a current spread of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. Lowering the range could concern members of Congress and some Clinton Administration officials that the Fed might raise short-term interest rates sooner than they would like, given the moderate growth rate of the economy.
 
February Auction
 Tomorrow, the Treasury will be making an announcement that could have some impact on the bond market, expecially the 30-year bond.
This is the announcement of the details of the quarterly auction of 3-year and 10-year Treasury notes and 30-year bonds. Many in the market are waiting to see whether the Treasury, to reduce borrowing costs and to help bring down long-term interest rates, will reduce the size of the 30-year bond auction.
In November, the Treasury sold $10.25 billion 30-year bonds. If the size of February's 30-year auction is not cut at least a little, the price of the 30-year bond could fall because part of its recent jump in price has been attributed to a bet that the Treasury would make such a move.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Morgan Fund To Invest In Banks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company, combining its tradition of bailing out troubled banks with its desire to become an aggressive investment firm, said yesterday that it had raised $1 billion for a fund to invest in commercial banks worldwide.
With money from corporate pension funds and wealthy individuals around the world, the fund, called the Corsair Partnership, is similar to the leveraged buyout funds that were popular in the late 1980's, except that it will focus on the banking industry and buy only minority stakes.
 
Two Years in the Making
 Morgan began to organize the fund in 1990, when several major banks appeared to be near collapse. The bank's management worried that it would be asked by Federal regulators to bail out failing institutions as it had in years past, said Nicholas B. Paumgarten, a longtime investment banker with the First Boston Company who was hired by Morgan to run the fund. 
 Before the Federal Reserve System was created, Morgan acted as a de facto central bank, providing cash to needy institutions, and as recently as the 1980's lent money to banks weighted down by troubled energy loans, Mr. Paumgarten said.
Instead of using capital simply as an aid to the industry, Morgan identified a new business opportunity. It established a fund that intends to buy stakes of 10 to 15 percent in overseas and domestic banks and to take positions on their boards.
But in the two years that it took Morgan to raise the money, the United States banking industry has largely returned to health and finds capital readily available through the sale of stocks and bonds.
 
 
Europe's Appeal
 As a result, the Morgan fund expects initially to invest in European banks, which are still saddled with the type of bad loans and depressed economies that had previously hurt banks in the United States. Morgan sees an opportunity to profit as the European banking industry consolidates.
Over the six-year investment period of the fund, Mr. Paumgarten expects to find opportunities in the United States as well. "The big U.S. banks don't need us now," he said. "But this is a bubble-and-burst business, and some will need us again in two years."
The fund is not interested in banks in Japan, Mr. Paumgarten said, because Japanese companies typically resist foreign influence. The Morgan fund expects to be involved in the major decisions of the banks in which it invests.
Though banks, including Morgan, have been using their own money to invest in other companies, the Corsair fund is the first large investment pool from a commercial bank, furthering the industry's move into businesses traditionally dominated by Wall Street.
It is also the first fund of its size to invest in a single industry. Last year Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities unit of the Equitable Companies each established funds of about $1 billion to invest in leveraged buyouts and other opportunities, regardless of industry.
"It's a difficult environment to raise money for private equity funds; investors are being very cautious," said Steven P. Galante, publisher of Private Equity Analyst, a West Newton, Mass., newsletter. "There has been a big falloff since the peak of leveraged buyout activity in 1987."
Morgan was successful, Mr. Galante said, because of its contacts with investors and the reputation of its analysts. Moreover, the bank put up $100 million -- 10 percent of the fund, compared with the 1 percent that is typical in the industry.
Morgan is also charging investors fees that are lower than customary. Instead of a 2 percent annual fee, it will charge a one-time 2 percent fee when the investments are made, and the bank will invest that fee in the fund. When the fund is closed out in 10 years, Morgan will earn 20 percent of the profits, but only if the return exceeds 20 percent a year. Such a fee structure, placing a high performance requirement on the fund manager is unusual, Mr. Galante said.
Mr. Paumgarten said that he expected the fund to earn a 30 percent annual return.
 
Private Placements
 Rather than buying banks' stock in the open market, Morgan hopes to make its investments through private placements, an approach that will allow the fund managers to gain access to financial information not available to the general public. Morgan expects bank executives to be open to its requests because of its reputation and resources, Jeff M. Garrity, a vice president in Morgan's private placement department, said.
"From a C.E.O.'s perspective, if you have J. P. Morgan as an investor and on your board," he said, "it gives your bank a blue-chip panache."
Morgan also hopes to sell its services to the banks in which it invests, Mr. Garrity said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Europe's Monetary Turmoil Adds Fuel to Dollar's Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued its rally yesterday, benefiting from turmoil among European currencies and more favorable news about the American economy.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $330.30 an ounce, up 10 cents from Friday. But the Republic National Bank said gold slipped 10 cents an ounce to a late bid of $329.60. 
 The day's heaviest currency trading occurred in Europe, where dealers had their first opportunity to react to the weekend devaluation of the Irish pound. The 10 percent reduction caused a wave of concern to sweep through trading floors overseas.
The British pound fell sharply. The Government in London said the devaluation of the Irish pound strengthened its case for overhauling Europe's 13-year-old Exchange Rate Mechanism, which was intended to stabilize currencies in preparation for establishing a single currency for the 12 members of the European Community. Britain withdrew from the mechanism last year.
"This is adding more fuel to the argument for lower European rates, either through formal devaluations or coordinated cuts" of interest rates, said Ronald Holzer, the chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Lower rates overseas make yields on dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.95 yen, up 0.65 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.93 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.05 yen, up from 124.65 on Friday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.4538, down from Friday's $1.4873. In New York, it cost $1.4595 to buy one pound, down from $1.4865 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6358 German marks, up from 1.6110; 1.5180 Swiss francs, up from 1.4880; 5.5310 French francs, up from 5.4495; 1,514.00 Italian lire, up from 1,493.50, and 1.2630 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2678.

HEADLINE: Purchasing Managers Find Economy Is Gaining Ground

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
American manufacturers virtually roared into 1993, according to a report yesterday that was the first solid data on the economy's momentum so far this year.
The closely watched purchasing managers' index, a measure of a half-dozen aspects of manufacturing, jumped from 55.4 percent in December to 58 percent in January, its highest level since the summer of 1988, the economy's last really good year. 
 "It's a strong report, one of the strongest in years," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the National Association of Purchasing Management survey and director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes.
Instead of faltering, as some had feared, the recovery seems to have gotten on more solid footing. A reading over 44.5 percent indicates that manufacturing is expanding; a reading over 50 percent is a sign that the whole economy is gaining ground.
"It's powerful stuff," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "It should be enough to affect the Administration's perception of the need for stimulus."
A separate report yesterday on the construction industry, however, showed that sector was still struggling at the end of 1992. The Commerce Department said outlays for new construction fell four-tenths of a percent in inflation-adjusted terms in December from November. Worse, October and November outlays were revised sharply lower.
 
Signs of Stronger Future
 Home building was the bright spot in the month and is likely to continue strong, given robust sales and mounting mortgage applications in January. But all other construction, from apartments to offices to stores, remained stalled.
The purchasing survey found that factory production in January grew at the fastest pace in five years. Even more encouraging, new factory orders zoomed to their highest level since 1983. Order backlogs, which were shrinking for much of last year, got fatter. And one of the favorite indicators of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan -- suppliers' delivery times -- suggested that factories were so busy that more customers were reporting delays in January than in December. Rising orders and backlogs and longer waits for supplies all point to further production increases, economists say.
"This means that the economic expansion is not going to evaporate," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
The strength in orders, moreover, was clearly because of stronger domestic demand. Export orders, still surprisingly solid, have merely been bobbing around in recent months.
Manufacturers are still not adding new workers, however, and the strong growth of production is almost entirely because of rapid gains in factory productivity. Nonetheless, the purchasing managers' hiring measure, which was edging down in several of the last six months, did strengthen a bit in January, suggesting that the contraction in the factory work force may be easing.
"It's been my feeling for some time," Mr. Bretz said, "that order backlogs will have to grow for several months in a row before employment expands again. This is a good start."
 
Better Profit Outlook
 Meanwhile, the purchasing managers' report suggested that the profit picture in manufacturing, already quite bright last year, is set to become even brighter in 1993 -- and for a widening circle of industrial companies. The biggest gains in orders and production were in plastics, paper, chemicals, metals, heavy machinery and -- no surprise -- computers.
Though companies are still having a hard time raising prices, the survey showed that more companies were able to make their price increases stick or avoid price decreases in January than in December. Together with rising sales volume and improving efficiency, that suggests that profit margins are getting fatter.
The purchasing managers survey has tracked the ups and downs of the gross domestic product reasonably well, according to economists. "It's quite reliable," said Mr. Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence. "Right now it's basically confirming other indicators."
Despite the flurry of good economic news in the last week, including a 9.1 percent increase in orders for durable goods in December, most forecasters still expect the economy to settle down from the robust 3.6 percent rate of growth in the second half of last year.
Job worries and slow employment growth, for example, may prompt consumers to pull back a bit. The University of Michigan reported on Friday that consumer confidence in the economy leveled off in January after a post-election surge, edging down from 91 points to 89.3 points.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage dropped to 7.86 percent last week from 8 percent the previous week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the lowest rate since the week that ended on Sept. 11, when the rate was 7.84 percent. The agency, known as Freddie Mac, said the average rate for a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 7.37 percent, from 7.51 percent a week earlier. In its weekly report, Freddie Mac said the average interest rate for adjustable mortgages fell to 5.06 percent from 5.20 percent.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Dan Shaw

 BODY:

A Chance to Crow
Donna Karan should be kvelling. Her "cold shoulder" black dress finally made it to the White House. 
 On Sunday night, Hillary Rodham Clinton wore Ms. Karan's best-selling dress, which has long sleeves and cutouts at the shoulders, to her first official White House dinner. The dress, which was ubiquitous at inauguration parties, was worn by Candice Bergen at last year's Emmy Awards.
 
Dressing a Show Quickly
 Ellen Shanley, the curator of "Dress for Excess: Mainstream and Extreme in Men's Wear," the new exhibit at the Fashion Institute of Technology, is trying to catch her breath.
A curatorial coordinator at the Shirley Goodman Resource Center, which includes F.I.T.'s museum, Ms. Shanley had only three and a half weeks to pull the show together; its opening last Thursday was scheduled to help celebrate the 100th-anniversary of the Daily News Record, the men's wear trade paper. Ms. Shanley was asked to put together her very first show after the school's longtime curatorial team, Richard Martin and Harold Koda, left to run the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
On Jan. 4, with only the title to guide her, Ms. Shanley began pulling items from the F.I.T. archives, where she found a breathtaking array of clothes that look quite contemporary: a circa-1895 American-made, beige-linen sack suit that might be mistaken for a 1993 Calvin Klein; plush striped waistcoats from the 1920's that Romeo Gigli could send down the runway today; a circa-1930 tweed "breakfast jacket" with a shawl collar in two-faced wool with braided frog closings that looks just like a Matsuda. "I was surprised by how much detail used to go into men's wear," Ms. Shanley said.
She also chose some items that are easily dated, like an Italian brown wool double-knit leisure suit (circa 1970), and a blue tie-dyed corduroy suit that Bloomingdale's carried in 1973. Anyone who thinks the current bell-bottom boom is license to wear any clothes that were considered fashionable 20 years ago is well-advised to check out the exhibit, which brings to mind Santayana's dictum, "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it."
 
The de la Renta Shuttle
 If nothing else, the airline industry is benefiting from Oscar de la Renta's debut as a haute couturier.
Last week, when the designer presented his first couture collection for the House of Balmain in Paris, he was surrounded by a legion of New Yorkers who'd flown over for his debut, fans like Mica Ertegun, Nan Kempner, Jerome Zipkin, Barbara Walters and Linda Wachner. Now, Mr. de la Renta is flying the collection and fitters to New York, where they will take up residence at Bergdorf Goodman from Feb. 23 to 26.
The store is planning to give Mr. de la Renta a haute homecoming, with the de rigueur luncheon, fashion show and Fifth Avenue windows.
 
Mail-Order Fakes
 If you're looking for counterfeit Chanel bags and faux Louis Vuitton luggage in Manhattan, you head for Canal Street. If you want to buy them in Sweden, you can order from a mail-order catalogue called Fake.
"We just discovered it, and we don't know who's behind it yet," Christian Blanckaert, the president of the Comite Colbert, a French trade group, said from Paris last week. "We are talking with the Swedish authorities."
The Comite Colbert, which represents 70 French luxury-goods manufacturers with $6 billion in sales, is also concerned about counterfeiting elsewhere. It has issued a report calling the Italian Government's battle against counterfeiting "very weak" and will publish a report about the problem in Turkey next month.
"This is not just an economic problem," Mr. Blanckaert said. "It threatens our patrimoine, our cultural heritage, too."
