HEADLINE: C.I.A. Nominee Wary of Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton's nominee to head the Central Intelligence Agency refused today to endorse any immediate cut in the nation's estimated $29 billion intelligence budget, warning of multiplying threats to American security.
Resisting invitations to describe a new era of austerity for the nation's intelligence agencies, the nominee, R. James Woolsey, instead outlined what he said were widening and vexing challenges. He used vivid imagery to paint a portrait of the country's task with the cold war won. 
 "Yes, we have slain a large dragon," Mr. Woolsey told the Senate Intelligence Committee. "But we live now in a jungle filled with a bewildering variety of poisonous snakes. And in many ways, the dragon was easier to keep track of."
 
Wary of a Debate
 Mr. Woolsey, whose nomination won praise from Republicans and Democrats, appeared headed for certain Senate confirmation. But his reluctance to join in the debate about potential budget cuts left him oddly disengaged from a Congressional battle that began to flare even as he spoke.
In declining to outline specific budget cuts, Mr. Woolsey insisted that his testimony did not reflect any formal Administration conclusion about the proper level of intelligence spending. But his strong warnings about the gravity of threats appeared intended to serve notice that he would be highly wary of budget-cutting efforts that might weaken intelligence programs.
As a former arms-control negotiator and the most conservative member of Mr. Clinton's national security team, Mr. Woolsey also seemed determined to establish his independence from the new Democratic chairman of the Intelligence Committee, Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, who has indicated that he plans to seek cuts beyond the $1.6 billion that Congress stripped from the budget last year.
As they left office last month, both former President George Bush and the departing Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, warned bluntly that such an effort would lead to disaster. But President Clinton's calls for sharp cuts across the military budget has led to expectations that he would impose a similar levy on intelligence accounts.
 
More Threats, Not Fewer
 Mr. Woolsey said he remained acutely aware of the need for economies in government, and he indicated that he would try in coming months to identify areas in which intelligence spending might be prudently reduced. But he said he would be reluctant to identify specific targets before an intensive review.
Pressed to be more specific, Mr. Woolsey indicated only that he would be more willing to endorse reductions in spending than to countenance a cutback in manpower at a time when the number of serious threats to American interests, despite the collapse of the Soviet Union, had "grown, not shrunk."
"In many ways, today's threats are harder to observe and understand than the one that was once presented by the U.S.S.R.," Mr. Woolsey said. He went on to liken ethnic violence in the former Yugoslavia to a cancer that could metastasize anywhere, and to list a host of other problems, including the spread of weapons of mass destruction, as "extraordinary" challenges.
The confirmation hearing, held in a stark and modern chamber, was convened amid tight security because of the unsolved killings last week of two C.I.A. employees as they sat in traffic outside the agency's headquarters in suburban Virginia.
 
Strong Endorsement Seen
 Mr. Woolsey, a 51-year-old Washington insider who has traversed the barriers between public and private life for more than two decades, met with scant criticism from committee members. The panel limited its questioning to a day, and it is expected to recommend overwhelmingly on Wednesday that the Senate confirm his nomination.
That swift embrace of Mr. Woolsey stands in sharp contrast to the 11-day ordeal to which the panel subjected Mr. Gates during combative hearings in the fall of 1991 before recommending, in a divided vote, that he be confirmed.
But it was plain from the beginning of today's session that Mr. Woolsey, who like Mr. Clinton is a Rhodes Scholar and a Yale Law School graduate, was among friends. So plentiful were other Rhodes Scholars among the senators who introduced Mr. Woolsey or were serving on the panel that Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, groused good-naturedly about what he called "a Mafia that's taking over the Administration."
But within the Intelligence Committee there were clear indications of recurrent tension over the question of budget-cutting. As Mr. DeConcini and some other Democrats made plain that they intended to pursue deeper cuts, Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, took issue with the chairman's contention that intelligence agencies might have to accept less than state-of-the-art technology.
"If we're not ahead of the curve, we're going to be behind it," Mr. Wallop said. "If we're not on the cutting edge, we're going to be under it."
He added, "What you don't know can hurt you."
 
An Owl Who Spies?
 Mr. Woolsey, whose bespectacled face and balding pate can give him an owlish look, spoke with confidence but maintained a studied caution as he sat alone at a witness table, a battered leather briefase at his feet. He answered questions during open sessions in the morning and afternoon, and he later testified behind closed doors on more sensitive issues.
He said he had not reached a final decision on what he termed the "hottest" issue facing the agency: whether intelligence information should be shared with private American companies. He pledged if confirmed to order a "thorough review" early in the Administration to come up with a "systematic policy" on economic intelligence.

He greeted Senators before a hearing. From right were John W. Warner, Dennis DeConcini and Howard M. Metzenbaum. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Shifts Gears;
'Motor Voter' Accelerates

 BODY:
President Bush vetoed the "motor-voter" bill last year, offering all sorts of flimsy reasons that barely hid cynical political calculation. Fortunately, democracy won't die that easily. The bill, designed to make it easier for all Americans to register and vote, is due to clear the House Rules Committee today and to hit the House floor for a vote by the end of the week.
The common-sense measure's nickname describes its core provision: States would be required to permit voter registration when people obtain or renew a driver's license. The law would also require that states offer registration by mail and at unemployment, welfare and other government offices. Those states that already have well-structured "motor-voter" programs posted significantly higher voter registration and voter turnout rates in the 1992 election. 
 President Clinton has endorsed the bill, removing any White House hurdle to enactment. As a result, leading House Republicans have turned to fear tactics in a last-ditch effort to block the reform.
Hoping to exploit concerns about illegal aliens recently heightened by the Zoe Baird mess, Robert Michel, the House minority leader, Newt Gingrich, the minority whip, and two other key Republican Representatives have signed a letter that depicts the measure as a "Non-Citizens Voting Rights Act." They assert it will invite an epidemic of illegal voting.
Yet it's hard to see why registering at the Department of Motor Vehicles would encourage any more fraud than doing so at the Board of Elections. Indeed, states that now allow such registration have seen no increase in cheating. And nothing in the statute interferes with the stern enforcement of voting requirements by the states.
What Mr. Michel and the other G.O.P. opponents really fear is that the unregistered may tend to vote Democratic. The best response to that, however, is not to block the participation of potential voters but to woo them with attractive candidates and positions on the issues -- in other words, to show some faith in democracy.

HEADLINE: Let's Go Back to Before Reagan's 'Tax Reform'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Congress and Clinton: A Handshake if Not a Kiss" (The Week in Review, Jan. 10): You are to be commended for quoting Prof. Charles Jones of the University of Wisconsin asking, "How are we going to solve these problems within the constraints of the great Reagan debt?"
Why do so few have the courage to state openly that our runaway national debt is the Reagan debt continued into the Bush Administration? The debt incurred during these 12 years is more than the indebtedness accumulated over 200 years of borrowing since the birth of the Republic. We all know this to be so. 
 When President Reagan invited David Stockman into the woodshed, he was told by his budget director that the figures didn't add up, that his proposed tax cuts coupled with increased military spending would lead to huge deficits. This warning was ignored on the theory that lower taxes would encourage economic expansion and growth, and thus wipe out the deficit. It didn't work, and the deficit continued to grow.
We've gone through a period of sybaritic license for the rich, coupled with failure of investment to keep up with the country's needs. It was safer to lend money to the Government than to risk loans for innovative investment. There was no money for adequate investment in infrastructure or housing. Revenue went to build up the military. Tax policy made the rich richer, while falling rate of investment led to falling employment and an increase in the number of poor. Past Reagan debt is so staggering we no longer feel free to use deficit financing to deal with our serious socioeconomic problems.
To avoid repeating our mistakes, it is imperative to recognize that the massive indebtedness that limits our ability to deal with problems is due in large part to the Reagan tax cuts.
Is there an American leader with the courage to declare that to deal with the mess that President Reagan got us into it is necessary to re-examine our entire tax and budget policy?
 
MORRIS SUKENIK
Garden City, L.I., Jan. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: Let's Go Back to Before Reagan's 'Tax Reform';
Structural Recession

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Economists Meet, and Puzzle Over a Slump" (Business Day, Jan. 9), reporting on the American Economic Association meeting in Anaheim. Calif.: Economists will remain puzzled as long as they insist on talking about "the recession" because there are two different recessions at work, one cyclical -- which seems to be over -- the other structural, going strong and with no end in sight. The structural recession is characterized by a reversal of the usual cause-effect sequence. Layoffs, especially at high wage levels, are its main source rather than its result.
The two recessions interact: a cyclical downswing in 1990, combined with drastic cuts in defense spending and with growing global competition, have acted as catalysts to accelerate the restructurings of the workplace. They were driven in part by the efforts of businesses, mainly in the service sector, to reap long-overdue productivity returns from a huge investment in information technology. 
 There are different roads to productivity gain. One is to take advantage of technology to obtain more and higher-quality output with better trained personnel. Another is to operate with a reduced -- in the latest euphemism, "right-sized" -- work force. In the face of shrinking demand, most companies opted for the second route, which led to a self-feeding chain: layoffs, deterioration of disposable income and consumer confidence, demand retraction, more layoffs. (According to an American Management Association report, one of four surveyed companies has had three or more downsizing rounds.)
Conventional economic measurements are misleading: unemployment statistics do not reflect the many jobless who have given up trying, nor downward migrations to lower-level or part-time jobs. Besides, in an economy increasingly dependent on information and knowledge work, we measure the utilization rate of industrial equipment, but are blind to huge capital squandered when scientists drive taxis and college graduates sell fast food.
The productivity-employment dilemma and the massive vanishing of high-wage jobs are a few of the critical issues the new Administration must address in fighting the structural recession, by far the more dangerous.
 
SIGFRIDO LICHTENTHAL
Scarsdale, N.Y., Jan. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeking $31 Billion in Stimulus

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Laying the political groundwork for economic battles to come, President Clinton has told governors and members of Congress that he wants $31 billion in new spending on jobs and on tax breaks for business this year to stimulate the economy.
Mr. Clinton also emphasized some domestic goals in a speech to the nation's governors today, asking them for help in reorganizing the welfare system. To that end, he said, he plans to name a group to study the best way to make welfare a form of temporary support with the goal of limiting payments to two years. He did not provide a schedule for putting his ideas into action.
 
Unpleasant Choices
 Addressing the National Governors' Association in his first policy speech as President and meeting privately with Congressional leaders in sessions that will continue Wednesday, Mr. Clinton embarked on a strategy to win support for the politically unpalatable choices he is likely to present in coming weeks on taxes, Social Security and the deficit. 
 Even as Mr. Clinton made his rounds today, the economy showed signs of rebounding on its own as consumer confidence strengthened. The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Indicators, had its biggest gain in nearly 10 years in December, and statistics showed that home sales also increased markedly last year as interest rates fell.
White House officials said the positive economic news was welcome but would not deter Mr. Clinton from trying to stimulate the economy further with spending programs that could stymie his efforts to reduce the budget deficit.
 
More Jobs Needed
 George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said the good news had not extended to jobs. "We need to have long-term job growth," he said. "We need an economy where incomes are growing."
In his meetings with lawmakers today, Mr. Clinton did not discuss how much his plans would cost. Many senators have said they will fight any proposals for an energy tax and cuts in Social Security benefits.
Instead, Mr. Clinton altered his plan of inviting lawmakers to the White House in favor of making a trip to Capitol Hill that lent symbolic heft to his pledge to work with Congress. After a week in which Mr. Clinton was forced to battle members of his own party over whether to allow homosexuals to join the military, he appealed today to his fellow Democrats for unity and for support for the economic program he will present on Feb. 17, said lawmakers who were present.
"There was a very broad consensus about dealing with reality and getting the deficit down in a real way," said Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Mr. Clinton is using this week to solidify support for his domestic program among political leaders who share some of his goals: the governors, who are holding their annual meeting here. They asked the President to increase spending on construction projects to create jobs and stimulate further investment.
In recent weeks, economists and Administration officials have suggested they were considering economic stimulus packages worth $15 billion to $60 billion. Last week, after Administration officials had suggested $20 billion as a likely target, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress he approved of the Administration's plan to speed growth with short-term spending.
But as the date for submitting the package has drawn closer, officials have settled on a somewhat higher figure, divided roughly between spending and tax breaks. But they have said every day that no final decision has been made.
"We generally agreed that if there is going to be a short-term stimulus in the 10-, 20-, 30-billion-dollar range that it has to be something that can be done quickly, in 30- to 60- to 90-day period," said Gov. Ben Nelson of Nebraska.
 
Reorganize structuring Welfare
 Mr. Clinton's proposal to reorganize welfare, which would limit how long recipients would get benefits without working and provide worker training for recipients, is particularly popular among governors in both parties.
"No one likes the welfare system as it currently exists, least of all the people who are on it," Mr. Clinton told the governors. "The taxpayers, the social service employees themselves don't think much of it either. Most people who are on welfare are yearning for another alternative, aching for the chance to move from dependence to dignity. And we owe it to them to give them that chance."
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would quadruple to $4 billion the amount the Government spends on job training for welfare recipients and add $2 billion in tax credits for the working poor. Mr. Stephanopoulos said today that those targets might change because projections about increases in the deficit were higher than expected.
For the past year, Mr. Clinton has stressed mutual responsibility, arguing that the Government should do more to help the poor and the poor should do more to help themselves. He said today he would appoint a panel of representatives from Cabinet departments to consult with Congress and state officials. The panel, officials said, would be charged with devising a program that cracks down on parents who do not pay child support and limit welfare payments to two years.
After that, the recipient would have to take a job or perform community service to receive Government aid. One of four people on welfare stays on the welfare rolls eight years or longer, White House officials say.
"We ought to be able to lift people who work 40 hours a week with kids in their home out of poverty," Mr. Clinton said. "And we will remove the incentive for staying in poverty. It will be much less expensive than to have government direct supplements to pay people to remain idle. And it will reinforce the work ethic."
Mr. Clinton's plan garnered support in divergent circles today.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the chairman of the Finance Committee, said he was "hugely gratified" by Mr. Clinton's promise to change welfare. The Senator was a sponsor of the Family Support Act that passed in 1988 and espoused many of the same principles as Mr. Clinton's proposal.
And Robert Rector, an analyst on welfare and family issues at the conservative Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington said: "He really does have a really coherent package here. What I fear is, we will get free health-care coverage for the poor, for working families and others and forget this other part about making the welfare recipients work."
 
Wooing Senators on Deficit
 At the Capitol today, Mr. Clinton encouraged senators to make suggestions on the components of his deficit-spending program, which is expected to be divided equally between new spending and tax breaks for business. Lawmakers who attended the meetings said the discussion lacked specifics on costs.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said that no final decisions had been made about the components of the stimulus package and that higher and lower price tagshad been discussed. But Mr. Stephanopoulos said the $31 billion figure was "in the ball park."
"There was a very broad consensus about dealing with reality and getting the deficit down in a real way," said Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois.
Mr. Simon said the President asked the senators "to weigh in in the next few days" on their views of what his economic package should include.
Senator Kerry said the President "said very clearly that he was going to make cuts" in programs to offset the new taxes that are likely to be part of an economic package.
But the White House has taken pains to concentrate on the good news of increased spending, and officials are less forthcoming about the down side of Mr. Clinton's formula, the tax increases and budget cuts that are just as likely to be part of Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message.
"The President is not eager to move forward on any proposals that will have any kind of an undue impact on people," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "There's no question about that. But he also has said in the end his package will be fair. And he remains committed to that."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1518 words

HEADLINE: Economy Shows Expansion, But Jobs and Regions Falter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Despite lingering joblessness and areas where the recession stubbornly hangs on, most economists say the United States economy is expanding solidly and seems poised to continue growing.
Layoffs by large companies like I.B.M. and Sears are grabbing headlines and indeed, joblessness is now higher even than when the recession began. In this recovery, growth has come primarily from improved production by workers already on the payroll, rather than new hiring. But this is contributing to hefty corporate profits, more investment by business and longer hours for those employed.
Furthermore, job creation by small companies is starting to offset the very visible job cutbacks at big-name enterprises. Borrowers have now repaid some of their debts, and consumer confidence has strongly rebounded.
 
Index Soars 1.9%
 Signs of the recovery taking hold showed up strongly in a variety of statistics released in recent days. The Government's main measure for predicting the economy, the index of leading economic indicators, soared 1.9 percent in December, its third straight advance and the brightest forecast for growth in nearly 10 years, the Commerce Department reported today. 
 At the same time, the department found that sales of new one-family homes climbed 6.3 percent for the month, a gain even bigger than it appeared because of a sharp upward revision for November home sales.
 Other signs of the strengthening economy in the last week included a bullish report about manufacturing activity from corporate purchasing managers and a big jump in December in new orders for long-lasting goods.
 Analysts said that these figures were further confirmation that the economy was solidly expanding, and that only strong job gains were lacking to put an end to doubt about robust 1993 growth.
"That the United States economy is beyond the recovery stage and in the nascent phase of an expansion seems clear," said John R. Williams, an economist for the Bankers Trust Company, in the bank's current market letter. "Practically every piece of data, with the exception of some labor market news, is increasingly upbeat."
Although the economy has picked up smartly in most areas, some have remained distressed. In contrast to the early 1980's, when the two coasts boomed for years before the middle of America made its comeback, California, New York and New England are still in trouble.
California's economy was late to enter the recession, and while other parts of the country started to bounce back, its real estate market continued to erode, it lost thousands of defense jobs and suffered such a severe budget crisis it was forced to pay its employees with I.O.U.'s.
Only now is the state's economy showing some signs that it has begun to stabilize; for example, its unemployment rate, which peaked above 10 percent in November, retreated to 9.7 percent in December.
The Northeast, one of the first areas to go into recession, has recovered substantially better, though unemployment rates in big states like New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts remain at 8 percent or more, above the 7.3 percent national average. But housing prices in the Northeast had the biggest advance of any region in 1992.
 
Growth Weaker Than Normal
 Although it has picked up, national economic growth in this recovery is still far weaker than normal. For example, last year's 2.1 percent growth was less than half what economists have come to expect after a recession. Even so, the expansion now under way would ordinarily leave little reason to embark on the kind of economic stimulus President Clinton is planning. But he is undoubtedly motivated by the discouraging reports on the jobs front.
On Friday, the Labor Department is expected to report expanding payrolls for January but at less than half the typical pace of job creation.
Political pressure to improve employment is particularly intense because of the high number of white-collar employees who have lost jobs and have little prospect of returning to work soon.
Today's bullish economic reports came as the Federal Reserve Board began a two-day meeting to set strategy for the year on interest rates and the money supply. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, last week told Congress that he was confident that recovery would continue, even though growth was still running into "strong headwinds." He also indicated a willingness to continue to accommodate growth as fast or slightly faster than seen so far.
The strong leading indicators for December announced today were not expected to cause significant change in either the Fed's stance or that of the Clinton Administration because they were largely expected.
 
Public Works Programs
 President Clinton is continuing to fashion a plan for short-term economic stimulus, which by latest accounts seems likely to total $31 billion in deficit spending, including outlays for roads and bridges and incentives for business to invest in new equipment.
Despite the succession of encouraging statistics on the economy, most analysts expect at least some slackening in late winter and spring.
This reflects both the lagging job growth and a likely pause in consumer spending. Americans will be receiving smaller tax refunds for 1992 as a result of the Bush Administration's election-year effort to spur activity by reducing the tax withheld from paychecks.
Moreover, the spur from rebuilding in Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii after hurricanes is now waning.
David Orr, chief economist for the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said, "First-half gross national product growth will drop back into the 2 to 2.5 percent range, followed by a return to the 3 percent-plus range in late 1993" as the Clinton stimulus program takes effect.
But some economists are more optimistic. Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns, is forecasting 4 percent growth this year. He also expects unemployment to decline by a full percentage point.
"At the root of a free-market economy is the company," said Mr. Kudlow, who was chief economist for the Office of Management and Budget in the early Reagan years. "If business is making money, it will expand. All American business is emphasizing productivity, productivity. Once that has run its course, job creation will follow."
Housing has been one of the strongest areas of the economy since last year, reflecting the marked decline in mortgage rates and increasing consumer confidence. Today's figures showed new homes sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 656,000 in December, 6.3 percent ahead of the 617,000 pace the month before.
David Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said he was pleased with the December results, declaring activity "on a firm footing.
For 1992 as a whole, sales rose to 608,000, or 19.4 percent above the 1991 level. The median price of new homes remained virtually unchanged at $120,100.
 
Big Regional Shifts
 This, however, masked significant regional shifts as the median price rose 8.4 percent in the Northeast, to $169,000; 4.9 percent in the South, to $104,900, and 4.5 percent in the Midwest, to $115,000. In the West, the median price dropped 8 percent, to $130,000.
The 1.9 percent jump in the leading indicators' index was the biggest since April 1983, when the economy was rebounding from the severe recession of 1981-82. In the first four months that year, the index posted increases averaging just over 2 percent.
Moreover, the December jump was broadly based, with 9 of the 11 components contributing to the gain and only two holding it back.
The biggest gain was a rebound in the University of Michigan's survey of consumer expectations, which rose sharply in November and December, though it has since leveled off.
Sizable gains also resulted from a smaller number of first-time claims for jobless benefits, higher orders by manufacturers for consumer goods and materials, a rise in contracts and orders for plants and equipment, a rise in unfilled orders for durable goods, higher levels of building permits and higher stock prices.
Small increases came from a longer-than-average workweek and from more companies' reporting slower deliveries from suppliers, suggesting backlogs.
The two negative components were a decline in the M-2 money supply and lower prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle. The money supply now seems to be expanding, however, and prices of materials have been held down partly by the large-scale unloading on world markets of Russian minerals.
Another Commerce Departmentindex, of indicators that tend to move in line with the economy rather than ahead of it, rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December after no change in November, the report showed. The December rise in this coincident index matched that of October, the best performance since February 1990, showing that 1992 ended on a strong note.
The index of lagging indicators, meanwhile, eased one-tenth of 1 percent, a sign to economists that bottlenecks and other inflationary pressures were being eclipsed.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Success and Failure, All From the Same Source

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
Promise and Power The Life and Times of Robert McNamara By Deborah Shapley Illustrated. 734 pages. Little, Brown. $29.95. 
Every biographer of a public figure faces a daunting challenge because image makers often erect an official fence around their liege. Nevertheless, after all the research in the library stacks, the personal interviews and the self-serving declarations by friends and foes, an author must stop, weigh everything and then try to discover the answer to a fundamental question: What makes this person tick?
 In "Promise and Power," her biography of Robert Strange McNamara, Debra Shapley gives it a good shot, but despite her voluminous notes, sources and bibliography, her subject remains an elusive personality. At excessive length, Ms. Shapley, a Washington journalist who specializes in military, arms-control and technology issues, conveys more about Mr. McNamara's familiar times than about the V-8 engine driving his enigmatic life.
 This may not be the author's fault. As portrayed by the Ms. Shapley, her subject -- former president of the Ford Motor Company, former Secretary of Defense under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, former president of the World Bank -- appears as a Janus-faced individual on almost every controversial issue.
 There is the Detroit whiz kid able to make tough business decisions, but doing so in an impersonal if not offensive way with his underlings. There's the charts-and-pointer civilian leader valiantly placing budgetary controls on the military establishment, yet thinking that Harvard Business School management methods can win a peasant war for a corrupt ally against a dedicated enemy. There's his sincere effort to improve the conditions of the poor in underdeveloped lands, but the reality that the programs he engineers frequently fall short of his claims.
 Secretary McNamara was considered intelligent but insensitive by his contemporaries in Washington. Yet he was sometimes openly emotional when toughness was considered the proper public face for the Kennedys and their spear carriers. He carried conflict like a concealed weapon in his briefcase, but why and to what end?
 Ms. Shapley writes: "It was his nature to be wedded to large organizations while mistrusting and fighting them. He made the same inner choice many times -- at Ford, over Vietnam and at the Bank -- always at the center and alone, with secret insights and plans, maneuvering the machinery he had built, playing against his corporate self. Yet to redirect a faltering organization, a leader needs the trust of subordinates. So his past manipulations kept coming back to haunt him."
 In her own area of expertise, the author praises Mr. McNamara for his intellectual leadership in nuclear strategy, arms control and third-world development. She believes he made a major contribution in the closed meetings that resolved the Cuban missile crisis. And she says he was also able to whip the World Bank into shape, even though his subordinates there often feared him.
 Any McNamara biography must be centered on his role in the Vietnam War. Ms. Shapley's main contribution is a series of interviews she conducted with him about his loyal wartime stance in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and his reported doubts about the success of the war. The interviews indicate that like the fellow hawks whose advice widened the war -- Dean Rusk, McGeorge Bundy, William P. Bundy, Walt W. Rostow, Henry Kissinger, all of whom are covered in the book -- Mr. McNamara still doesn't seem to get it. In light of history and the debatable domino theory about the future of Southeast Asia, the question was not how to turn Vietnam into a winnable war but whether it was a justifiable war.
 In one of the interviews, Mr. McNamara says: "If I didn't believe we had a chance of progressing on the political track as a result of our military pressure . . . I should have strongly recommended withdrawing from Vietnam, and if the Government wouldn't do it, I should have resigned. There's no question about that in my mind." He continues, "So the fighting was not in vain, even though I was pessimistic about how well we were doing in the field."
 Ms. Shapley writes that Mr. McNamara "says here for the first time publicly that he and Kennedy planned to withdraw all U.S. advisers by the end of 1965, even if the South Vietnamese 'were going to be defeated.' "
 "I know for a fact that John Kennedy would have withdrawn from Vietnam," she quotes Mr. McNamara as saying.
 She continues: "Thus he adds his name to the list of former Kennedy advisers who have made this assertion, and like them, he has offered no proof. He has not said what evidence he has: On this most sensitive issue of all, his habit of glimpse and concealment goes on."
 "Promise and Power" is a diligent, often outspoken biography. Even though Ms. Shapely was granted interviews -- and, incidentally, allowed Mr. McNamara to review the quotes directly attributed to him -- she does not pull her punches. She observes that "the same qualities that made McNamara sincerely work to help society and brought success led to failure as well." And in a harsh judgment, she says that the paradox of his legacy is that he is "a pivotal figure in the weakening and decline of America, despite the many virtues of the American Century he embodies."
 The book does include material about Mr. McNamara's personal background, his children and late wife, and his companionable relationship with a married woman. But if there's a key that unlocks the mystery of this strange public personality, it would probably have to be found in the autobiography that Mr. McNamara promises never to write.

 Health-insurance coverage varies. Many policies cover a portion of the fee -- typically 50 to 80 percent -- and many impose an annual maximum on payments for mental-health care.

HEADLINE: CLINTON REBUFFED ON PLAN TO REDUCE ELECTION SPENDING

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
President Clinton summoned Congressional Democrats to the White House today to seek help in keeping an election-year promise to act swiftly to change campaign finance laws. But he won no agreement on the basic elements of such a package, and there were signs that the White House was backing off its own plans in the face of Congressional resistance.
Leading Democrats emerged from the one-hour session declaring that for the first time in 12 years they were in accord with a President over the general notion that the amount of money needed to run for office should be reduced and that donations by political action committees should be limited further.
 
President Carter's Mistake
 But the participants said they did not discuss specifics, and there was no agreement on issues that were at the heart of promises made by Mr. Clinton during the campaign. One pledge was to limit political action committee contributions to $1,000, instead of the current $5,000 per candidate; another was to provide free or discounted television time for candidates who agree to limit their spending, and a third was to restrict "soft money" donations that are intended to skirt Federal spending limits. 
 Neither was there an agreement on a timetable for drafting the package. Supporters of a campaign finance overhaul contend that President Jimmy Carter's campaign finance proposal did not survive because he waited too long after taking office to push it through a reluctant Congress.
But participants in today's meeting said that regardless of what came out of the discussions any changes in campaign financing would not take effect until after the 1994 mid-term elections.
 
Divisions Become Apparent
 White House officials and Congressional leaders both said that the meeting was successful and that its purpose was not to begin drafting legislation but to begin organizing on the issue. It was clear afterward, however, that many divisions remained.
The uncertainty over campaign finance came during a relatively smooth week in which Mr. Clinton had largely succeeded in turning attention to the economic and social issues he wants to stress and away from his struggles of last week over homosexuals in the military.
The President's day began with a speech to about 200 employees of the Office of Management and Budget in which he returned to his campaign promise to make the wealthy pay their fair share of taxes.
"Before I ask working Americans to work harder and pay more," Mr. Clinton said, without divulging details, "I will ask the economic elite who made more money and paid less in taxes to pay their fair share."
Prodded by Ross Perot, who helped make campaign finance a top issue during last year's Presidential race, Mr. Clinton has considered overhauling campaign finance laws as important if he is to prove that he came to Washington as an outsider and will not settle for politics as usual. But campaign finance has never been popular among lawmakers, who are afraid that tampering with campaign finance rules would hurt their chances of being re-elected.
 
Using the 'Bully Pulpit'
 That is why Mr. Clinton "will have to pull out all the stops and use the bully pulpit with the American people on this," said Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat.
Recalling Mr. Perot's emphasis on the issue, Mr. Boren said: "My fellow members should certainly understand that if they want to vote against campaign finance reform they do so at their own peril, because of what Bill Clinton said about it and what Ross Perot said about it. As much as anything else, the reform agenda was what this election was all about."
As he prepared to meet with Congressional leaders, Mr. Clinton told reporters today that he was committed to the campaign finance package, saying, "I want to pass a bill this year, as early as we can" and "I hope we can get a good bill."
Howard Paster, Mr. Clinton's chief Congressional liaison, insisted that the President would not back off from a tough package. "The key here is that he's moving on it," Mr. Paster said. He said the meeting today had demonstrated that Mr. Clinton had made the issue a high priority. "The nature of commitment is well established," he said.
But some White House officials said that major elements of what Mr. Clinton had proposed during the campaign were back on the table, and George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, repeatedly declined opportunities during his daily briefing today to say that the proposal would include provisions that Mr. Clinton had pledged in the campaign.
 
Differences Played Down
 Emerging from the White House this evening, the Congressional leaders sought to gloss over differences on basic issues like partial subsidies for candidates to buy television time, calling them technical questions. "We did not write the bill today or begin the writing of it," said Thomas S. Foley, the House Speaker. "We did not go item by item down the list of technical questions involved in the bill, and decide how we will approach those."
Mr. Boren, for years a leading champion of campaign finance legislation, said before the session: "I hope afterwards we have a timetable and goals. We really need some deadlines imposed on us."
But afterward, Mr. Boren and other members said there was no timetable. Asked what he meant by "early action," Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said, "It means early -- as fast as we can."
Two things that the participants did seem to agree on involved what the bill would not include: they said it would not call for full public subsidies for candidates who agreed to limit their spending, an idea that is unpopular with many incumbents as well as with Republicans, and that whatever bill was passed would not take effect until the 1996 election.
Fred Wertheimer, the president of Common Cause, a group that for years has lobbied for tougher campaign finance laws, said in an interview this week that the issue was so important in the 1992 campaign that any finance package should take effect by the mid-term elections of 1994.
"You've got some folks on the Hill who are looking for Clinton to take them off the hook on this," Mr. Wertheimer said. "The challenge here for President Clinton is to move forward with a strong proposal and a request for immediate action."
As evidence of Congressional cooperation with the White House, George J. Mitchell, the Senate Democratic leader, said after the meeting, "What's possible is what we passed last year -- we passed a good strong bill, and that's where we begin this year."
Although few Democrats doubt that some campaign package will emerge, the question is how strong it will be. David Wilhelm, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has said, for example, that eliminating soft money in campaigns could greatly damage Democratic candidates around the country.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeking $14 Billion Cut By the Military

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Les Aspin has directed the Pentagon to produce a spending plan for the next fiscal year that is at least $14 billion less than the budget for the current year, according to internal Pentagon documents.
Before he left office, President Bush had already proposed spending $3 billion less on the military in the next fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. But Mr. Aspin's directive would cut the spending by nearly four times as much and make the Clinton Administration's first step toward honoring a campaign pledge to reduce military spending more. 
 About $8.3 billion of what Mr. Aspin hopes to cut is to come from the operating budgets of the Army, Air Force, Navy and Marines. That is likely to mean faster cuts in troops, less training time and fewer ships than President Bush had envisioned in his final budget.
 
Reducing Troops in Europe
 The military budget for the current year is $283 billion, in 1994 dollars, adjusted for anticipated inflation of 3.7 percent. Before he left office, former Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had proposed a $280 billion spending plan for the next fiscal year.
In a departure from Mr. Cheney's plan, Mr. Aspin directed that money for the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, which operates the "Star Wars" anti-missile program, be kept at the current level of $3.8 billion. Mr. Cheney had requested $6.3 billion for it.
In general, Mr. Aspin is using the Cheney plan as a basis, while seeking deeper cuts. Mr. Aspin, for example, directed the Pentagon to comply with legislation that forces in Europe be reduced to 100,000 troops by 1996 from about 185,000 now. The Bush Administration had hoped to modify that timetable.
The savings from deeper cuts would be applied to reducing the Federal deficit and perhaps be used for programs to stimulate the economy, senior Defense Department officials said.
Mr. Aspin, in memorandums to the acting service secretaries sent late Tuesday, ordered the services to submit their reductions by next Monday. The Navy and Marine Corps were told to reduce their combined budget by $3 billion, the Air Force by $2.8 billion and the Army by $2.5 billion. Each reduction is about a 4 percent cut from levels outlined by the Bush Administration.
"You should avoid numerous, piecemeal adjustments," Mr. Aspin wrote. "In proposing your changes, do not lose sight of our first duty to maintain a sound, ready and effective force."
The reductions may be offset by $2 billion to $3 billion Mr. Aspin's wants to add for new programs, including ones to help American weapons factories convert to commercial products and the former Soviet republics dismantle their nuclear arsenals.
It is too early to say whether the Congressional armed services and appropriations committees, one of which was headed by Mr. Aspin until he became Defense Secretary, will demand even deeper cuts than he is proposing.
Once the services submit their revised budget projections, the Defense Department will forward its overall budget request to the White House Office of Management and Budget by Feb. 23, senior officials said. The Administration is to submit the final budget proposal to Congress by March 23.
Anxious to dispel the perception that the fight over homosexuals in the military has paralyzed Pentagon planning on other major issues, like the budget, Defense Department officials provided copies of Mr. Aspin's letter and an accompanying three-page document, "Policy and Programming Guidance for FY93/94 Budget Amendment" in response to questions from The New York Times.
Senior Pentagon officials said amending the budget proposal for the 1994 fiscal year marked the first step in fulfilling Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to cut $60 billion more than Mr. Bush had said he would from military spending between now and 1997.
"This amended budget puts us on a line to get to that $60 billion neighborhood," said one senior Defense Department official.
The policy guidance to the services addresses the size of the armed forces, combat readiness, the Star Wars program and weapons modernization. These are some of its salient goals:
*Shrinking the number of active-duty troops to 1.4 million in 1997 from 1.8 million now in a way that minimizes instances of uniformed soldiers or sailors' being forced out of the military.
*Maintaining a robust budget for new research programs to sustain the American military's technological superiority.
*Reducing reserve forces "at a rate that is realistic in light of previous rates enacted by Congress."
The guidance also recommends allotting the Star Wars program as much as it now receives. But the Clinton Administration would give priority first to advanced anti-missile rockets like the Patriot missile, then to a ground-based anti-missile defense that would protect the country against an accidental or limited nuclear attack. Finally it suggests giving just enough money to maintain a research program on a plan to build missile-killing rockets to orbit the Earth. These priorities are ranked in largely the opposite order from that in which the Bush Administration had placed them.
Top-ranking military planners said today that Mr. Aspin's cuts fall within the range of budget options they had been developing since last year when it became clear that even if Mr. Bush was re-elected military spending would decline.
Senior Defense Department officials said that their immediate focus since Election Day had been on amending the budget for the 1994 fiscal year and that the services would receive additional guidance on budgets from 1995 to 1999 after Pentagon planners completed a policy review in the coming weeks.
But there are still several questions, underlying the framework of the budget for the 1994 fiscal year. Mr. Aspin's aides are struggling to determine whether savings projected at $71 billion over five years incorporated into Mr. Bush's budget can be achieved on schedule. Philip A. Odeen, a former Pentagon and National Security Council official, will lead independent experts over the next four to six weeks in scrutinizing the final Bush Administration budget.

Aspin Gets a Deputy
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- President Clinton today nominated William J. Perry as chief deputy to Defense Secretary Aspin. Mr. Perry, 66, served in the Carter Administration as Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, responsible for military acquisitions. He is currently an engineering professor at Stanford University, co-director of the Stanford University Center for International Security and Arms Control, and chairman of Technology Strategies and Alliances, a management consulting concern.

HEADLINE: Monetary Fund Criticizes Russia on Inflation

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
In an unusually strong criticism, the International Monetary Fund's top official faulted Russia's Government today for letting inflation get out of control, saying the risk of hyperinflation threatened Russia's fledgling democracy.
The official, Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, said hyperinflation would hurt Russia's poor the most, would jeopardize other economic reforms, and was causing a severe flight of capital that would make economic recovery more difficult. 
 "Many democracies in the world have been killed by hyperinflation," Mr. Camdessus said in an interview with Izvestia, the Russian newspaper, released here today. "Hyperinflation must be stopped at all costs."
Prices in Russia are rising by about 50 percent a month -- a dangerously high level that economists have termed hyperinflation.
Mr. Camdessus attributed the high rate of inflation to the creation of billions of rubles in new money, especially in the form of credits to prop up foundering state enterprises.
The United States and other industrial nations are looking to the monetary fund, which has 175 member nations, to assess Russia's market-oriented reforms and coordinate aid to Moscow.
While Camdessus voiced optimism that Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin had vowed to reduce inflation, he also noted that Russia had violated the promise it made last year to cut inflation to about 5 percent a month.
One of his biggest worries is capital flight, in which Russians, frightened by the plunging value of the ruble, are transferring their savings to banks in Western Europe. The ruble's value has plummeted to a record low of 572 rubles to the dollar from 163 in August.
"When savings go out, or stay out instead of entering or going back to the country," Mr. Camdessus said, "investments go down, growth goes down, and foreign investors are discouraged from putting their money in Russia."
Dangling a carrot in front Russia, Mr. Camdessus said he believed that Western nations should finance benefits to the country's unemployed and a safety net for the elderly and the poor.
"I am certain that we can get higher contributions" from the wealthy industrial nations than the $24 billion in aid promised last year, he said, "if Moscow makes an ironclad commitment to get its economic house in order.
But in a warning, he also said many nations did not think it made sense to grant aid to Moscow if it did not do what was needed to reduce inflation "so that this money stays in Russia" instead of heading to "foreign bank accounts in Zurich, Paris or London."

HEADLINE: 3 Western Nations Demand Zaire Leader Yield Power

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 3

 BODY:
As bloodshed intensified here, the United States, France and Belgium demanded today that President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire transfer power to the transitional government led by his rival, Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi.
A note was turned over to a Mobutu aide here, and was made public in Brussels. It essentially called on Mr. Mobutu to live up to an earlier accord to give the transitional government control of the economy and management of the government. Mr. Mobutu, who has ruled Zaire for 27 years, was reported to be at his palace in the northern part of the country. 
 The note said the current economic and social disorder results from Mr. Mobutu's failure to "transfer authority to the transitional government."
"These developments have brought Zaire to the brink of political and economic collapse, and are subjecting Zairians to unbearable hardships," the note added.
Rival army factions battled each other in Kinshasa today, leaving many dead and whole neighborhoods of Zaire's capital in ruins, witnesses said.
Fighting that erupted shortly after midnight is believed to have pitted President Mobutu's elite presidential guard against mutinous troops in Camp Kokolo, a military barracks near the city's center. It was the heaviest fighting since rioting that reportedly left several hundred people dead broke out last Thursday.
The fresh fighting between rival military forces, which lasted until dawn, spread to another military camp on the outskirts of the city. Witnesses also said soldiers attacked and pillaged what was left of Kinshasa's central market, killing several civilians.
 
Hundreds Reported Dead
 There were no firm estimates of the death toll in the fighting today. Mr. Tshisekedi, Zaire's Prime Minister and Mr. Mobutu's archrival, said that at least 1,000 people had been killed in Kinshasa on Tuesday, though the Belgian Foreign Minister, Willy Claes, said in Brussels that the true figure was closer to 300.
Sketchy reports of fighting in Kisangani, Lubumbashi and other Zairian cities also circulated here.
According to The Associated Press, Mr. Claes said in Brussels that Mr. Mobutu "has the blood of more than 300 people on his hands" from the rioting.
The latest demand of the three nations most closely aligned to Mr. Mobutu in the past was seen as a further blow against him. However, he has been able to hold onto power in recent years even though he long ago lost the support of the United States, Belgium and France. Under pressure, Mr. Mobutu agreed two years ago to have administrative power turned over to a transitional government, but he never lived up to his agreement.
Under the arrangements proposed in the note, he would be able to remain in charge of foreign policy and the army, but the running of the economy would to be entrusted to the transitional government headed by Mr. Tshisekedi. Zaire, with some of the world's largest deposits of diamonds, copper and other resources, is economically ruined. Mr. Mobutu has been widely accused of squandering the treasury.
It was not known what leverage the Western powers might wield over Mr. Mobutu. French and Belgian troops have been sent to Kinshasa to help in the evacuation of foreigners. Herman J. Cohen, the United States assistant Secretary of State for African affairs, flew to Brussels tonight, it was reported in Washington, for further urgent consultations with French and Belgian officials.
The note said that the only way to halt the violence was for Mr. Mobutu to transfer authority to the transitional government.
"The transitional government should have the means to maintain order in compliance with human rights and the capability to resume the democratic process and to restore economic stability without further obstruction by the President," the note said.
Belgium, the Central African country's ruler in colonial times, announced today that it would begin withdrawing 550 soldiers from Brazzaville, capital of the neighboring Congo, who had been sent to help with the evacuation of Belgian citizens and other foreigners from Zaire. Brazzaville is across the Congo River from Kinshasa.
The imminent departure of Belgian troops has stirred a wave of panic among many ordinary Zairians who fear that the armed forces, already increasingly beyond the Government's control, will completely disintegrate.
About 3,000 Belgians, the biggest European group in the sprawling country, lived in Zaire before the current crisis. So far, about 1,100 foreigners have fled, leaving embassies operating with skeleton staffs, businesses abandoned and Zaire's huge copper and cobalt mining operations stripped of foreign experts.
 
Mobutu Away From Capital
 President Mobutu so far has not reacted publicly to his country's latest crisis, except to blame his political opponents for trying to sabotage his Government. Significantly, the President has not visited Kinshasa since last October, and is said to have spent the last week or so in his palatial retreat in Badolite, a town about 700 miles northeast of here.
But Mr. Mobutu is not the only figure who appears to have sought to distance himself from the turmoil. Mr. Tshisekedi has been virtually invisible in recent days. Aides to Mr. Tshisekedi say he is carefully studying various options and is reluctant to make any public pronouncements lest he stir emotions in an already volatile situation.

HEADLINE: Japan Cuts Key Rate By 3/4 Point

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 4

 BODY:
After more than a week of tense behind-the-scenes prodding, the Bank of Japan announced this morning that it had cut its official discount rate to 2.5 percent from 3.25 percent in an effort to revive a badly weakened economy.
Today's three-quarters of a percentage point reduction in the discount rate, which is what the central bank charges commercial banks for short-term loans, is effective immediately. It brings the rate down to match the low set during the economic boom of the late 1980's. The rate is also a benchmark that affects other rates banks charge for loans and offer on deposits. 
 Expectations of a rate cut had been discussed in leading newspapers here for more than a week. Some Government officials had apparently leaked the news in an effort to force the central bank's hand.
On Wednesday, several senior officials said the Bank of Japan would finally announce the reduction after an extraordinary meeting of its policy-making board. So there was no surprise in the decision.
 
Tokyo Market Little Moved
 And Tokyo stocks showed little reaction today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the day down 31.4 points, or 0.18 percent, at 17,190.63. Tim Hayashida of Merrrill Lynch Japan, said, "The market is going to need signs of a more fundamental economic recovery before there's a real change in sentiment."
Yasushi Mieno, the Bank of Japan's governor, has come under criticism for his apparent reluctance to reduce the discount rate. Some in the central bank reportedly feared that such a reduction might set off a surge in stock and real estate prices.
On Wednesday, Mr. Mieno again said that "the economy remains in a severe adjustment phase," the language he has used to acknowledge the degree of the slowdown. The economy is expected to grow by less than 1.5 percent this fiscal year.
This morning the central bank said, "The Japanese economy is still faced with stagnant final demand against the background of cautious investment and consumption behavior by corporations and households."
Pressure for the reduction in the key lending rate also came from the United States and other big trading partners.
[In Washington, there was quick favorable reaction. Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen issued a statement saying: "We welcome the reduction in Japanese interest rates in light of recent economic conditions. It should help to strengthen domestic demand and, in turn, help shrink Japan's very large external surplus. And it will assist in strengthening world economic growth."]
Japan's trade surplus has soared over the last two years, exceeding $100 billion in 1992. It is expected to rise further this year, in part because the weak Japanese economy has reduced the appetite for imports.
The United States has thus been among those prodding the Government to take more aggressive steps to stimulate the economy so that Japan will import more and export less.
Pressure on Japan to act has increased with the arrival of the Clinton Administration, which is viewed as tougher on trade issues than Bush officials were. In addition, Japan will play host in July to the next meeting of leaders of the world's seven top industrial nations. Political leaders insist that the Government take strong action to halt the rise of the trade surplus to avoid criticism then.
But some economists argue that the reduction might turn out to be destructive, causing the already huge trade surplus to grow. Yukio Noguchi, an economics professor at Hitotsubashi University here, said the interest cut would have little effect on growth because there is little demand for credit. In fact, he said, the reduction might hurt consumer spending by sharply cutting sharply income from bank deposits and other interest-bearing securities.
Banks and other financial institutions should benefit, however. The rate cut will ease pressure on the large number of companies that have become overburdened with debt.
Mr. Noguchi and some other economists also said that the rate reduction might widen Japan's surplus by weakening the value of the yen.
Evidence of the Japanese recession has been growing. Consumer spending has dried up, corporations have slashed their capital spending budgets, profits are down for the third year, and banks have slowed lending. There has been virtually no growth in the money supply since September.
In the meantime, inflation is running at less than 2.5 percent and unemployment has risen slightly, to 2.4 percent in December. While that sounds remarkably low by American standards, the Japanese are accustome to full employment.
Today's move was the sixth reduction in the discount rate since 1991, when the Bank of Japan reversed a tight money policy.
The recession is in large measure a product of the policies of the central bank. When the value of the yen nearly doubled in 1986, the Bank of Japan cut interest rates to all-time lows in an effort to assure that exporters would not be strangled.
With the discount rate then at 2.5 percent, banks began a lending spree that spurred a boom in corporate spending in new plants and upgraded technology. But the loose monetary policy set off a speculative boom that sent stock and real estate prices flying and encouraging reckless lending by some financial institutions.
In May 1989, the central bank sought to bring this price spiral under control, starting to raise rates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Times Mirror Reports Quarter and '92 Loss

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company, which publishes The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and other newspapers and magazines, today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $61.7 million, as a result of several charges to reduce staff, restructure operations and make accounting changes.
The charges, which totaled $268.8 million for 1992, gave the company a net loss of $66.6 million for the year. 
 Weak economic conditions in the Los Angeles and New York markets made 1992 a difficult year. Advertising revenue has fallen sharply, forcing the company to cut costs. Times Mirror officials said they do not foresee an upturn this year and continue to look for ways to cut expenses.
In the newspaper group for 1992, advertising revenue was down 3.1 percent, and ad linage down 3.6 percent. National advertising was hardest hit, off 7 percent for the year.
The $61.7 million loss for the fourth quarter compares with a loss of $13 million in the fourth quarter of 1991. Revenue totaled $1.01 billion, up from $974.7 million. For the year, Times Mirror's loss of $66.6 million compares with net income of $82 million, or 64 cents a share, in 1991.
The company took a one-time charge of $65.3 million, or 51 cents a share, in the fourth quarter to pay for employee-buyout programs at The Los Angeles Times and Newsday. Times Mirror also took a $58 million charge -- 45 cents a share -- in the quarter for restructuring Matthew Bender, its legal publisher, to reflect a decline in demand.
In addition, the company took an after-tax charge of $145.5 million, or $1.13 a share, to adopt new accounting rules related to retirement health care and life insurance benefits.
Despite the losses, Times Mirror stock gained $1.50 today, closing at $33.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Take Show to Detroit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Bill Clinton grew so fond of campaigning on live television over the last year that he will continue the practice as President next week in a one-hour question-and-answer session broadcast from Detroit with audiences in three other cities.
Administration officials announced today that the President would travel to Detroit on Feb. 10, for a program that would be simultaneously broadcast on ABC affiliates in Detroit, Seattle, Miami, Atlanta and nationally on the C-Span cable network. 
 The "town meeting" in Detroit, Mr. Clinton's first out-of-town appearance as President, will be one week before the President delivers a major speech on economic issues before a joint session of Congress.
Mr. Clinton appeared on the Detroit station, WXYZ, in a similar format in September. He began conducting the televised roundtable sessions in New Hampshire while trying to rise above a tide of negative news coverage.
The President's aides have advised him to take his message to the people by appearing on live broadcasts rather than in news conference settings. This dovetails with the aspirations of local news programs, which are happy to pay for the broadcasts, in exchange for the prestige of such an event.
"We've been maintaining constant contact with the Clinton people," said Tom Griesdorn, the general manager of WXYZ. "We told them that if they were interested, when the President took his show on the road we would certainly like to be at the top of the list."

HEADLINE: Norwest Acquiring Citibank-Arizona

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Norwest Corporation, a highly profitable Minneapolis banking company with an appetite for growth outside its home region, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of Citibank-Arizona.
Although the Arizona bank has not been a good investment for its New York parent company, Citicorp, Norwest expects to do better. The Arizona economy has begun to improve, and the terms of the deal call for Citicorp to keep all the bank's questionable loans, which caused a loss of $13.4 million in the first nine months of last year. Norwest will pay $58 million for the bank's $1.9 billion of deposits and take on about $1 billion of good loans. 
 Norwest concentrates on the consumer business and is one of the most geographically diverse big banking companies. Its Norwest Mortgage subsidiary operates in 49 states and was the third-most-active mortgage lender in the country last year, while Norwest Financial, a consumer lending company, operates more than 770 offices in 46 states.
 
Lost Earlier Bid
 The deal for Citibank-Arizona, with 59 branches, mostly in Phoenix and Tucson, is not Norwest's first foray into the state. After buying three small Arizona banks a few years ago, Norwest tried last year to buy Valley National, the state's largest bank. Norwest lost that bidding contest to the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and will now become the fourth-largest bank in the state, trailing the BankAmerica Corporation, Banc One, and First Interstate Bancorp.
This latest deal is consistent with Norwest's strategy of diversifying geographically while concentrating on the consumer business, where the profit from each customer is small but so is the risk of significant losses. By expanding outside the Middle West into the Southwest, Norwest's fate is less closely linked to the economy of a single region.
"The diversity of Norwest is one of its most attractive features," said John D. Leonard, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers. He predicted that Norwest would seek other acquisitions, "but always at a price that is favorable to Norwest, and limited to areas that are part of or adjoining the markets where they are already present."
Norwest stock rose $1.125 after the deal was announced yesterday to close at $46.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Citicorp, which acquired the unit in January 1988, said the transaction, expected to be completed in the second quarter, would have little impact on its profits. Its stock rose 12.5 cents to close at $26.
 
 
Reaching Retirees
 Richard M. Kovacevich, the chief executive of Norwest, said that the Arizona purchase would reduce profits per share slightly this year but would prove very profitable in subsequent years. "We have a chance for a real home run," he added, if Midwesterners who retire to Arizona turn to Norwest because it is a familiar name. He noted that 12 percent of the population of Phoenix and Tucson comes from states where Norwest has banks.
Norwest's diversification strategy has allowed it to sidestep many problems faced by other large banks, which suffered heavy losses from bad loans in recent years and are disgruntled with low profit margins in lending to large corporations.
Last year, only about 5 percent, or less than $30 million of Norwest's record $518.4 million profit, came from serving big businesses. Shunning large but low-profit loans was one key reform at the bank in the mid-1980's, and Mr. Kovacevich said he did not look for any rapid expansion in the corporate banking business.
 
Passing of the Mantle
 Buying the Arizona bank is Mr. Kovacevich's first major venture since he assumed the chief executive's job early this year. Lloyd P. Johnson, who is 62 years old and was the primary architect of the bank's revival in the last half of the 1980's, remains chairman.
Mr. Johnson, a banker who was hired from the Security Pacific Corporation in 1986 to turn around Norwest, which was foundering from bad loans and organizational problems, is more soft spoken than his successor and seems most at home plotting strategy in the board room.
Mr. Kovacevich, who is 49 and is credited with the rapid growth of Citibank's New York branch system in the 1970's, seems to crave contact with people and projects the image of someone comfortable running a chain of department stores or lending a hand at a bank branch. He waxes enthusiastic about banks' untapped potential as retail stores for financial services and goes so far as to compare Norwest's strategy to such successful retailers as Wal-Mart and Home Depot.
 
Retailing Bent
 "I don't consider myself to be a banker," Mr. Kovacevich said, adding that banking is just one of many product lines, and one that could be greatly improved at most banks.
"I never heard of a retailer who didn't want customers coming to the store," he said. "Yet you often hear bankers complain about people who waste their time, ask too many questions and get the carpet dirty."
Although smaller than several of its Arizona competitors, Norwest may be able to earn more than its size would suggest. Its Arizona bank branches are supplemented by 15 offices of Norwest Mortgage, and 12 offices of Norwest Financial, which often makes loans at high interest rates to customers who have been rejected by banks.
 
Fringe Benefits
 Mr. Kovacevich said that in Colorado, where Norwest acquired the $6 billion-asset United Banks in 1991, business has doubled at its mortgage company and sharply increased at its consumer finance company since the acquisition.
Although many banking companies own mortgage and consumer finance companies, few can match Norwest's success in those businesses.
Norwest sold most of its mortgage business to the General Motors Corporation in 1986 to raise cash, but kept a nucleus of 45 offices. The business grew rapidly after that, with Norwest Mortgage boasting 458 offices and profits of $53.4 million last year.
Norwest Financial sprang from the 1982 acquisition of Dial Finance, and the business's profits have risen for 18 consecutive years. It earned $159 million last year, through 770 branches in 46 states and an affiliate in Canada.
While the mortgage and consumer finance businesses have been good in recent years, Norwest is looking to other areas for growth in the future.
 
Eye on Insurance
 One prospect is the insurance business. Norwest developed a network of insurance agents before the insurance industry was largely closed to banking companies. With 94 offices, selling all kinds of insurance and a speciality in farm crop insurance, Norwest is the 14th-largest insurance agency company in the country. Because only about 9 percent of the bank's customers use its insurance affiliate, company officials expect rapid growth in insurance sales, a business considered very low risk.
With profits mounting from so many areas, Norwest has the luxury of making acquisitions and planning for its long-term health, even if that means immediate profits are less than they could be. Les Biller, executive vice president, noted that Norwest Mortgage could have increased profits by $100 million last year if it had chosen to sell the servicing rights on its mortgages instead of holding onto the rights and stretching out the profits over several years.

HEADLINE: Senior C.I.A. Analyst Admits Discord Over Russia

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Reflecting the complexity of Russia's problems, one of the Central Intelligence Agency's most senior analysts today laid out the divisions within the intelligence community and among independent Western and Russian experts on how best to reform Russia and promote its nascent democracy.
George Kolt, the National Intelligence Officer for Russia and Eurasia, told a Senate panel of three broad areas of disagreement over the degree and pace of reform. His testimony illustrates how difficult it will be for the Clinton Administration to reach a consensus on a strategy for Russia as it begins its formal policy review. 
 In the campaign, Mr. Clinton stated that "no national security issue is more urgent" than promoting reform in the former Soviet Union. But since the election, he has said nothing of substance on the subject. Administration officials acknowledge that budget contraints, Mr. Clinton's determination to focus on domestic problems and the enormity of the problem in Russia and the other republics will dramatically limit what the United States will do.
Asked at a hearing of the Senate Armed Service Committee by Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat and committee chairman, to describe the areas of greatest uncertainty and disagreement about the former Soviet Union inside the intelligence community, Mr. Kolt said the disagreements were widely shared both inside and outside government.
Politically, Mr. Kolt said, there was a debate over whether President Boris N. Yeltsin "should push for a breakthrough" by holding new elections and setting up a new constitutional system or or whether it is better to stick to a "policy of compromise," of slower, more even movement. Economically, he added, some analysts believe that "shock therapy is the only way to reform" the economy, while others hold to the view that radical change is 'too distruptive," and that there has to be gradual change controlled by the state.
A third issue of disagreement, he said, relates to what is "the greatest danger" in Russian today: inflation, which leads people to hold on to money less and less, a view he said he shared, or unemployment, the view that the ingrained system of barter keeps the economy going and that there should be a willingness to run an inflationary policy to curb unemployment.
Mr. Kolt's articulation of the debate is well known, but his willingness to admit that the C.I.A. and other Government intelligence agencies have not reached a consensus on how to tackle the problem is unusual.
Perhaps what was most interesting about Mr. Kolt's remarks was that he tended toward the optimistic end of the spectrum on the current reform movement. He rattled off a litany of positive developments, including the move toward privitization, the "lively media" and the increasing importance of the Constitutional Court.
"So much has been accomplished" in a peaceful way, he said, adding that Mr. Yeltsin's leadership has been "critical" in making political and economic tradeoffs and maintaining popular support. But when questioned by Senator Dirk Kempthorne, the Idaho Republican, about whether Mr. Yeltsin was "our best hope" for a pro-Western Russian leader, Mr. Kolt offered praise but not exclusive support, saying that there were other reformers and entrepreneurs who were important.
At one point Mr. Kolt seemed to be promoting more aid for Moscow, saying that the Russians were asking the United States for $26 million to continue a privatization effort, an amount that would make "a key difference."
But he also called the problem of Russia and the other republics the biggest American security concern for decades to come, and noted the downside: the widespread crime and corruption, the absence of a concept of private property, a disunified currency system, the political infighting and the danger of hyperinflation. He said he believed there was a "possibility and a danger," but not a probability, that Russia itself would break up. If that happened, he added, it would create problems with nuclear security, could spawn wars on Russian territory and destabilize the region. It could "make Bosnia pale in comparison," he said.
