HEADLINE: Sales of U.S.-Built Vehicles Hit Highest Level in 2 Years

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built vehicles surged 24.6 percent in late January to their best level in two years, the nation's auto makers said today, confirming earlier indications of a recovering national economy.
Sales of domestically built cars from Jan. 21 through 31 rose 19.1 percent from the comparable period last year, to 215,493. Sales of domestically built light trucks, a category that includes mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups, rose 34.1 percent from a year earlier, to 140,716. There were nine selling days in the current period, compared with 10 selling days in last year's period. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of domestic car sales for the period was 7.6 million, up from 5.9 million in mid-January and 6.1 million a year earlier.
For the entire month, car sales rose 4.3 percent, and truck sales were up 22.5 percent from January 1992. The monthly results include the 9 major Japanese and 10 European auto makers that sell vehicles in the United States.
Theordor R. Cunningham, executive vice president for sales of the Chrysler Corporation, said the auto maker was pleased with consumer response to its new products. He noted that January marked the company's fifth consecutive monthly increase in car sales and 16th consecutive increase in light-truck sales.
Robert L. Rewey, vice president of sales operations for the Ford Motor Company, said Ford's factories will produce 20 percent more cars in the first quarter than in the comparable period last year. Other auto makers are also increasing production, insuring high employment rates and weekly income figures for auto workers and workers in supplier companies.
"Pent-up demand is a very real factor at this time," said Yale Gieszl, executive vice president of Toyota Motor Corporation's United States sales subsidiary. Sales of Toyota cars built domestically were up 2.8 percent in late January to 11,058. For the month, however, sales of Toyota cars dropped 3.2 percent, to 19,179.
Karen Radley, owner of Karen Radley Acura in Woodbridge, Va., said: "The last recession was the first time the Washington, D.C., area auto market suffered. But we're starting to see Democrats coming to town and buying new cars."
Hunter Perry, sales manager of the Mike Perry Motor Company in Nacogdoches, Tex., said, "A lot of people are financing who used to pay cash because the lending rates are so low." Mr. Perry said his biggest seller was the Chrysler mini-van.
 
Big 3 Stocks Are Up
 Ford sold a total of 103,889 cars and trucks in the late-January period, up 27.3 percent from a year earlier.
Ford's domestic car sales rose 26.7 percent to 58,487, while its light truck sales jumped 30.5 percent to 42,422. For the month, Ford's domestic car sales rose 18.5 percent to 127,742, and truck sales rose 15.8 percent to 95,013.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Ford shares closed up 62.5 cents yesterday, to $47.75.
General Motors sold 139,742 cars and trucks in the the period, up 13.4 percent. G.M.'s domestic car sales rose 10.1 percent to 89,735, while light-truck sales rose 27 percent, to 47,333.
The sales numbers helped lift G.M. shares yesterday to $1.75, to $39.125, despite the prospects that the company will report a record loss for 1992.
For the month, G.M.'s domestic car sales fell 0.9 percent to 181,623. Its truck sales rose 18.09 percent to 110,643.
 
Chrysler Sales Up 31.6%
 Chrysler's late January vehicle sales were estimated by Ward's Automotive Reports to be up 39.8 percent. The company does not report 10-day sales. Chrysler's actual monthly sales were up 31.6 percent.
Chrysler sold 55,041 domestic cars in January, an increase of 31.9 percent from a year earlier. Chrysler's domestic truck sales for the month also were up 31.9 percent to 82,551.
Chrysler shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to close at $39.
 
 
Japanese Brands
 Honda's car sales in late January were down 7.5 percent, to 18,586, compared with 22,315 a year earlier.
Isuzu truck sales rose to 3,178, up 86 percent from 1,898.
Mazda sold 3,525 cars, up 43.4 percent from 2.731, and 277 trucks, down 5.0 percent from 324.
Mitsubishi of America sold 2,278 cars, up 37.4 percent from 1,842.
Nissan sold 8,353 cars, more than double the 4,371 it sold a year earlier; truck sales were up 24.7 percent, to 4,184, compared with 3,728.
Subaru sold 1,571 cars, a 48.1 percent increase from 1,179.

HEADLINE: Most Big Concerns Post Gains in Quarter

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Fourth-quarter reports from nearly two-thirds of the nation's 500 largest companies show a strong rebound in profits, helping to support the stock market's brisk advance.
Based on announcements so far, Wall Street economists now expect the quarter's net earnings to nearly double the total from the last quarter of 1991. The 1991 net results, however, were severely depressed by one-time charges for layoffs and cutbacks, far greater than the write-offs taken in 1992. 
 Operating earnings, a more reliable guide to continuing performance, are up about 20 percent for the fourth quarter, economists say.
They expect profits to continue climbing through 1993, as companies that have already become more efficient benefit from a strengthening economy as well.
"You're getting the best part of the earnings cycle," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch. "Companies have been forced to cut their costs during the recession, and now they are on a productivity rampage."
 
At the Forefront
 Technology and banking companies have been among the strongest earners, a performance typical as a recovery gets going. These groups have also been at the forefront of the stock market's rise.
Among the leaders of these industries, Intel's quarterly income more than doubled in the fourth quarter of 1991. Citicorp went from a loss of 53 cents to a gain of 53 cents a share.
Improved earnings among cyclical and financial companies continued to flow yesterday, as 3M's earnings rose 12 percent and Allied-Signal's 20 percent. Salomon Inc. earned $1.10 a share after a loss of 41 cents.
Market strategists are divided, however, over how well stock prices incorporate the further improvements they expect. Many said that yesterday's rally, with the Dow gaining 45.12 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,373.79, was fueled by upbeat earnings reports and signs of economic strength.
 
Anticipated Income Improvement
 Mr. Steinberg said that most investors already anticipated continued earnings improvements in the 20 percent range. "Luckily, it looks like that will be forthcoming," he said. "If there's any shortfall, it's going to be problematic."
Some others say this year's earnings can propel the market substantially higher. Abby Joseph Cohen, a market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, said that based on predicted earnings and the current level of interest rates, stocks are 15 to 20 percent undervalued. With interest rates likely to remain stable, she sees the Standard & Poor's 500 producing a total return, including dividends, of 13 to 15 percent through the rest of the year.
The companies most likely to be left out of the earnings parade are those that do a lot of business overseas, especially in products vulnerable to foreign recessions, she said.
Foreign reversals account for some of I.B.M.'s record losses, and are one reason that Wall Street's outlook for Ford and General Motors is not as bright as for Chrysler, which does most of its business at home.
Using the net earnings that 326 of the S.& P. 500 have already reported, and analysts' estimates for the rest, Bloomberg Financial Services calculates that total earnings for this index will be $5.09, compared with $2.55 last year. These and other earnings totals usually do not include accounting charges for retiree benefits.
The earnings announced so far are a few percent behind analysts' estimates, which in most quarters are too optimistic.
Net earnings for the first two quarters of this year were stronger than in the final quarter, but the fourth quarter had greater one-time costs for cutbacks.

HEADLINE: Will Marriott Ever Stand Divided?

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Marriott Corporation's proposal in October to split the company in two has not only put at risk the squeaky clean reputation forged by three generations of close-knit Marriott family management. It has also provoked a lawsuit by bondholders that some analysts say could unravel the restructuring plan and hobble the hotelier.
"If they don't come up with a compromise position that satisfies bondholders, they would have to continue operating as one company," said Arthur Adler, a hotel consultant at Coopers & Lybrand. "That could adversely affect their ability to fund a whole range of initiatives that will make them a more profitable company -- everything from expansion to developing new computer systems." 
 While Marriott has been in talks with bondholders in recent months to make the restructuring more palatable and keep the dispute out of court, those negotiations broke down this week. Though talks may well reopen, the risk of a court fight to keep the company whole and Marriott's conviction to split it up makes this proposal among the riskiest undertakings in the $9.1 billion Bethesda, Md., company's 66 years, since J. Willard Marriott started with a root beer stand in Washington.
The object of the bondholders' criticism is a restructuring plan that would load most of the corporation's $2.9 billion debt (about $1.9 billion in bonds) onto the Host Marriott Corporation, a new company that would inherit the parent's vast real estate holdings. That includes 141 hotels that Marriott has been unable to sell in the current depressed real estate market and that cost it heavily in interest expenses. The other company, Marriott International Inc., will retain existing management contracts with some 750 hotels and motels and with 3,000 corporate and institutional cafeterias.
Marriott's 20-year bonds tumbled 30 percent after the plan was announced. Moody's Investors Service Inc. promptly downgraded its ratings on Marriott bonds, while the Standard & Poor's Corporation placed Marriott's debt on creditwatch for a possible downgrading.
And institutional bondholders, led by PPM America Inc., sued the company and three top officers, accusing them of securities fraud for selling $400 million worth of bonds last April and May without informing investors of intentions to split up the company. A separate class-action suit was filed on behalf of all Marriott bondholders.
"Marriott should have disclosed at an earlier date the fact they were contemplating the restructuring that would have the catastrophic consequences that eventually developed," said Lawrence Kill, a partner at Anderson, Kill, Olick & Oshinsky, which represents PPM, whose clients hold more than $120 million in Marriott bonds.
A Marriott spokesman, Robert T. Souers, said the split was needed "to continue our strategy of being a management company as opposed to a real estate ownership company." Marriott realized, he added, that with all that real estate on its hands, the company was being penalized by interest costs and by analysts' asking when it was going to sell the property.
If the companies were separated last year, Marriott International would have had sales of $7.4 billion and operating cash flow of $500 million, while Host Marriott would have had sales of $1.7 billion, and operating cash flow of $350 million -- much of which would have been eaten up by annual interest payments of about $225 million.
Curiously, most other hotel concerns have separated these functions. At the time of Marriott's proposal, its stock shot up from $17.125, to $21.875. It closed at $24.25 yesterday, up 37.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
Under the restructuring, shareholders would receive a special dividend of one new share of stock in Marriott International for each share they own in the Marriott Corporation, which will change its name to Host Marriott. The Marriott family owns 25.8 percent of the stock.
But bondholders say the restructuring makes them bear the burden of the company's mistakes.
 
A Building Boom
 Throughout most of the 1980's, Marriott built hotel after hotel, then sold or franchised them while retaining the management contracts, which have accounted for more than half of Marriott's revenues for the last decade.
"Hospitality companies thought they were being undervalued so the whole industry shifted from being owner operators to franchises or running management companies, which are cash flow businesses," said Steven A. Carvell, associate professor of finance at the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration.
Marriott pioneered that shift and became its most skillful player, with a return on equity of more than 20 percent in the 80's. But the 1986 tax revision law eliminated most real estate tax shelters, and Marriott was uncommonly slow to respond, according to some. "They were saddled by commitments and debt," Professor Carvell said. "And when you're that big sometimes you're a lumbering giant."
While analysts generally accept the Marriott rationale for splitting the company, one analyst who refused to speak for attribution suggested a possible additional motive:
"Host Marriott may have medium-term problems working themselves out of debt," he said, "so Marriott executives can say we'll pop this company into a Chapter 11 without affecting the larger company."
 
A Strong Denial
 Steven Bollenbach, Marriott's chief financial officer and the prime architect of the plan, categorically denied any such intention. "The strategic reason for this special dividend," he said, "is to separate the heavy capital business from the service business."
To make both companies economically viable, he said, Host will refinance properties and sell real estate -- although he said it might be five years before the market for hotels improves. Meantime, Marriott International will provide Host Marriott with a $600 million back-up credit line through 1997, if needed.
Beyond that, Host Marriott will be "by far" the biggest customer of Marriott International, Mr. Bollenbach said, accounting for about 20 percent of its management contract business. "You don't set up a deal where your biggest and best customer is designed to have financial trouble," he said. Moreover, Mr. Bollenbach will be president and chief executive of Host Marriott.
In their recent meetings, the bondholders were pushing Marriott to sell so-called targeted stock in each of the new companies. That is, Marriott would remain a single company responsible for all its bonds and would issue two series of stocks, one tied to the earnings and assets of Marrott's real estate holdings and the other to the hotel and services businesses.
"That way there would be one legal entity so the bonds would be the obligation of the holding company," said Ed Whiting, a vice president at Whitman Heffernan Rhein & Company, financial adviser to the PPM Group. He added that when the company first rejected that proposal, some weeks ago, "We continued to come to Marriott with new ideas and variations on the theme," but Marriott rejected them also.
 
Refining the Plan
 Nick Hill, a Marriott spokesman, said yesterday the company continues to talk to bondholders and to look at "refinements" that might make its restructuring plan more attractive.
Meanwhile, a hearing is scheduled on next Thursday in Federal District Court in Baltimore, at which the court is to rule on the bondholders' requests for documents from Marriott. Since the company agreed not to contest the requests, John Stark, the general counsel at PPM America, said lawyers for PPM will begin taking depositions soon afterwards, and PPM's suit will be ready to go to trial in April.

HEADLINE: Medical Trends Shake Prospects Of Drug Makers

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
After more than a decade of sharply rising prices for prescription drugs -- and profits to match -- fundamental changes in medical spending are clouding the prospects of pharmaceutical companies, which have long ranked among the most profitable and technologically innovative of corporations.
The outlook is battering the companies' stocks, long a favorite of investors, and many reached lows in trading yesterday before bouncing back with the market as the Dow Jones industrial average surged 45.12 points in a burst of economic optimism. [Page D1.] 
 The growing pressure on pharmaceutical prices is coming from cost-conscious large private purchasers like health maintenance organizations and mail-order suppliers that demand deep discounts. It is also coming from Congress and the Clinton Administration as they press for the Government to cap price increases for drugs for the first time.
Industry executives argue that if price controls result, research to develop new life-saving drugs could suffer for lack of financing.
The latest criticism from Washington came yesterday in a report by the Senate Committee on the Aging. It said that despite the promises of many drug companies to keep their prices from rising faster than inflation, 19 of the 31 largest manufacturers had increased prices in 1992 by more than double that rate.
Seven large drug companies, including Merck and Pfizer, had pledged to hold down price increases to no more than the general inflation rate. Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who heads the Committee on the Aging, and Senator William S. Cohen of Maine, the panel's ranking Republican, urged the Clinton Administration to include drug price restraints in its package of health-care legislation.
The changes in drug buying, which have been gathering momentum for more than a year, have soured the longstanding enthusiasm for the drug industry among Wall Street investors. Stock prices of seven of the 12 largest American drug companies fell to 13-month lows yesterday morning before rebounding later in the day in the strong market rally.
Securities analysts said the low share prices reflected investors' diminished expectations for continued robust growth in drug profits. The 12 companies, which include longtime favorites of investors like Merck & Company, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and Johnson & Johnson, have lost $87.33 billion in combined stock market value in the 13 months between Jan. 1, 1992, and Tuesday.
About one-third of the combined loss, $29.69 billion, took place this year. "It is a continuation of the awful times of 1992," said Neil B. Sweig, a pharmaceutical analyst with Capital Institutional Services, a stock brokerage firm. "We're in a sour state of events."
In the last 13 months, Merck has lost $20.36 billion in stock value, Bristol-Myers Squibb lost $15.57 billion and Johnson & Johnson $9.16 billion, according to a compilation by Mr. Sweig.
Since the beginning of 1992, while stock prices were soaring, drug stocks declined by more than 27 percent. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks increased 6.1 percent, on average, in the 13 months.
Pharmaceutical executives have long argued that drug price rises are essential to finance the development of important new drugs, which the industry contends may each cost more than $200 million to bring to market. Innovative drugs for cardiovascular and digestive tract diseases, for example, have helped millions of Americans to avert expensive surgery and related hospital costs, they say.
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a Washington trade group, contended that Senator Pryor, in an attack on manufacturers' pledges to contain drug price increases, had "distorted or misused" drug price reports by ignoring the lower prices paid by large health insurance plans. Rather, the Senator concentrated solely on prices at drugstores, which he said supplied most of the elderly.
The industry association said it "acknowledges the need for health-care cost containment." It told the Clinton transition team in December that a drug benefit should be part of any federally required basic health-care coverage for people under 65. The association added that it would be willing to discuss extending drug coverage to elderly Medicare beneficiaries, who are the main customers for the companies' products.
But analysts noted that the industry dismayed even many of its friends this week by objecting to a proposal by Clinton Administration officials to have the Government distribute vaccines without charge to all children. The industry spokesman said a Government program would make vaccines unprofitable and force the companies to curtail research for new ones.
Most securities analysts and stock fund managers are gloomy about the industry's prospects, at least for the next year or so. "Everybody's panicking out," said Barbara Ryan, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons. "The companies are on the chopping block in Washington. Everyone's fearful of what Washington will do."
Richard Vietor at Merrill Lynch Research said many drug companies were having difficulty adjusting to changes in buying practices. He noted that managed care organizations, which authorize health purchases of patients for large groups, had severely restricted the companies' ability to raise prices at will.
"The companies are like battleships that have entered stormy waters," he said. "They are finding it difficult to change course because the products they were depending on were conceived under rules of pricing flexibility that are no longer appropriate."

HEADLINE: Billing System For Hospitals Is Overturned

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
A ruling by a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday threatens to destroy New York State's delicate system of subsidizing hospital care for some patients.
The judge said the state was violating Federal law by adding an extra charge to hospital bills paid by some insurers and health maintenance organizations. That arrangement has benefited hospitals and nonprofit insurers like the Blue Cross-Blue Shield plans. 
 Hospitals throughout the state have received $160 million a year as a result of the system. And the embattled Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has benefited by paying hospital bills that are 24 percent lower than those paid by profit-making insurance companies.
Empire, whose financial woes have provoked an investigation by a United States Senate subcommittee, recently imposed rate increases of up to 20 percent on 1.4 million subscribers.
 
Threat to System
 Health-care experts say that yesterday's ruling could put New York on the same path as New Jersey, which lost a similar lawsuit last year and hastily had to patch together a new way of paying for indigent care and setting hospital rates. With New York's hospitals already pleading financial hardship, and some two million citizens with no health insurance, the result could be disastrous for New York as well, experts say.
"This is beginning to pull apart the foundation on which New York's hospital financing system is built," said Robert Jaffe, a lobbyist who represents New Yorkers for Accessible Health Care Coverage. "This is eventually going to unravel the system."
In his decision, which the state plans to appeal, Judge Louis J. Freeh of Federal District Court in Manhattan found that the hospitals' practice of tacking surcharges onto the hospital bills of commercial health insurers and health maintenance organizations violated the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known commonly as Erisa. Under the law, employee contributions to benefit funds can be used only for the "sole and exclusive benefit" of the workers and their families.
Judge Freeh found that the surcharges -- 24 percent for commercial insurance companies, and 9 percent for H.M.O.'s -- unfairly increased insurance costs for the benefit funds and used the employees' money for purposes that had never been intended. "In fact, it diverts a not-insignificant amount of these resources to a state-specified use which is unrelated to the health care of plan participants," Judge Freeh wrote.
The ruling does not in itself pull down the state's hospital financing system, but it begins to chip away at it. In a similar case pending in Federal Court in Brooklyn, a group of unions have challenged a different state surcharge using the same Erisa argument. In that case, the 5.5 percent is tacked on most hospital bills and raises $1.1 billion a year that is used to subsidize health care for people without insurance.
In the New Jersey case, the state's method of subsidizing indigent care through hospital surcharges was also declared illegal on the ground that it violated Erisa. As a result, New Jersey had to change drastically its hospital financing system by deregulating hospital rates, charging new health-care taxes, and raiding its own unemployment insurance fund to pay for indigent care.
In New York, the state is now trying to renegotiate the rates that hospitals can charge patients, and if it loses the Brooklyn case it may lose the ability to regulate hospital rates at all.
"It could very well mean reverting back to a system in which hospitals set their own prices," said Jeannie H. Cross, a spokeswoman for the Hospital Association of New York.
 
Law Faulted
 State officials responded to the ruling by criticizing the Erisa law.
"To the extent that Erisa limits the state's flexibility to devise ways to pay for care and subsidize the uninsured, it's a real problem for us," said Peter Slocum, a spokesman for the State Health Department. "This demonstrates the need for major reform at the national level."
Yesterday's ruling, if upheld, will have an immediate impact on the state's hospitals, which will lose the $160 million they take in every year on a 13 percent surcharge tacked on to the hospital bills paid by commercial insurance companies.
The state stands to lose, too, by missing out on expected revenues from two surcharges it imposed in order to close this year's budget gap. These are a 9 percent surcharge on H.M.O.'s, and an additional 11 percent surcharge on commercial insurers, bringing the total extra cost for commercial companies to 24 percent. All told, the state hoped to get $90 million from the surcharges.
The ruling also has immediate and potentially unfortunate implications for Empire Blue Cross and Shield, the state's largest insurer. Empire and the state's other Blue Cross plans do not pay the hospital-bill surcharges, and in fact are meant to benefit from them. If they are no longer able to pay charges that are 24 percent lower than those of the commercial insurers, the Blue Cross plans might well lose more customers to their competitors, officials said.
Commercial insurers praised the ruling yesterday. "Consumers for too long have had to subsidize Blue Cross," said Chris Petersen, senior counsel for the Health Insurance Association of America, one of the parties that sued the state. "No one business should be afforded a state-subsidized advantage over another business."
State officials said they worry about what would happen if New York loses the Brooklyn case as well.
"We have a very delicately balanced reimbursement system in this state," said Michael J. Dowling, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services. "We don't have an alternative other than what we're doing right now, which is appealing the case."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Broad Surge for the Dollar On Europe's Market Turmoil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar surged ahead again yesterday, gaining against all major currencies but the Japanese yen amid continued turmoil in European markets.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $329.30 an ounce, off $1.10 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold lost $1.05 an ounce, to a late bid price of $328.50. 
 Dealings were active in Europe, where the Danish krone fell to its lowest allowable level in the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. That prompted intervention by several central banks, including Germany's Bundesbank, to prop up the sagging currency.
Pressure on the European currencies has intensified since the weekend devaluation of the Irish pound. The nervousness increased ahead of today's scheduled meeting of the Bundesbank's policy-making council. Despite heavy speculation that they would cut interest rates, the finance ministers are not expected to take any dramatic action.
"The possibility of a Bundesbank easing just intensified the pressure on the European currencies," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA. High interest rates generally bolster a currency.
 
U.S. Data Help Dollar
 Aiding the dollar, more good news about the United States economy came from the nation's auto makers, which reported surprisingly strong sales for January.
One of the dollar's biggest gains came against the German mark when the dollar briefly surged past the 1.65-mark level, its highest exchange rate since last April. The dollar ended the day in New York at 1.6450 marks, up from 1.5405 marks on Tuesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.33 yen, down 0.65 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar fell to 124.30 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 124.38 yen, down from 124.69 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4350, from $1.4465 late Tuesday. The pound also hit a historic low of 2.3610 against the German mark amid reports of possible cuts in British interest rates. In New York, it cost $1.4340 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.4440.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5255 Swiss francs, up from 1.5210; 5.5750 French francs, up from 5.5495; 1,537.50 Italian lire, up from 1,522.00, and 1.2667 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2645.

HEADLINE: L.I. Protests U.S. Data-Gathering Change

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Nassau and Suffolk County Executives and the president of Long Island's largest business and civic group today urged the Federal Government to rescind a decision that would eliminate the Island as a separate statistical area in gathering Federal data.
At a news conference this morning, officials said the change could cost Nassau County $17 million in Federal money and would have a similar impact on Suffolk County, where figures were not yet available. They also added that the change could deter the Island's efforts to attract private businesses. 
 The dispute is a result of a decision in December by the Federal Office of Management and Budget to put Long Island, northern New Jersey and one county in Pennsylvania with New York City in the same "primary metropolitan statistical area." Officials said the new district could affect Federal aid because it would alter statistics like the median income and labor costs used in allocating Federal funds.
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said Nassau's largest potential loss would be $6 million in Community Development Block Grants. James L. LaRocca, president of the Long Island Association, the civic group that has spearheaded the campaign against the new district, said the issue is critical to the Island's economic growth.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mobil Promotes One of 3 in Race for Chief

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had named Lucio A. Noto president and chief operating officer. Analysts said the promotion was a signal that he was ahead in the race to succeed Allen E. Murray as chairman and chief executive next year, when Mr. Murray reaches the mandatory retirement age of 65.
Mr. Noto, 54, becomes the third New Yorker in a row to be president of the oil giant, which moved its headquarters from 42d Street in Manhattan to Fairfax, Va., three years ago. Mr. Murray, born in Queens, followed the Brooklyn-born William P. Tavoulareas in the job. 
 Mr. Noto, Mr. Murray and Mr. Tavoulareas, said Bernard J. Picchi, an oil analyst at Kidder, Peabody, "are gritty, hard-edged characters who didn't go to Oxford or Harvard; tough, street-smart kids with very independent personalities."
 
Two Others in Contention
 Also in the race to succeed Mr. Murray are Paul J. Hoenmans, 60, and Eugene A. Renna, 48. Mr. Hoenmans is executive vice president for exploration and production; Mr. Renna heads the refining and chemicals operations. They and Mr. Noto are directors and members of the board's executive committee.
Mr. Noto has been chief financial officer since 1989, but his 30-year career has covered many positions, with an emphasis on international experience, which has become increasingly important to global oil companies, especially Mobil.
Mr. Murray has been president and chief operating officer since succeeding Mr. Tavoulareas in 1984 and chairman and chief executive since 1986, when he replaced Rawleigh Warner Jr.
 
'In Much Better Shape'
 Mobil has reduced debt, slashed costs and expanded profitably in the Far East in the Murray era. "The company is in much better shape," said George F. Friesen, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital Group.
Mr. Noto headed Mobil's refining and petrochemical business in Saudi Arabia in the 1980's. In 1986 he became vice president for planning and economics at Mobil's former headquarters in New York.
Earlier in his career he was a marketing and planning executive in Italy and Japan. He graduated with a bachelor's degree in physics from the University of Notre Dame in 1959, and from Cornell University with an M.B.A. degree in 1962. He attended Regis High School in Manhattan.
Mobil's shares gained 37.5 cents yesterday, closing at $64.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Lumber Rally Continues In Face of Tight Supplies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A record-breaking rally in lumber continued yesterday as futures prices leaped the permitted daily limit for the eighth straight day on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Spruce 2-by-4's for March delivery rose $5, to $318.50 for 1,000 board feet. Lumber sold on the cash market for as much as $364 for 1,000 board feet as wholesalers continued to pay for tight supplies, said Curt Cunningham, president of Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. He said that mills in the Pacific Northwest and British Columbia were taking only enough orders each day to cover one day's production and that customers were waiting four weeks to have orders filled. 
 Lumber prices have climbed steadily since early November as signs of economic recovery have sent dealers scrambling for supplies reduced by logging bans in the Northwest.
Federal timber sales in the Northwest and California plunged 57 percent in the 1992 fiscal year, mainly as a result of a court-ordered halt to logging while timber interests and environmentalists fought over preserving ancient forests and the northern spotted owl. Those disputes are still unresolved.
 
State-Owned Timber Removed
 On Monday, the Washington State Board of Natural Resources announced it would remove 140 million board feet of state-owned timber from this year's sales list, further reducing the lumber supply.
"A major amount of timber has been removed from the public domain for cutting," said Ted Bloch, president of the Bloch Lumber Company, a Chicago wholesaler. "People have been talking about this now for four or five years and it was almost like the boy who cried wolf. But this year it's caught up and the wolf is in the sheep fold."
On other commodity markets, grains and soybeans were mostly higher, while livestock and meat futures were mixed. And oil prices finished little changed in quiet dealing on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Light sweet crude for March delivery fell 7 cents, to $19.93 a barrel; March heating oil rose 0.12 cent, to 55.98 cents a gallon; March unleaded gasoline fell 0.06 cent, to 55.85 cents a gallon, and March natural gas rose 1.4 cents, to $1.583 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING (N)

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that its strong fourth quarter was led by American sales that were the best in four years. The St. Paul-based diversified manufacturer said earnings rose 11.5 percent in the period, while sales rose 4.7 percent. It said weakness in Japan and Europe offset the strong sales in the United States and Latin America.
"In view of the slow economy in the U.S. and internationally last year, the company has done a good job, particularly since a lot of their products are in cyclical businesses," said Frank Rolfes, an analyst at Dain Bosworth in Minneapolis. 
 The company's memory technology group, which makes video and computer tapes, posted the weakest results, Mr. Rolfes said, noting that the unit "is struggling with price competition" with the Japanese and other producers in the United States.
The company said its life sciences sector, which makes health and safety products ranging from bandages to traffic control devices, had continued to do well. The company would not break out results for its units.
Last year, 3M took a previously announced charge of $140 million for plant restructurings and voluntary staff reductions. Earnings rose slightly for the full year.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Will Clinton halt or foster a drift toward trade protectionism?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
JUST where does Bill Clinton stand on free trade? If the President knows, he is not telling.
Mr. Clinton's refusal to be pinned down during the campaign was probably smart politics, allowing the self-styled New Democrat to hang onto union votes even as he was wooing Kmart shoppers who cared more about the price of blue jeans than their national origin. But smart campaigns do not necessarily make for smart government. 
 The interest coalition supporting open trade has never been overwhelmingly strong, and for a host of reasons the opposition is growing more formidable. Without a President deeply committed to liberal trade, there is scant hope of stopping the drift toward protectionism in everything from steel plate to memory chips to cellular phones.
The conventional wisdom is that enlightened governments in general -- and postwar Washington in particular -- have championed open trade because they understood it meant better, cheaper products for all. But Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology believes this standard story, in which the consumer is king, has got it all wrong.
In trade, he argues, governments represent parties with the most focused interests: domestic producers maximizing their markets. Trade has become freer because producers in each country get the point that they can export more only if they permit more imports -- and that the profits and jobs pie will be larger if they make concessions in order to gain concessions.
But increased trade inevitably creates losers as well as winners. And the political game of organizing exporters into an effective coalition requires motivation and skill.
This White House may prove to have the skill; while Mr. Clinton's foreign trade team is inexperienced, it does include some tough, determined negotiators. However the Administration's motivation to champion exporters at the expense of import-competing firms is in serious doubt.
For one thing, notes Robert Hormats of Goldman Sachs International, President Clinton will be asking businesses to pay more for health care, environmental cleanup and deficit reduction. In return, industry -- particularly older industries like autos and integrated steelmakers that are among the most vulnerable to both foreign competition and high-cost government mandates -- will undoubtedly demand protection on the trade front.
Mr. Hormats points out, moreover, that such special pleading will be particularly hard to resist because the big industrial economies are out of synch on economic growth. With America emerging from recession and both Europe and Japan heading in, America's trade deficit is almost certain to rise -- and with it, Congressional calls for protectionism. Consider, too, higher unemployment abroad, which will fuel protectionist sentiments, particularly in Europe.
Wait, it gets worse. Years of sluggish growth worldwide have left virtually every heavy industry with excess capacity. And James Bovard, the author of "The Fair Trade Fraud" (St. Martin's Press), notes that the way trade laws are written in both America and Europe makes it illegal for foreigners to sell goods at prices dictated by free market competition.
In cyclical industries with high overhead like steel or autos, it pays to keep pushing out the product as long as variable costs -- labor, raw materials -- are covered. The idea, or at least the hope, is to keep production moving, covering losses in hard times with fat margins at the boom end of the cycle.
But "anti-dumping" statutes require that prices charged by foreigners represent at least "fair value," defined as fully allocated costs plus a healthy profit. Thus price-cutting, which is both normal and, from economists' perspective, desirable for domestic producers, is against the law for foreign competitors. And in recent years, Mr. Bovard argues, Commerce Department bureaucrats have been enforcing the statute with a vengeance.
In the dumping decision announced last week, steel from 19 countries was judged to be selling at an average of 27 percent below cost. But look closely, Mr. Bovard says, and it is plain that the judgment was arbitrary: Where foreign producers could not or would not provide truckloads of cost data on demand, the Commerce Department typically took the domestic industry's own estimates as the "best information available." In the case of MEI, the hapless Romanian steel exporter, data that arrived by mail from Bucharest a week past deadline were ignored.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, likens trade liberalization to a bicycle that "will topple, absent continued forward motion." For Mr. Bergsten that means, at very least, a bold effort to generate a "mini-package" of reforms at the Uruguay Round trade talks before all momentum is lost in the spring. The toughest issues could be left for a "Clinton Round," with the explicit threat that America would pursue separate regional negotiations with Pacific Rim countries if Europe balked at speedy settlement.
All this assumes, of course, that Mr. Clinton cares enough about open trade to invest political capital in its pursuit. He may not have much time to make up his mind.

HEADLINE: Ballet Theater Reduces Work Time

 BODY:
The dancers and management of American Ballet Theater reached an agreement yesterday to reduce the performers' guaranteed work weeks from 36 to 26 this year. The dancers have also agreed to extend their current contract, which runs through Oct. 31, for another year without wage increases.
The unusual agreement, part of a larger stabilization plan, is expected to save Ballet Theater $2 million in the next two years. Management and the dancers have also agreed to negotiate the number of guaranteed work weeks if similar reductions appear necessary for the 1994 season. 
 The dancers will continue to receive supplemental unemployment benefits provided by the company, under the terms of their contract, during the weeks they are not working. In a statement yesterday afternoon, the negotiating committee representing the company's 70 dancers said: "The dancers of American Ballet Theater are committed to working with the new directors of the company, and by maintaining an ongoing dialogue with them, will work together to preserve one of America's national treasures."
Gary Dunning, executive director of Ballet Theater, said: "This agreement is indicative of a tremendous spirit of cooperation, innovation and sacrifice that has pervaded the company over the past several months. I am deeply grateful to the dancers, their negotiating committee and A.G.M.A. for recognizing the needs of the company and assuming crucial leadership positions." A.G.M.A. is the American Guild of Musical Artists, the dancers' union.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SHAWMUT LIKELY TO RESTORE DIVIDEND IN 1993

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The Shawmut National Corporation said yesterday that it would probably restore its common dividend in the middle of this year. The Boston-based bank holding company omitted its quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share in October 1990 and 1991 when its results were hurt by the New England recession and souring real estate loans. It has 311 branches in New England states. A Shawmut spokesman said the bank agreed with analysts' 1993 earnings estimates of between $1.40 and $1.55 a share, compared with 81 cents a share in 1992. Shawmut shares were up 50 cents, to $20.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, after hitting a new 52-week high of $21.25.

HEADLINE: Head Off A Trade War

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk; Leonard Silk is a former economics columnist of The New York Times.

 BODY:
Fears are spreading that the Clinton Administration is moving toward a trade policy so aggressive as to unleash protectionism and a trade war among the major industrial countries. During the campaign, Mr. Clinton was ambiguous about what trade policy he would pursue. On one side, he proclaimed support for an open world economy based on free-trade principles; on the other, he courted business and labor by promising a highly aggressive campaign against foreign countries and companies accused of wiping out American jobs.
Mr. Clinton and his aides now seem to have come down on the aggressive side. The Administration has threatened to block sales to the Government of European telecommunications and power-generation equipment and a wide array of services, charging that the European Community has run a buy-Europe policy against American products. His Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, declared that the U.S. might withdraw from the government-procurement code of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 Has Mr. Clinton crossed the Rubicon -- or is this just a get-tough threat to get the Europeans and Japanese back to serious bargaining on measures to open markets? Some economists who advised him during the campaign say they are not sure if he is bluffing. But Mr. Clinton's advisers, including those in the Administration, are split into two camps: one urging essentially free trade, the other managed trade, aimed at opening markets abroad with threats of retaliation if foreign governments will not yield. The core of managed trade would be commitments by nations to accept certain proportions of imports in their domestic markets.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, new chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, contends that managed trade, not free trade, is the only viable alternative in the real world to protectionism.
But while Mr. Clinton stays remarkably silent on the trade issue, many American industries are seizing what they see as an opportunity to push on an open door for Federal protection or trade relief. Pressures are rising from producers of steel, autos, oil, semiconductors, weapons, movies, textiles and apparel.
Mr. Clinton is running out of time to make up his mind. Producers' demands will drive him to protectionism, which will spread as foreign countries retaliate, as they have already started to do. If he intends to hold to his general endorsement of an open world trade policy, he must act now to block protectionist demands.
How can he do so? By declaring that he will press to bring the Uruguay Round talks of GATT to a successful end, and then moving to strengthen GATT as an instrument for freer trade and investment for all nations.
Protectionism feeds on world recession, sluggish growth and unemployment. Mr. Clinton must go for growth, abroad as well as at home. This means acting immediately to gain the cooperation, not the hostility that will stem from a beggar-my-neighbor trade policy, of U.S. trading partners, including Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Mexico.
Expansion by the industrial countries is crucial to nourish growth in the rest of the world -- and provide markets and resources to prevent the economic and political disasters threatening the third world and ex-Soviet empire. Flirting with protectionism is flirting with a world catastrophe.
The U.S. should take the lead in building a more open global economic system. The next and more difficult stage will require that other nations address the internal regulations, monopolistic practices and structural differences that are now the principal impediments to the expansion of trade and investment.
But if others, Japan and Germany most of all, do not lend greater support to a U.S. effort to strengthen the world trading system, protectionist pressures will intensify and the only alternative may be a highly inefficient form of managed trade, in which national power rather than economic choice will determine, and distort, trade -- to the harm of consumers and producers everywhere.

HEADLINE: Amtrak Gains Accord for Wide Use of Fast Trains

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Clearing an important obstacle to the development of high-speed rail travel outside the Northeast, the nation's freight railroads agreed today to let Amtrak use fast European trains on their tracks.
Under the agreement, Amtrak plans to guarantee that the freight lines will be indemnified against liability for accidents involving its trains, said W. Graham Claytor Jr., president of Amtrak, the national passenger railroad corporation. 
 The freight lines had cited safety concerns and legal liability in their refusal to allow high-speed trains on their tracks. The freight carriers own almost all of the track outside the Boston-Washington corridor.
Amtrak is now testing a Swedish-built train, the X-2000, with a top speed of 155 miles an hour, between New York and Washington. It plans to begin regular high-speed train service on its own tracks between Washington and Boston in 1997.
With today's agreement, Amtrak said it would now consider high-speed service between New York and Buffalo; Miami, Orlando and Tampa, Fla.; Washington, Richmond and Charlotte, N.C.; ; Chicago and Detroit; Milwaukee and St. Louis; San Diego, San Francisco and Sacramento, Calif., and Eugene, Ore., Seattle and Vancouver.
"We're talking about corridors, mostly under 300 miles," Mr. Claytor said. "Eventually the corridors can be joined."
Amtrak would ask Congress and state transportation officials to provide money for improving signal systems and tracks and the elimination of grade crossings, he said.
Mr. Claytor said that the mechanism for indemnification of the freight carriers against damages was unsettled and that such a move could require Congressional action.
Edwin L. Harper, president of the Association of American Railroads, whose members haul more than 90 percent of the nation's freight, made it clear that indemnification was the price of the agreement.
"We believe that if privately owned rail freight rights-of-way are to be used by new passenger operations, then the private owners should be indemnified and insured against any and all financial liability arising from accidents affecting passenger services," Mr. Harper said at a joint news conference with Mr. Claytor.
While the indemnification agreement eliminates an important practical obstacle, it is still not clear whether there would be enough passenger demand for high-speed train service to make it economically feasible.
Amtrak breaks even on the Washington-New York route, where it serves more than 40 percent of those traveling between the two cities. The benefits are considered social rather than economic: relieving traffic congestion, highway accidents and air pollution.
Mr. Harper noted that European countries subsidize their passenger rail services and added, "In fact, there are no profitable rail passenger systems in the world."
As part of its plans for the New York-Boston run, Amtrak plans to electrify the rail line between New Haven and Boston. It expects to reduce traveling time on the 231-mile Washington-New York trip to a little over two hours from just under three hours, and the New York-to-Boston time to under three hours from the current four hours.
In addition to the X-2000, Mr. Claytor said Amtrak this summer planned to test the German Inter City Express, with a top speed of 185 miles an hour, on its Northeastern tracks. One or both trains will be selected for the Northeast corridor, Mr. Claytor said, and can now be considered for other routes, too.
The trains will be built in the United States, he said. ABB, the Swedish conglomerate that manufactures the X-2000, has a train operation in Elmira, N.Y., and Siemens, which makes the German train, has many factories in the United States but none that make trains.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS PASSES MEASURE PROVIDING EMERGENCY LEAVES

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Congress gave President Clinton his first legislative victory tonight, passing the family-leave bill to guarantee workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for medical emergencies.
The Senate passed the bill 71 to 27, and the House followed on a 247 to 152 vote, just minutes before midnight. 
 Mr. Clinton plans to sign the bill on Friday morning to make the political point that domestic legislation, stalemated during the Bush Administration, would now pour forth because Democrats control both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue.
The House, which passed a similar bill late Wednesday night, had to take a second vote because the Senate version included a statement about homosexuals in the military.
 
Parts of Compromise
 That statement is a bland declaration backing two elements of the compromise between Mr. Clinton and Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, on the President's proposal to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military.
It endorses Mr. Clinton's order to the Defense Department last week to study the issue and its implications, and it directs the Senate panel to hold hearings on the issue, which Senator Nunn had already announced he would do. But it lets stand the President's decision to stop asking prospective recruits whether they are homosexuals.
 
Vetoed Twice by Bush
 The family-leave bill was vetoed twice by President George Bush, who said it would impose unnecessary costs on businesses. It would require employers to give workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to deal with birth, adoption or a serious illness affecting themselves or members of their immediate families. Employers would have to maintain health insurance coverage.
In Dade County, Fla., the first municipality in the country to pass a measure that most closely resembles the Federal bill, many of the 2,500 businesses covered by the law say it is less expensive than anticipated and actually increases worker satisfaction and productivity. [Page A14.]
The Federal bill, which would cover employees of companies with 50 or more workers as well as Federal, state and local government employees, embraces about half of the nation's work force. It would take effect six months after it is signed by the President.
Vice President Gore, who presided over the Senate as the bill was passed, said of the vote, "The Congress has shown courage and foresight," adding: "We are seeing in just two weeks what a difference Bill Clinton makes. American families will no longer have to choose between their families and their jobs."
In another Democratic effort to show the party could enact bills Mr. Bush had thwarted, the House passed a measure directing the states to make it easier to register to vote by offering registration in many public buildings, including motor vehicle and welfare offices. .
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Democrat from Connecticut who has been the chief sponsor of the family-leave bill since 1985, said: "This has been a long time coming. I'm very gratified we have a President who will sign it. Hopefully, we'll now move on to more issues involving people: jobs, the economy, health care and families."
Some critics of the family-leave bill have insisted it would hurt small business. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said: "We have no idea how much it will cost business. We are talking about tens of thousands of jobs being lost or not created because of this bill."
On a local level, he said, 71 companies in Kansas have exactly 50 employees. He predicted that many would dismiss a single employee to avoid the requirement.
 
Subject of Debate
 But little of today's debate actually concerned the leave bill. Because it was the first legislative business of the year in the Senate, a bill the Administration badly wanted, and was the first to come up after last week's disputes about homosexuals in the armed forces, Republicans made it a target for their unhappiness with Mr. Clinton's intention to end the ban.
The statement on homosexuals in the military was adopted as a substitute for a Republican proposal to prohibit any changes in the military's ban. The proposed Republican amendment, killed on a 62-to-37 vote, to the family-leave bill would have required the military to continue questioning recruits on sexual orientation.
"It is clear that President Clinton has already made up his mind," Mr. Dole said. "And he has already acted without Congressional approval. I am convinced that he will continue down this road, regardless of the evidence, regardless of outcome of hearings, and against the advice of our military leaders."
And he insisted that any vote against his amendment "is a vote to put homosexuals in our military."
Senator Dan Coats of Indiana, who led the Republican attack, contended that admitting homosexuals would severely damage the morale of the armed forces. He said sex was a "tension-creating, conflict-creating element that destroys morale." The problem could be overcome, he said, by separating men and women in the services. But no such separation was possible between heterosexual and and homosexual soldiers, he said.
 
Effect on Morale
 Senator Bob Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, said Mr. Clinton had chosen a "course which jeopardizes the readiness and morale of the Armed Forces."
The argument that defeated the Dole proposal was pushed by Senators Nunn and George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader. They contended that Mr. Clinton's agreement to defer most changes in policy until July would give the Senate and the armed forces the time to study the issue carefully.
But just as the Senate heard from outright opponents of admitting homosexuals, it heard from advocates.
Two Marine veterans, Senators John Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, argued for including homosexuals. Senator Chafee said it was absurd to think that homosexuals would flood into the armed services, but he added that the military should adapt "or get out."
 
Question of Civil Rights
 Senator Carol Moseley Braun, an Illinois Democrat, said: "The simple truth is this debate is not about military capability at all. It is about irrational fears and prejudices. It is about civil rights and leadership in a Democratic society."
Saying the issue was similar to the exclusion of blacks from the Navy in World War II, she quoted a 1942 Navy memorandum that said: "Men on board ship live in particularly close association. In their messes one man sits beside another; their hammocks or bunks are close together.
"How many white men would choose, of their own accord, that their close associates in sleeping quarters, at mess and in a gun's crew should be of another race?"

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Family Leave: Highlights of the Act"
 
Employees's Provisions
 Allows a worker to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave in any 12-month period for the birth of a child or an adoption, to care for a child, spouse or parent with a serious health condition or for the worker's own serious health condition that makes it impossible to perform a job.
 Provides that an employee must be returned to their old job or an equivalent position upon returning to work.
 Requires an employer to keep providing health care benefits during the leave, as though the worker were still employed, but does not require the worker on leave.
 Prohibits a worker on leave from collecting unemployment or other Government compensation.
 Covers only a worker who has been employed for at least one year and for at least 1,250 hours (25 hours a week).
 
Employer's Provisions
 Exempts any company with less than 50 workers.
 Allows a company to deny leave to a salaried employee within the highest-paid 10 percent of its work force, if letting the worker take the leave would create "substantial and grievous injury" to the business operations.
 Permits an employer to obtain medical opinions and certifications on the need for the leave.
 Allows an employer to ask the employee to repay the health-care premiums paid by the employer during the leave if the employee does not return to work. (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeking Negotiated Path To Bosnia Pact

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has set aside for now the use of military force to resolve the Balkan crisis and is preparing instead a diplomatic effort to modify the peace plan for Bosnia to make it acceptable to the Muslims, Administration officials said today.
The officials declined to specify what changes they would seek in the partition of Bosnian territory envisioned by the current plan, fashioned in recent months by former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, a former British Foreign Secretary, under the authority of the United Nations and the European Community. Washington has refused to endorse the plan because it sees it as unfair to the Bosnian Muslims. 
 Mr. Clinton spoke during the recent presidential campaign about possibly using military force, including bombing Serbian targets if necessary, to relieve Bosnia, suggesting that President Bush had been timid in his approach on the Balkan war.
But for now his Administration appears to have rejected such options as it has confronted the complexities of the Bosnian situation and the actual prospect of ordering military intervention, and as the parties themselves have stepped up discussions of a peaceful settlement in recent weeks.
The officials said that the Clinton Administration does not have a map of its own that it would like to see put into effect in Bosnia, but will support any outcome that all the parties can live with. That, however, effectively dictates an American diplomatic initiative that pressures the Serbs to give more territory to the Muslims than now provided in the plan, while making sure that the appetite of the Muslims does not grow out of proportion, the officials indicated.
This diplomatic initiative by the Administration will likely be combined with a stepped-up humanitarian relief program for Bosnia and Herzegovina, the officials said. But the President's advisers still have not decided how big the increase in aid would be, or how they would get it into Sarajevo and other besieged towns.
While the Administration officials insist they are not ruling out the use of force, they acknowledge that for various domestic and international reasons it is not really an option at this time.
 
Meeting at White House
 The President's top national security advisers crystallized the plan at a three-and-a-half hour session in the White House on Wednesday and presented what they called their combined humanitarian-diplomatic initiative to Mr. Clinton. The President has yet to give his formal approval to the effort, although it seemed likely that he would do so, the officials said.
The meeting of Mr. Clinton's advisers was called as pressure mounted on the Administration to produce its own policy on the Bosnian crisis.
Administration officials acknowledged that they hade no "silver bullet," as one official put it, to resolve the Bosnian crisis. The emerging Clinton approach, which is expected to be made final and announced shortly, is viewed by officials as the best they can come up with given the fact that Russia is unwilling to tolerate any military moves against Serbia, that the European allies have lined up behind the peace plan designed by Lord Owen and Mr. Vance, and that the Pentagon is reluctant to get involved militarily.
Lord Owen has accused the Administration of rejecting the settlement without having an alternative, saying that the plan is "the best settlement you can get."
The peace plan would create 10 autonomous provinces in Bosnia and Herzegovina and establish guarantees for the protection of minority groups within each. Proponents argue that, far from rewarding the Serbs, it would require Serbian forces to withdraw from substantial areas.
The plan has won the full endorsement only of the Croatian side in the war. The Serbian side has accepted the concept of dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina into autonomous regions but wants the map redrawn more to its liking. The Muslims object to the plan altogether, saying it would dismember the country of Bosnia and Herzegovina and reward the Serbs for their "ethnic cleansing" campaign, under which thousands of Muslims have been killed and many others expelled.
The Clinton Administration has been on the defensive all week for the way in which it has distanced itself from the Vance-Owen initiative, without having an alternative ready. Administration officials are now trying to signal that they do have an alternative in the making, while appealing for time to complete it properly.
"In Bosnia, we've inherited one of the most difficult foreign policy problems that can be imagined, I think one of the most difficult that I've ever known," Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher told reporters today.
 
'The Hard Questions'
 "I make no apologies for the fact that we're taking time to ask the hard questions, sometimes unpleasant questions, in order to determine the fairness and feasibility of the plan put forward by Mr. Vance and Lord Owen," he added. "I think the American people want us to ask those tough and searching questions."
That was not the theme that Mr. Clinton articulated during the campaign, when he lambasted Mr. Bush for not being more aggressive in coming to the aide of the Bosnians, by military means if necessary. But, as in many other areas, the Administration is now discovering the difference between campaigning and governing.
The Administration officials said that Mr. Clinton has no intention of trying to impose an American-modified version of the Vance-Owen plan on the warring factions. It will instead try to use a combination of economic and diplomatic carrots and sticks to try to encourage the parties themselves to agree to an arrangement that will be satisfactory to all.
"We don't modify it," said one policy maker. "The parties modify it, and we use our diplomacy to support that process."
The Clinton Administration has taken the view that Vance-Owen initiative is impractical, unenforceable and rewards ethnic cleansing. Mr. Clinton believes, aides said, that the United Nations should not impose a diplomatic settlement on the victim, just because the aggressor has agreed to it.
Secretary Christopher has been in touch with all the parties and the United Nations in an effort to determine how the United States can use its influence to modify the Vance-Owen plan. Administration officials feel that they have some leverage to exercise on the Serbs and others by threatening to withhold American diplomatic recognition or foreign aid, or threatening war crimes tribunals, among other things.

HEADLINE: Clinton Chooses New York Judge For Justice Post

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton has settled on Kimba M. Wood, a Federal District judge in New York, as his nominee for Attorney General but will not announce her selection until background checks are completed, Administration officials said today.
With the White House still stung by Mr. Clinton's embarrassing withdrawal of his first nominee for the job, Zoe Baird, after she admitted hiring illegal immigrants for household work, officials said the selection process was moving with extreme caution. 
 In contrast to the Baird nomination, which was hastily made and known only to a small circle of advisers until two days before it was announced, the White House seemed to be putting out Judge Wood's name to test public reaction and insure that no damaging disclosures surfaced before officially nominating her.
 
Backup Candidates
 The officials left open the possibility that if the background inquiries led to questions about Judge Wood's qualifications or political viability as a nominee, the President was ready to shift to another candidate. These officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the backup choices are Charles F. C. Ruff, a Washington lawyer who is a former senior Justice Department official and is also a leading contender for deputy Attorney General under Judge Wood, and former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia, who has known Mr. Clinton from their days on the Democratic Leadership Council.
Judge Wood, 49, was appointed to the court by President Ronald Reagan in 1988 at the request of Senator Alfonse D'Amato, the New York Republican, although she described herself at the time as a moderate Democrat. Her most noted decision was the 10-year prison sentence she imposed on Michael R. Milken, the financier at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. who had pleaded guilty to securities fraud. She later reduced the sentence, which gave her a reputation for toughness, to 2 years after prosecutors said he had cooperated with the Government.
While Judge Wood has not produced any opinions considered to be landmarks, she has written some creative and unusual decisions, legal experts say. She ruled last year that an advertising agency for the Wilkinson Sword Inc. was jointly liable with the company when it falsely claimed that its Ultra Glide razor was better than Gillette's Atra Plus Blades.
White House officials said Judge Wood impressed Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, in separate interviews last week and that Mrs. Clinton has insisted that a woman be selected for the job.
 
No Date for Announcement
 If Judge Wood is ruled out after the background check, the officials said, Mr. Clinton will turn to a man of high stature in legal or political circles. Both Mr. Ruff and Mr. Baliles are said to meet that requirement.
Judge Wood, who was raised in a military family, earned her law degree at Harvard University. She is married to Michael Kramer, a political columnist for Time magazine, and they have a 6-year-old son, Ben.
White House officials said aides today began reviewing Judge Wood's opinions and personal history and that an announcement could come any day, depending on when the background checks are completed.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said there was not a definite day set for the announcement, and he denied that Mr. Clinton was being driven by pressure to select a woman.
"The President is going to make an announcement soon, I hope," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "I don't know the exact timing. I expect it will be within several days, but he will pick the best person in his judgment for the job."
 
Support in New York Supporters
 Judge Wood's backers in the White House are notably different from those of Ms. Baird, a corporate lawyer who was backed by a circle of Washington insiders and Secretary of State Warren Christopher. The person Mr. Clinton initially had in mind for the job also had strong Washington connections: Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Judge Wood is said to be well regarded by White House advisers from New York: Bernard W. Nussbaum, the chief counsel; Robert E. Rubin, head of the National Economic Council, and Susan Thomases, a New York lawyer who is close to the Clintons.
Ms. Thomases said in a telephone interview today that she had enormous respect for Judge Wood. "She is one of the most disciplined, most thoughtful people I've known since college," Ms. Thomases said, "but she is not a personal friend." She said she had not brought her to the Clintons' attention but had told them that if Judge Wood becomes the nominee "I will do everything I can to help her" get through the nomination process.
At first blush, Judge Wood, whose benefactor was Senator D'Amato, would not be a likely choice for Attorney General in a Democratic Administration. Before her appointment to the bench, Judge Wood had no experience with criminal cases and had never conducted a trial before a jury. Her specialty was antitrust law, which she practiced at the New York firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae for 17 years. And she has virtually no administrative experience.
But Judge Wood is well regarded by colleagues on the court, and other female judges and lawyers often seek her guidance.
Among Judge Wood's opinions are some that legal experts consider creative and unusual. In a case involving charges of embezzlement, Judge Wood froze the assets of the defendant and then released enough money for him to appeal her order after recognizing she might have been in error. The order was ultimately upheld.
As a lawyer, one of her biggest cases involved defending underwriters and brokers of Lloyd's of London in an investigation by five state Attorneys General who were examining whether the insurers had colluded to raise premiums and make some policies unavailable.
Judge Wood's initial 10-year sentence of Mr. Milken was the most severe imposed in any of the Wall Street corruption cases that came to light with the confessions of Ivan F. Boesky.
Laurence H. Tribe, a law professor at Harvard University who was a legal consultant to Mr. Milken, said Judge Wood's performance in that case demonstrated her capacity for management. "She was highly innovative and imaginative," he said, "and she was creative in boiling down a very chaotic situation."
