HEADLINE: G.M. IS HELD LIABLE OVER FUEL TANKS IN PICKUP TRUCKS

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 4

 BODY:
A state court jury today held the General Motors Corporation responsible for the death of a Georgia teen-ager in the fiery crash of one of its pickups, finding that the company had known that the trucks had a defective fuel-tank design but that it had failed to correct the problem. The case has been closely watched by the car industry and safety experts.
Already reeling from more than $10 billion in losses in the last seven quarters and the resignation last year of its chairman, Robert C. Stempel, G.M. now faces negative publicity and possible economic fallout from the Georgia case. A former G.M. safety expert testified at the trial that the company had intentionally misled the public about a dangerous safety problem.
 
Besieged by Problems
 G.M.'s stock closed today at $37.75, down $1.375, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained almost 43 points. The news of the jury's award came a day after the auto maker announced disappointing January car sales and saw its credit rating lowered because of huge pension obligations. 
 The jury awarded $105.2 million to Thomas and Elaine Moseley of suburban Atlanta, whose 17-year-old son Shannon burned to death in a 1989 accident in which his 1985 GMC Sierra pickup burst into flames when it was struck from the side. Jurors awarded $4.2 million in actual damages and $101 million in punitive damages.
 
Federal Decision Pending
 Large jury awards are often reduced on appeal, and under Georgia law, trial judges have the authority to reduce or raise jury awards. If upheld, it would be the largest judgment in the history of the auto industry. Judge A. L. Thompson, who presided over the trial, did not say whether he would adjust the award.
The verdict, involving a gas-tank design that has already generated more than 130 other lawsuits, comes as the Federal Government is considering ordering the recall of 4.7 million pickups produced by General Motors between 1973 and 1987.
 
G.M. Denies Defect
 The company said in a statement today that the jury had been swayed by the emotionally charged nature of a case in which a family suffered "a terrible and tragic loss." But the company said it stood behind the safety of the trucks.
"Despite this decision, General Motors remains confident that a full examination by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of the technical issues in this matter will bear out our contention that the 1973-1987 full-size pickup trucks do not have a safety-related defect," the company said in its statement. General Motors said late today that it would appeal the verdict.
Fighting back tears after the jury's verdict was announced, Mr. Moseley said of the verdict: "It's achieved our purpose. We've given a statement to G.M. and the Government. It's for everybody out there -- people I don't know, the son I did know."
Critics say more than 200 people have died in full-sized Chevrolet and GMC pickups made between 1973 and 1987 because the trucks had side-mounted fuel tanks outside the truck frame, allowing them to rupture when the vehicles were struck on the side.
Six previous lawsuits involving the G.M. pickups have gone to trial, said Ed Lechtzin, a company spokesman. G.M. has won three, and plaintiffs have won three, he said, adding that some other cases had been settled out of court.
This case drew extraordinary attention for these three reasons:
*It produced by far the most internal documents from G.M.
*A former G.M. safety engineer, Ronald E. Elwell, provided damaging testimony when he told the jury that the company had intentionally hidden its knowledge of a dangerous safety defect.
*It was the first case to come to trial since the beginning of the Federal inquiry that could lead to the recall.
 
'They Must Recall Them'
 "I think the jury today sent a clear message to General Motors that the cover-up on these defective pickups is over and that they must recall them," said Clarence Ditlow, executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, an advocacy group in Washington that called last year for the recall of the trucks. "It's inevitable that these trucks will be recalled."
Tim Hurd, a spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said the verdict will not have a bearing on the investigation it began Dec. 8 into the gas-tank design.
But critics of the company said the trial had produced crucial evidence that the trucks are unsafe, and jurors agreed.
"I hope they'll read this verdict and make it right," John Dale, a juror, said of the Federal investigators. "They need to recall the trucks."
G.M. has said a recall would cost more than $1 billion. Mr. Ditlow said that the company was using an inflated figure as an argument against a recall, and that the real cost would be more like $300 million. Even so, he said, the costs of a possible recall and pending lawsuits would make the design the most costly defect in the history of the auto industry.
 
'More Will Burn'
 The ruling against the company capped an embarrassing and damaging case for G.M. The company changed lawyers shortly before the case went to trial; it had to contend with damaging testimony from Mr. Elwell, whom the company had used as its own expert in the past; and, in a vain attempt to salvage the case, it brought out as a witness Mr. Stempel, who recently resigned in the wake of the company's devastating losses.
The Moseleys' lawyers, James Butler Jr. and Robert Cheeley, argued that Shannon Moseley had burned to death because of a faulty fuel-tank design and that jurors should punish the company so severely that Federal regulators would feel compelled to order a recall that would prevent any more accidents.
"More will burn," Mr. Butler told jurors in his closing argument on Monday. "More will die unless something is done about this."
Fred Bartlit, a lawyer for G.M., tried to prove in a largely technical defense that Shannon Moseley had died instantly in the collision, which he said occurred at such a high speed that the teen-ager's death could not be attributed to the truck's design.
The company changed the design in 1988, moving the tank inside the frame, but has said it did so for design, rather than safety reasons. Critics say the change it made was not adequate to protect against fires.
"We all feel desperately sorry for the Moseleys," Mr. Bartlit said in his final argument. "We all want to help. But testimony that is inconsistent with the laws of nature cannot help."
As the case unfolded, the Moseleys refused G.M.'s offers to settle, insisting that it go to trial. Much of the most compelling testimony came from Mr. Elwell, who had testified in more than 15 previous cases that the pickups were safe. Switching sides in this case, he testified that G.M. had known for years that the "sidesaddle" design was defective but had refused to fix it for fear of alerting the public.
He said the company withheld crash-test data from him until 1983, but also said that out of fear of losing his job, he had continued to defend the company until 1989.
Defense lawyers first tried to block his testimony, and, to question his credibility, used his admission that he had testified on behalf of a design he believed was unsafe. Company officials sought to paint Mr. Elwell as a disgruntled employee who had sued the company last year in an employment dispute and was now seeking revenge.
The jury also heard the testimony of Mr. Stempel, who resigned last year as G.M.'s chairman. He said he believed the pickups were safe, but he acknowledged that the trucks' rate of fire deaths in side collisions was higher than the rates for competitors' vehicles.
The jury also viewed videotapes of General Motors' own crash tests between 1981 and 1983. In the tests, a pickup was struck in the side by another vehicle moving at 50 miles per hour. In virtually every case, the pickup's fuel tank broke open.
The company said the tests had been run as a part of an overall effort to improve the fuel safety of its vehicles. But Mr. Elwell insisted that company officials, concerned about growing pickup litigation, had begun a rush program because they had known the pickups were "no longer defensible."
 
Negative Publicity Feared
 Industry analysts said the negative publicity from the case could be as damaging as the actual costs at a time when G.M. was trying to recover from last year's losses and management problems.
"The important question in the long run is the issue of public relations, because G.M. is in the process of rebuilding its image after many years of being in an unfavorable light," said Maryann Keller, an auto industry analyst with the firm of Furman Selz.
David Ruprecht, the drunken driver and co-defendant who served 28 months in prison for vehicular homicide after running a red light and plowing into Mr. Moseley's truck, told jurors: "I hope each of you give justice to Mr. and Mrs. Moseley. I wish Shannon had been driving a Ford truck."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A state court jury in Atlanta yesterday found General Motors liable for damages in the death of Shannon Moseley, 17. His parents, Thomas and Elaine Moseley, seated above, claimed Shannon burned to death in a 1989 accident because his GMC pickup truck had a faulty gas-tank design. HEADLINE: A Clinton Aide's Farewell To Clients: Keep in Touch

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Robert E. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company who is President Clinton's top economics adviser, sent a letter in December to many of his clients urging them to continue doing business with the investment banking firm and to stay in touch with him at the White House.
A copy of one of the letters, on Goldman, Sachs stationery and signed by Mr. Rubin, assures a Japanese client that Goldman, Sachs can continue to work closely with the client despite Mr. Rubin's departure. "I am confident that Goldman, Sachs will continue to work as well or even better with" the company, Mr. Rubin wrote, "given the strength of trust and the bond of mutual respect between our organizations." 
 The three-paragraph letter concludes, "I also look forward to continuing to work with you in my new capacity."
 
'Many' Such Letters
 Mr. Rubin said in an interview on Wednesday that he had sent "many" such letters, but he refused to provide a number. He said the statements were social phrases intended to encourage cooperation between private industry and Government and not intended to encourage any improper contacts or special pleading.
"What it meant was, it's in the interest of the U.S. Government to work constructively with everybody," Mr. Rubin said.
Dee Dee Myers, a White House spokeswoman, said the letter does not violate Federal ethics laws or regulations.
But the letter highlights the looseness of Government regulations on contacts between Administration officials and their former clients, said Charles R. E. Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit research organization here. He said it had created at least the appearance of a conflict of interest.
Mr. Rubin's correspondence also sheds some light on his extensive dealings in international business and finance. Mr. Rubin, the head of Mr. Clinton's new National Economic Council, is not subject to Senate confirmation. He has not yet filed his financial disclosure forms with the Federal Government but is required to do so by Feb. 19.
An adviser to a Japanese executive who received the letter provided a copy of it on the condition that neither the executive nor his company be identified. The adviser said that as many as 1,000 Goldman, Sachs clients in the United States, Japan, Europe and elsewhere received similar letters.
Mr. Rubin also said in the letter, "I hope I can continue to rely on your interest and support as I move from Broad Street in New York to Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, D.C., and would be grateful for whatever suggestions you would offer."
A Federal lawyer who had read the letter and who spoke on the condition of anonymity said, "It doesn't strike me that there's anything there that would raise any kind of specter of a violation of law or regulation."
Federal ethics regulations are mainly aimed at limiting contacts by former Administration officials with the agencies they have left. The rules require that officials not participate in decisions in which they have a financial interest and that they not accept compensation from companies and firms. But the rules do not prohibit officials from maintaining contacts with their former clients.
The letter was dated Dec. 18, 1992. Mr. Rubin joined the Administration in late January.
 
'A Fascinating Letter'
 Mr. Lewis of the Center for Public Integrity, who made his comments after a reporter read him the letter, said: "This is really a fascinating letter, because it's really an open door to contacts by his former clients. Lots of times in positions like this, people send letters saying, 'Don't contact me.' "
Mr. Rubin said he had severed his financial links to Goldman, Sachs and that he was putting his investments in a blind trust fund over which he would have no control. He reportedly earned $15 million in 1991 and has a net worth estimated at more than $50 million.
Mr. Rubin said in the interview that he would not participate in decisions that might involve Goldman, Sachs directly, but he did not rule out participating in decisions that might affect the investment bank's clients.
"Goldman, Sachs, of course, dealt with everybody," he said, adding that it would be difficult to remove himself from all issues that might affect a Goldman, Sachs client.
Ms. Myers said that White House lawyers would review Mr. Rubin's past financial work to develop a list of issues in which he would not be allowed to participate. She said the final list would exclude him for one year from decisions that would directly affect some of the clients with whom he dealt personally.
While the list is being drafted, she said, Mr. Rubin "is dealing very, very cautiously with his former clients."
She added, "As the head of the National Economic Council, it is Mr. Rubin's responsibility to the President to work with business leaders around the world to present the President with the best advice available."
Mr. Rubin said that because his position does not require Senate confirmation, he had not prepared a formal policy statement on when to remove himself from decisions in which he might face conflicts of interest.
A former ethics official in the Bush Administration, also speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that "assuming severance of all financial ties, there is no legal prohibition to dealing with former clients and employers, but we always tried to negotiate a grace period of a year or so," when such dealings were prohibited.
Mr. Rubin said his remark in the letter about continuing to work with a client was not meant in any way to urge the client to continue doing business with his former employer. "It was just sort of a social phrase, it had nothing to do with Goldman, Sachs," he said in the interview.

The Dow Leads the Stock Market to Record Highs
Propelled by falling American interest rates and exuberant corporate earnings, the stock market surged again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 42.95 points, to close at a record high of 3,416.74. In just the last two days, the Dow has risen nearly 3 percent in value. Page D1.

 Germany's powerful central bank lowered its major rates yesterday. The surprising German move was meant to reinforce the battered European curency-exchange-rate system, rekindle growth in a flagging economy and silence critics. Page D1.

HEADLINE: Democrats Stung by Weicker Rebuke On Passing Bill to Cut Income Taxes

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s impromptu imitation of Dolly Parton, singing "Here You Come Again," may go down as one of the more lasting images of his budget address on Wednesday, not for the quality of the singing, but for the stinging 10-minute rebuke of the Democratic Party that followed when the laughter died.
Less than 90 minutes before the speech, the Democrats, who control the General Assembly, had passed a bill to cut income taxes for the middle class. The vote fulfilled a central campaign promise for many lawmakers, and addressed, they said, the elements of unfairness in the law. 
 Mr. Weicker mocked and belittled their aims, and his tone of high-handed dismissal will carry a price, lawmakers said today, especially if he decides to seek a second term next year, as he has lately indicated he might. Some of the central budget ideas in the speech were also pronounced dead by legislative leaders. Mr. Weicker, meanwhile, announced that he would veto the income-tax bill as soon as it reaches his desk.
"I understand we've been busy," Mr. Weicker told the combined House and Senate. "Within a year and a half of putting it in there," he added, referring to the income-tax law, "here we go again."
 
Faulting Tone of Words
 In conversations around the Capitol today, voices were filled with a startling bitterness about Mr. Weicker's words, and what many felt was his patronizing tone. Some were angry that Mr. Weicker had squelched the tax bill so publicly, others dismayed that he had so openly embraced the aims and oratory of the Republicans, who had opposed the plan as unfair to the upper income classes.
"The tone was the error," said Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a Democrat from West Hartford and a deputy majority leader in the Senate. "If the shoe were on the other foot, and legislators were to glare down at him and sardonically chastise him, he would be offended, too."
Mr. Weicker, an independent third-party Governor and former Republican, has never been loved in the legislature, but he had been considered by many Democrats as a sort of kindred spirit: a liberal on most issues, whatever his party label.
The Democrats formed the core of the bipartisan coalition that Mr. Weicker assembled in 1991 to pass the income tax, and Mr. Weicker helped many of them win re-election in November by putting them on the ticket of his third party, called A Connecticut Party, which controls the top ballot line on all elections.
Legislative leaders also met with Mr. Weicker last week and told reporters afterward that they believed he would not stand in the way of the tax-revision plan.
"A number of people kept faith with the Governor -- the Governor has betrayed them," said Senator John B. Larson, the President pro-tem of the Senate and a likely candidate for Governor next year. "The Governor came off as a patronizing elitist, where he's right and everyone else has a right to be wrong."
 
Weicker Calls Cuts Minimal
 The Democrats' tax plan would have granted $156 million in new tax exemptions and deductions, with the greatest benefits going to families making $50,000 to $100,000. The costs of that cut would have been born by families earning more than $145,000, who would have seen their top marginal tax rate rise to 6.25 percent, from 4.5 percent.
Mr. Weicker said in attacking the proposal that the cuts, spread over such a large class of taxpayers, would be minimal compared with the big increases that would be faced by upper-income earners -- the very decision makers and business leaders who Mr. Weicker said he was trying to attract to Connecticut to help rebuild the economy.
In his speech, Mr. Weicker proposed about $170 million in new taxes, including a plan to replace the 5-cent bottle-deposit law with a 5-cent-a-bottle tax that would support environmental programs. He also asked the legislature to cut off about 22,000 residents from general assistance welfare relief on July 1 if they are deemed employable.
Both those notions were considered to be sinking fast today.
 
Override of Veto Is Unlikely
 "If a veto is done, Democrats will cut Governor Weicker much less slack on the initiatives he's seeking," said Representative Miles S. Rapoport, who has been one of the Governor's most dependable supporters. And overriding a veto is unlikely. The tax proposal passed 84 to 66 in the House, 17 votes short of the 101 needed for an override. It passed 21 to 14 in the Senate, where 24 votes would be needed to override.
Underlying even some of the most caustic comments about Mr. Weicker today was respect for his often canny manipulation of a legislature where he lacks even a single member of his tiny political party. The state Democratic chairman, Edward L. Marcus, said he believed Mr. Weicker, perhaps for strategic reasons, had chosen to hitch his star to the fortunes of the Republicans in siding with them on the tax fight.
The Republican chairman, Richard Foley Jr., said he expected no such alliance with the Governor, and would not particularly welcome it.
"I would characterize the Governor's discovery of Republican ideals like this," Mr. Foley said. "Even a blind squirrel finds some nuts."

HEADLINE: Japan's Growing Trade Surplus Is a Minus in U.S. Equation

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 5

 BODY:
After years of negotiations to reduce Japan's huge trade imbalances with the United States, Japanese exports are once again rising dramatically and Japanese corporations appear to be backsliding on their commitments to purchase more goods overseas.
As a result, Japanese leaders fear that their first efforts to build a relationship with the new Clinton Administration will be undercut even before they begin. In recent weeks, the United States Ambassador, Michael H. Armacost, is said to have warned Japan that it should come up with concrete proposals to improve the trade picture before meeting President Clinton or other officials. 
 This week, in a sign of Japan's eagerness to revive its economy, the Bank of Japan cut the discount rate, the interest it charges on money borrowed by commercial banks, to 2.5 percent from 3.25 percent. Government officials fervently hope the step will spur imports and impress Japan's trading partners that it takes the trade imbalance seriously.
The Japanese economic downturn, one of the biggest in recent history, has worsened the trade situation as companies seek to stimulate earnings by stepping up their exports.
 
No Climate for Change
 Government officials also say privately that in a climate of corporate cutbacks and even some of the country's first layoffs in a generation, Japanese firms cannot be persuaded to buy more foreign parts and components at the expense of their long-term relationships with their traditional suppliers.
The depth of the problem became evident today, when Japan released its trade totals for 1992. Japan's surplus with the world was $132.63 billion, a record, and more than twice the figure in 1990.
While figures for the United States were not immediately available, it will probably account for a third of the surplus, running a trade deficit with Japan of $45 billion to $47 billion. The new level will approach the record of $52 billion six years ago, when the trade figures created a crisis in relations and sharp new pressures on trade.
The changing trade situation comes at what Japanese officials describe as the worst possible time, fueling Japan's image as an economic aggressor just as the Clinton Administration is facing its first demands from several industries to provide protection from Japanese imports.
In telling the Japanese to come up with some concrete proposals, Mr. Armacost has carefully steered clear of saying what kind of new initiatives to offer or that they should be a condition of a first meeting, American officials here said. But he is said to have made it clear by implication that a major plan to spur Japanese Government and private spending, and thus improve imports, would be the best way to avoid souring the first encounters with Mr. Clinton's economic team.
But so far, the Japanese Government, enmeshed in complicated arguments over its budget for next year, has shown few signs of heeding the advice beyond the Bank of Japan's move to cut the discount rate.
 
Business Blames Government
 Business executives are increasingly blaming the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa for reacting far too slowly and sticking by a spending program that it devised months ago and that, as a stimulus, now appears completely inadequate.
Last week Mr. Miyazawa conceded in Parliament that the Government had badly misjudged the depth and severity of Japan's downturn. But the Prime Minister, his approval ratings in the polls already at near-record lows, declined to commit himself to greater spending.
"There is a feeling that it is not nearly enough," Yotaro Kobayashi, the chairman of the Fuji-Xerox Company and a spokesman for the Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business organization, said of the Government's stimulus program in an interview. But Mr. Kobayashi also said that Japanese business was partly to blame for the resurgence of the trade surplus.
After contending for several years that the Japanese economy was rapidly shifting away from overdependence on exports and that trade surpluses were in steady decline, Mr. Kobayashi and other business executives now concede that many of Japan's biggest firms are trying to export their way out of Japan's economic troubles.
 
Change Was illusory
 A few, when speaking on the condition that their names not be used, say that the "fundamental reforms" that the Government said industry was undergoing through the late 1980's were actually illusory, and that the progress American firms made to become supplier to Japanese industry has been halted, and in some cases eroded.
At the same time, Japanese officials have clearly grown more edgy about the new Administration.
In the two weeks since the inauguration, disputes with Japan have arisen over steel, autos and commercial airline routes, and a bill was introduced in Congress to renew a law the Japanese detest: the so-called "Super 301," which allows the United States to retaliate unilaterally against countries that Washington judges are discriminating against American goods.
Almost immediately after the "Super 301" bill was introduced, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry leaked information that it was drawing up legislation for Japan to respond with import restrictions of its own.
But there is growing recognition in Japan that the trade surplus numbers alone will encourage the Clinton Administration to adopt a much harsher tone on trade.
"It would be hard to imagine a worse situation in which to build a relationship with the Clinton people," a senior Japanese official who has long struggled with trade questions said recently.
 
A General Plan
 Next week, Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe will travel to Washington for Japan's first close encounter with the new Administration. But Japanese officials are already trying to dampen any expectations that he will follow Mr. Armacost's advice and bring anything more concrete than a general plan for a new organization that would talk about reconciling fundamental differences about the way business is done in the world's two largest economies.
The Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman, Masamichi Hanabusa, said this week that Mr. Watanabe would ask for more time to see the effects "of our big stimulative measures."
"I don't think that is empty-handed," he said. "But I don't say it is full-handed."
Few Japanese officials are eager to acknowledge a less obvious reality of the trade surplus with the United States: the figures would be dramatically worse if Japan had not spent much of the past decade building factories all over Southeast Asia, from air conditioning plants in Thailand to electronics factories in Indonesia and Malaysia.
The result is that many of the products Japan once exported from here are now assembled, with Japanese components, in other nations. Thus, the final products do not go on Japan's trade ledgers, even though much of the content is of Japanese origin.
The surplus with the rest of Asia has quadrupled in only six years, and this year Japan's surplus with Southeast Asia will be roughly the size of the surplus with the United States. Politically, however, it is less of a problem for Japan: Heavily dependent on Japanese foreign aid and technology, and often eager for investment of any kind, many of those countries are unwilling to complain too loudly.

HEADLINE: House Passes Voter Bill Over G.O.P. Opposition

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
House Democrats stood almost as one today and passed legislation fiercely denounced by Republicans that would make it easier to register new voters and harder to purge them from precinct rolls.
The legislation, the daylong debate over it and the party-line vote of 259 to 160 echoed an election-year battlewaged in Congress last spring and summer over voter registration. The Senate, which now gets the bill, is expected to pass it and send it to the White House, just as it did last year. 
 While George Bush vetoed the bill last year, President Clinton, is certain to sign it, perhaps as soon as March.
The voter bill, like family-leave legislation, is one of several Democratic initiatives vetoed by Mr. Bush that Democrats want to enact early this year to show their political muscle.
 
Bitter Pill for G.O.P.
 Passage of the voter bill would be a bitter pill for Republicans, who argued last year and again today that it is a plot to expand the ranks of Democrats. But Democrats and many civic groups insist it is intended to encourage voting, although they also acknowledge that it would largely benefit poor and relatively powerless Americans who historically lean toward Democrats.
More than 122 million Americans are registered to vote, but 57 million others of voting age are not.
"I think that enfranchising poor people -- and that's what we're talking about here, people who can't afford cars, people who can't afford nice houses -- is a noble thing," Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., an Indiana Democrat, said in today's debate.
The legislation, nicknamed the "motor-voter bill" because of its tie to driver's licenses, includes a sweeping clause that would effectively register as a voter anyone over the age of 18 who applies for or renews a license. That would include nearly 9 in 10 adults, and registration would be virtually automatic unless an applicant deliberately waived the process.
 
Registration by Mail
 But the measure also takes steps to enroll the remaining 10 percent of adults by ordering all states to permit registration by mail and to designate popular government offices as voter-registration agencies. Among agencies that would register voters are those dealing with welfare, unemployment and services for people with disabilities. States could add branches at marriage-license desks and even private offices.
Republicans assailed the measure on three fronts: that it is too costly, that it is intended to give Democrats an electoral edge and that it is an invitation to rig elections.
Some were especially incensed by what they saw as special efforts to enroll core Democratic constituencies in welfare and jobless-benefits offices. Several Republicans complained that the bureaucratic burdens of complying with the bill would cost the states scores of millions of dollars.
Democrats say the bill would cost $25 million over five years.
 
Voter Fraud Feared
 Republicans warned that quick and easy registration would encourage corrupt political machines to steal elections. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip, predicted a wave of fraudulent voting by illegal immigrants, noting that the Department of Agriculture estimates 300,000 illegal aliens already get food stamps at welfare offices, and thousands more have driver's licenses.
Democrats responded that the Republicans' real fear was that new voters would oppose their policies.
"The fraud issue being raised here today," said Representative Al Swift, a Washington Democrat, "is the biggest fraud in this debate."

HEADLINE: In Florida, Family Bill Wins Converts

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 4

 BODY:
When the Dade County Commission was considering a family-leave ordinance in 1991, Malone & Hyde Food Distributors was among the many companies that testified against the idea, arguing that the legislation would impose an unnecessary and disruptive burden on them.
But nearly a year after the law took effect in Florida's most populous county, the company has a new attitude. "We had reservations about being told what we could and couldn't do, but it hasn't really had any affect on us," said Janet Blair, the personnel director. None of the 600 employees have yet asked for a family leave "even though they are aware of it," she added. 
 Nationwide, 25 states and the District of Columbia have some type of family-leave legislation. But Dade County was the first county in the country to pass such a measure, and its ordinance most closely resembles the Federal bill, according to the Families and Work Institute, a organization in New York City that studies the issue.
In Dade County, many of the 2,500 companies covered by the law have reached conclusions similar to that of Malone & Hyde Food. Some, like Ms. Blair, say it is because few employees are taking the leaves. Others say it is proving less expensive than expected and actually increases worker satisfaction and output.
 
Big Gain in Loyalty
 "Not only do you get a tremendous amount of loyalty, since they know they can come back to their job, but from the productivity perspective you get more done because they come back refreshed," said Stephen Cerrone, director of human resources at Burger King, which has its corporate headquarters here. "This has been nothing but positive for us."
The legislation's backers say they have been pleased with the results. Commissioner Larry Hawkins, who sponsored the ordinance, and other county officials have said that the policy is working as expected and that there have been few complaints.
Like the bill passed by Congress last night, which provides for 12 weeks of leave, the legislation here, which took effect in March, lets workers take six days more, up to 90 days, of unpaid leave for the birth of a child or the illness of an immediate relative, with a guarantee they will have a job when they return. Because of the similarities, workers and corporate managers here say that once a Federal bill became law, the misgivings around the country would probably ease.
Edward Garcia, a service representative for Southern Bell who was able to take six months off to care for a sick child, said he was pleased. "I was allowed to return to the same title, the same office, the same supervisor and the same money," he said. "How could I not be grateful to a company that granted me this, that helped my son incredibly?"
Fears that large numbers of employees here would immediately try to take advantage of the program have proven to be unfounded.
"There has been very little abuse compared to the size of our work force," said Henry C. Fraind, director of management and operations for the Dade County school system, which employs 38,000. "You can't earn money when you're out, sitting at home."
Many critics of family leave argue that obligatory policies will add to the cost of doing business, thereby leading to higher unemployment. Senator Connie Mack, a Florida Republican who opposes the Federal bill, said in a statement this week that "it is ridiculous for the Government to pile regulation after regulation on employers and not expect job losses to follow."
But companies here that offer family leave say their experience has been otherwise. The costs have not been "oppressive," said Terry Johnson, a spokesman for Southern Bell, which has about 5,500 employees here and was one of several larger corporations that already offered family leaves.
That is not to say, though, that companies have not had to make adjustments.
 
New Strategies
 "The challenge to our managers and bank team is the staffing issue," said Elizabeth Ferrer, vice president for human resources at Barnett Bank of South Florida, who has taken two maternity leaves herself. "One thing we have done is to have a larger support team throughout Dade County, so that when family leave occurs we have somebody who can step right into that place."
But Mr. Cerrone of Burger King said that by shuffling workers around, his company has actually "gotten some yardage out of exposing people to different areas of the business."
Executives of smaller companies, however, argue that it has been harder for them to comply with the county ordinance because they do not have as much flexibility. Lombardo Perez, president of Metro Ford, an automobile dealership here that has 92 employees, said that only one of his workers, a mechanic, had asked for the family illness leave.
"My one reservation about this is that in some very specialized jobs, like an air conditioning mechanic, it can be difficult to get a temporary replacement," Mr. Perez said.
Mr. Perez also said he was happy to hold a job for productive workers. But "if they're not good employees, I'm not going to want to do the same," he added.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward Garcia was able to take six months off from his job at Southern Bell to care for a sick child because of family-leave legislation in Dade County, Fla. "I was allowed to return to the same title, the same office, the same supervisor and the same money," said Mr. Garcia, with his son Bryan. "How could I not be grateful to a company that granted me this, that helped my son incredibly?" (Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Jersey Retaliates for New York Taxi Fee

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
In the latest skirmish in the trans-Hudson wars, officials in New Jersey said yesterday that they would begin charging New York City limousines and taxis $200 a year per vehicle for the right to bring passengers from New Jersey to New York.
Members of the Bergen County legislature, which enacted the law Wednesday evening, described it as a tit-for-tat action intended to encourage New York's Taxi and Limousine Commission to rescind regulations for out-of-town hired cars that went into effect last week. 
 "We don't want to do this," said Richard A. Mola, vice chairman of the county's Board of Freeholders, its governing body. "All we want to do is to get New York to take back their law, which is plain wrong."
Accusing New York authorities of trying to gouge New Jerseyans, Mr. Mola said that he thought New Jersey's limousine companies had suffered enough in the recession and that the new expenses were ill timed.
Just as, over the years, New Yorkers and New Jerseyans have bickered over taxes, the birthplace of baseball and the Statue of Liberty, limousine owners and drivers in the two states spoke derisively of one another yesterday.
"Manhattan is just another town," said Tim Rose, vice president of Garden State Limousine of North Arlington, N.J., describing his objection to the New York regulations. "They want to charge us for going from town to town."
Deleroy Mayles, a New York driver, countered: "I only go to New Jersey when I absolutely have to. There's nothing of interest there." The new regulations principally affect limousine companies with corporate clients.
If the Taxi and Limousine Commission does not alter New York's regulations in 30 days, Mr. Mola of Bergen County warned, the police will begin enforcing the law in New Jersey. Any New York limousine found picking up a passenger in New Jersey would be given a $500 ticket for the first and second offense, and could be confiscated after a third offense. Those penalties are similar to New York's strictest penalties for operating a vehicle without a proper license.
Yet the Taxi and Limousine Commission seems unlikely to budge. Mr. Del Valle noted that the regulations were written into state law, which was passed last November and that took effect last week, and would not easily be changed. He defended the regulations as sensible.
' "We regulate the industry for a reason," Mr. Del Valle said. "When you get into a car, you want to know that it's not Jack the Ripper behind the wheel." He estimated the trans-Hudson limousine and taxi traffic at fewer than 2,000 cars
The new laws in both states require a $200 licensing fee for each limousine and a $500 fee for the limousine company, both annual fees. Mr. Del Valle said that New Jersey limousines would be exempt from New York motor vehicles tax, which costs local taxis $1,000 and limousines $400.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The productivity of American workers shot up by 4 percent in the fourth quarter. Along with big gains in January retail sales and record-breaking activity on the stock market, the data suggest that a full-fledged recovery might be under way. [Page D1.]
The Dow surged 42.95 points, to a record close of 3,416.74. Most other market averages reached new highs and Big Board volume was the seventh highest in history. [D1.] 
 Retail sales roared ahead at a surprising pace in January, with almost every major store chain posting large gains. [D2.]
Some corporations are expanding pension benefits, even though their current plans are underfinanced, because they know the Federal Government will pay the bills if the plans fail. [D1.]
After years of selling Cray Research supercomputers, John A. Rollwagen will become a Government policy maker. [D1.]
A former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, Robert E. Rubin, who is President Clinton's top economic adviser, urged many of his clients in December to continue doing business with the firm and to stay in touch with him at the White House. [A1.]
Inner-city homeowners are severely underinsured, and it is harder for poor members of minority groups to buy insurance than it is for poor whites, a national study says. [D2.]
 
International
Germany lowered major interest rates after several European currencies were battered by speculators and domestic data showed a deepening recession. The step followed a rate cut by Japan. [D1.]
Japan's trade surpluses are roaring back, which has Japanese officials fearing a looming political disaster. [A7.]
 
Companies
A jury held General Motors responsible for the death of a Georgia teen-ager in the fiery crash of one of its pickup trucks. Finding that G.M. knew the trucks had defective fuel tanks, the jury awarded $105.2 million in damages. [A1.]
Cray Computer announced a 1992 loss of $50.4 million, and its founder, Seymour Cray, is starting to lift the company's veil of secrecy in hopes of attracting investors.[D3.]
Ten Kemper Securities brokers and five staff members from one office defected to Shearson. Kemper retaliated by canceling its charge card with Shearson's parent, American Express. [D3.]
Mazda of America is said to be planning a shakeup in which its top American executive will relinquish some of his power to his Japanese boss. [D3.]
Travelers will take a $485 million fourth-quarter charge for real estate losses and speed the sale of foreclosed properties. [D3.]
General Motors introduced a gold Mastercard for affluent customers of its successful credit card business. [D3.]
Northwest Airlines reported a fourth-quarter loss of more than $200 million and a loss for the year of more than $380 million. [D3.]
 
Markets
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to its lowest level in six and a half years, and bond traders began to focus on today's unemployment report for clues to the rally's fate. [D12.]
The dollar made modest gains against the German mark and Japanese yen after those countries cut key interest rates. [D14.]
Wheat futures tumbled amid doubts that the Clinton Administration would be able to revive grain sales to Russia. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
Dallas Semiconductor has cast itself in a markedly different mold than the other chip makers whose stocks have been carried to new highs recently. Market Place. [D4.]
Guinness hopes new advertising by Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano for its stout will exploit beer drinkers' apparent desire for more heft in their brews. Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Clinton's National Service Program Will Have Modest Start

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The White House said today that the ambitious national service program Bill Clinton proposed in the Presidential campaign would begin as a more modest and economical effort to encourage volunteerism.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said President Clinton "intends to fulfill his commitment to build a national service plan" but acknowledged that it would be costly to do immediately. 
 In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said his Administration would replace the existing student loan program with one that would give students tuition aid in exchange for donating time to community service after graduation.
Today Mr. Clinton said that he always intended to enact the national service program in stages and that it would take six years for the full slate of options to be offered.
 
Avoiding a Mess
 "Unless the mechanics are such that we can't implement the service program, which I don't believe is the case, I would expect us to get, you know, to be well beyond what you would call a pilot program as soon as we implement it," Mr. Clinton said.
Eli J. Segal, the director of the Office of National Service, said there would not be enough volunteer service slots to accommodate every student who received Government assistance. He said the President was considering a plan that would also allow students to repay Government loans in amounts related to post-graduate income.
"I think we're in the process stage of figuring out one of the best ways of achieving the objectives," Mr. Segal said. "I think if we had all the money in the world, President Clinton would probably not want to throw it all at this right away. We don't want to create a program that would create a mess in the process."
Neither Mr. Segal nor Mr. Stephanopoulos would characterize the amount of money Mr. Clinton will set aside for the national service program in the budget he gives to Congress on March 23. But both indicated that the President had been forced to change some of his goals as economic circumstances changed.
 
Lowering Their Sights
 "It's true that the economic circumstances have changed since his election," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "The deficit is bigger. We are going to have to make tough choices. Some of those choices might entail scaling back some of the investments that he dearly wants to move forward on."
Mr. Segal said limited resources had forced him to focus more on coordinating volunteer programs than on putting a college aid program in place. But he insisted that the service program would eventually emerge intact and should not be classified as another campaign promise that might soon be broken.
"This is at the soul of Bill Clinton," he said. "This is not peripheral. This is not like middle-class tax cuts. He'll walk away from a lot of things before he walks away from national service."
Mr. Segal has been meeting with leaders of volunteer groups and has begun to identify volunteer offices in several Federal departments.
Until coordination is established on that level, he said, the full program will not be ready to begin.

HEADLINE: STRONG ECONOMIC SIGNALS LIFT DOW TO A RECORD;
Productivity Increases 4% In a Surge Without Hiring

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers shot up 4 percent in the fourth quarter, the Labor Department reported yesterday -- fresh evidence that corporate America is helping to generate a new surge in the American economy without hiring many new workers.
The productivity numbers issued by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics were startling. The 4 percent rise in last year's fourth quarter was the highest increase for a single quarter since the early 1970's. And the 2.6 percent rise in productivity for all of 1992 was the best improvement since 1972. 
 The latest data were announced along with eye-popping gains in retail sales in January. [Page D2.] The Government also announced that factory orders jumped 5.3 percent in December and that new claims for unemployment benefits fell in the latest week for the first time in three weeks. These reports, along with the enthusiasm shown by investors in the stock market, suggest that a full-fledged recovery might at last be under way.
 
A Question Still Unanswered
 But a huge question remains unanswered: Can the surge continue while companies are getting all the production they need from their existing workers? So far, the stronger productivity -- that is, the greater efficiency in what workers produce in a given period -- has worked against new hiring. And at this point after previous recessions, new hiring was already well under way.
The adverse effect of a productivity increase on job creation "can be bad in the short term because of what it does to consumer spending and to consumer confidence," said Nancy Lazar, a senior economist at the ISI Group, a consulting service. "But long term, it is positive because as profits rise, so do stock prices, and that should encourage hiring. Maybe that is already beginning."
Yesterday's report covered the seventh quarter since the recession ended in March 1991. Although the latest improvement was unusually strong -- with the service sector and the manufacturing sector both turning in strong gains -- the average quarterly rise in productivity over those seven quarters was roughly the same as the average for the first seven quarters of recovery that followed each of the seven major previous recessions since World War II.
What is different this time is this: While the output of goods and services rose each quarter by more than 11 percent on average after previous recessions, the average quarterly growth in output since March 1991 has been only 4 percent. Total output of goods and services differs from productivity, which is the amount workers produce per unit of time.
 
 
Room for a Rise
 The strong growth in output after the earlier recessions left room for employment to rise without dampening productivity. In fact, total hours worked throughout the economy except in farming and government employment rose 5.9 percent on average in the previous recoveries, while in this recovery hours worked actually fell six-tenths of a percent.
"This tells you, to be very literal about it, that the number of hours worked in the nonfarm sector was less in December than it was at the lowest point in the recession," said Edwin R. Dean, associate commissioner for productivity at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. He attributed the drop mostly to layoffs and attrition, rather than to fewer hours worked by the same number of people.
"What has happened is that the recovery in output of goods and services has been so weak that it has been possible to produce that output by simply using the services of skilled workers somewhat more intensively," Mr. Dean said.
More important, unit labor costs -- the cost in wages to produce a car, for example, or a sled or a machine -- have risen far less in this recovery than in the previous seven, going up only 2.3 percent on average for the seven quarters, compared with 5.3 percent for the same period in the previous recoveries.
The productivity gains, in effect, have not yet been passed on in higher wages, Mr. Dean said. That has helped to make companies more profitable and also given them leeway to lower prices, thus making the companies more competitive on world markets -- but at a cost of frozen wages in America, discouraging the demand among consumers that in the past has sustained recoveries.
 
'Double-Edged Sword'
 Such findings sharpen a debate over whether rising productivity can itself sustain a surge in economic activity -- despite the job problem -- to convert the surge into a lasting healthy recovery. "It is a double-edged sword," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "It is good for the improved efficiency of our companies and thus for competitiveness. But it is tough on workers, who are victims of the downsizing that has been required to boost productivity."
Clearly, the productivity has some advantages. Ms. Lazar, Mr. Roach and many other economists argue that the higher profits that have resulted in recent months from improved productivity are already encouraging some companies to invest more in new machinery. The production of machinery, in turn, helps to create jobs.
Despite much-publicized layoffs at giant companies, the number of jobs has been rising slowly in recent months, mostly at small companies employing 20 workers or fewer, according to the National Federation of Independent Business. But the job growth has not been sufficient to absorb all the Americans who want to work, and the unemployment rate has remained above 7 percent.
Productivity improvement also helps to hold down inflation, because rising demand can be met without running short of workers to produce the needed goods and services. Lower inflation -- it was only 2.9 percent last year -- allows interest rates to fall, encouraging the borrowing by consumers and businesses that stimulate spending and recovery.
 
On the Dark Side
 The dark side of strong productivity is inadequate job growth and income, weakening demand and also the recovery. The surge in consumer buying in recent months, in fact, is often attributed to a rise in consumer debt, a trend that cannot continue. Productivity is particularly an obstacle to growth, many economists say, if it results not from more skillful work habits but from shrinking a company's work force because there is not enough production to keep all of the staff busy.
"It is hard to quantify how much to attribute to the slash-and-burn approach and how much to other, more positive factors," Mr. Roach said.

HEADLINE: STRONG ECONOMIC SIGNALS LIFT DOW TO A RECORD;
Index Jumps 2.6% in 2 Days; Other Averages at Highs

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The stock market surged again yesterday, as a headstrong rally in the bond market and exuberant corporate earnings propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to a record closing. The index has risen 2.6 percent in the last two days.
Most other market averages reached new highs as well, on emphatic Big Board volume of 351.14 million shares, the seventh highest in history. But until yesterday, the Dow was the only major market indicator not to set a record this year. 
 Yesterday's 42.95-point gain in the Dow, to 3,416.74, came as the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.18 percent, the lowest since August 1986. Traders say further gains may depend on today's employment report. [Page D12.]
 The advance among stocks and bonds followed interest rate cuts by the German and Japanese central banks, moves that are expected to help the languishing global economy. Encouraging economic reports on productivity, retail sales and factory orders also fueled the stock market's advance.
 
'Best of All Worlds'
 The Dow's new high capped an 8.9 percent rise since Oct. 9, built on the economy's recovery and a surge of investing through mutual funds.
 "We've got the best of all worlds here," said Robert H. Stovall, president of the Stovall/Twenty-First Advisors money-management firm. "Interest rates down, business cycles recovering, inflation not a problem."
Higher stock prices and lower interest rates have great benefits for the economy, allowing companies to raise money and expand at less expense. Any stimulus provided by the financial markets ultimately lessens the need for the Government to keep the economy moving through increased spending.
Some strategists caution that with stocks at these levels, the release today of an even slightly disappointing employment report would cause share prices to tumble. "That report has to be great for the market to do better," at least in the short term, said Laszlo Birinyi, president of a financial consulting firm that bears his name. "People are going to be looking for an excuse to sell."
Economists anticipate word of continued improvement in payrolls, with the consensus for a gain of 125,000 jobs in January.
But some bond traders fear that a strong report on employment could end the credit market's rally, pushing yields back up. Rising bond yields, in turn, would draw money out of the stock market.
The Dow, weighed down by humbled industrial giants like General Motors and I.B.M., has recently lagged behind other averages. With a gain of 88.07 points in the last two days, however, it has rushed to the market's forefront, past the high of 3,413.21 set on June 1.
The Standard & Poor's 500, a broader index, had a more modest rise of 2.36 to 449.56, still continuing a streak of records.
Although General Motors moved lower and I.B.M. gained a modest 7/8 point, to 51 3/8, most industrial heavyweights stepped lively. Among the Dow stocks, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing rose 3 1/2 points to 104 1/4, Allied Signal was up 3 1/2 to 65 3/8, International Paper rose 3 points to 68 3/8 and Goodyear gained 2 1/2 points to 73 1/2.
Mr. Birinyi and many other strategists say the improving economy and stable or lower interest rates could, over coming months, send stocks still higher. Earnings reports for the latest quarter have shown significant improvement.
Some analysts are less confident about the Nasdaq stocks that have led the market higher since fall. The Nasdaq composite index set a record yesterday, but rose only 0.18 points to 708.85.
 
 
Computer Issues Lose Ground
 Small stocks edged ahead, but the Nasdaq 100 index of this market's largest stocks was stranded with a loss of 4.58 points, to 748.49. Some popular computer technology issues lost a point or more, with Microsoft down 3 3/8 to 85, accounting for about two-thirds of this average's decline.
Hank Striefler, co-manager of the Lehman Brothers Nasdaq trading desk, said the Dow industrials were due to make up lost ground. "We've been acting so great that we have to give them a chance to catch up with us," he said.
A minority, however, sees a more ominous pattern. David G. Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said the market's highs in recent days had been based largely on anticipation that long-term interest rates would hit seven-year lows. He noted the strong gains among utility stocks, banks, Dow industrials and other issues that profit the most from declining rates. Some Nasdaq stocks, which he says are less dependent on lower rates, have cooled.
In his view, a reversal in interest rates, even if it results from an upbeat jobs report, could puncture the stock market's progress. "The whole world will be watching the unemployment numbers," he said. "All you need is a couple little things to upset the apple cart."
 Since fall, the market has seldom flown in formation, with one sector, then another, soaring ahead. The Nasdaq index, dominated by smaller stocks, has gained 24 percent since Oct. 9, more than twice as much as the Dow.
Investors chose Nasdaq stocks because they seemed most likely to benefit from President Clinton's plans to encourage small, young businesses. The Nasdaq issues are also usually favored by individuals, who have poured record amounts into stock mutual funds.
Some market watchers say the Dow has suddenly emerged this week because investors are sated with their Nasdaq profits, and the Dow stocks now look like a cheap way of betting on an accelerating recovery.

HEADLINE: Zaire Opposition Seeks Foreign Troops to Restore Order; Capital Is Calm but Nervous

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Adding a potentially explosive element to Zaire's political crisis, Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi called today for foreign military intervention to help restore order after a week of civil disorders.
"What we need is foreign pressure, whatever it is, be it moral or physical," Mr. Tshisekedi said at a news conference, his first public appearance since marauding soldiers went on a rampage a week ago. 
He said he had made the appeal because the Zairian Army "does not respect the rule of law."
Mr. Tshisekedi's remarks came as diplomats from France, Belgium and the United States, Zaire's main creditors, held talks in Brussels to discuss ways of forcing President Mobutu Sese Seko to yield virtually all control over the Government to the Prime Minister.
 
President Is Intransigent
 But President Mobutu reacted angrily to the three nations' appeal Wednesday that he step aside, telling a French news agency that Zaire's political imbroglio was mostly a result of bungling by Mr. Tshisekedi and other opposition leaders. His creditors, the President said, were trying to punish the "fire brigade" while allowing "arsonists to go free."
African and Western diplomats say the friction between Mr. Mobutu and Mr. Tshisekedi has reached a stalemate. "Neither side has shown any willingness to compromise," said one African diplomat. "They would rather see this country go up in flames than appear to be the first ones to blink."
In a statement today, the Union for Democracy and Social Progress, Zaire's biggest and most influential opposition group, said Mr. Mobutu should be impeached for "high treason." The group, which is led by Mr. Tshisekedi, said the President had committed "barbaric acts" in order to "cling to power by force."
 
Inertia and Impotence
 Left unsaid was the fact that Mr. Mobutu has shown absolutely no inclination to yield, and Mr. Tshisekedi has no power to make him do so. Also unmentioned is that the President is in tight control of the armed forces and has no qualms about using them.
Moreover, African and Western diplomats said, although Zaire's creditors seem eager to get rid of Mr. Mobutu, no one appears ready to do so by force. Rather, the Western nations are believed to be more likely to use sanctions and other economic tools.
Until now, the creditors had urged Mr. Mobutu and the opposition to accommodate each other in a power-sharing arrangement; Mr. Tshisekedi's selection was supposed to be part of that process.
 
Funny Money, Soldiers Say
 The current crisis, the most serious threat to President Mobutu in decades, began last Thursday when soldiers rioted after being paid in new high-denomination bank notes that were issued by the President but outlawed by Mr. Tshisekedi and rejected by traders. They closed Kinshasa's airport and the river port on the Congo, and looted stores and private houses. As the pillaging and unrest spread, France and Belgium flew in hundreds of troops to evacuate their citizens from Zaire, which was once the Belgian Congo.
Today the streets were calm, but vast segments of the economy have shut down. Not a single gas station, for instance, was operating in central Kinshasa. Nor, it seems, were any pharmacies open. Banks have been closed for months.
In the few stalls open in the central market, the price of a sack of manioc, Zaire's staple food, has doubled in less than a week. At hospitals, supplies are depleted and doctors admitting only emergency cases.
Mr. Tshisekedi said President Mobutu was behaving as if Zaire's provisional Parliament did not exist.
"He is resisting what the people want and the pro-democracy conference decided, which is change for the country," the Prime Minister said.
"I'm not prepared to take orders from somebody whose political record for the last 28 years is a clear disaster. President Mobutu did not appoint me and he cannot get rid of me."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Evaluating Mobutu
 BRUSSELS, Feb. 4 (Special to The New York Times) -- Diplomats from the United States, France and Belgium today discussed their options if President Mobutu does not cede power.
The diplomats refused to comment on their five-and-a-half-hour meeting, but participants said options included seizing Mr. Mobutu's assets, expelling his diplomats and limiting the travel of Zairian officials.
All three countries, and the European Community's development fund, have suspended aid to Zaire because of Mr. Mobutu's actions.
Belgium held firm today to its decision to impound 14.5 metric tons of freshly printed five-million-zaire banknotes that Mr. Mobutu's forces had sought to fly by chartered airplane from a provincial field at Ostend to his embattled capital.
The bills, which feature Mr. Mobutu's picture and are supposedly worth $2 each, were printed by Harrison & Son of Britain. President Mobutu's previous printers, Gieseck & Devrient of Germany, canceled his account on the ground that he was not creditworthy, apparently fearing they would be paid with the same bills they were printing.
There were also continued demonstrations today outside the Zaire Embassy here. Some demonstrators laid flowers on the pavement to commemorate the victims of the violence in Zaire, while others threw eggs against the facade.

HEADLINE: National Study Finds Insurance Industry Bias

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
A nonprofit community development group says that it has found evidence in a national study that homeowners in inner-city neighborhoods are severely underinsured and that it is harder for poor members of minorities to buy insurance than it is for poor whites.
The study of 13 cities was conducted by Acorn, an activist group that has prodded the banking industry on lending practices in poor areas. It described its research as the first national study in a decade of whether insurance companies practice redlining. 
 The report comes at a time when regulators around the country are expressing increasing concern about the availability and cost of insurance for the inner-city poor, particularly in California, New York and Texas.
"Discrimination clearly perpetuates itself throughout the financial marketplace," said Maude Hurd, the president of the organization, which is active in 24 states. "It may well be time for the Federal Government to take an active role in protecting the interests of low-income and minority families."
The Acorn study found that insurance agents are five times more likely to refuse homeowners in inner cities a chance to buy insurance than they are residents of high-income areas.
The survey of insurance-company data in five Midwestern cities also found that people living in poor minority neighborhoods were far more likely to be without insurance than residents of poor white neighborhoods. In Milwaukee, for example, homes in poor minority areas were more than four times as likely than white-owned homes to be without insurance.
A spokesman for Acorn, Deepak Bhargava, said his organization had studied the filings of insurance companies and analyzed that data by ZIP code for Chicago; Kansas City, Mo.; Milwaukee; Minneapolis-St. Paul, and St. Louis. In addition, the organization surveyed agents in 624 phone calls in 13 cities across the country.
 
 
Findings Disputed
 Spokesmen for insurance companies bitterly dispute that they are guilty of discrimination by race or geography. Higher risks in poor areas make insurance more expensive, they say, and often difficult for poor people to afford.
"It is clearly more difficult and more expensive to get insurance in urban areas, but it is often more difficult and more expensive to get groceries" and other products, said Lynn Schubert, an assistant general counsel with the American Insurance Association, a trade group representing more than 200 property and casualty companies. "We are absolutely opposed to any kind of racial discrimination."
Sean Mooney, a spokesman for the Insurance Information Institute, another insurance trade group, cautioned that a large number of uninsured residents in an area might reflect the fact that poor consumers might decide not to buy. He said he had not had time to study the Acorn data.
"I don't see anything here that goes to the question of whether anybody just can't get insurance," Mr. Mooney said. "People who are poor sometimes decide not to."
Whether insurance is available and affordable is a crucial issue in economic development for inner-city areas, economists say. Without insurance, property owners are unable to get mortgages and business are unable to get credit. And inner-city residents pay auto insurance premiums that are many times higher than suburbanites.
After the riots of 1968, a Federal study found a widespread lack of insurance in inner-city areas, and Congress established state-run plans known as Fair Access to Insurance Requirements, or FAIR. The plans were intended to make insurance available to residents of high-risk areas, but since 1979 there has been no multistate review of how many people are underinsured and how hard it is to buy insurance in urban areas.
Among Acorn's findings were that low-income neighborhoods were underinsured in comparison with wealthier areas. In Chicago, for example, only 51 percent of the occupied single-family units in low-income neighborhoods were insured, compared with 90 percent in high-income areas. In Milwaukee, 51 percent of single-family units in poor areas were insured, compared with 84 percent in affluent areas.
People who said they lived in low-income ZIP codes, the organization said, faced numerous obstacles to buying from agents, compared with those saying they lived in affluent areas.
People from high-income areas were refused a policy 6 to 8 percent of the time, compared with 38 percent of the callers from low-income neighborhoods, the organization said. In New York City, for lower-income areas, agents refused to give a price for a policy 26 percent of the time. The surveyors experienced no refusals for people calling from high-income areas.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Poor and Uninsured" shows percentage of occupied one to four family housing units in low income areas. (Source: Association of Community Organization for Reform Now)

HEADLINE: Strong January Sales Signal Good Quarter for Retailers

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Retail sales roared ahead at a surprising pace in January, with almost every major store chain posting eye-popping gains.
What's more, because most merchants managed their inventory so carefully during the holiday season, they were not just getting rid of clearance merchandise last month, a trend that bodes well for their first-quarter profitability. 
 "In contrast to the doom-sayers who say there's nothing to support a recovery, consumer spending is leading us out of this weak economy," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.
The Salomon Brothers Same-Store Growth Index, which includes the sales of 22 different retail companies, rose 5.8 percent in January. Mr. Feiner had been expecting a 4 percent increase in the index.
 
Wal-Mart Sales Up 26%
 Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retail company, sold more than $4 billion worth of goods in January, a 26 percent increase over all and a 10 percent jump in sales of stores that have been open at least a year. The company hit a sales record of $55.5 billion in the year that ended last month.
Sears, Roebuck & Company's retail business had a 8.3 percent increase in comparable store sales, and Limited Inc. said its same-store sales climbed 6 percent in the four weeks that ended Jan. 30.
Analysts consider sales in stores open at least a year a better indicator of a retailer's performance because new stores distort total sales figures.
Analysts said that while the pace of spending was not sustainable, sales would nonetheless continue to show healthy increases as the year continued and consumer confidence grew. "Sales are being driven by improving hope for the future, thanks to one man -- namely, Mr. Clinton," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a retail consulting firm.
 
Kmart Growth is Weak
 The rising sales tide failed, however, to buoy all retailers. Comparable store sales at the Kmart Corporation, which had meager sales gains in December, crept up just three-tenths of 1 percent. The Woolworth Corporation also eked out a fractional increase of two-tenths of 1 percent.
Some store companies reported sales for five weeks that ended Jan. 30 while others reported their sales for the four weeks that ended the last Saturday of last month, making comparisons between retailers somewhat difficult. J. C. Penney, for example, posted a 1 percent decline in same-store sales during the four weeks that ended Jan. 30 because a major furniture promotion shifted from the last week of the month to the first week of February. But had Penney counted sales during the four weeks that ended Jan. 23, the company would have posted a 6.2 percent comparable store sales increase.
Some analysts had worried that consumers would shut off the flow of dollars in January once they got bills reflecting their markedly increased use of credit cards during the holiday season. But Mastercard International reported yesterday that its card holders in the United States charged almost $7.2 billion worth of goods and services during the month, a 21.1 percent increase.
 
Apparel a Pacesetter
 Clothing, a category of merchandise that did not sell well during the recession, is now blowing out of stores, retailers said. For example, Clothestime Inc., a specialty store chain that sells trendy fashion merchandise, posted a 12 percent gain in same-store sales.
Same-store sales at Gap Inc. increased 7 percent, and the Ann Taylor Corporation reported an 11 percent increase in sales in its stores open at least one year. Both chains warned, however, that their sales came at the expense of profits as they marked down prices to move merchandise out of their stores.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Yield Falls Again

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.18 percent yesterday, its lowest level since August 1986, and traders began to focus on today's January unemployment report for clues to the rally's fate.
The price of the 30-year bond finished up 10/32 , pushing the yield down from 7.21 percent on Wednesday and 1 basis point below the 7.19 percent reached last Friday. 
 All the gains were made in the morning, after the Japanese and then the Germans cut their short-term interest rates. Some traders said the cuts brought some foreign buyers into the Treasury market.
"Unemployment Friday" is always an uneasy day in the bond market. Bond traders have to guess what the closely watched nonfarm payroll number will be, and, even if they get that right, they must gauge how investors and traders will react to it.
Today's report may be even trickier to assess than usual because it comes at a time when the 30-year bond has rallied to its lowest yield in six and a half years.
With a weak employment report, the price of the long bond could rally the full point needed to push the yield down to a level not seen since the 1970's.
But an unexpectedly strong jump in nonfarm payroll jobs could dash hopes for an immediate further rally.
Such a report could make investors and traders pay more attention to other recent economic data, including the 9.1 percent surge in orders for durable goods in December and the 24.6 percent increase in sales of domestically manufactured vehicles in late January. Those reports show that the economy is growing at a healthy pace and probably a little faster than many had counted on.
Barbara L. Kenworthy, the portfolio manager of taxable fixed-income funds at the Dreyfus Corporation, summed up the uncertainty this way: "I think the market is probably a little overdone, but I think it is going further. Yet I recognize that I am skating on thin ice."
The problem in figuring what might happen is that even if one could know what the data will show, it is impossible to say how the market will react.
For example, if nonfarm payrolls jumped by 180,000 jobs in January, which is a high forecast, then the normal reaction would be for the market to sell off because the faster pace of growth signaled by the report would make investors and traders worry about inflation.
"I am hearing that the market will behave in the conventional way; that the higher the number, the less the market will like it," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities.
"But given the way the market has behaved recently, I am not so sure of that," he added hastily.
What he meant was that traders, investors and speculators have ignored the recent string of data showing the economy picking up some speed. One explanation has been that a stronger pace might lead to the Clinton Administration's reducing the size of its economic stimulus package. A little more growth is preferable to a stimulus plan that could get out of control.
But instead of indicating that, Administration officials said this week that the package would be even larger than some had anticipated, probably totaling $31 billion. But there has been little reaction to this.
When the market is in such a state of denial, when it dismisses data that contradict the direction of prices and yields, it can move to its own beat for some time.
This has been the case recently because of two strong factors supporting higher prices. One is that inflation remains around 3 percent and appears likely to remain low for the near future. Another reason has been the speculation about a cut in the size of the 30-year bond auction, which could help prices by reducing supply while demand remains steady. On Wednesday, the Treasury not only announced a $1 billion cut in the size of the 30-year bond auction next week but also a $500 million reduction in the size of the 10-year auction.
But if this focus is broken, the direction of the market could change quickly.
On the other hand, if the jobs number is weak -- there are forecasts as low as 50,000 to 80,000 new nonfarm jobs -- then the market should rally. The report would say that the economy is not moving fast enough to reverse the growing positive expectations about inflation.
But that is also in doubt, according to Ms. Kenworthy. "If the number is mildly weak, people will say that is O.K.," she said. "But if it is veryweak, the market could give back some ground. People will say, 'Whoops, Clinton is going to increase the size of the stimulus package.' "
 
Treasury Market
 The 10-year note and the 30-year bond received support from the cut in the auction size announced by the Treasury on Wednesday.
In the when-issued, or pre-auction, market, the three-year note to be auctioned on Tuesday was trading at a yield of 4.71 percent. The yield on the 10-year note to be auctioned on Wednesday was 6.34 percent, and the yield on the 30-year bond to be auctioned on Thursday was 7.15 percent.
The Treasury auction of one-year bills went well, with the average discount rate at 3.32 percent, the lowest since 3.12 percent in October. Following are the results from the one-year auction:
