HEADLINE: Politicians Ride the Rails In Annual Campaign Rite

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Cary Edwards was only up to the fourth car of the 18-car train when he ran into a woman wearing a lapel sticker that said, "Hire Me -- I'm Legal."
Mr. Edwards, who is nothing if not quick on his feet, said, "Make sure you have a green card; I'm checking." 
 With that, Mr. Edwards, who is running for the Republican nomination for Governor and who is having trouble because he employed an undocumented Portuguese woman as a housekeeper, sailed on down the rocking train aisle to shake yet another hand and buss yet another cheek. He had 14 cars to go.
His Republican rival for the nomination, Christine Todd Whitman, who was going the other way on the train, and who has had illegal immigrant problems of her own, stopped for an interview with a television reporter.
 
'A Good Place to Mix'
 "The major issue is the economy," she said, "and this train trip, with all the economic leaders of the state on board, is a good place to mix and mingle and do some serious business as well."
So it would seem. At least 1,400 people, lawyers and lobbyists, the press and publicists, office holders and hopefuls, almost all of them movers and shakers, paid $325 for the crowded, jostling four-hour train ride today from Trenton to Washington for the 55-year-old political ritual called, simply, "The Chamber Trip."
"This," observed a woman making her way, rush-hour subway style, through several of the highly active club cars on the train, "gives new meaning to the phrase 'press the flesh.' "
This year was particularly popular, what with all 120 members of the New Jersey Legislature, not to mention the Governor, up for election, with the new man in the White House expected at the dinner that was the ostensible goal of the two-day excursion, and with all three candidates for Governor on board.
 
Peculiar to New Jersey
 Gov. Jim Florio, along with both Republican leaders of the Legislature, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, held court along with New Jersey Chamber of Commerce brass in a V.I.P. coach near the end of the train.
Everybody else tramped the cars end to end, endlessly, shaking hands, mending fences, winning friends and influencing people in a ceaseless march that some have dubbed the March to Washington.
The trip is a political rite peculiar to New Jersey, and once, when campaigns were shorter, the traditional opening of the political season.
"It's toned down a lot since the days when it was basically an all-male smoker," said Alan Karcher, a legislator who has made the trip -- invoking Sinclair Lewis, he once nicknamed it the Babbitt Special -- since the late 60's. (Women were first allowed in 1968.) "Guys used to bring flasks and stumble off the train."
 
Edwards Sponsors 2 Cars
 It's staider now but still important. "I've got 50 staff people on this train," said Mr. Edwards, who sponsored two cars himself. 'You can't travel around the state for a year and see this many people that are important politically."
Governor Florio, who had originally plan to skip the trip this year, changed his mind a week or so ago, but said the change of heart had nothing to do with a recent break in his bleak poll ratings, and the concurrent troubles both his rivals have encountered over the illegal hiring issue. "I have gone on this trip for 26 years," the Governor said. "It's obviously a major social event."
 
'Your House Is in Order'RXx
 In a 10-minute speech before the dinner crowd at the Sheraton Washington, President Clinton spoke of tough decisions that he, the Congress and the nation face on the economy and other matters. He ended with a series of political plugs for Mr. Florio.
"Not so long ago you elected a Governor who had to make some of those decisions," Mr. Clinton said to sparse applause. "For all the pain suffered by Governor Florio and the Legislature, the truth is: your house is in order now. I hope you are proud of him, because I am."
The Chamber of Commerce inaugurated the train ride to Washington and Congressional Dinner in 1937 as a way for lobbyists and business people to meet the Congressional delegation, and each other. It has evolved into a political event, although the meeting, greeting and influencing has not been cast aside.
Slow economic times have curbed participations a bit in recent years, but William F. Faherty Jr., president of the state Chamber, said this year was a sellout. "I could have sold a thousand more tickets if we could have gotten the cars," he said. 'Everybody wanted to come."

HEADLINE: High-Tech Policy Major, With a Minor in Trade

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
When President Clinton announced the appointment of a supercomputer industry veteran, John A. Rollwagen, as Deputy Secretary of Commerce last Friday, the move alarmed at least one group: the Japanese. The news media in Japan immediately seized on the appointment as fresh evidence of the new Administration's hard-line stance on trade issues.
As chief executive of Cray Research Inc., the dominant producer of supercomputers, Mr. Rollwagen has spent several years jousting with the Japanese Government and with computer executives and the news media in Japan, as he has put pressure on that country to open its federal markets to his company's machines. 
 Now, after 19 years at Cray Research, the last three as chairman, Mr. Rollwagen is shifting from selling supercomputers to becoming a Government policy maker on technology and trade issues. His new role is emblematic of the desire of the new Administration to sharpen its focus on the relationship among the United States' trade policy, advanced technology development and economic competitiveness -- a stance also evident in the President's appointment of Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a high-tech policy expert, to lead the Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Girding for the Battle
 Perhaps the clearest sign of Mr. Rollwagen's intentions in his new job came in a letter to employees announcing his resignation from Cray Research. "Whether we like it or not," he said, "our country is in an economic war."
The appointment has been greeted particularly warmly in Silicon Valley, where there has long been concern that the Government has been ineffective at supporting embattled high-technology companies facing foreign competitors.
"I couldn't have been more pleased that the Administration has reached out and selected a high-technology C.E.O.," said John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer Inc., where Mr. Rollwagen has been a member of the board. "The Clinton Administration is going to take a different tack on global trade than we've seen in previous administrations," Mr. Sculley said, "and John Rollwagen has the practical experience required."
International trade may turn out to be the most manageable of Mr. Rollwagen's challenges in his new role as the high-tech visionary at the Commerce Department. Transforming the agency into the "technology powerhouse" that the Clinton campaign envisioned in order to build a national system of high-speed computer networks and nurturing commercial technology development will require deft leadership from Mr. Rollwagen, a business outsider who must overcome long-entrenched and powerful Washington interests.
The problems plaguing the Commerce Department today, Clinton officials say, are not only ossified management and a bureaucratic culture, but also the scattered mission of the agency, which does everything from taking the census to predicting the weather.
Although the department's diverse missions will remain, technology is almost certain to acquire greater importance. Mr. Clinton and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown have both said that they intend to direct the Administration's technology policy from the Commerce Department, and that in the future the agency will become more of a player in setting the Government's agenda.
 
Toes May Be Stepped On
 The Clinton Administration is still sorting conflicting advice on what to do with the department, which until now has been viewed as a bureaucratic backwater. Some of Mr. Clinton's backers argue that the Commerce Department is the ideal place to forge a new industrial policy by creating a superagency that would include the department's National Institute of Standards and Technology, or N.I.S.T., and might absorb the Defense Advanced Projects Agency, some of the Energy Department's national laboratories and even the Patent and Trademark Office.
But such a transformation would require stepping on powerful toes and the consensus is that Mr. Rollwagen will initially have to work with a much more modest set of resources.
High-tech executives have been discussing a variety of possible near-term projects that they think could pay dividends for the economy and that the industry would support. These are among them:
*Pushing through administrative proposals to free new portions of the radio spectrum for innovative applications that might create new industries.
*Expanding the existing programs of the N.I.S.T., like the industrial extension services that have been set up to help small businesses, and the advanced technology development grant program.
*Moving the department's National Telecommunications and Information Agency directly under the office of the Under Secretary of Commerce for Technology as a way of to solidify the Administration's push to create a national high-technology information system. In the past, this agency has seldom had a measurable impact on policy, usually taking a back seat to the independent Federal Communications Commission.
Conventional wisdom is that there will be a natural working relationship between Mr. Rollwagen and his new boss, in which Mr. Rollwagen will act as the planner and technology visionary and Mr. Brown will be the implementor. This would be a break with the past, since the deputy position has traditionally been filled by someone with administrative and political experience in the Government.
Mr. Brown, however, is viewed as the consummate Washington insider, while Mr. Rollwagen is more policy-oriented -- a cerebral man must now buy several suits simply to have an adequate wardrobe for his new job. Whether a role reversal occurs, and creates friction between Mr. Brown and Mr. Rollwagen, remains to be seen.
 
Private Industry's Role
 A more substantive challenge for both men will be finessing the ideological debate in Washington over what role the Government should play in assisting industry. Mr. Rollwagen is clearly an activist on this matter, but industrial policy is likely to be a contentious issue under the Clinton Administration.
Moreover, government spending to subsidize technology development is likely to have little effect without significant internal changes at the nation's technology companies, academic researchers say.
"One of the overwhelming messages is that private business strategy has to be the basis for technology development," said Joe Morone, a professor of management at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and author of a recently published study, "Competing in High-Tech Markets."
"We can complain all we want about closed Japanese markets," he said, "but if they open their markets and we have products that are inferior, it's not going to us much good."
Cray Research is currently challenging the Japanese Government over its award of a supercomputer contract to the NEC Corporation of Japan. Cray maintains that its machine is better and is demanding that it be able to test the Japanese computer to see if it lives up to NEC's performance claims. The Japanese are expected to rule on Cray's demand by the middle of next month.
 
A Charge of Favoritism
 Back home, meanwhile, most high- technology leaders are enthusiastic about Mr. Rollwagen's new role at the Commerce Department. But some are not.
In the turbulent supercomputer industry, for example, such competitors as the Thinking Machines Corporation and the Intel Corporation believe that Cray Research has been singled out for special treatment by the Government. They say that while Cray has lagged behind them in developing the new massively parallel supercomputer technology that represents the industry's state of the art, the company has been coddled.
The Bush Administration had pressed the Japanese to open their market to Cray supercomputers, and the Energy Department financed a project late last year involving Cray and several of the national laboratories to develop massively parallel computer software.
"This nation has to decide whether it wants to support a national supercomputer company," complained a top executive at one of Cray Research's competitors.
Those protests notwithstanding, Mr. Rollwagen's appointment has done a great deal to set the tone for a strong relationship between business and the new Democratic Administration.

HEADLINE: Hospitals and Bills

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 4

 BODY:
When New York State began regulating hospital rates in 1983, a mainstay of the system was the hospitals' ability to charge more for some patients to help keep down costs for others.
The extra charges were meant to advance the state's goal of helping nonprofit insurers like the Blue Cross plans, which did not have to pay the surcharges, compete more evenly with profit-making insurance companies, which were required to pay them. They were also used as a way to channel more money into the state's ailing hospitals, already staggering under the weight of increased health costs. 
 But on Wednesday, Judge Louis J. Freeh of Federal District Court in Manhattan struck down a large part of New York's payment system, saying the hospitals could no longer impose the extra charges. The ruling, which the state plans to appeal, deprives the hospitals of $160 million a year, makes the position of the ailing Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield even more precarious, and, most significant, threatens to dismantle New York's complicated and fragile hospital financing system.
 
'An Imperfect System'
 "It's been an imperfect system that's been patched together with Band-Aids and other temporary solutions," said David P. Rosen, president of Jamaica Hospital, which would lose $1 million a year if the ruling is upheld. "This literally takes the entire reimbursement system and trashes it."
The case was brought by a coalition of commercial insurance companies, which argued that the extra charges -- 24 percent for commercial insurers and 9 percent for health maintenance organizations -- unfairly penalized their customers.
New York State countered that the hospitals should be allowed to continue charging commercial insurers more than they charge nonprofit insurers like Empire Blue Cross or the state through its Medicaid program. Because of the nonprofit insurers' special mission to accept any applicant who applies and to set rates without regard to age or risk of illness, the state argued, they are entitled to pay less.
But Judge Freeh agreed with the commercial companies, holding that the extra charges violated the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known commonly as Erisa, because they were using employees' money for purposes that had never been intended -- in this case, to keep costs down for others. Under the law, employee contributions to benefit funds can be used only for the "sole and exclusive" benefit of workers and their families.
 
Another Blow to Empire
 The decision is another blow to Empire, New York's largest insurer, which has depended on the state's system. Without the handicap of paying higher hospital bills, officials say, commercial insurance companies may be able to lower their insurance rates and woo customers away from Empire.
It also hurts the state's hospitals, which lost $397.4 million in 1991 and would lose $496 million more if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1 were to take effect. "What this does is attack the fundamental social philosophy underlying the hospital reimbursement system, where you give Blue Cross and Medicaid a break and cap the amount the commercial insurers would pay," said Jeannie H. Cross, a spokeswoman for the Hospital Association of New York.
Last year, New Jersey's system of paying for indigent health care through extra charges on other patients' hospital bills was declared illegal on similar grounds, and the state had to scramble for alternatives. It ended up completely reorganizing its entire system within a few months by deregulating hospital rates, charging new health-care taxes and raiding its own unemployment insurance fund to pay for indigent care.
The two cases have sent a shudder through hospitals and state health agencies in New York State, which are anxiously awaiting the results of another case pending in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. In that case, a group of trade unions has challenged yet another hospital bill surcharge, a 5.6 percent extra payment tacked on to all hospital bills that is used to collect $1.1 billion a year for indigent care.
 
Other Possibilities
 Should that system be struck down as well, state officials say, they do not know what alternative they have. Most possibilities -- deregulating hospital fees, charging new broad-based taxes or denying health care to some 2 million people who are too poor to pay for health insurance but not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid -- are decidedly unattractive.
"Right now the plan is to appeal and win," said Paula Wilson, executive deputy commissioner of the State Health Department. "There's no plan beyond that to discuss at this point."
In the absence of other viable plans, state officials are praying that either they will be able to wrest a waiver from the Federal Government of the Erisa requirements, or that the Erisa law will be revised, or that the Clinton Administration will enact some sort of universal health-care proposal.
"The Federal law which pre-empts state level actions is hampering the ability of states to achieve health care reform," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Committee on Health, speaking of Erisa. "It is important that Congress quickly re-examine the Federal pre-emption of state law under Erisa."

HEADLINE: For Neediest Cases Fund, Late Is Better Than Never

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The end of the 81st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is fast approaching, prompting a flurry of last-minute check writing by contributors who sheepishly admitted that they had procrastinated their way through the last few months.
In a letter with her $25 donation, Dorothy Sluter of Hillsdale, N.J., referred to an unofficial motto of the fund. " 'To delay may mean to forget,' and that is exactly what happened in my case," she wrote. "I have belatedly found the enclosed check, which I meant to send before New Year's. Still, better late than never!" 
 Stuart and Penny Lachs of Brewster, N.Y., expressed similar sentiments. "As you note every day, 'To delay may mean to forget,' " they wrote in a letter with their $125 contribution. "This year we resolved not to forget."
Raymond and Betty Kaplar mailed their $50 check and a note apologizing for their tardiness all the way from Jerusalem. And Adam L. Berger, who gave $36, said he was so immersed in his studies that he did not have time to send his donation.
"If you want to know why I'm so late with my check this year, you have Harvard College's outdated exam policy to blame," he wrote, noting that Harvard holds finals after Christmas. "I'm happy to report that I finished my last exam this morning, putting four straight weeks of work behind me."
Mary M. Jones of Manhattan donated $100 and quickly scribbled her letter to the fund. "I apologize for the informality of my note paper and envelope," she wrote. "But I kept putting off sending my contribution until I got organized -- which may be never."
 
Fund Is Down
 This year's Neediest Cases campaign, which ends on Feb. 28, is down about $700,000 when compared with this time last year. The drop comes at a time when the seven charities supported by the fund are struggling to help thousands of people who have lost their jobs because of the recession. All contributions go directly to the charities because The Times pays the fund's expenses.
C. W. Reiquam of Lakewood, Colo., sent $100 and said he had "planned to contribute before, but somehow it slipped by." Kathleen L. Jerome, who gave $100, wrote that she was "running a bit late this year -- but better late than never."
And Myrna V. Lewis of Rockland County, N.Y., gave $50.
"I almost didn't do it this year," she wrote. "There have been so many other needs. But I couldn't miss even once."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed After Japan And Germany Lower Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other major currencies yesterday, posting moderate gains against the German mark after the Bundesbank moved to cut key interest rates.
The dollar gained marginally on the yen after the Bank of Japan cut its discount rate. But the move "had been so widely anticipated that it had little effect on currency markets," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.65 yen, up from 124.375 yen on Wednesday. 
 Gold prices declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $329.00 a troy ounce, off 30 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold lost 15 cents to a late bid price of $328.35.
European markets saw high-volume trading after the Bundesbank, the German central bank, announced it would cut the discount and Lombard rates. The dollar advanced strongly on the move, which came unexpectedly and was aimed at stabilizing European currencies.
Hectic activity brought major corporate players into the market, analysts said, but trading cooled and the dollar pulled off against the mark with heavy profit taking when trading shifted to domestic markets.
"The German easing was not as pronounced as one might have expected," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
Traders said the dollar had been driven higher in recent weeks on anticipation of a German rate cut, and that after the Bundesbank announcement, attention quickly turned to the United States economy, including today's unemployment figures, the prospects for an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve and the disclosure of President Clinton's economic policy package scheduled for later this month.
"The market has to deal with the fact that one of the things that had been keeping it going has happened," Mr. Waxman said. "We will need a very strong sign on employment to keep the rally going."
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4445, from $1.4350 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.4405 to buy one pound, compared with Wednesday's $1.4340.
Other late dollar rates in New York included: 1.6565 German marks, up from 1.6450; 1.5325 Swiss francs, up from 1.5255; 5.600 French francs, up from 5.5750; 1,536.00 Italian lire, down from 1,537.50, and 1.26295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.26655.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

Identity Crisis in Chicago
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- This is a particularly fecund moment for the nexus between America's first and second theater cities. "The Goodbye Girl," Neil Simon's Broadway-bound musical, closed up shop last weekend after six weeks at the Shubert Theater here -- the city's first pre-Broadway tryout in three decades. And "The Song of Jacob Zulu," the Steppenwolf Theater Company's play about apartheid, featuring the music of Ladysmith Black Mambazo, is also on its way to New York. On Saturday, it opened a two-week reprise engagement of a production that had its world premiere last year. 
 In addition, "Wings," the musical adaptation of Arthur Kopit's play about a recovering stroke patient, which was a recent hit at the Goodman Theater here, opens at the Joseph Papp Public Theater on March 9.
"Wings" was the first show directed by Michael Maggio since a double lung transplant in 1991 released him from a lifelong enslavement to cystic fibrosis and an imminent death. Mr. Maggio, who is 41 and is to direct the show in New York, purposely chose this project for his return. "Not to get too Shirley MacLaine about it, but what I've gone through has certainly heightened my sense of the spirit," he said. "And transcendence is very much at work in this musical."
The Remains Theater, which is a likely Chicago stop for David Mamet's "Oleanna" and Larry Kramer's "Destiny of Me," is now presenting "Snakebit," a new play by David Marshall Grant, which was being scouted last weekend by Nicholas Martin, associate artistic director of Playwrights Horizons. The play, about a gay man whose last female lover was his best friend's wife, was directed by Campbell Scott, who recently appeared in "On the Bum" at Playwrights, as did one of the actors, John Benjamin Hickey.
A leader in the regional theater boom, Chicago has a substantial history of launching productions toward New York, of course, and its theater professionals have long relished its place outside the media glare that attends Broadway, an atmosphere that has nurtured ensemble groups and placed an emphasis on theater art rather than theater economics.
"Chicago actors get in a room and don't worry about money, about agents, about how this role will affect their next gig," said Larry Sloan, the artistic director of Remains, who was once an associate at Lincoln Center Theater. "In New York, there's always pressure to make each role part of a career. I once worked with an actor in New York who wouldn't wear a fat suit. That would never happen in Chicago."
Still, after a decade in which the native playwright David Mamet and several members of the once-renegade Steppenwolf company "allowed us," in the words of Mr. Maggio, "to step up into the national theater," Chicago finds itself in a bit of an identity crisis.
"I'm a big Chicago booster," said Roche Schulfer, the Goodman's producing director, "but there's a little bit of second-city syndrome. You've got to make it in New York to prove your chops."
There are generational growing pains. Companies like Steppenwolf, now in its 17th season, and Remains, in its 14th, have moved into newer, roomier quarters and consequently up to bigger budgets and bigger fund-raising headaches.
"We moved into this place for a song," said Mr. Sloan of Remains's three-year-old home on the second floor of a weird, sparsely patronized, vaguely new-age mall. "But that song has become a whole CD of expenses."
As attendance has increased and subscription lists have grown, these groups have faced the responsibility of pleasing their patrons. At the same time, in the Chicago tradition, smaller companies have arisen to take their place as the new kids on the artistic fringe. ("Like everybody who graduates from college in Chicago, they formed a theater company," Mr. Maggio said of the four-year-old Looking Glass Theater.)
"We've had to evolve," said Randall Arney, a founding member of Steppenwolf and now its artistic director. He added that he was in touch monthly with the other 22 members of the acting troupe, which includes John Malkovich, Gary Sinise and Laurie Metcalf. Steppenwolf's $8.28 million theater is two years old, and fund raising for it goes on.
"We still work hard to maintain a mom-and-pop organization," Mr. Arney said. "But during the 80's, we were able to build a superstructure to protect this artistic bubble." The company's next production, Arthur Kopit's "Road to Nirvana" -- a flop at the Circle Repertory in New York two years ago, which Steppenwolf is reviving, Mr. Arney said, simply because the company likes it -- is a vicious, profane Hollywood sendup. Indeed, it is something of a risk for a group whose subscription list has grown to 18,000 from 13,000 in three years.
"There'll be a lot of our original subscribers who'll love it," Mr. Arney said. "They'll say, 'Thank God,' you know?"
Overall, the Chicago theater teeters between the provincial and the national. This is clear from a scan of current productions. On the one hand, there is an evident commitment to plays about blacks and contemporary black issues that New York, at the moment, cannot match. Two plays are now up: August Wilson's "Two Trains Running," which closed on Broadway in August, at the Goodman, and "The Song of Jacob Zulu," which was written by a white man, Tug Yourgrau, but is given authenticity by Mambazo and a fierce performance by the South African actor Zakes Mokae. And previews begin on Friday of Cheryl West's "Pudd'n and Pete," a contemporary love story about the struggling new marriage of two middle-aged black people, a janitor and a secretary.
On the other hand, with "The Destiny of Me" and Paul Rudnick's "Jeffrey" -- plays that plumb the problems of living with AIDS and not just confronting it -- running in New York, the two new AIDS plays here seem a tad behind the curve. Both "Snakebit" and Steven Dietz's "Lonely Planet," at the Northlight Theater in Evanston, are grounded in lamentation that the plague is evil and unfair -- a verity to be sure, but by this point a worn dramatic artifice. And they share an almost identical climactic scene in which a character calls to find out test results, an unfortunate coincidence and, one would think, an avoidable one if the theater community here is as tightly knit as everyone says.
 
'Goodbye Girl' in Progress
 "The Goodbye Girl" closed here on Saturday night with an acknowledgement from both performers and critics that the six-week tryout was a success. That is, the show that left is much better than the one that arrived. Two nights earlier, the show introduced a new opening number, its fourth, a duet between Paula, the title character, played by Bernadette Peters, and her 10-year-old daughter, Lucy (Tammy Minoff). An exuberant song about their hoped-for move to California from New York City, it's meant to help Paula lighten up; in the first act, she has been perceived as a drip. In addition, the expository book sections at the beginning have been nearly eliminated, so the show now opens like a musical: with music.
"As a result, the rest of the act played better," the director, Michael Kidd, said before rehearsal the next morning. "The audience is happier. You could tell that right away."
Mr. Kidd is, of course, the replacement for Gene Saks, who was dismissed amid much hoopla in early January. Mr. Kidd would not comment on what he'd changed, but the producer, Emanuel Azenberg, said that Mr. Kidd's strength was in staging musical numbers and that the show is about 25 percent changed since Mr. Kidd's arrival.
Several cast members, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Saks's dismissal was necessary, although none really blamed him.
"We'd reached a plateau, and it was clear we weren't rising any higher," one person said, echoing a consensus, although one dissenter said Mr. Saks "was just a scapegoat."
(Actually, given the economics of a big musical, it was a success that the show opened here at all. An unusual labor agreement with the local stagehands' union pared the number of members the union generally requires on a show's payroll. That, and concessions from performers -- Ms. Peters and her co-star, Martin Short, worked for $1,000 a week, a fraction of what they'll receive in New York -- saved $1.5 million, Mr. Azenberg said.)
The show, scheduled to open at the Marquis Theater in New York on March 4, is now back in rehearsals, still with "a lot of work to do," in the words of Neil Simon. In any case, to judge from a morning photo session last Friday, little tension remains from the earlier brouhaha. As the cast posed for the camera, there was much horseplay, led mostly by Mr. Short, who at one point, with his arm around Ms. Peters, tweaked a potentially rumor-mongering observer by calling out, "You know we're having an affair, don't you?"

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Behind the Scenes With Bush and Gorbachev

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

At the Highest Levels
The Inside Story of the End of the Cold War
By Michael R. Beschloss and Strobe Talbott
498 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95
During the years 1989 through 1991, history leaped into fast forward as events overtook expectations and the cold war came sliding to a dramatic end. In these three short years, there came in mind-boggling succession the liberation of Eastern Europe, the reunification of Germany, the disbanding of the Warsaw Pact, the Persian Gulf war, the collapse of a hard-line Soviet coup and the formal dissolution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics 
 These events, of course, are familiar to anyone who reads the papers or follows the news on television. Now, however, the historian Michael R. Beschloss and Strobe Talbott, the Clinton Administration's new ambassador at large in charge of dealing with the former Soviet Union, have filled in the details of this historical outline, providing the reader with an intimate and utterly absorbing behind-the-scenes account of the negotiations between George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev that helped shape these momentous events.
The authors say that early in their research they "quietly asked a large number of American and Soviet officials if they would speak with us on a regular basis about what was happening within and between their two Governments," and that they obtained the cooperation of these officials "on the condition that we not identify them as sources." Although this approach leaves the reader wondering exactly how the blow-by-blow accounts of secret meetings and conversations were reconstructed and verified, it also makes for a highly fluent narrative with the heft and density of history and the emotional resonance of fiction. Former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the former Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, one suspects, are two frequent unidentified sources.
Clearly the background of the two authors makes them particularly well-suited to the job they've undertaken in this volume: Mr. Beschloss is the author of a critically acclaimed study of the tension-filled relationship that developed between President John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, during the early 1960's ("The Crisis Years: Kennedy and Khrushchev, 1960-1963"); and Mr. Talbott, in addition to writing several volumes on arms control, wrote a book with Michael Mandelbaum about Mr. Gorbachev and President Ronald Reagan ("Reagan and Gorbachev").
As in these earlier books, Mr. Beschloss and Mr. Talbott look at the events leading to the end of the cold war through the prism of personality, turning what might have been a dry, chronological account into an almost novelistic story of two leaders and the political chess games they played with each other and with their own advisers and adversaries at home.
The result is a remarkably readable book that gives the general reader an appreciation of the role personal leadership (or the lack of it) can play in the making of history, as well as a good basic lesson in complicated processes of diplomacy: how domestic agendas and difficulties can shape and inhibit foreign policy, how foreign policy decisions can impinge upon domestic concerns; how public declarations can belie understandings reached in private.
Mr. Talbott and Mr. Beschloss reveal that in December 1987, Vice President Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that President Reagan was surrounded by "marginal intellectual thugs," who would jump on any evidence that he, the Vice President, was a closet liberal. Therefore, he would have to do and say certain things to get elected during the 1988 campaign, things Mr. Gorbachev should ignore.
It was a remark that Mr. Gorbachev would have to take comfort from during the long "pause" in Soviet-American relations that Mr. Bush took during the opening months of his Administration despite the urgings of Margaret Thatcher and others to capitalize on the opportunities made possible by the new Soviet openness.
By the end of 1989, Mr. Beschloss and Mr. Talbott report, all this had begun to change. The revolution in Eastern Europe, along with a friendly summit in Malta and pressure from the American public and Western allies for serious engagement with the Soviet Union, had combined to plant the seeds for an intensely personal partnership between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, a development that at once reflected the American President's penchant for personal diplomacy and suited the Soviet leader's taste for high-risk showmanship.
Although Mr. Bush had been warned from the start that it was dangerous to support Gorbachev the man, rather than the new Soviet policy of openness, the authors of "At the Highest Levels" report that the White House consistently ignored advice from the C.I.A. to diversify support for democratic reformers in the Soviet Union. In 1989, Mr. Talbott and Mr. Beschloss say, the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, fell asleep during a meeting with Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, who had been hustled into the White House through a side door. As late as April 1991, they add, Mr. Bush was still reluctant to issue a formal invitation to Mr. Yeltsin, worried that such a move might alienate his old friend Mr. Gorbachev.
As depicted in this book, the Bush Administration's decision to put all its eggs in Mr. Gorbachev's basket had an assortment of serious consequences. It contributed to Mr. Bush's longstanding reticence on the subject of Baltic independence. It contributed to the White House's willingness to discount repeated warnings (from the C.I.A. and former President Richard M. Nixon, among others) about a possible Soviet coup. And according to Mr. Beschloss and Mr. Talbott, it contributed to the eventual downfall of Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush themselves.
"Gorbachev came to believe," they write, "that it was more important for him to cultivate his relationship with Bush and his fellow Western leaders than to reach an accommodation with Boris Yeltsin and other champions of democratization, decentralization and free market economics.
"Bush was so intent on shoring up Gorbachev that he was slow to perceive that by the summer of 1991, the Soviet leader was largely a spent force. Bush created the impression that he cared more about his friend in the Kremlin than about the principles of freedom and independence. His ties to Gorbachev -- and his reluctance to support Yeltsin -- ultimately became a liability in Bush's campaign for re-election."
Such assessments are rare in "At the Highest Levels," which for the most part eschews interpretation for straightforward reporting. Although the portraits of Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush that emerge from this volume are hardly new, they have been judiciously and powerfully amplified. President Bush comes across as a prudent, cautious man, fearful of making "the wrong mistakes," a man whose main contribution to ending the cold war was coaxing the Soviet Union toward surrender by, in the authors' words, "exercising restraint and refraining from pushing" too hard.
Mr. Gorbachev, in the end, emerges as a far more tragic figure, a forceful and charismatic man who spent his first four years in power unleashing a revolution that would change the world and who ended up "being a baffled witness of its consequences."

HEADLINE: Press Harder on Deficit Reduction

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is headed in the right direction with two of its major plans for reducing the Federal budget deficit -- a sharp cut in defense spending and a reduction in the cost of Social Security. But the Administration can't afford to flinch as it confronts two of the nation's most powerful interest groups, the military and the elderly.
Secretary of Defense Les Aspin's proposals to cut the military budget are fine as far as they go, but they don't go far enough. As Senator Everett Dirksen once observed in another context, a billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking about real money. Mr. Clinton needs to add some more real money to Mr. Aspin's unnecessarily modest proposals. 
 The Administration is also on the right track in debating ways to control the costs of Social Security. No deficit-reduction package will sell politically unless it distributes the pain widely and fairly, and the elderly must be part of that calculus. The only real choice is how to do it -- between a proposal that would hurt the poor and a far better strategy that would ask the wealthy to bear the burden.
Secretary Aspin has asked the Pentagon to cut the 1994 defense budget to $269 billion, $11 billion lower than the Bush Administration was proposing. He and Congress can surely find an additional $6 billion or so in unneeded spending on items like those below. That may not seem like much, at least by Pentagon standards, but it could add up to many billions more in later years.
What counts is not just the amount to be cut, but the way he cuts it. Reducing training and exercises provides only a one-year savings. Reducing current forces yields little immediate saving but saves billions over time. Cutbacks in new weapons yield both current savings and future dividends -- eliminating the costs of manufacture and of manning and maintenance for years to come.
There are plenty of candidates for trimming. The Navy does not need the new carrier it is building. Halting construction now would save nearly $3.8 billion in 1995, and billions more in future years. The Navy can also reduce procurement of guided missile destroyers from three per year to two. And the armed services want many more new tactical aircraft than they need or can afford.
Since the nuclear threat has disappeared, a number of strategic arms can be retired immediately, like Minuteman III missiles, half the B-52's and 8 of the 18 nuclear-armed subs. Nuclear warhead production can also be cut back.
In reducing personnel, Mr. Aspin has directed that cuts come from active duty forces. That's not enough. He also needs to cut the reserves, even if members of Congress object to losing local pork.
There are limits to what cuts in personnel can be realized in the coming year without unduly damaging morale. But the Administration must plan now for much deeper cuts in coming years to give the armed services time to adjust and allow those who have served their country honorably time to prepare for civilian jobs.
President Clinton will probably have to squeeze Social Security as part of a deficit-reduction package that spreads the pain across America. But he doesn't have to clobber the elderly poor by temporarily suspending cost-of-living increases in benefits, known as COLA's. A fairer way is to raise taxes on benefits to wealthier retirees.
Politically, it might seem foolish to threaten any of the nation's 30 million elderly recipients. The fact that Mr. Clinton might try testifies to the depth of his budget problem.
After paying for new programs he promised voters, the President must reach, by 1997, about $150 billion a year in spending cuts and tax increases to meet his pledge to slice the deficit nearly in half. Social Security -- 25 percent of Federal outlays -- looms as a likely target.
Eliminating COLA's for a year would produce huge savings by lowering the base on which future increases are calculated: about $38 billion over five years. But the consequences will be severe. The elderly rely on COLA's to keep their benefits even with inflation. A one-year suspension would push a half-million elderly into poverty.
There's another, so far overlooked, reason to keep Social Security COLA's intact. The Clinton deficit-reduction plan could include higher excise taxes on cigarettes and alcohol and higher energy taxes. With COLA's in place, the elderly poor will be immunized from price hikes. But without COLA's, the poor would face smaller monthly checks and higher heating and transportation bills. That would be an unconscionable double whammy.
That's why taxing benefits would make better policy. Social Security benefits would be taxed more like private pensions. The percentage of benefits subject to income tax would be raised from 50 percent, under current law, to 85 percent. To protect the poor, the tax hike would not apply to couples with annual incomes under $32,000 a year, or individuals with incomes under $25,000.
Raising taxes on benefits would save Washington less, about $30 billion over five years. But the tax hike would be fairer. Current retirees get back from Social Security much more than they paid -- including interest on those contributions. There is no justification for exempting well-to-do families from paying taxes on the difference.
If Mr. Clinton stands up and takes on the nation's retirees, one of Washington's most ferocious lobbies, he will deliver a resounding message that he's serious about the deficit. If he shrinks back, he will signal another year of budget games. Taking a fourth of the Federal budget off the budget-cutting table would force Congress to take impossibly large swipes at everything that remains.

HEADLINE: JUDGE WITHDRAWS FROM CLINTON LIST FOR JUSTICE POST

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Judge Kimba M. Wood withdrew today from consideration for Attorney General after the White House learned she had employed an illegal immigrant as a baby sitter before it became illegal to do so.
That stunning setback left President Clinton scrambling for the third time to fill the post. 
 There was no evidence that Judge Wood, who sits on the Federal District Court in New York, did anything illegal, but White House officials said they told her to withdraw because they feared the kind of public outcry that struck down the Administration's first choice for Attorney General, Zoe Baird, who had employed two illegal aliens for household work.
 
A Blank List
 White House officials said they were angry at Judge Wood because she had not told Mr. Clinton and other officials about her baby sitter, even when she had been directly asked. In her statement, however, Judge Wood said she had not misled the White House.
After the hasty search for a first nominee, then the rush to replace Ms. Baird, the Clinton Administration was forced by Judge Wood's withdrawal to start virtually from the beginning in looking for the nation's top law-enforcement official.
"They have nobody on their list now, period," said a Democratic Senator who is close to the White House. "They've got to start from scratch."
As late as Thursday evening, White House officials confidently said Mr. Clinton planned to announce Judge Wood's selection as soon as background checks were completed. But what the officials viewed as a done deal disintegrated later that night as officials questioned Judge Wood and studied documents she had submitted.
 
Trained to Be Playboy Bunny
 The sudden turnabout on Judge Wood is a blow to Mr. Clinton, who two weeks ago withdrew Ms. Baird's name after she admitted she had hired the illegal immigrants and had knowingly neglected to pay the required taxes for household employees.
Tonight the White House issued a statement on behalf of Mr. Clinton. "I understand and respect Judge Wood's decision not to proceed further with the possibility of being nominated as Attorney General," it said. "I was greatly impressed with her as a lawyer, a judge and a person. I respect her legal talents, judicial record and integrity. I wish her well."
The White House officials said they had also recently discovered that Judge Wood had briefly trained as a Playboy bunny years ago when she was a student in London and that they feared that that might become the source of jokes.
In the statement issued by her lawyer's office in New York, Judge Wood did not cite her stint as a Playboy trainee but said the issue was her hiring of an illegal immigrant from Trinidad, who worked for her for seven years. Judge Wood said she did not act illegally because her baby sitter was hired in March 1986, several months before the enactment of a Federal law making hiring of illegal aliens unlawful. The baby sitter obtained legal residency in December 1987, she said.
"On Jan. 29, I met with the President at the White House to discuss the possibility of my appointment," she wrote. "In the course of a wide-ranging discussion of policy issues, I was asked if I had a 'Zoe Baird' problem. I said I did not. And I do not."
Judge Wood went on to say: "I have fulfilled every legal requirement with respect to the employment of our babysitter. Nevertheless, and after further consultations, I have concluded that in the current political environment, proceeding further with the possibility of my nomination would be inappropriate."
 
Problems With Backups
 Complicating the matter is that the President is not ready to name a substitute candidate. Officials had initially said that if Judge Wood did not pass the background checks they would probably turn to Charles F. C. Ruff, a Washington lawyer and former senior Justice Department official, or former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia. But today, they said that questions had been raised about whether Mr. Ruff had employed an illegal alien and that the President was not ready to pick Mr. Baliles.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, sought in an interview tonight to play down any implication that the Administration was at fault. He said Judge Wood was asked about the issue of illegal aliens once by the President and twice by Bernard W. Nussbaum, the White House chief counsel.
"The White House search process discovered the problem," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "Judge Wood was asked about this matter twice before she interviewed with the President and once in her interview with the President. As the process moved forward, the White House did discover it because she delivered financial records that she had hired a baby sitter who was in the country illegally. After this information was discovered, and after consultation with the White House, Judge Wood decided to withdraw."
Asked about the disclosure that she had trained to be a Playboy bunny, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "I just don't know anything about it."
Officials close to the White House said the trouble developed in part because President Clinton, pressed by his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, insisted on finding a woman for Attorney General, which limited the field of Democratic contenders with a law-enforcement background. The problem with Judge Wood, they said, was that although she is a respected jurist, she lacked the law-enforcement and managerial credentials for the post. So when the disclosures arose, there was no great desire by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is chairman of the Judiciary Commitee, or other influential players to press her case.
 
A Lark in London
 Judge Wood is 49 years old and was appointed to the court by President Ronald Reagan in 1988. She had no experience with criminal cases before her appointment and had never conducted a trial before a jury. But she has earned the respect of other judges and lawyers who have come before her, and the President and Mrs. Clinton are said to have been favorably impressed when each interviewed her last week.
People close to the situation said Mr. Nussbaum contacted Judge Wood on Thursday to tell her that he had heard a rumor that she had put herself through the London School of Economics as a Playboy bunny.
According to people familiar with the conversation, Judge Wood told Mr. Nussbaum that in 1966 she was a student in London and that on a lark she had signed up for the bunny trainee program for the Playboy Club there. She told him she quit after five days, before actually being employed by the club or drawing a paycheck.
Mr. Nussbaum is said to have told Judge Wood that the episode would not disqualify her.
Even after the disclosures were made, officials said, Judge Wood wanted the White House to press ahead, as did some Administration officials. But the White House backed down, they said, after learning that Mr. Biden and others had serious reservations about the nomination.
As early as Thursday night, the White House struggled to contain the political fallout. Hours after some Administration officials told reporters an announcement on Judge Wood would be forthcoming as long as background checks did not turn up anything serious, officials called reporters at home after midnight to urge them to back off the story. At the time, they did not say there were developments that had diminished Judge Wood's prospects.
 
'They Want Squeaky Clean'
 By this morning, White House officials said Judge Wood's selection was in grave doubt, and as the day wore on and rumors flew through the capital it looked increasingly likely that her candidacy might not last the day.
Administration officials said Judge Wood and her husband, Michael Kramer, a political columnist for Time magazine, spent much of the day closeted with Administration officials in the hope of salvaging the nomination.
Officials involved in the background checks said the White House was being far more cautious than in the checks of Ms. Baird. They said officials were not only concerned about finding instances of illegality but anything that could raise any appearance of impropriety. "They want squeaky clean," said one official involved in the process. "They're worried about how all this will play in Peoria."
Another official who was deeply involved in examining Judge Wood's background expressed sympathy for the judge and said: "Under any other circumstances, this would have been totally ignored. But we can't afford the battle right now. It's a perception problem."
Fellow judges who serve with Judge Wood in the Federal Courthouse in lower Manhattan also expressed sympathy for her.
"I'm very, deeply disappointed for her sake," said Judge Thomas P. Griesa. "I think she would have made an outstanding Attorney General. "I'm really disappointed."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE HITS A 25-YEAR RECORD IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
The unemployment rate for New York City soared to 13.4 percent in January from 11 percent in December, hitting the highest level in the 25 years that the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics has tracked the city labor market, the bureau reported yesterday.
There were 447,000 people out of work in January, excluding those who had dropped out of the city labor market and were not actively seeking jobs. The number of jobless, which was up from 369,000 in December, was also the highest on record.
 
Seasonal Effect at Work
 The data were not seasonally adjusted, meaning that they were not statistically smoothed out to account for seasonal variations like the hiring of temporary workers by retailers during the December holiday season who are then laid off in January. Because of such practices, the unadjusted rate typically jumps in January, but even so this increase was unusually high. It surpassed the previous unadjusted peak of 12.1 percent reached in July. 
 Nationally, the unemployment rate eased two-tenths of a point in January, to 7.1 percent, and businesses expanded payrolls by 106,000, the Labor Department reported. But the national rate, which was adjusted for seasonal changes, dropped only because the total number of people in the labor force fell, and job growth has yet to rise at anything near the pace of overall economic activity. [Page 47.]
A seasonally adjusted rate for New York City was not available from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, but economists in the City Comptroller's office calculated one. Even by this measure, the city's unemployment rate was quite high: 12.8 percent, the highest since the office began to calculate it in January 1985.
 
A 'Stalled' Recovery
 "What was an anemic job recovery in New York City has now stalled," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional commissioner.
Noting that rebounds in employment often lag behind recoveries in the output of goods and services, economists pointed out yesterday that they had been predicting the city would lose another 50,000 jobs this year. Still, they said other indicators suggested that the city's economy was in fact expanding, albeit at an anemic pace.
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for New York State in January was 8.5 percent, the same as in December. New Jersey's rate fell to 7.4 percent from 8.3 percent, but the bureau said that was mainly because fewer people sought jobs.
January data for Connecticut have yet to be released. But some big Connecticut employers like the Pratt & Whitney jet-engine division of the United Technologies Corporation have announced plans for large layoffs, suggesting that the state's unemployment rate will not decline significantly anytime soon. The rate rose in December to 7.4 percent from 7.3 percent in November.
"As a job machine, the tristate regional economy has yet to come to life," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Several economists emphasized that the figures did not necessarily mean that New York City's economy was again contracting. Indeed, they said other indicators -- including wages, initial claims for unemployment insurance, business failures, business requests for telephone connections and stock market activity -- showed that it was still expanding and they expected it to grow by a sluggish 1 or 2 percent this year.
"There are too many positive things going on nationally and locally for the city to sink back into a deep recession," said John Tepper Marlin, the chief economist for the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman.
The Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University's business school said the city economy had been growing since June. "It's not entirely a surprise that unemployment went up in January," said Anirvan Banerji, an economist at the center.
According to the latest figures from the New York State Department of Labor, the city has lost about 370,000 jobs since April 1989, including 114,000 last year. The consensus among economists is that employment in the city in 1993 will remain unchanged, at best.
Bureau of Labor Statistics data indicated that employment among New York City residents fell by 98,000 in January. Typical seasonal factors, for example, layoffs by retailers and by companies with outdoor work like construction or recreation, do not appear to account for all of the job losses, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
While not all economists agreed with him, he also cited a continuing "restructuring and downsizing" in sectors like manufacturing, banking, advertising and accounting. He said that while retailers in New York and New Jersey had a good holiday season, they appeared to hire fewer temporary workers than usual, and he said Wall Street firms continued to handle their strong level of business without increasing employment.
"For New York State as a whole, 1993 starts out better than 1992," Mr. Ehrenhalt said, "but a job recovery is hardly yet a safe bet, particularly given what is happening in New York City."
The seasonally adjusted number of unemployed residents of New York State was 731,000 in January, up slightly from 726,000 in December. The number of employed rose a scant 19,000, to 7,877,000.
In New Jersey, the number of unemployed dropped to 290,000 in January from 332,000 in December. But the number of employed fell by 36,000, to 3,640,000. In other words, the drop in the unemployment rate reflected the fact that fewer people were looking for work.

HEADLINE: Balkan Mediators Ask U.S. Assent For NATO Planes to Keep Peace

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The international mediators trying to solve the Balkan crisis want the United States to support the use of NATO war planes to enforce provisions of their peace plan for ending the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, arguing that this would reassure Muslims and deter Serbs from further aggression.
The co-chairmen of the United Nations and European Community effort to bring peace to Bosnia, Cyrus R. Vance, a former American Secretary of State, and Lord Owen, a former British Foreign Secretary, also want the United States to provide modern satellite communications for the expanded 25,000-member peacekeeping force that the United Nations will be asked to send to Bosnia if all three factions agree to their proposals, officials close to the negotiations here say. 
 In addition, the two mediators are pressing the United States to take the lead in setting up a new international court to try those accused of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia as well as a special commission to monitor human rights issues.
The mediators hope that provision for enforcement of their peace proposal through air power, coupled with some alterations in their suggested division of territory that would be more favorable to Muslims, would together encourage the Clinton Administration to throw its full weight behind a modified version of their plan.
 
Interest in Washington
 Officials here said Lord Owen has received information from Washington that suggests the policy debate inside the new Administration is moving in his favor, with President Clinton now leaning toward supporting such a modified version of the Vance-Owen plan.
Such a step would mean that the United States would have to tell Bosnia's beleaguered Muslim forces they would not get any outside military help and that they should settle for a negotiated end to the conflict along the lines of the Vance-Owen plan.
So long as the United States is undecided about their proposal, however, the Serbs and the Muslims have little incentive to accept it.
Under the plan, which divides Bosnia and Herzegovina into 10 highly autonomous provinces, the armed ethnic factions are required to disengage and withdraw their artillery and other heavy weapons out of range of their opponents. The weapons would be stored with the United Nations peacekeeping force in areas where they could be monitored.
Mr. Vance and Lord Owen are now suggesting that the United States might strengthen that aspect of their plan by using NATO war planes to enforce the ban on military flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina and, if necessary, to bomb any army that fires its heavy weapons or fails to place them under United Nations monitoring.
Officials said such steps would help to reassure the Muslim side, which has fewer artillery and big mortar pieces than the Serbs. The enforcement operation would be organized by NATO's existing air command but would be under the control of the commander of the United Nations peacekeeping force.
Mr. Vance and Lord Owen, the officials said, also hope to negotiate changes in their plan for dividing the country into ethnically mixed provinces that would take more territory from the Serbs and give it to Muslims and Croats, thus helping making it more acceptable to the new American Administration, which has claimed it rewarded "ethnic cleansing."
Only when the United States is fully committed to their approach is there any chance that the Serbs and Muslims can be persuaded to accept it. This is because to secure Serbian support the Security Council must be ready to threaten President Slobodan Milosevic's Government in Belgrade with even tougher economic sanctions unless he uses his influence with the Bosnian Serbs to make them sign.
Similarly, the Muslims are holding out because they still hope that the United States will reject the Vance-Owen plan and either lift the arms embargo against the former Yugoslav republic so they can rearm or send a military force to rescue them. Bosnia's Croats are the only faction that has fully accepted the plan so far.

HEADLINE: Judge's Hiring of Illegal Alien in 80's Did Not Violate Immigration Law

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Judge Kimba M. Wood was right when she said tonight that she violated no law in hiring an illegal immigrant to work as her baby sitter in March 1986.
Congress outlawed the practice eight months later. On Nov. 6, 1986, President Ronald Reagan signed the Immigration Reform and Control Act, which prohibits the hiring of illegal aliens. 
 Under the immigration law as it existed before that date, it was against the law for illegal aliens to be in the United States, but it was not illegal for Americans to employ them.
The prohibition on hiring illegal aliens took effect immediately when the bill was signed by President Reagan on Nov. 6, 1986. It applied only to hiring that occurred after that date, and the penalties of the 1986 law did not apply to the continuing employment of illegal aliens who had been hired before it went into effect.
The 1986 law was passed after a bipartisan majority in Congress concluded that it was inconsistent, perhaps even hypocritical, to treat employer and employee so differently. The main purpose of the law was to curb the influx of illegal aliens. Recent studies by the Census Bureau show the law has not achieved that goal.
 
Judge Defends Acts
 Judge Wood, who sits on the bench in Federal District Court in Manhattan, withdrew her name tonight from consideration for Attorney General, declaring, "All of my acts were lawful." But she acknowledged that her baby sitter was in the United States unlawfully from 1980 to December 1987, when she gained legal status under the amnesty provisions of the 1986 law.
Even under the old immigration law, it was forbidden to bring an illegal alien into the United States or to conceal or harbor an illegal alien. For such offense, the law authorized a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $2,000 fine.
But a famous provision of the old law, known informally as the Texas proviso, stipulated that the employment of illegal aliens "shall not be deemed to constitute harboring."
This section was called the Texas proviso because many Texans took advantage of it by hiring illegal aliens from Mexico and other countries south of the border.
Judge Wood said her baby sitter's visa had expired when she was hired in March 1986. Most aliens with expired visas entered the United States legally, but fell into illegal status when they stayed here longer than allowed by the Federal Government.
 
Concern About Practice
 Although Judge Wood's action in hiring an illegal alien was not prohibited in early 1986, there was a growing consensus in the mid-1980's, expressed by members of Congress, that the employment of illegal aliens was an undesirable part of the underground economy. Jobs were seen as a magnet that drew illegal aliens to the United States.
Given this consensus as well as the strong public reaction to the case of Zoe Baird, President Clinton's first nominee for Attorney General, who withdrew after the firestorm over her employing two illegal aliens, it would have been politically awkward for Judge Wood to defend her hiring of an illegal alien at a confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
The 1986 law was known by the names of its sponsors, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky.
Charles Gordon, who was general counsel of the Immigration and Naturalization Service from 1966 to 1974, said that before passage of that law, "there was no prohibition at all on employment of illegal aliens as household workers."
Commenting on Judge Wood's fate, Mr. Gordon said in an interview: "This is an outrage. It was never contemplated that the law would be used to penalize career people who needed assistance to help them in the care of children."
In a letter to the editor of The New York Times last month, Mr. Gordon said the 1986 law and its "employer sanctions" should be reconsidered because they were ineffective.
David Carliner, an immigration lawyer who has written a book on the rights of aliens, also said that Judge Wood had done nothing illegal.
"It was made quite clear by the Justice Department that employers hiring undocumented workers before that date were not in violation of the statute, which was a criminal statute," Mr. Carliner said in an interview. "The department made clear that employers would be able to continue employment of people in illegal status who were hired before Nov. 6."
Mr. Carliner said Judge Wood was being treated too harshly. "She is being penalized for an action that was not illegal or improper at the time she employed the baby sitter," he said. "She didn't violate the law. I don't understand why she should have any adverse judgment relating to her because of this situation. It was done by many employers, and none of them were prosecuted or penalized."

HEADLINE: Text of Statements by Clinton and Wood

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
Following are statements by Judge Kimba M. Wood of Federal District Court in New York, who withdrew her name yesterday from consideration for the post of United States Attorney General, and by President Clinton:
 
 
 
Wood's Statement
 After consultation with the White House, I have decided to withdraw my name from consideration by the President for nomination to the post of Attorney General. The reasons for this decision are as follows: 
 On January 29, I met with the President at the White House to discuss the possibility of my appointment. In the course of a wide-ranging discussion of policy issues, I was asked if I had a "Zoe Baird" problem. I said I did not, and I do not.
First, since I hired my babysitter in March 1986, I have submitted all required forms and paid all required taxes on her behalf. Second, I complied fully with all immigration laws and made all filings and disclosures that should be made in compliance with the immigration laws. My hiring of my babysitter was legal in March 1986 (prior to the Fall 1986 enactment of the Immigration Reform and Control ("IRCA") which rendered hiring illegal aliens unlawful if they were hired after IRCA's passage), and my employment of her continued to be legal after the passage of IRCA, because IRCA explicitly excluded from its provisions employers whose employees were hired prior to its passage.
In March 1986, it was lawful to openly employ aliens who were in the country, like my babysitter, on an expired visa, as long as the required taxes and forms were filed. However, although all of these acts were lawful, my babysitter, like anyone pursing legalization, was not legally in this country from 1980 until she obtained legal residency in December 1987 through the IRCA amnesty program.
I maintained and provided seven years of records with respect to my babysitter and other household help. These records included my federal social security, FUTA and W-2 filings and payments, and my State unemployment compensation, disability insurance and workers' compensation filings and payments, as well as the files I kept relating to my babysitter's immigration status, including my Application for Labor Certification and her application for federal amnesty pursuant to IRCA.
In sum, I maintained appropriate records and made all required filings and payments for the seven years that my babysitter has been in my employ.
Thus, I have fulfilled every legal requirement with respect to the employment of our babysitter. Nevertheless, and after further consultations, I have concluded that in the current political environment, proceeding further with the possibility of my nomination would be inappropriate.
 
 
 
Clinton's Statement
 I understand and respect Judge Wood's decision not to proceed further with the possibility of being nominated as Attorney General.
I was greatly impressed with her as a lawyer, a judge and a person. I respect her legal talents, judicial record and integrity. I wish her well.
