HEADLINE: Germans' Apprentice System Supports Economic Vitality

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 5

 BODY:
When Michel Sorgatz finished school last year, he did not have to read classified ads to find a job in his chosen field. Instead he entered an apprentice program at one of Germany's largest companies that will teach him a profession and virtually guarantee him a job.
On his way to a high-tech career working with metals, Mr. Sorgatz, 19, spent three weeks learning on the job at Siemens and two more weeks at a specialized school. At the end of his three-year apprenticeship he will take an examination, and if he does well, he will probably be offered a job at Siemens, an electronics and computer products manufacturer. 
 The German apprentice system has been in effect for decades, and is an outgrowth of the guild system that began in Central Europe centuries ago. But only in the postwar era, when Germans established a range of heavily subsidized social programs, have the government, labor and industry instituted such a wide-reaching and highly regulated and subsidized career training and placement system.
The system is considered a major reason for Germany's long economic boom. With the Clinton Administration searching for ways to make the American labor force more competitive, various public agencies in the United States are studying Germany's approach.
"You can't be too sure about the future given the overall economic situation, but in general I think the German system is positive," Mr. Sorgatz, who earns a gross salary of $600 a month, said one recent morning. "The best aspect of it is that you get theoretical training and practical experience at the same time."
When finished training, Mr. Sorgatz would earn three to five times his apprentice salary, as do trained employees working in his department.
Dietrich Volker, who directs training programs for Dresdner Bank, said, "It's a very expensive system, but if you ask anyone who's ever studied it whether it works, you will get a resounding yes."
The German system requires a greater level of regulation than may be acceptable in the United States. Germany officially recognizes nearly 400 professions, and to practice any of them fully, a citizen must hold a diploma from a specialized school.
Although the German system has succeeded in producing several generations of highly productive workers, it is not without critics. Some say that by regulating employment so tightly, the system rewards formal training over talent.
A hairdresser who has great natural ability or has been tutored privately, for instance, may work in Germany but may not open a salon. Salons may be run only by certified hairdressers who have completed a formal three-year training program and passed an examination.
Other critics say that while the German system works well in finding jobs for craft workers and business administrators, it is less effective at placing university-trained professionals. In addition, although job training and placement has long been considered a western German success story, the system has not yet managed to stabilize the labor market in newly absorbed eastern states. Many people in the east have lost jobs in antiquated industries and have no modern skills.
 
Most Are Pleased
 But most Germans are evidently pleased with their country's career training system. A recent survey of 10,000 apprentices by a group called Young German Business showed that 19 of every 20 were learning careers they find interesting, and that only 3 percent were pessimistic about job prospects.
Because the German career-training system is administered by various federal and state agencies, its full cost is difficult to compute. Budget figures, however, show that state and local governments spend a total of about $5.5 billion for vocational education every year, with the federal Government adding about $4.5 billion.
The system is costly not only for taxpayers, but also for industry, which at any given moment is supporting nearly 1.5 million apprentices. These apprentices perform work, but not enough to earn back their training costs and salaries. One research agency has estimated that business invests about $8,400 a year in each apprentice.
Businesses also assign many of their experienced workers to part-time teaching posts at vocational schools, picking up most of the costs themselves.
Despite these heavy costs, however, most business leaders are pleased by the results.
"Our German economy lives from the high quality of its workers," said Bernhard Jenschke, an administrator of vocational programs in Berlin. "Business recognizes this, and pays a great deal of money to guarantee a steady flow of highly trained workers. It's an investment in human quality."
Mr. Jenschke has received several delegations of American educators and labor planners recently. He told them that Germany's career-training programs have social as well as economic benefits.
"We help young people bridge the gap from school to career at an important time in their personal development," he said. "When German kids are between 16 and 20, most of them are in a combination of school and career training. They know that if they do well, they will have good futures. They're motivated. They get a sense of orientation and meaning to their lives. They don't feel hopeless or drop out of society."
Principal responsibility for overseeing the German system lies with the Federal Labor Agency, a sprawling nonprofit corporation run by representatives of business, labor and government. The agency employs 96,000 people at its headquarters in Nuremberg and at 184 branch offices and 646 counseling centers.
 
Employing Many Psychologists
 The labor agency has a legal monopoly on career counseling in Germany, but it does much more than channel people into vocations. It is the largest employer of psychologists in Germany, and offers a range of testing services devised to bring each citizen into the career where he or she will be happiest and most productive.
In addition, the agency supports a research institute at which 120 specialists analyze long-term trends affecting the German economy. They predict which industries are likely to grow, which new ones are likely to emerge, and what sorts of skills future German workers will need.
"We have a system that has provided us with great prosperity and stability," said Joachim Drechsler, a Siemens executive. "The American hire-and-fire system would definitely not be accepted here."
Like most German companies, Siemens replenishes its work force by hiring and training apprentices. Its 20,000 employees in the Berlin area are responsible, in addition to their other tasks, for guiding about 1,100 young apprentices who are learning 20 trades and professions. The apprentices earn between $575 and $675 a month.
"It is a very complex system, and it could be adopted in a country like the United States only in steps," Mr. Drechsler said. "First you'd have to decide that you want to pay the price. After that, you'd try to figure out where to begin -- maybe by building a network of modern vocational schools."
Germans usually have their first contact with the labor agency at the age of 14 or 15. Counselors visit every ninth-grade class to explain the agency's work and encourage students to use its Career Information Centers. At the centers, all visitors are entitled to individual counseling.
The Career Information Centers are heavily used. On most days they are full of young people taking computerized tests, watching films that describe the rudiments of various careers, and reading files that explain salary ranges and working conditions.
About two-thirds of German students choose a career path -- not necessarily one they stick to -- when they are in the 10th grade. They then apply for an apprentice position at a company and, after acceptance, enter the dual system of work and study that is the core of career training in Germany.
Most German concerns prefer to hire new employees only at the entry level, and to fill other openings by promoting from within. The way to rise through nearly any company, therefore, is to begin in its apprentice program.
Apprentices work not only in large companies like Siemens, but also in countless small and mid-sized factories and offices.
Ayfer Ataf, 20, thinks she wants to be a dental assistant. After finishing the 10th grade, she signed up for a three-year training course, of which she has completed about half. The Berlin dentist, Peter Schmidt, for whom she works makes a special effort to hire children of Turkish or other immigrants as his apprentices, or to hire applicants from eastern Germany. By doing so, he believes, he is helping to integrate German society.
Miss Ataf spends two days a week at a school in Berlin where all the students are dental assistants. They learn about dental technology and office administration, but also pursue academic subjects like literature and social studies.
On the other three days, Ms. Ataf wears a white jacket and works as an assistant to Dr. Schmidt, earning about $500 a month. He is pleased with her work and says he will be happy to hire her at the end of her training, but she is not sure she will accept.
"I look at this as a three-year experience, not a lifetime commitment," Ms. Ataf said. "If I decide it isn't for me, I'll take an apprenticeship in some other field, maybe as a hospital technician. There are plenty of possibilities."
Students who do not enter the "dual system" after the 10th grade usually remain in school for three more years. Then they begin a process similar to what the 10th graders went through, except that the number of occupations open to them is greater.
 
Some Jobs Unregulated
 A few professions in which creative ability and other intangible skills are thought to be required, including journalism, are left unregulated. Employers in these professions are free to hire people regardless of their training or lack of it. Standards for hiring university professors and other highly specialized professionals are also left largely to employers' discretion.
Nearly everyone entering the German work force, however, has either completed an apprenticeship or used some of the resources offered by the labor agency.
A growing number of apprentices are well into their 20's or older, including women entering the work market after raising children and people who want to change careers in mid-life. The labor agency is trying to insure that these applicants are given the same opportunities as new graduates, but some companies still prefer young people as apprentices.
The newspaper Frankfurter Rundschau recently published a long study analyzing problems in the "dual system." But it acknowledged in an editorial that most Germans consider the system so successful that it should not be altered.
"Do we really need apprentices in every bakery, art studio, hotel, travel agency and gas station?" the editorial asked. "The usual answer is, 'Of course we do, because otherwise what would happen to our businesses and industries? How would we keep training the typical German high-tech workers who are the envy of the world from Japan to Detroit? What would become of our social and economic stability?' "

HEADLINE: Hanga Roa Journal;
As World Crowds In, an Island Shields Its Culture

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANGA ROA, Easter Island

 BODY:
The topography is like the political climate in this speck of land with its Polynesian people isolated in the South Pacific.
At first, Easter Island appears to be a pleasant and even breathtaking place, with undulating pastures carpeted in pale green that spike up to rounded peaks and then plummet into blue Pacific. But just under the surface are sharp volcanic rocks that make walking painful. 
 Born of fire three million years ago, the island has been a territory of Chile for 104 years. Now its people are beginning to vent pent-up anger and fight the growing dominance of Chilean and Western culture.
In November, a militant group that had been formed to protect the Polynesian culture staged demonstrations to stop the Chilean Navy from building a lighthouse on a sacred ceremonial site. Navy officials say the lighthouse was intended to help island fishermen.
 
Statues and Sacred Rocks
 The same group had interfered earlier in plans to use what its members considered sacred rocks to repair the airport runway and had stopped the Chilean Government from sending one of the island's giant stone statues, or moai, to an exhibition in Hawaii.
Many islanders are openly challenging the Government in Santiago, demanding control over their land; the use of their native language, Rapa Nui, as the main language in schools; a school curriculum better oriented to their Polynesian culture; local management of archeological sites, and the appointment of islanders to all local government posts.
"We have lived 104 years as Chileans, but more than 1,000 as Easter Islanders," Alberto Hotus Chavez, Mayor of Hanga Roa, said.
For scientists here, Easter Island is an example of exotic, unique and weakened cultures struggling to survive amid a shrinking, modernizing world.
"This is an extraordinary culture," said Gonzalo Figueroa, the foremost Chilean archeologist on the island, which is 2,300 miles off the Chilean coast. "But islanders are finding their children are going off to school in Santiago, learning different ways, not speaking their native language. They are very worried about that."
For the Chilean Government, the stirrings seem almost like ingratitude. Government officials say the islanders receive large subsidies from Santiago and are not required to pay taxes.
"What is being discussed is not change, but the velocity of change," said Angel Cabeza, director of Cultural Affairs at the National Forest Service in Santiago. "As far as we are concerned, the Rapa Nui have economic and political power in their hands." The people and culture, as well as the language, are called Rapa Nui.
But Mr. Cabeza conceded that the central issue, control of the land, will not be resolved quickly.
Currently, 40 percent of the island is administered as national parkland, another 40 percent is Government land on which an agricultural testing station is operated. The islanders own only the remaining 20 percent.
Government officials fear giving up control over some of the most exotic archeological sites in the world, and they worry that it might lead to a movement for independence.
On the island it is hard to find many who say they favor independence, mainly because they realize that their deep economic dependence on the mainland.
 
Cultures Clash
 Though they are outwardly friendly, the Rapa Nui and Chileans acknowledge a complex clash of two very different civilizations.
Chileans, known for their industriousness, say they cannot understand the ethos of the Polynesians, many of whom say they pride themselves on leaving time to enjoy the sun that sparkles off the water.
And islanders say they are offended by what they describe as a persistent racism and treatment as second-class citizens by Chileans.
"When I was going to college in Santiago, they nicknamed me the cannibal," said Virginia Haoa, the secretary of the Corporation for Cultural Protection, the group that blocked the lighthouse. "I realized then how different we were and that we had to fight for our culture."
During the 16th and 17th centuries cannibalism was widely practiced here, as a result of deforestation and hunger, archeologists say. The practice gradually came to an end.
 
New Source of Worry
 Islanders are worrying now about another new exposure to Western culture, the first filming of a major motion picture on Easter Island that is being co-produced by Kevin Costner.
Island officials say they are worried that some of the hundreds of film-industry members who will come for the filming will bring drugs and AIDS.
"A lot of us are getting tested voluntarily," Zane Weiner, production manager for the film, said. "As far as drugs, if we find someone taking drugs, we'll send them home."
Perhaps the most radical manifestation of the low-level cultural warfare is the emergence of the Corporation for Cultural Protection.
"We are different from Chileans in language, culture and way of thinking," Rodrigo Paoa, the group's founder, said. "As a Rapa Nui, if I want to sleep, I sleep. If I want to eat, I eat. I can spend a week without spending any money. If we are not careful, people will turn this island into another Hawaii or Tahiti, where the only important thing is money."

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Rises At Fastest Pace in 3 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
American consumers borrowed heavily to buy cars in December, driving up their debt at the fastest rate in nearly three years, the Government said today.
Consumer installment credit rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.1 percent in December, to $725.9 billion, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Federal Reserve said. 
 It was the biggest increase since borrowing rose at a 6.4 percent rate in February 1990.
Credit outstanding rose at annual rates of 1.8 percent in November and four-tenths of 1 percent in October. Before the most recent gains, credit outstanding had shrunk for seven consecutive months.
For the year, consumer credit was down three-tenths of 1 percent. That followed a 1 percent drop in 1991 -- the first since 1958 -- and a 2.6 percent gain in 1990.
The cutback in borrowing during the recession and subsequent economic doldrums was a reaction to the huge debt levels that many consumers built up during the 1980's.
Borrowing finally began increasing after many Americans reduced their monthly payments by refinancing their mortgages and other loans at lower interest rates.
But economists said consumers were unlikely to completely revert to the free-spending ways of the previous decade until the economy begins providing more jobs.
"A number of families have reduced their debt loads, but they're more cautious," said Norman Robertson, a private economist in Pittsburgh. "I would not look for a sudden surge of borrowing and spending."
In December, automobile loans advanced at a 7.3 percent annual rate to $259.3 billion, following a 4.2 percent increase in November.
Revolving loans outstanding, which include credit card balances, increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.7 percent, to $251 billion, the fifth consecutive increase.
Other consumer loans rose at a 3.1 percent annual rate to $215.6 billion. This category includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations.

The Economy
New York City's unemployment rate soared to 13.4 percent in January, the highest level in 25 years. Officials said the data were evidence that the city's anemic job recovery had stalled. [Page 1.]
The nation's unemployment rate eased two-tenths of a point in January, to 7.1 percent, but the rate dropped only because the number of people in the labor force fell. [47.]
Consumers borrowed heavily in December, driving up their debt at the fastest rate in nearly two years. [34.]
The Fed said it abandoned its tilt toward lower interest rates in December and adopted a neutral policy. [35.]
 
 Companies
British Airways' chairman resigned amid other management changes taken to restore the airline's image after reports of a dirty tricks campaign against Virgin Atlantic Airways. [35.]
American Airlines may close two hubs and retire several planes in a retreat from its strategy to operate nationwide. [35.]
Analysts wonder whether Jack in the Box will be able to recover from the crisis created when two children died from infections linked to tainted food at some of its restaurants. [35.]
Barr Laboratories was ordered to recall batches of some of its medicines and stop distributing others until it studies its manufacturing process. Its stock price dropped 30 percent. [37.]
Amgen shares plummeted after earnings were released and analysts lowered their recommendations on the stock. [37.]
Microsoft was not disciplined by the F.T.C. over accusations of unfair competition in personal computer software. [37.]

International
Interest rate cuts by Japan and Germany were welcomed by American officials, many of whom want the two nations to do more to stimulate their languishing economies. [34.]
 
Markets
The Dow hit a second straight record high, rising 25.40 points to 3,310.03. Its gain for the week was the third-best ever. [35.]
Treasury bond prices advanced, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 7.15 percent. [44.]
Lumber futures took a wild ride, with the March contract up the $10 limit while subsequent months closed $10 lower. [46.]
The dollar finished stronger against the German mark but mixed against other major currencies. Gold was mostly lower. [46.]
 
 Your Money
A home office presents pitfalls in taking tax deductions unless strict Internal Revenue Service guidelines are followed. [33.]
Many stock newsletters will now boast of good "long term" performance because the effects of the October 1987 crash are gone from their five-year track records. [33.]
The few extra dollars that began showing up in weekly paychecks after withholding taxes were cut last year means that refunds will be skimpier and that some will owe taxes. [33.]

HEADLINE: Japan's Surplus Increases 61%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Japan's current account surplus jumped 61 percent to a record $117.62 billion in 1992, the Government said today.
The Ministry of Finance said the surplus in the current account -- the broadest measure of trade in goods and services -- rose from $72.9 billion in 1991. The previous record, $87 billion, was set in 1987. 
 The trade component of the nation's balance of payments rose to a record $132.6 billion surplus in 1992 from the previous high of $103 billion a year earlier, the ministry said.
Japan was already under increasing pressure from the United States and the European Community to trim its surpluses. But a sluggish economy is dampening imports while a strong yen exaggerates the size of Japan's exports.
Figures for the American portion of the imbalance were not immediately available.
Japanese exports rose to $330.8 billion in 1992 from $306.56 billion. Imports slipped to $198.2 billion from $203.57 billion.

HEADLINE: Florio Receives More Cheery Budget News

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio, who this week returned from Washington with $412 million in back Medicaid payments to bolster his soon-to-be-released state budget, has gained some more bright budget news from the Federal Government and a state judge.
Treasury officials said today that the Department of Labor has postponed a $96 million debt repayment that dates to Gov. Thomas H. Kean's administration. And a Superior Court judge threw out a lawsuit by state employee unions challenging last year's revamping of the state pension system. 
 The pension change provided more than $1 billion for the current state budget and is expected to add more than $500 million to the budget that Mr. Florio will release on Monday, said Richard McGrath, a state Treasury Department spokesman.
Mr. McGrath said Federal officials told the state that it can wait until 1994 to repay $96 million to the state Unemployment Trust Fund, freeing those revenues for this year's state budget.

HEADLINE: Expert Links Mandatory Desegregation to 'White Flight'

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 5

 BODY:
Large numbers of whites have removed their children from public schools wherever mandatory integration plans have been imposed, an expert testified today in the state's defense against a suit challenging the racial and economic segregation in Hartford's schools.
In the Hartford area, said the expert, Prof. Christine Rossell of Boston University, a survey done for the state found that 51 percent of the whites questioned said they would move or resort to private schools if a desegregation plan assigned their children to a city school. 
 Flight occurs even when a plan covers an entire metropolitan area, as the plaintiffs are seeking for Hartford, as long as parents are not allowed to choose whether to take part, she said.
 
Seeking Desegregation
 "Every single mandatory reassignment plan that we can find in a metropolitan area suffers significant white flight," Professor Rossell said. "I can't find any that have not."
Professor Rossell attacked several important contentions of the plaintiffs in this suit, Sheff v. O'Neill, in which civil-rights lawyers say the segregation in Hartford's schools have denied the city's children an equal educational opportunity.
The suit contends that the state has not acted to eliminate the segregation. Despite more than 25 years of studies identifying segregation as a serious problem, 90 percent of the city's students are black or Hispanic, and two-thirds are poor.
It is also seeking a desegregation order covering Hartford and 21 surrounding towns, on the theory that including an entire metropolitan area eliminates a major incentive for white flight, the ability to avoid integrated schools by moving a short distance.
Professor Rossell, however, not only testified against both points, but offered herself as the ultimate evidence that people deeply involved in desegregation can change their opinions on the value of mandatory integration.
As late as the mid-1980's, Professor Rossell was a frequent expert for plaintiffs in desegregation cases, testifying on the extent of white flight that courts would have to expect, and helping to design plans to minimize white flight.
But as her research progressed, she said today, it began to show that voluntary integration plans, in which parents could choose to send children to new schools, or keep them in their neighborhood schools, were achieving greater mixing of whites and minority students than mandatory plans.
A chief reason, she said, was that so many whites left the public schools under mandatory plans that not enough remained to provide meaningful integration.
"The goal of a desegregation plan," she said, "should be to integrate minority and white students, and to have enough whites in that plan so that the schools look integrated."
 
'A Leader in the Nation'
 As a result of these findings, she said, "plaintiffs stopped calling me." Now she is a leading expert for school boards and other government agencies defending themselves against desegregation suits.
Professor Rossell began her testimony today by calling Connecticut "a leader in the nation" in financially supporting urban schools and in promoting efforts to integrate city and suburban students.
"This is a state that is committed to integration," she said. "It's not committed because of a court order, but because its elected representatives think that's what its people want."
As she compared white flight under mandatory plans and voluntary ones, Professor Rossell drew frequent objections from Ron Ellis, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, over her definition of "mandatory."
The plaintiffs are seeking a court order setting specific goals and deadlines for integrating schools in the Hartford area, but they would like the actual plan to include voluntary components, like magnet schools.
But Professor Rossell does not consider a plan "voluntary" just because it includes magnet schools. Unless parents can choose to keep their children in their current school, she said, a plan is mandatory, and magnet schools are then simply one way to take part.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has emphasized the potential of voluntary measures to achieve the goals he has offered in legislation calling for towns and cities to achieve greater racial balance.
Professor Rossell also testified that large-scale metropolitan plans do not minimize white flight because they add to one major concern of parents, the distance children have to travel, while not addressing a second concern, the quality of the school at the end of the bus ride.
Much of that testimony was also contested by Mr. Ellis because it focused on Los Angeles, where a busing plan ordered by state courts in the 1970's drove most whites out of what had been considered one of the country's best urban school districts.
While Professor Rossell contended that the Los Angeles plan was metropolitan because it covered a vast area, Mr. Ellis argued that it was not, because Los Angeles is a single school district, unlike Hartford and its suburbs.
Professor Rossell was an expert for the plaintiffs in the Los Angeles case. One of the chief witnesses for the defense was David Armor, a professor who will be the state's final witness here.

HEADLINE: U.S. Jobless Rate Falls As Labor Force Shrinks

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The labor market showed further spotty improvement in January as the nation's unemployment rate eased two-tenths of a point, to 7.1 percent, and businesses expanded payrolls by 106,000, the Labor Department said today.
But the latest survey, representing the first broad view of the economy's performance last month, showed that the unemployment rate dropped only because the number of people in the labor force fell. And job growth has yet to rise at anything near the pace of overall economic activity. 
 Though its findings were expected, the survey had been eagerly awaited because it is considered a reliable overall indicator of business activity as well as a gauge of social distress.
 
 
'Still Too High'
 Many economists as well as Democratic politicians said the figures underscored the need for a dose of Government spending to stimulate the economy. President Clinton called the 7.1 percent jobless rate, the same as in January 1992, "better, but still too high."
The survey was also the final major report to be published before President Clinton must decide on the contents of his spending initiative. Those plans, which are likely to add about $31 billion to the budget deficit, are to be announced on Feb. 17.
"He still believes that it's necessary to try to kick-start the economy, particularly in the area of job growth," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House press spokeswoman.
The basics of today's report had been fairly accurately predicted and thus did not surprise the stock or bond markets. Bond prices dropped slightly after the Labor Department's announcement, but then rose the rest of the day.
Still, deciphering the unemployment rate was more difficult than usual because of large seasonal swings, measurement difficulties, crosscurrents in various industry sectors and, in the case of January's rate, a figure that was far less encouraging than it first appeared.
The jobless rate fell to the lowest level in a year only because the work force dropped by 508,000, to its October level, after rising substantially in November and December.
Department officials said they could not account for this other than to note that January is typically a month of huge seasonal swings, including the discharge of workers hired for the holiday shopping season.
 Had the labor force remained unchanged, the rate would have risen about five-tenths of a point instead of declining two-tenths of a point, they said. The number of people with jobs, according to the department's survey of households, fell 240,000.
The household survey, conducted in 58,000 households through personal interviews and by telephone, asks people whether they are employed. The employer survey, based on records of more than 350,000 establishments, is considered a better gauge of the economy; it also reflects people who hold more than one job.
Typically, the labor force expands when the economy is on the rebound because people who have given up looking up jobs -- and are thus not counted as unemployed -- become encouraged enough to start searching again. There has been no clear trend in the size of the work force since mid-1992, following a hefty rise.
At the same time, there were some undisputed positives in today's report, most of them showing up in the survey of employers' payrolls.
The length of the workweek in American factories jumped another 12 minutes, to 41.4 hours, its highest level since 1966. Factory overtime edged up 6 minutes, to 4 hours, with employers determined to get maximum production from workers already on the payroll before hiring new ones.
 
 
'Stretched to the Limit'
 But employers will probably be unable to do this much longer.
"That is stretched to the limit," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for the Chemical Banking Corporation in New York.
In fact, factory jobs rose a moderate 34,000 in January, the second gain in three months following large losses from August through October. These gains were widespread, though an official expressed reservations about the accuracy of a big jump in the automobile industry because of shifts in that industry's seasonal patterns.
Another bright spot was that 57.4 percent of all industries added workers last month, up from 52.8 percent in December and the highest proportion since April 1992. Manufacturing industries posted similar gains.
"You could describe it as a pattern of moderate but pretty entrenched growth," Walter M. Cadette, an economist for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said of the report.
 Employment in retail trade climbed 69,000, entirely in bars and restaurants, automotive dealers and food stores. Department stores and other businesses selling general merchandise shed 5,000 jobs.
Construction employment fell another 37,000, partly reflecting harsh weather. Employment in the services industry edged down as small gains in business and health services failed to offset losses elsewhere.
The household survey showed that the improvement in the jobless rate was largely confined to adult men, whose rate fell four-tenths of a point, to 6.4 percent. That matched the rate for women, which was unchanged for the month. Unemployment among teen-agers was 19.7 percent, pushing the overall jobless rate up.
The number of unemployed who had involuntarily left their last jobs fell by 290,000, with 60 percent of the decline among those who were on layoff and were expecting to be recalled, the report also showed. The ranks of those out of work at least 15 weeks fell by 288,000, but there was a 230,000 increase in the number of newly unemployed.
Among the 11 biggest states, the only sizable changes in the jobless rate were nine-tenths of a point declines for New Jersey, to 7.4 percent, and for Michigan, to 7.1 percent. But because of relatively small state samples, these were considered to be of little statistical significance.
The unemployment rate for New York State was put at 8.5 percent, unchanged from December.
Regionally, the Northeast and West both posted declines of two-tenths of a point, to 7.9 percent and 8.3 percent, respectively, while the jobless rate remained at 6.8 percent in the South and 6.2 percent in the Midwest.
"All in all, it was a pretty good report," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist for CRT Government Securities in New York. "But it's not the type of employment growth that's going to satisfy the Clinton Administration and Congress."

HEADLINE: U.S. Officially Pleased at Foreign Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
American officials welcomed this week's interest rate cuts by Germany's and Japan's central banks, but they were reluctant to say in public what many express privately -- that the two nations should do more to stimulate their languishing economies.
Not only do Mr. Clinton's economic aides fear starting off wrong in relations with the world's two other industrial superpowers, but Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen has said he prefers private persuasion to public badgering when Washington wants to put pressure on its partners. 
 "We welcome the reduction in German interest rates," said Mr. Bentsen, who has called for greater cooperation among the Group of Seven leading industrial nations, as well as an increased commitment to growth.
American officials have talked with the Germans and Japanese in the last week. They declined to discuss the conversations.
But officials and economists said Germany and Japan cut their rates principally because of domestic economic slumps, not because of importuning from abroad.
Bush Administration aides vigorously and repeatedly pressed Bonn and Tokyo to cut interest rates and make other moves to keep their economies out of recession, but that pressure had mixed results, at best.
"There's no question the U.S. would like more stimulus in Japan and Germany," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, who served as an economic official in several previous Administrations. "But there's a realization that this will occur when those countries regard it as appropriate for domestic reasons, rather than in response to outside pressures."
 
Optimism in Washington
 Administration officials said they expected the rate cuts in Germany and Japan to spur growth there, adding that this should lead these countries to import more American goods. "Low interest rates around the world and in the United States help promote further growth and create jobs," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, at a news briefing on Thursday.
American officials seemed especially pleased by the German rate cuts because they believe they will help buoy growth throughout Europe and calm fragile currency markets.
Indeed, two Government officials, speaking privately, said they hoped that the Bundesbank, which had resisted lowering rates for fear of inflation, would soon follow its cuts Thursday with other such moves. That would reduce tension in Europe's monetary system, in which several countries have had to raise interest rates to keep their currencies from plunging against the German mark.
But officials are less eager for the Bank of Japan to cut its rates further because that could weaken the yen against the dollar and increase Japan's $47 billion annual merchandise-trade surplus with the United States. A weak yen as a rule means cheaper prices for Japanese products abroad, and many economists say that the yen is already undervalued in relation to the dollar.
Several officials said that as a next step, they want the Japanese Government to approve a big new economic stimulus program, with tax cuts and deficit spending on public works projects. Such a stimulus would in theory increase Japan's growth and imports without pushing the yen down against the dollar.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

FEARS OVER FREE-MARKET POLLUTION
Under the Clean Air Act of 1990, if a company could clean up its emissions more than required, it could sell the right to pollute to another company. But an announcement this week that the Long Island Lighting Company was selling some of its pollution rights to another company has raised fears in New York's environmental community. Because the law does not regulate the sales or require companies to provide any public information about them, at least until 1995, pollution could be quietly shifted from one region to another, critics say. Page 1.
 
 NEW YORK CITY
 
 JANUARY JOBLESS RATE HIGHEST ON RECORD
The unemployment rate for New York City soared to 13.4 percent in January from 11 percent in December, hitting the highest level on record in the 25 years that the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics has tracked the city labor market. There were 447,000 people out of work in January, excluding those who have dropped out of the labor market and are not actively seeking jobs. That number, up from 369,000 in December, was also the highest on record. Page 1.

A Federal judge ruled that Amtrak must permit an artist to display a montage criticizing the owners of the Coors Brewing Company on a giant billboard in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. Amtrak had rejected the artist's montage of pictures and text on the ground that it had a policy of barring political advertising. Page 25.

The former top tenant adviser to the New York City Housing Authority pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Manhattan to embezzling $32,000 in a case that law-enforcement officials said the authority's former chairwoman, Laura D. Blackburne, tried to keep quiet. Page 25.

 FALSE ALARM ON INSURANCE

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher Against Mark But Mixed in Other Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished stronger against the German mark, but mixed against other major currencies yesterday after an employment report showed improvement in the United States economy.
Gold prices were mostly lower worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $328.70 a troy ounce, off 30 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell 55 cents to a late bid price of $327.80. 
 The Labor Department reported that the nation's nonfarm payrolls rose by 106,000, slightly higher than expected. The unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point, to 7.1 percent.
The data, which provided signs of an improving economy, made the dollar and dollar-denominated securities more attractive than their European or Japanese counterparts.
"Worldwide it looks as though, temporarily at least, the rosiest picture is in the U.S.," one foreign-exchange trader said.
 
Impact on Interest Rates
 Traders said the numbers also persuaded the financial markets that the Federal Reserve would not lower interest rates soon. That is a positive for the dollar, since higher interest rates in the United States make it more attractive.
"It also means that a lot of people, if they want to get a nice return on dollar investments, would be getting into the bond market and stock market and would need to buy dollars to do that," the trader said.
In New York, the dollar settled at 124.45 yen, down from 124.65 yen on Thursday. The British pound cost $1.4460 in New York, vs. Thursday's $1.4405.
Other late dollar rates in New York included: 1.6580 German marks, up from 1.6565; 1.5325 Swiss francs, even with Thursday; 5.6075 French francs, up from 5.6000; 1532 Italian lire, down from 1536 and 1.26155 Canadian dollars, down from 1.26295.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.6554 German marks, up from 1.6540; 1.5279 Swiss francs, down from 1.5290; 5.5940 French francs, up from 5.5915; 1.8524 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8619; 1,527.00 Italian lire, down from 1,533.25, and 1.2615 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2630.

HEADLINE: Fed Adopted Neutral Stance At December Policy Meeting

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve said in a report today that its chief policy-making committee abandoned its slight tilt toward lower interest rates in December and adopted a neutral policy, a move that will probably disappoint politicians who want further rate cuts.
Such a neutral policy generally indicates that the Fed remains as worried about slow growth as about a possible increase in inflationary pressures. And the report, describing the Dec. 22 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, said the central bankers had not totally ruled out changing interest rates. 
 According to the report, the committee unanimously abandoned its bias toward lower rates in a reaction to the pickup in economic growth. The bias toward easing did not mean the committee planned to cut rates, just that it was predisposed to do so, especially if the economy deteriorated.
The Fed committee met again on Tuesday and Wednesday of this week, but its decisions at that meeting will not be announced until late next month. Many economists suggested that the panel held to its December decision favoring neither lower nor higher rates.
In a move today that some said demonstrated the central bank's intentions not to cut rates soon, the Federal Reserve in New York removed some reserves from the banking system. It acted after the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- had fallen to 2.78 percent, well below the Federal Reserve's target of 3 percent. Draining reserves from the system subtly tightens the supply of credit, helping push the Federal funds rate back up.
Still, the summary of the December meeting said members "observed that the next policy move might be in either direction."
"The need for some easing could not be ruled out, should the expansion again appear to be faltering," the report said.
But it also raised the possibility of increasing interest rates. "A stronger economic performance," the report said, "might raise questions as to the need for a tightening move at some point during the year ahead as a means of maintaining progress toward price stability while continuing to encourage maximum sustainable economic expansion."
The report added that if tightening was needed, it would be desirable to raise rates "before inflation pressures showed through in the actual price statistics in order to avoid sharp and potentially disruptive tightening actions later."
When Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified before Congress last week, several lawmakers criticized Fed officials for even talking about inflationary pressures and increasing interest rates when inflation is 2.9 percent and the jobless rate is above 7 percent.
The report said committee members in their December meeting anticipated that inflation would continue to fall, although "some now expected somewhat less improvement than they had earlier." The report said recent data on consumer prices and wages "had a somewhat less favorable tenor."
But the report saw several factors helping to hold down inflation, including unused industrial capacity. It noted that large-scale layoffs were tending to hold down wage demands and that productivity gains and import competition would also help hold down inflation.
The committee adopted its policy favoring lower interest rates in July when the economy was sluggish. It decided to continue that policy in its August and October meetings, although in October it adopted a stronger "marked" bias toward easing. The Fed last cut rates on Sept. 4, when it reduced the Federal funds rate to 3 percent from 3.25 percent.
The Federal Open Market Committee consists of the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board and the presidents of the Fed's 12 regional banks.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Kinds of Coins
Q What is the difference between bullion and numismatic coins?
 
 JEANNIE AARON, MANHATTAN
A "A bullion coin is a coin that has either silver or gold content and is usually 90 percent pure," said Harvey Stack, a partner of Stack's Coin Company. "The value of the coin is determined by its weight in relation to the current bullion prices on the commodity exchanges." Examples are dimes, quarters and half dollars dated 1964 or earlier. 
 In contrast, a numismatic coin can be made of any metal, including precious bullion metals, but is a rarity because of limited supply and great demand for the item. "Examples of American coins with such a scarcity are the 1877 1-cent piece and the 1885 5-cent piece," Mr. Stack said. Unusual foreign pieces like ancient Greek silver coins and medieval European gold coins are also in this category.
 
Municipal Bonds
Q What are pre-refunded municipal bonds?
 
 FRANK GALLO, BALDWIN, L.I.
A According to James F. Lynch, president of Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, pre-refunded municipals are tax-free bonds backed by Treasury securities, AAA-rated and generally maturing between 1994 and 2003. Originally issued when interest rates were higher than they are today, these bonds have been pre-refunded -- or called before their maturity -- by the issuance of other municipals at lower interest rates.
"When the issuer sells a new issue at today's lower rates, it takes the proceeds and buys U.S. Government bonds whose income and principal is used to pay off the old bonds," Mr. Lynch said.
He also noted that because of their high quality and liquidity, pre-refunded bonds were appropriate investments for people seeking maximum safety. Even though they are are always sold for more than their face value, their yield is typically higher than a comparable-quality bond selling at par.
 
Self-Directed Keogh
Q I have a self-directed Keogh account. Can I deduct the interest on money borrowed to make this year's contribution to the account?
 
 DITTE JENSEN, VENTURA, CALIF.
A Interest on any money borrowed for personal purposes, even to fund a Keogh contribution, is deemed to be nondeductible personal interest.
The broader question here, however, is really whether interest on this loan can be considered investment interest, which in some situations is tax deductible.
Morris Lipton of Lane & Lipton, a certified public accounting firm in Valley Stream, L.I., said that investment interest generally must produce what is known as portfolio income to obtain the tax benefit.
"Portfolio income is income from interest, dividends, annuities or royalties that are not derived in the ordinary course of trade or business," he said.
Mr. Lipton concluded that because the proceeds of the loan were going directly into a tax-deferred Keogh account that would not produce taxable portfolio income, the Tax Code would not recognize the interest you would be paying as deductible investment interest.

HEADLINE: Not Enough for Domestic Partners

 BODY:
In moving to grant them some of the benefits enjoyed by married couples, Mayor David Dinkins makes a welcome gesture of recognition and respect to the non-marital relationships that constitute "family" for millions of New Yorkers. Yet he continues to dodge the most urgent issue facing non-traditional families -- health care benefits.
The Mayor will create a city registry in which residents or nonresident city workers can file as "domestic partners." Homosexuals or unmarried heterosexual registrants will have the same standing as married couples in qualifying for city apartments, the same visiting rights at city jails and hospitals. Those who work for the city may also take unpaid leave to care for newborn children. 
 Those are worthwhile measures, but they fall short of Mr. Dinkins's 1989 mayoral campaign pledge to offer health coverage to the live-in partners of city employees. The Mayor now says he lacks the legal authority to issue an executive order. Yet that's not so clear.
Mayor Dinkins cites a letter from the State Superintendent of Insurance opining that state law bars insurance companies from offering group health plans that include domestic partners. But the judge in a pending lawsuit filed by three homosexual teachers has rejected that statutory interpretation, and a unanimous appellate panel has denied a move by the city to dismiss the case.
Instead of clinging to the city's legal brief, Mr. Dinkins might have exerted himself earlier in his term to try to persuade Gov. Mario Cuomo to change the state policy. If the Mayor's real concern is costs, he should say so openly and commission a realistic economic analysis. In localities that now offer health benefits to domestic partners, the costs have proved surprisingly modest.
While unwilling to test his own executive authority on the issue of health coverage for domestic partners of city workers, Mr. Dinkins has endorsed legislation in the City Council that would achieve the same thing. But Council Speaker Peter Vallone takes an obstructionist position, refusing even to allow hearings that might help educate the public and develop added safeguards against fraudulent use of such new coverage.
He says that state insurance and domestic relations law pre-empts any Council action. That conveniently constricting view of the Council's jurisdiction hardly masks Mr. Vallone's hostility to the civil rights of homosexuals.
The courts may eventually decide that existing laws against discrimination on the basis of marital status and sexual orientation require the city to grant the health benefits. In the meantime, more candor from top city officials would be refreshing.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Laundry And Debt

BYLINE: BY RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
I am trying to worry about the deficit but make no headway. Driving shirts to the laundry, I am worrying about the American laundry situation when a radio yakmeister insinuates himself into my ear.
He is worrying about the deficit. He asks people to phone him. I think he is in Seattle, but may be wrong because the laundry problem has my mind by the throat. 
 The radio is bleating idly away, soaking into the car upholstery. I usually leave it that way on the chance that sooner or later Daniel Schorr will come on and say something interesting.
Mostly what it picks up is America yakking. If my car seats could talk they would probably telephone Rush Limbaugh and denounce Congress for raising its pay.
So this day, Thursday, I am debating whether to give the laundryman a piece of my mind or treat him to some cutting sarcasm. Three weeks running my white shirts have come back tinted a faint but unmistakable blue.
The laundryman is a simple, hard-working man. The best way to get results, doubtless, is to speak forthrightly: "If these shirts come out blue this time, fella, my business goes elsewhere."
Yet I am not good speaking forthrightly. Simple, hard-working men on whom I have tried it sense that I lack the killer instinct to back up threats. On the other hand, a sneer would be lost on the laundryman, so there is no point in saying, "After washing these shirts, do you think you could bear to hold the dye?"
From this thought I segue instantly into a favorite worry: America can't cut the mustard anymore. How can we hope to sell Japan cars with steering wheels on the wrong side when we can't even get our white shirts back from the laundry white?
Somewhere around here I am aware of a radio talk show in progress. In a faraway place, possibly Seattle, a man is urging people to phone him and tell all America what they are willing to sacrifice to cut the Federal deficit.
The question shames me briefly. My answer, if hauled before this nationwide audience, would be a despicable, "Nothing." That's because I've always thought deficits highly overrated.
I recall Republicans railing for 30 years that deficits would kill us all, which they didn't. I recall the Republicans then running up a deficit that made the Democrats look like bush-league deficiteers. And now suddenly everybody agrees with the old-time Republicans that the deficit will kill us all.
My life in Deficit Land leaves me suspicious that politicians, not to mention economists, don't understand deficits any better than my laundryman, not to mention me, understands quantum electrodynamics.
Nevertheless, here is one of these inescapable call-in radio shows assuming that the kind of people who call in are so desperate about the deficit that they will go on the air and pledge sacrifices to end it.
Instantly my mind, accustomed to taking big philosophical leaps, propounds a proposition: If the American masses were to master the details of their daily toil -- the laundryman keeping the blue out of the white shirts, the oil-changer remembering to put fresh oil in the car after draining the crankcase, and so on -- then the habit of efficiency would become so ingrained in the national spirit that no deficit whatever could possibly occur.
In short, as long as the laundryman persisted in turning the white shirts blue, sacrifices would be powerless to cut the deficit.
Listening to America phoning in, I am heartened to see that it agreed with me. One caller, not a Congressman, said he would happily sacrifice Congress's pay raise. A Brooklyn woman who struggled, she said, to supplement her poor mother's paltry Social Security check offered to accept a substantial income-tax increase on my salary.
At the laundry I am too depressed to mention the blue in the shirts. Back home I walk past the TV set. Maury Povich is talking to a young woman. The caption on the screen identifies her as "Recovering Sex Addict." Another woman speaks. "Engaged to Recovering Sex Addict," says the caption. The audience is enthralled.
Was it for this and failed laundry that we won the Battle of Midway?

HEADLINE: Real Help for the Everglades

BYLINE: By Robert W. Hahn; Robert W. Hahn is an economist at the American Enterprise Institute and research fellow at Harvard. He consults for the U.S. Sugar Corporation.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In her hearings for confirmation as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner spoke of the need for a "new era of communication" between environmentalists and business. As one of her first moves, she has a rare opportunity to work to the benefit of the environment and the economy, resolving a dispute with which she is keenly familiar.
As head of the Florida Department of Environmental Regulation, she led the state into an agreement with the U.S. Justice Department aimed at preserving the Everglades, one of the world's great wetlands. The pact between Florida and the Federal Government called for protecting the area by reducing phosphorus runoff from farmland. The phosphorus, thought to harm native plant species, comes from soil, fertilizer, sugar mills, rain and irrigation water. 
 Despite a pro-business reputation, the Bush Administration, through the Justice Department, imposed a cleanup on Florida, requiring farmers to insure that their runoff water is cleaner than rain. The $400 million plan envisages building 35,000 acres of experimental filtering marshes which even some government environmental consultants doubt would work as advertised, and handing the bill to farmers. Sugar and vegetable farmers said that the costs would drive out most of the region's agriculture and, by some estimates, put 20,000 people out of work.
Because of the huge costs associated with the plan, the Everglades issue is far from settled: the so-called solution makes no attempt to balance the economy and environment.
Here's a way to break the logjam: adopt a system that allows pollution credits to be traded, an arrangement that was successfully built into the 1990 Clean Air Act to curb acid rain. The idea is to have government set targets for phosphorus reduction but give farmers maximum flexibility in achieving them.
The Justice Department plan made no attempt at a fair distribution of public and private responsibilities for cleaning up the Everglades. Initially, farmers were to pay for everything, no matter how much of the phosphorus problem they actually caused. Then there was talk of an arbitrary deal, dividing costs between agriculture and government.
While any division of environmental responsibility is arbitrary, people should be asked to pay to clean up only the part of the problem they cause. In the Everglades, farmers should be responsible for making sure that the level of phosphorus in water leaving their land is no greater than the rain and irrigation water that comes on in the first place. If government thinks the water should be cleaner than that, then it has an obligation to pay for the cleanup.
The key is to allow farmers to decide how best to reduce the phosphorus. Each farm would receive one credit for each pound of phosphorus it may put into public canals. Farmers whose water is easily cleaned up can sell their credits to others. That way, farmers will have a powerful market incentive to invest in new cleanup technology -- a Clinton Administration goal -- and costs will come down for everyone.
This market is intended to make pollution prevention pay. Farmers may well discover they can remove more phosphorus than they now believe is possible, thereby lowering public cleanup costs too. As the history of technological progress has always shown, where there is an incentive, someone finds a way.
Government may end up building filter marshes to meet some of its own cleanup responsibilities. Then the question will be which level of government should pay. As E.P.A. Administrator, Ms. Browner can help see to it that the Federal Government faces up to its share of blame for the problems in the Everglades.
Washington has poured money into a vast canal system near the Everglades that supplies water and controls floods, but it has hurt the environment by rerouting natural waterways and disrupting native life.
The Everglades, a national treasure, has received short shrift for too long. Ms. Browner can achieve an early victory if she can gain the support of environmentalists and farmers for a pioneer plan that could be the model for environmental policy for decades to come.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Who Pulled the Big Five's Plug?

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
"You don't care 'bout the water till the well runs dry," goes an old blues refrain. Classical-music fans who may have missed this bit of folk wisdom are discovering it for themselves, now that one of the luxuries of the radio landscape -- weekly national concert broadcasts of the best American orchestras -- is fast disappearing. In the last five years, corporations pinched by the recession have been withdrawing sponsorship for these series, which cost up to $1 million a year to produce. And many classical-radio programmers have come to see the concerts as a nuisance rather than a boon.
These broadcasts are important for many reasons. They offer newcomers to classical music large samplings of repertory in unvarnished performances and a concert context. They allow more devoted listeners to track the progress and programming of orchestras around the country, and with concert tickets selling for as much as $55, they give radio eavesdroppers something for nothing. They introduce new conductors and soloists. And they include new works, giving listeners quick access to pieces likely to cause a stir and granting a moment in the sun to scores that may never be commercially recorded. 
 For orchestras, the broadcasts establish a national profile that can translate into sales of recordings and concert tickets, and an image that helps attract donors. And they serve a crucial archival purpose that is vividly illustrated in the current exhibition of New York Philharmonic broadcasts at the Museum of Television and Radio in New York. They have even, in a way, helped orchestras perpetuate themselves.
"We decided at one point to personalize the orchestra by having the players speak in the intermission features," said Roy Hemming, the producer of the New York Philharmonic's broadcasts during the 1980's. "Week after week the musicians would bring up how important the broadcasts had been for them when they were growing up in different regions of the country. The Philharmonic's broadcasts convinced them that there was more to music than the school orchestra, and helped them set their professional sights."
Right now, the national radio roster is topsy-turvy. There are syndicated broadcasts by the Florida Philharmonic and the Detroit, Baltimore, San Francisco and Pittsburgh Symphonies. All are solid, polished ensembles but not brand names on the level of the so-called Big Five -- the New York Philharmonic, the Cleveland and Philadelphia Orchestras and the Chicago and Boston Symphonies. Yet since 1988, three of the five -- New York, Philadelphia and Boston -- have been off the air.
A fourth, the Cleveland Orchestra, is living on borrowed time. Since December, when the oil company BP stopped underwriting the broadcasts, the orchestra has been using concert recordings from its archive. It must find a new sponsor by the end of the season, and the search is not going well.
"We visited one Fortune 500 company," said Robert Conrad, the president of WCLV, the Cleveland station that produces and syndicates the broadcasts. "On our way to the meeting, we walked past empty office after empty office. We knew then that the company's financial situation precluded their helping us."
Only the Chicago Symphony's broadcasts are going strong. And recently its longtime sponsor, Amoco, asked the orchestra to find other sponsors to share the costs.
The reasons for this decline are many and tangled. Players in the big orchestras receive higher broadcast fees than their less famous counterparts, and most management efforts to save the broadcasts by seeking concessions in pay have been fruitless. By contrast, in Boston, where the symphony musicians regard local broadcasts as community service and demand no fees, concerts are carried live by two stations.
Orchestra broadcasts have a time-honored place on American radio. The New York Philharmonic was the first to take to the airwaves, in 1922, and the first to be carried coast-to-coast, by CBS in 1930. In 1937, NBC created the NBC Symphony for Arturo Toscanini. Concert shows were remarkably popular, and they kept famous conductors and renowned orchestras in the news. When the young Leonard Bernstein replaced an ailing Bruno Walter for the Philharmonic broadcast of Nov. 14, 1943, his debut became a national sensation.
By the mid-1950's, other orchestras were broadcasting, too. Only in the 1960's, when generalized radio formats splintered into special-interest stations, were orchestra broadcasts shunted into a smaller spotlight. Even so, as classical-music stations flourished, so did concert broadcasting. More of the smaller orchestras found sponsorship and broadcast outlets, and through the early 1980's, concert broadcasts were the centerpieces of classical stations' programming.
But as the costs of these shows have been spiraling upward, corporations that long saw them as classy advertising vehicles have been reconsidering, particularly since their own profits are down. Many continue to sponsor the orchestras' concert series and other endeavors. Thus, when Thomas W. Morris, the executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra, laments BP's decision not to renew its $900,000 annual radio sponsorship, he hastens to add, "Even without the radio, BP remains our biggest corporate donor."
Smaller orchestras have been luckier. Their production budgets are lower, and they have been able to tap into the civic pride of locally based companies whose national ambitions match their own. The Florida Philharmonic, formed only seven years ago, has been on the radio for three years in a 13-week, hourlong series syndicated by the Concert Music Network. Its sponsor, Alamo Rent A Car, pays $250,000 a year for the series, which is heard in 43 cities across the United States, and considers it a bargain.
"We do them because we think it's good business," said Mark Cannon, the director of marketing at the Fort Lauderdale company. "The Concert Music Network reaches about 12 million listeners a week. Even if the show is heard in a market where we don't have a rental car location, these are people who travel all over America, and who are likely to visit someplace where we are."
But the high-ticket orchestras that have been searching for corporate sugar daddies these last few years consistently report experiences like Mr. Conrad's in Cleveland.
"I think the days of broadcast seasons supported by huge funders are over," said Ruth Dreier, who produces several concert programs (including those of the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam) and has been a consultant to American Public Radio. "Orchestras are going to have to recognize that this kind of funding will never happen again, and that it's folly to keep looking in that direction. What we're going to have to do is build a consortium of sponsors that a lot of orchestras can draw from."
Until recently, sponsors have not wanted to share the spotlight or the on-air gratitude. Amoco's dealings with the Chicago Symphony suggest that things may be changing.
But matters have been further complicated for the large orchestras by mounting deficits, occasioned by a lethal combination of rising costs, dwindling government and corporate subsidies, the same maladies from which the entire American arts world has been suffering in recent years. "The larger orchestras have a broad range of activities that they are raising money for now," said Deborah Borda, the managing director of the New York Philharmonic, "so that while broadcasts are important to us, they are only one of many things that are."
In fact, orchestra managers offer divergent opinions about the importance of broadcasts in the grander scheme. "Outside Cleveland," Mr. Morris said, "the orchestra has three ways of being heard. There are the broadcasts, recordings and tours. Now one of those avenues may be closed to us."
Mr. Morris's colleague at the Chicago Symphony, Henry Fogel, who once ran a classical-radio station in Syracuse, said that determining the place of radio in the list of financial concerns is tricky: "When you are trying to find regular annual contributions, and corporate underwriters for major proj ects like tours, there's no question that you have to make priorities. If you say that radio's a priority, and you get a corporation to underwrite your broadcasts, chances are that you can cross that corporation off your list of companies that will also give you a quarter or half a million dollars for a tour.
"I don't know what's more important to an orchestra," he added, "touring or being on the radio once a week. Most orchestras would say touring. And in terms of the orchestra's image in the community, when we come back from Europe with great reviews, our contributors see it as a sign that this is truly a great orchestra. But I'm not so sure that the people of Chicago think about the fact that the orchestra is heard on some 500 radio stations in the United States."
All this is occurring as classical-radio programmers around the country are asserting that the traditional fly-on-the-wall concert format -- the full concert, with intermission interviews and program notes read by an announcer -- is too dull for listeners today. But the facts sometimes suggest the opposite. A spokesman for WNCN in New York noted recently that the Chicago Symphony's two-hour broadcasts often received the highest ratings of any of the station's programs. This contradicts WNCN's much-emulated programming philosophy, which prizes bright, brisk, unchallenging music and holds that informed comment on the music should be left to textbooks. So the station regards Chicago's success as an anomaly.
"Because Chicago is the only orchestra broadcast we carry," explained Mario G. Mazza, WNCN's director of programming and operations, "it's like a jewel on black velvet. It's perceived as a high-quality product, and it has done well for us in the 25- to 54-year-old demographic. That's why I keep it.
"But I would not want to do a lot of this," he added. "Radio programmers like to maintain control of the sound of the station. And since a lot of orchestras are taking a strong stand on behalf of modern music, a lot of that can show up on the air."
Mr. Mazza is not alone in wanting to control his airwaves. His direct competitor in New York, Warren Bodow of WQXR, has said, "The radio should not necessarily be regarded as a pipeline from the concert hall to the living room." Several years ago Mr. Bodow and other station directors argued that orchestras should allow stations to delete contemporary works. When this was proposed to the New York Philharmonic, in the late 1980's, the orchestra responded that the broadcasts had to run intact or not at all. The stations relented.
The control issue is sometimes negotiable. To the stations, concert broadcasts mean easy profits. The stations incur no production costs. And in important markets the sponsors not only provide the programs free but also buy the air time.
"In television, commercial companies buy the air time, and the stations use the revenue to pay for the programs," said Joseph H. Kluger, the president of the Philadelphia Orchestra, which has been off the air since 1990. "Here, the sponsor is paying for the programming and for the air time. Our sponsor, Cigna, underwrote our programs to promote the image of the company. After five or six years, they concluded that they had accomplished what they set out to do, and their advertising people told them that the arrangement was no longer efficient.
"The problem is," he added, "the stations take the view that they aren't going to be paying for programming in any case. If they don't carry the broadcasts, they can just as easily go into their libraries, put on a couple of compact disks and call it 'The Philadelphia Orchestra Hour.' "
But Ms. Dreier, in an audience study carried out for American Public Radio in 1991 and 1992, found that a majority of listeners preferred concert broadcasts over disk jockeys spinning CD's. In four cities, study groups were drawn from listeners in a demographic group regarded as typical of the public-radio audience nationwide: highly educated, affluent 25- to 45-year-olds, including some who were passionate about classical music and some, mostly at the younger end of the scale, who viewed classics as one interest among many.
"What we found was encouraging," Ms. Dreier said. "Both the audience we have, and the target audience, perceived value in the concert broadcasts. But they have to be produced in a way that is attractive to listeners. Orchestras have to realize that a straight transmission of the concert, with an announcer calling the moves in a not very interesting way, has to change."
Orchestra managers have reached a similar conclusion. Most are considering one-hour shows that include recent performances, interviews and perhaps archival recordings. Still, many believe that even if the major orchestras can recapture their place on the air through such measures, something vital will have been lost.
"In Cleveland," said Mr. Conrad of WCLV, "we want to produce concerts that convey what the audience hears in Severance Hall. These programs are put together carefully by the music director. And his purpose would be defeated if we mixed and matched. We have to do a careful balancing act. While we're a profit-oriented station, we're not in it entirely for the profit. It was our choice to broadcast classical music. If we just wanted to be entrepreneurs, we'd be rocking and rolling."
 
 
 
THE BIG FIVE, DROPPING FROM THE AIR WAVES
 For many years until 1988, all of the Big Five orchestras had national radio outlets for concert broadcasts. One by one, these programs have been disappearing. Here is a status report.

Chicago Symphony Orchestra
On the air, but . . . .
 
 Status: Amoco, the orchestra's longtime radio patron, has asked the symphony managers to find other sponsors to share both costs and credit.
Prospects: "I think we will remain on the air," said Henry Fogel, the orchestra's executive director. "It is conceivable that it will be with a reduced schedule."
 
Cleveland Orchestra
On the air, barely.
Status: When BP, an oil company, withdrew its sponsorship in December, the orchestra began distributing a 13-week series of Mozart concerts from its archive, hoping a new sponsor could be found by May.
Prospects: "We have been looking," said Thomas W. Morris, the orchestra's executive director, "and we are examining alternatives that involve more than one sponsor."
 
Boston Symphony Orchestra
On the air locally, off nationally.
Status: The orchestra never had a national radio sponsor; stations paid for use of its programs until last year. Its concerts are still carried live by both WGBH and WCRB in Boston.
Prospects: "We have a committee that has approached potential sponsors and is working aggressively," said Kenneth Haas, the orchestra's managing director, "but no luck yet."
 
Philadelphia Orchestra
Off the air.
Status: Cigna, an insurance company, withdrew its radio sponsorship in 1990.
Prospects: "We have sent proposals to every conceivable potential sponsor, unsuccessfully," said Joseph H. Kluger, the orchestra's president. "But I'm an eternal optimist."

Off the air.
Status: The first orchestra in the country to broadcast its concerts (in 1922), the Philharmonic lost its Exxon sponsorship in 1988.
Prospects: "I know the Philharmonic will be back on the air," said Deborah Borda, the orchestra's managing director. "The question is when, and what the format will be."
