HEADLINE: A DIRECTORY CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
Record Bookings in a Buoyant Year

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL reports on travel and tourism for The Times.

 BODY:
THE first two weeks of the year are always the cruise industry's busiest, but reservations during that period this year broke all records. Carnival and Royal Caribbean together booked more than 125,000 passengers in the first week, 8,000 more than last year's record, and other cruise lines also reported big increases. The main reasons for the booking surge, according to industry executives, were pent-up demand and an improving economy.
Reservations have since returned to normal, but if the economy continues to improve and potential world trouble spots stay quiet, the industry expects almost five million passengers this year, 10 percent higher than 1992. At least five new ships are scheduled for delivery this year, at least six others are planned by 1996 -- which, despite the increased bookings, may be too much of a good thing from the industry point of view. 
 While spring and summer itineraries feature few new destinations, some of the more exotic ports of call include Ho Chi Minh City, Warnemunde in the former East Germany, and two of the Baltic states: Riga, Latvia, and Tallinn, Estonia. And Premier will be the first cruise line with regular stopovers at Port Lucaya on Grand Bahama Island.
Many destinations will experience a marked increase in cruise ship visits, including Waterford, Ireland, where Royal Viking will be joined by six other lines, and Dominica, in the Windward Islands, where several ships will be calling at Cabrits, its new port. American Hawaii recently resumed cruises to Kauai, which was closed to cruise ships after Hurricane Iniki tore through last year.
One of the biggest traffic increases will occur in the Panama Canal; 15 ships will cross it this year. Carnival's Tropical will make a series of transcanal sailings from San Juan, marking Carnival's first departure from the Caribbean and Mexico. Sun Line has scheduled three 12-day canal cruises in March, originating in Galveston, Tex. Royal Caribbean, which crossed the canal 10 times last month, will offer two 11-night passages in April.
In the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, some cruise line officials began referring to the Mediterranean as the Dead Sea. But it is on the itineraries of 17 lines this year, including spring or summer cruises by Windstar, Crown Odyssey and Seven Seas (which will enter European waters for the first time after three seasons in Alaska).
The Mediterranean is often at the mercy of world events, but that area is not alone. Bowing to customer complaints, Seawind Cruise dropped its scheduled port call in Caracas, after two attempted coups rocked the Venezuelan capital last year -- one of them involving shooting in the streets.
Moreover, only a handful of ships will call at sub-Saharan Africa. Part of the reason is lack of the necessary infrastructure to handle large numbers of tourists, but cruise line officials also say many of their passengers generally, if unfairly, equate Africa with famine and civil unrest.
However, Princess Cruises will visit Africa this year for the first time. In November it will offer a 16-day trip between Mombasa, Kenya, and Singapore, with stops at Zanzibar and the Seychelles, as well as a 14-day trip from Athens to Mombasa. Next year its 19-day cruise will stop at Dakar, Senegal, in west Africa.
A record 24 ships will call at Alaska between May and September, at fares for the 7- to 15-day cruises ranging from about $1,000 per person to $4,000. While many ships promote their casinos, fitness centers, sports bars and similar amenities, World Explorer, entering its 16th year in Alaskan waters, says its accent is on learning -- it bills the 12,000-volume library aboard its Universe as the largest afloat.
Regency Cruises also sails to Alaska, as well as South America and the Caribbean. On June 7 it will launch the first of 30 seven-day cruises this year between New York and Montreal -- the most of any line, and double the number it ran previously.
Although still small in numbers of visitors, Asia is the fastest growing cruise destination. The number of ships calling at Singapore more than doubled last year over 1990, and later this year Windstar will be the first cruise line to establish year-round operations there.
At least six cruise lines will call this year at China, the most since the Beijing Government killed and imprisoned protestors in Tiananmen Square in 1989. SeaQuest Cruises alone offers three different itineraries to China this spring, from 11 to 15 days. Ocean Grace, a luxury Japanese cruise ship, will put in at four mainland Chinese cities during an eight-night tour in May. And Pearl Cruises, which claims to have pioneered cruising to China in 1982, will be back again this year and will also visit Vietnam on five different sailings.
Several lines, including Seabourn, will enter Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia for the first time. Others, including Cunard, Sagafjord, Seven Seas, Orient and Pearl, will expand itineraries in the region.
"Unlike some other parts of the world, Asia is stable," said Herb Goodfellow, president of The Travel Company of Atherton, Calif., one of the oldest and largest all-cruise agencies. But future growth will be hampered by inadequate port facilities in the region and high air fares.
While American travelers are not yet flocking to Ukraine, Odessa America Cruise Company ("The Cruise Line of the Czars") offers a seven-day cruise each Saturday from St. Petersburg, Fla., to Honduras, Belize and Cancun.
Those cruises -- aboard the 400-passenger Gruziya ("Georgia"), which is registered in Odessa, Ukraine, and has a Ukrainian and Russian crew -- sail only through May, at which time the ship is repositioned to Montreal for five months.
While exotic destinations usually require two or more weeks, the two- to five-day cruise market continues to be the fastest growing. This summer, for example, for the first time, Regency will offer five "cruises to nowhere" from New York, each of them last two to three days at sea. Majesty is offering four-night cruises from Miami that stop at Playa del Carmen and Cozumel, Mexico.
Prices are about the same as last year, especially to such competitive destinations as the Caribbean, which accounts for more than 60 percent of all cruises, and from West Coast ports to Mexico. Moreover, at least six new ships are scheduled to join the fleet this year, including Carnival's Sensation (2,600 passengers), the CostaRomantica (1,350), Norwegian's Windward (1,246), the Crown Dynasty (820), and two from Holland America -- the Statendam (1,266) and its sister ship, the Maasdam (1,266). The 7,869 new berths will bring the industry total to well above 100,000 for the first time, but they will also add to what critics complain is the overcapacity that has driven fares on many East Coast cruises to the Caribbean and West Coast cruises to Mexico to levels below $100 a night per person, includng air fare.
And there appears to be little let-up. Carnival and Holland America (a subsidiary of Carnival) each has a new ship scheduled for delivery next year, while Carnival has yet another one scheduled for 1995, by which time industry officials had hoped the shipbuilding binge would pause to let demand (and higher prices) catch up with supply. Last month Carnival announced plans for a 2,600-passenger ship, for delivery in 1996, while Princess said it would build a 1,950-passenger ship to enter service in the fall of 1995.
A new Miami-based line, American Family Cruises, recently announced that in December it would begin seven-day Caribbean cruises for families with children, adding Alaska in the summer of 1994. While its two ships are refurbished rather than new, its 2,800 berths will add to the competition. And while not a direct competitor, the Delta Queen Steamboat Company, the New Orleans-based line that plys America's inland rivers, also expects to take delivery of a new paddlewheel late next year, its third boat.
The care and feeding of children is on the minds of many in the industry, not just the marketing officials at American Family Cruises. While cruises often include movies and menus for the younger set, Celebrity's 1993 cruises to Bermuda have expanded the offerings to face painting, scavenger hunts, dance lessons, video tournaments and photo contests. Dolphin's cruises feature Fred Flintstone and Yogi-bear characters. Holland America will provide youth counselors aboard its cruises during spring break, and will offer activities for teenagers and preteens.
SUCH new approaches are important in the current highly competitive market. "Overcapacity is making it hard for the cruise industry," said Mr. Goodfellow. He characterized last year's discounted fares to Mexico and the Caribbean as "a bloodbath," and said he expected a repetition in 1993.
To avoid such a fate, many cruise lines now give their biggest discounts to passengers who book earliest, then reduce the discount as departure dates near. Royal Caribbean pioneered the concept last year, and at least a half-dozen other lines have adopted similar programs. This year, as part of a $40 million advertising campaign, Royal Caribbean has a toll-free number for potential customers to request brochures and videos.
Holland America is offering early booking discounts of up to 10 percent for its cruises to Europe, starting from New York in May, and savings of up to $400 per couple on its cruises to Alaska. Seabourn passengers booking two successive cruises totaling 21 days or more can save up to 50 percent for one of the two cruises. Celebrity is offering 50 percent off for the second person on selected 10- and 11-night cruises to the Caribbean. And Radisson is offering 50 percent off the published tariff rates on its Caribbean trips in March.
But travel agents say many passengers are still likely to wait for, and get, last-minute deals on the most competive cruises.
And discounting remains so rampant that several lines are considering omitting the rate sheet from future brochures.

HEADLINE: Apartment Rentals Tightening

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
FUELED by a growing demand and a slowly shrinking supply, rents for New York City's unregulated apartments, which had declined significantly since the stock market crash in 1987, are starting to show signs of bottoming out.
To be sure, few brokers foresee a quick return to the days of the mid-80's when finding a decent rental -- at least by New York standards -- required a bribe called "key" money or a perusal of funeral notices for soon-to-be vacated apartments. 
 Indeed, the market continues to be very soft, and rents last year dropped in many parts of the city, particularly in areas where gentrification never fully took hold and for such apartments as studios, small one-bedrooms, fourth-floor walk-ups and units in buildings without doormen.
But the rent declines were not, for the most part, as steep as they were in previous years. Overall, rents in New York have dropped about 15 percent since the real estate recession began in 1988, about half as much as the sale prices of co-ops and condominiums.
Moreover, at the luxury end of the market and in a few select neighborhoods, rents appear to have stabilized. And in some places, such as parts of Brooklyn, Queens, Westchester County and midtown Manhattan, some rents have even started to rise.
"What we are seeing now is a tightening of the market," said Alan Rogers, managing partner for Douglas Elliman, which, along with Feathered Nest and J.I. Sopher and Company, is one of the three largest rental brokers in the city.
"You have much less product around and you are obviously going to get an increase in prices, and that is actually happening," Mr. Rogers said. "I see rents going up 10 percent this year."
Some tenants have already felt the change in the market. In 1990, for example, Barbara Schassar easily found a large one-bedroom duplex in the West Village of Manhattan for $1,875 a month -- not cheap but probably less than a comparable apartment in the same neighborhood would have commanded a few years earlier.
"There were good deals out there, and rents had declined," said Ms. Schassar, a lawyer who paid $2,800 in 1988 to live in a two-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side. She lived in London and Tokyo in 1989.
LAST year, though, Ms. Schassar sought a new apartment in the West Village. She wanted the same amount of space, but, to accommodate her two dogs, she wanted a two-bedroom unit. She eventually found such a unit. The rent was $2,295 a month.
"The tenant wasn't even out of the apartment yet and the landlord said, 'If you don't take it, someone else will,' " said Ms. Schassar, who rented the unit. "I think the rents may have come full circle in the course of five years."
The ups and downs in rents in recent years have had little effect on those who live in an estimated 1.3 million rent-stabilized or -controlled units, about 70 percent of the city's 1.9 million apartments. The rest are market-rate apartments that either fall outside the rent-regulation system or have had a high turnover, and thus have more frequent rent increases. Unregulated apartments include those in buildings with fewer than six living units or those built without tax incentives since 1973.
Many tenants in unregulated apartments, however, are not experiencing rising rents -- at least not yet. If renewing a lease, they are often still able to negotiate one with no increase in rent. And if searching for a new apartment, they are often able to negotiate a lease for a new apartment for hundreds of dollars less than the landlord is seeking. In some cases, they may even pay less rent than would be required for a comparable rent-stabilized apartment.
Further, an increase in rents isn't discernible in two reports released last month by the National Cooperative Bank in Washington and Feathered Nest.
The National Cooperative Bank report, which surveyed 109 units, showed that, overall, rents declined by 6 percent in 1992, about the same amount as they did in 1991. In three areas, though, rents increased. They are midtown Manhattan, by 9 percent; Brooklyn and Queens by 7.5 percent and Westchester County by 5.9 percent.
Rents, according to the National Cooperative Bank, showed the greatest decrease -- 14.8 percent -- in Lower Manhattan. On the Upper West Side the drop was 4.2 percent and on the Upper East Side, 2.7 percent.
"My feeling is that you are going to see a stabilization this year," said Grace A. Huebscher, a corporate vice president with the bank. "I don't think you will see another decline."
FEATHERED NEST'S report, which surveyed almost 10,000 apartments, showed that rents in 1992 declined or stayed the same for virtually all sizes and types of apartments in most parts of the city. Even so, Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, said that conditions in the rental market were changing, more rapidly than renters might realize.
"Prices are no longer very negotiable and owners are no longer are paying commissions," she said. "And because of the 20 percent drop in the supply of available apartments, prices should begin to rise this year."
Ms. Packes said that her survey covered 60 to 80 percent of the unregulated rental market in Manhattan and that the existing rental stock was gradually being absorbed because there was no new construction coming onto the market.
She noted that despite the large number of individual co-op and condominium owners who could not sell their units and had rented them out, there were fewer rentals available last year in her listings (9,881) than in 1991 (11,655) and 1990 (13,902). The number of listings last year, though, was still far more than the 2,684 recorded by Feathered Nest in 1987, when the rental market was at its tightest.
"The rental market is shrinking," she said.
Added Mr. Rogers of Douglas Elliman: "The product is not there anymore. There is definitely a shortage of specialty apartments. All you have is turnover of the existing product, and even a lot of that is now being sold. People are getting the prices they wanted two years ago when there was a stalemate."
HE noted that many new large apartment buildings, such as the six-year-old Windsor Court, a 31-floor, 709-unit building on Lexington Avenue and 31st Street, had had high vacancy rates for several years but had filled during the last two years. "We have started a waiting list for the next three months," he said.
He also said the rents at Windsor Court had returned to their original levels; a one-bedroom apartment in the luxury complex now rents for about $1,600 a month, he said, up from the $1,400 charged in 1990.
Furthermore, Mr. Rogers said, renewal rates are increasing and, unlike what was happening in the last few years, renters are requesting long-term leases, usually for two years, which were common before the recession.
"People were reluctant to make long-term commitments," he said. "I think we're going to see two-year leases again."
Individual landlords are also having little difficulty finding tenants. Ms. Packes of Feathered Nest estimated that about 60 to 70 percent of the rentals currently seeking tenants are owned by individuals rather than large corporations, such as Glenwood Property Management, which owns dozens of high-rise apartment buildings in the city.
One such individual landlord, Ed Baum, who owns a 1,200-square-foot, two-bedroom floor-through co-op in a brownstone in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, recently rented it with the help of a broker. "It has gone very smooth so far," he said. "It's a new experience for me, being a landlord -- I never drew up a lease before. A key concern for me was to find a tenant that would enjoy living in a space that we tried to make our home for seven years. And I think we did that."
Ms. Packes noticed another trend indicating that rents might be rising: Building owners are no longer paying brokers a fee for finding tenants.
Indeed, when Ms. Schassar rented her new apartment in the West Village, she was originally told that the owner of the building would pay the broker's fee. Just before signing a lease, however, she was told that the policy had changed, that the owner would pay only half the fee.
"It's starting to move back to the tenants paying the standard 15 percent of the annual rent," Ms. Packes said.
The dominant dynamic involved in the rental market these days is the decreasing supply. Ms. Packes, added, though, that there also appeared to be many people who, in the past, would have bought apartments but were now renting, increasing the demand.
She said that even though they were able to afford buying an apartment and could get financing, they were also frightened by the outlook for the economy, particularly their own jobs.
Some are also worried about the low rate of appreciation and the lack of liquidity associated with any real estate investment in recent years. Others do not expect to stay in the city for the five to seven years that many brokers believe is now necessary to make buying a home in New York a profitable proposition.
Then there are also co-op and condominium owners, such as James A. Goldsmith, who can't sell their units, rent them out and then become renters themselves. "I don't have a lot of confidence in the market, and I'm not sure co-ops are necessarily a great form of ownership," Mr. Goldsmith said.
LIKE many apartment owners in Manhattan, Mr. Goldsmith never expected to become a landlord, much less a tenant. He bought his two-bedroom apartment on East 97th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues in 1987 at the insider price of $141,000. With the birth of his second child in 1990 he needed a larger apartment and put his unit on the market for $250,000. There were no bidders.
So Mr. Goldsmith, who is 36 years old and a real estate broker, rented his apartment. He charged $1,800 a month, but had what he described as a problem tenant who often paid his rent late.
A year later, he put his apartment on the market again, this time for $175,000. Once again, there were no bidders. "We had some people who looked and said they liked it, but nothing ever materialized," he said.
In 1991, Mr. Goldsmith again rented out his apartment. This time, however, it fetched only $1,500 a month, far from the amount necessary to cover the monthly mortgage and $1,100 maintenance payments. On top of the negative cash flow, he is also paying rent on his six-room apartment on East 81 Street between Third and Lexington Avenues.
"We'll probably try to sell again in the summer," he said. "It depends on the market, how people feel about the economy and what other apartments in the building have been sold for."

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Builder's Motto: 'Move On, Clean House'

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, DEL.

 BODY:
Packing is a pleasure for Vernon and Beverly Toulson, or so they say. It is certainly a familiar experience. They have moved 21 times in the last 23 years.
The most recent move was from Vero Beach, Fla., to Delaware, where they lived temporarily in Mr. Toulson's parents' house before moving six months later into a new house in this high-end residential suburb half a dozen miles northwest of Wilmington. They sold the house in Vero Beach after having lived in it a year and now their 6,400-square-foot French-country-style house here is on the market for $950,000. 
 Through his company, Toulson Builders, the 48-year-old Mr. Toulson has built 15 of the houses they have lived in over the 23 years, including the current one.
He said that he fell into the pattern in the early years as a way of saving money and limiting his risk. Also, he said, he found it easier to get construction financing when the lender knew that he was going to live in the house as a primary residence.
"Obviously there are some savings." he said. "I'm not paying interest on two mortgages and two electric bills and all those things. But when we sell, we have to pay capital gains and moving costs and points on a new mortgage, so in the end it's probably a wash."
He likened himself to a new-car dealer who enjoys riding around in a new car, showing off his product and selling it to get the money for a newer model. Sometimes the sale takes only two months; one took two years.
When the current house is sold, he said, he probably will buy another for $300,000 to $350,000, live in it, improve it and then -- as always -- sell it.
The interior of the manor house here reflects the unusual Toulson life style. The large rooms lack the familiar clutter of ordinary family living. This is not just an illusion created by the 10- to 22-foot ceilings and the absence of curtains and draperies on the large windows. The usual odds and ends of note paper near the kitchen telephone are missing; the paneled library is strikingly spare -- no books, family photos or other memorabilia. Even the walk-in closets -- the size of most bedrooms -- are pristine in their neatness.
Perhaps the most personal room belongs to the couple's daughter Kelley, 19. Another daughter, Kim, 25, moved back to Dover, Del., from Florida about eight years ago to live with her grandmother and finish high school with her childhood friends. Today both daughters say they will never move.
The homes have ranged from modest 2,400-square-foot houses built in the early 70's in Seaford, Del., to the 6,400-square-foot house the family now has in the exclusive Versailles area of Greenville. The most expensive home the family lived in was one on the waterfront on John's Island, Fla., that they built in 1989 and sold for $1.4 million.
In each home, including those in some glitzy areas of Florida, the Toulsons recycled the same Queen Anne dining room suite and Chippendale living room furniture they started with. But Mrs. Toulson, the daughter of a Delaware builder who built custom homes for employees of Delaware's major chemical companies in the 60's, has learned to pare down. Her rule of thumb is if it hasn't been used in six months, out it goes.
"My mother will tell me I need such and such appliance and I always say, 'No, I'll just have to move it,' " she said.
Mrs. Toulson, who recently opened her own decorating business, also learnedhow to adapt her life style to the need to sell. She's not a collector, nor does she believe in making a personal statement with her decorating. That does not sell homes.
"We do most everything with somebody else in mind -- with the idea of resale," she said. "We would never do anything just related to our family."
The Versailles home now on the market is the first house in Delaware the Toulsons have built since moving back to the state after building in exclusive communities in Florida through the 80's.
After some market research, Mr. Toulson decided to build a grand speculative house on nearly three acres of what was once the park on the estate of Victor duPont. The idea is to show Wilmington's wealthier potential purchasers a sample of his work. The site was bought from a developer who had put in roads and utilities.
Last year the Toulsons won the Regal award from the Home Builders Association of Delaware for the best house with more than 2,500 square feet. But it has been for sale since July and remains unsold, as do dozens of others of extravagant homes, both old and new, that dot what is know locally as "Chateau Country."
Once almost exclusively the domain of the heirs to the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company chemical fortune, much of the rolling countryside has gone under the bulldozer in recent years. Several large parcels, formerly held by the du Ponts or senior managers of the company, have been sold as subdivisions, albeit with homes priced from $800,000 to more than $1 million.
Developers, some of whose immigrant grandfathers did construction work for du Ponts,moved into the old du Pont mansions with the lovely French names while they put up $850,000 homes often called "McMansions." Mr. Toulson himself and his father before him worked at "the Company."
After nearly 75 years of Old World, almost royal living, the children of some of the industrialists who built fortunes from the two World Wars and the subsequent rebuilding, are being forced to sell property to pay millions in taxes on illiquid land assets.
"The real developer is Death," said William Sellers, director of environmental management for the Brandywine Conservancy in Chadds Ford, Pa. "Estate taxes on land can be disastrous for families who didn't do a lot of planning -- people can really be left with zero."
Those landowners who managed to sell in the 80's can now count themselves lucky.Credit for developers has become almost nonexistent in Delaware. Furthermore, in this tiny state it is well known by bankers and buyers alike that huge houses, whether old or new, are just not moving for a variety of social and economic reasons.
"I'm not sure how much of a market segment there is for the big home," said Mrs. Toulson. "Of course, we only have the one. For those people sitting with five or six spec houses it could be a little bit scary."
Mathematically, a buyer would have to make well into six figures to be able to comfortably maintain and support a million-dollar house, even if very little was financed.
A corporate executive with a major Delaware company recently bought an $825,000 home in Chateau Country -- actually New Castle County. He financed $650,000 at 9 percent, bringing his monthly payments to slightly more than $5,300. His annual income, therefore, had to run about $250,000 to meet lending requirements.
But according to information supplied by the Delaware State Data Center, only 1 percent of households in Delaware, or 3,487 families, make $150,000 and up. Real estate agents say the only segment feeling sanguine about trading up are physicians and others with health-care businesses. Christopher S. Patterson of Patterson-Schwartz & Associates, a Wilmington real estate agency that has traditionally gotten most of the upper-income listings, says physicians are almost the only buyers looking in the million-dollar price range.
Some real estate agents say, however, that even physicians are seized by uncertainty as the nation struggles to deal with the health-care crisis and the talk of reducing the mortgage interest deduction. Libby Zurkow, an agent with Patterson-Schwartz, said several of her physician clients had opted to buy lower-priced houses.
Mrs. Toulson says when she and her husband do sell their million-dollar property they will move to an upper-middle-class subdivision where homes in the $350,000 price range are similar to the kind that were built by her father. But they won't stay.
"We'll fix it up and move," she said. "I don't think we'll ever stay in one house. I simply can't imagine living in any house for more than, say, two years."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 13; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1360 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Deals With Foreigners;
A Wrong Number, or Color, Can Terminate Talks

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
SINCE nearly a third of the 350 or so corporate tenants in the World Trade Center's four buildings are Asian, you'd think there would be a smattering of them in Building No. 4. There's nary a one.
Why? 
 Because the number 4 is to many Asians what the number 13 is to many Americans.
"One Thai tenant even refused to rent Suite 28-14 in Tower No. 2 because there was a four in the address," said George Rossi, the complex's assistant director.
People can talk about global economies and homogenized business practices all they want. The fact is, renting space to a foreign company is still a -- well, foreign experience.
Landlords tell of Japanese tenants who expect leases to be just five pages long, since so much rental business is done on a handshake in Japan. They tell of Eastern European tenants who, despite perestroika, do not understand the concept of landlords' profit. They tell of Chinese tenants who balk at green doors because green signifies bad luck.
Indeed, talks with brokers, landlords and architects turn up a host of war stories about accommodating to a foreign client's needs. There are locational and layout requirements that, to Americans, seem to make no sense. There are conflicts between wanting to blend in with their neighbors while retaining their cultural identity.
And perhaps most of all, there are negotiations that seem to last forever.
Mara R. Spiegel, a vice president who handles investment sales for Helmsley-Spear, routinely has to renegotiate building prices with Italian buyers after they had gone to contract, when American companies would think the price was chiseled in stone.
"There is a barter mentality in the Mediterranean countries, and bargaining lasts to the last moment," she said. "The problem is, we expect them to operate our way and they expect us to operate their way."
Japanese companies often refuse to sign a lease until even low-level employees agree that the space is right.
"When a deal falls through, the Japanese see it as a learning experience, not a setback," said Jeffrey Lichtenberg, a partner in Peter R. Friedman Ltd., a Manhattan brokerage that often represents the Sumitomo Corporation, both as landlord and tenant.
Actually, the time problems with foreign companies can be procedural as well as cultural. They often must get approval from the home office before agreeing to lease or design terms that change dozens of times during typical negotiations.
Moreover, landlords often hold out for huge security deposits or letters of credit to make sure that if the tenant defaults, they can still get their rent.
"You don't want to chase someone to Europe to sue," said Edward A. Friedman, president of Newmark Retail Services.
The time lag can be particularly large when it comes to high-image retailers. Richard Evans, vice president of New Spectrum Realty Services, helped Gianfranco Ferre, the big Italian designer, find its new store on Madison and 70th. It took more than a year to consummate the deal, Mr. Evans reported -- not because of sticky negotiations, but because the company's architects had to sign off on every aspect of the design.
"For European designers, their New York stores aren't just profit centers, they are showcases to the world," Mr. Evans said.
As frustrating as the time lags, brokers say, are clients who refuse to be steered around pitfalls.
G. Tyson Maroon, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, tells of one Japanese company that wanted to expand a distribution center to include a customer service area. Since a lot of high-priced space was at stake, Mr. Maroon offered to try for a long-term lease at a lower rental than they were paying. His client, afraid to alienate the landlord, insisted on negotiating alone.
The upshot: What should have been a five-month negotiation stretched to two years -- and the client didn't get a long lease or the best price.
"Their nature is to not confront, to wear the opposition down, and it just doesn't work in real estate," Mr. Maroon said.
NEWMARK'S Mr. Friedman recalls trying to persuade the Sock Shop, a British hosiery chain, that if it opened stores too close to each other in Manhattan it would be cannibalizing its own markets.
"In London such clusters had helped them keep competition at bay, and they figured it would work here," Mr. Friedman said.
The too-close locations, combined with bad merchandising decisions, killed the Sock Shop's chances in New York.
Other brokers report missed opportunities on the part of overly conservative foreign clients. Mr. Maroon was surprised when an Indian company passed up a chance to rent the space under its store, even though access to the basement would have made the space far easier to sublet.
"An American or Korean firm would have intuitively taken the space," Mr. Maroon said. "The Indian companies pay more attention to numbers than to gut instinct."
By contrast, he says, German clients readily take risks. A few months ago, Lufthansa "pounced on the idea" of using a barter firm to trade some high-rent space it wasn't using for air and print advertising time.
"Getting Americans comfortable with barter takes a lot longer," Mr. Maroon said.
But not as long as getting South Americans comfortable with inflation, American style. Steven P. Pressler, managing director of Promenade Real Estate, which manages many Brazilian-owned buildings in New York, says that South Americans who own buildings here often insist on escalation clauses tied to consumer price index increases, even if they might do better with, say, a porter's wage escalation.
"They're used to rampant inflation, and they sleep better knowing they're protected against its effects," Mr. Pressler said.
Cultural differences are not confined to the negotiating table. Architects chase different parameters for foreign clients, too.
"COMPANIES with ancient ethnic traditions want their space to reflect their roots," said Matthew Cusumano, a partner at Manhattan-based SCR Design Organization who put a Buddha in the Bank of Thailand's reception room at 40 East 52d Street and set up a tent at the entrance to Saudi Petroleum's offices at 527 Madison Avenue, near 52d Street.
Actually, it's more than their roots; often it's their current traditions. Mr. Cusumano included an eastern-facing conference room in Royal Air Moroc's offices at 55 East 59th Street so employees who wished to pray toward Mecca could do so. Others report that, because German custom dictates that all employees must sit within 20 feet of a window, German companies are rarely attracted to the huge loftlike spaces that Japanese companies, with their penchant for open office layouts, covet.
Japanese companies also require one or two rooms with armchairs, sofas and coffee tables, more similar to living rooms than conference rooms.
Why? Japanese tradition dictates that only after exchanging pleasantries in an informal setting do you move to meeting rooms for actual negotiations.
The paternal relationship that many Japanese companies have with their employees also has an impact on where they set up shop.
The Hitachi Corporation recently moved from one Westchester building to another across the street, with no appreciable improvement in space or rent terms, solely because the second had a cafeteria. Marubeni America Corporation recently leased 85,000 square feet at 450 Lexington Avenue, near 45th Street; the company passed up a chance to lease similar space, at much less money, at Americas Towers, because it was four long blocks farther from Grand Central Station and most of its employees lived in Westchester and Connecticut.
"The Japanese tend to work late and their main concern is the safety of their staff," said Jeffrey A. Landers of Landers Commercial Real Estate, which handled both deals.
Mr. Rossi recently came up against tradition of another sort. He wanted to get a Chinese restaurant into prime space in the World Trade Center. He couldn't even get prospects to return his calls. The reason, he found out: The site faced a cemetery, and to the Chinese, that was bad luck.
"I should have guessed," Mr. Rossi said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Matthew Cusumano of SRC Design Organization at the Bank of Thailand's office at 40 East 52d Street. (Stephanie Berger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Focus: Greenville, Del.;
Builder's Motto: 'Move On, Clean House'

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, DEL.

 BODY:
PACKING is a pleasure for Vernon and Beverly Toulson, or so they say. It is certainly a familiar experience. They have moved 21 times in the last 23 years.
The most recent move was from Vero Beach, Fla., to Delaware, where they lived temporarily in Mr. Toulson's parents' house before moving six months later into a new house in this high-end residential suburb half a dozen miles northwest of Wilmington. They sold the house in Vero Beach after having lived in it a year and now their 6,400-square-foot French-country-style house here is on the market for $950,000. 
 Through his company, Toulson Builders, the 48-year-old Mr. Toulson has built 15 of the houses they have lived in over the 23 years, including the current one. He said that he fell into the pattern in the early years as a way of saving money and limiting his risk and that he found it easier to get construction financing when the lender knew he was going to live in the house as a primary residence.
"Obviously there are some savings." he said. "I'm not paying interest on two mortgages and two electric bills and all those things. But when we sell, we have to pay capital gains and moving costs and points on a new mortgage, so in the end it's probably a wash."
He likened himself to a new-car dealer who enjoys riding around in a new car, showing off his product and selling it to get the money for a newer model. Sometimes the sale takes only two months; one took two years.
When the current house is sold, he said, he probably will buy another for $300,000 to $350,000, live in it, improve it and then -- as always -- sell it.
The interior of the manor house here reflects the unusual Toulson life style. The large rooms lack the familiar clutter of ordinary family living. This is not just an illusion created by the 10-to 22-foot ceilings and the absence of curtains and draperies on the large windows. The usual odds and ends of note paper near the kitchen telephone are missing; the paneled library is strikingly spare -- no books, family photos or other memorabilia. Even the walk-in closets -- the size of most bedrooms -- are pristine in their neatness.
Perhaps the most personal room belongs to the couple's daughter Kelley, 19. Another daughter, Kim, 25, moved back to Dover, Del., from Florida about eight years ago to live with her grandmother and finish high school with her childhood friends. Today both daughters say they will never move.
The homes have ranged from modest 2,400-square-foot houses built in the early 70's in Seaford, Del., to the 6,400-square-foot house the family now has in the exclusive Versailles area of Greenville. The most expensive home the family lived in was one on the waterfront on John's Island, Fla., that they built in 1989 and sold for $1.4 million.
In each home, including those in some glitzy areas of Florida, the Toulsons recycled the same Queen Anne dining room suite and Chippendale living room furniture they started with when they got married. But Mrs. Toulson, the daughter of a Delaware builder who built custom homes for employees of Delaware's major chemical companies in the 60's, has learned to pare down. Her rule of thumb is if it hasn't been used in six months, out it goes.
"My mother will tell me I need such and such appliance and I always say, 'No, I'll just have to move it,' " she said.
Mrs. Toulson, who recently opened her own decorating business, also learned how to adapt her life style to the need to sell. She's not a collector, nor does she believe in making a personal statement with her decorating. That does not sell homes.
"We do most everything with somebody else in mind -- with the idea of resale," she said. "We would never do anything just related to our family."
The Versailles home now on the market is the first house in Delaware the Toulsons have built since moving back to the state after building in exclusive communities in Florida through the 80's.
After some market research, Mr. Toulson decided to build a grand speculative house on nearly three acres of what was once the park on the estate of Victor duPont. The idea is to show Wilmington's wealthier potential purchasers a sample of his work. The site was bought from a developer who had put in roads and utilities.
LAST year the Toulsons won the Regal award from the Home Builders Association of Delaware for the best house with more than 2,500 square feet. But it has been for sale since July and remains unsold, as do dozens of others of extravagant homes, both old and new, that dot what is know locally as "Chateau Country."
Once almost exclusively the domain of the heirs to the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company chemical fortune, much of the rolling countryside has gone under the bulldozer in recent years. Several large parcels, formerly held by the du Ponts or senior managers of the company, have been sold as subdivisions, albeit with homes priced from $800,000 to more than $1 million.
Developers, some of whose immigrant grandfathers did construction work for du Ponts,moved into the old du Pont mansions with the lovely French names while they put up $850,000 homes often called "McMansions."
Mr. Toulson himself and his father before him worked at "the Company."
After nearly 75 years of Old World, almost royal living, the children of some of the industrialists who built fortunes from the two World Wars and the subsequent rebuilding, are being forced to sell property to pay millions in taxes on illiquid land assets.
"The real developer is Death," said William Sellers, director of environmental management for the Brandywine Conservancy in Chadds Ford, Pa. "Estate taxes on land can be disastrous for families who didn't do a lot of planning -- people can really be left with zero."
Those landowners who managed to sell in the 80's can now count themselves lucky. Credit for developers has become almost nonexistent in Delaware. Furthermore, in this tiny state it is well known by bankers and buyers alike that huge houses, whether old or new, are just not moving for a variety of social and economic reasons.
"I'm not sure how much of a market segment there is for the big home," said Mrs. Toulson. "Of course, we only have the one. For those people sitting with five or six spec houses it could be a little bit scary."
Mathematically, a buyer would have to make well into six figures to be able to comfortably maintain and support a million-dollar house, even if very little was financed.
A corporate executive with a major Delaware company recently bought an $825,000 home in Chateau Country -- actually New Castle County. He financed $650,000 at 9 percent, bringing his monthly payments to slightly more than $5,300. His annual income, therefore, had to run about $250,000 to meet lending requirements.
BUT according to information supplied by the Delaware State Data Center, only 1 percent of households in Delaware, or 3,487 families, make $150,000 and up. Real estate agents say the only segment feeling sanguine about trading up are physicians and others with health-care businesses. Christopher S. Patterson of Patterson-Schwartz & Associates, a Wilmington real estate agency that has traditionally gotten most of the upper-income listings, says physicians are almost the only buyers looking in the million-dollar price range.
Some real estate agents say, however, that even physicians are seized by uncertainty as the nation struggles to deal with the health-care crisis and the talk of reducing the mortgage interest deduction. Libby Zurkow, an agent with Patterson-Schwartz, said several of her physician clients had opted to buy lower-priced houses.
Mrs. Toulson says when she and her husband do sell their million-dollar property they will move to an upper-middle-class subdivision where homes in the $350,000 price range are similar to the kind that were built by her father. But they won't stay.
"We'll fix it up and move," she said. "I don't think we'll ever stay in one house. I simply can't imagine living in any house for more than, say, two years."

LENGTH: 2289 words

HEADLINE: The Man Who Would Be Governor Again

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AT 8:30 on a brisk Wednesday morning, 150 members of Italian-American organizations around the state trouped to Drumthwacket, the Governor's mansion in Princeton, to join Jim Florio and his wife, Lucinda, for breakfast.
As the guests milled about the first floor, engaging in ritual small talk and nibbling on Italian pastries, their hosts were pursuing a ritual of their own in the upstairs apartment -- a breakfast of cereal, bananas and coffee. 
 "No matter how many breakfasts we have to go to, we always have our Cheerios together in the morning," Governor Florio said later during a day that seemed largely devoted to his all-but-announced candidacy for re-election. His prospects have brightened considerably since the time when his public approval ratings were less than 30 percent; in fact, polls now show him on a par with both candidates running for the Republican nomination.
During this 11-hour day, the Governor traveled hundreds of miles by car, train and helicopter; gave four speeches; met with Republican legislative leaders and generally set forth the political themes that are likely to be repeated in the months to come.
9 A.M.: The Florios walk hand in hand down the stairs. Mrs. Florio is immediately surrounded by a circle of guests while her husband works the room, exchanging handshakes and smiles with the predominantly male crowd.
Thirty minutes later, he stands with his wife on a flight of steps and delivers a casual 10-minute speech. He says he will soon introduce the third state budget in a row that calls for no new taxes while providing more funds for education. The brash political gamble he took in his first year in office, when he pushed through the largest tax increase in the state's history, is now paying off, he says.
President Clinton's victory, Mr. Florio suggests, is a vindication of sorts for his own style of government: "I think the American people voted for active leadership. You look at the problems, you analyze them, you put together a plan and then you move forward. That's obviously what we've been trying to do in New Jersey."
9:48 A.M.: The Governor, outfitted in a dark gray single-breasted suit and paisley tie, slides into the back seat of a black 1992 Fleetwood, which immediately moves out onto Route 206. A state trooper is at the wheel; another state trooper drives the car that follows close behind. Over the next hours, Mr. Florio will be accompanied by as many as four troopers and will exchange not a word with any of them.
As the Fleetwood heads south toward Trenton, Mr. Florio holds up scraps of paper on which his breakfast guests have jotted down their names and telephone numbers. "I've got notes in every pocket," he says. The paper ends up in a leather portfolio he will carry with him all day.
In part, the Governor says, his heavy schedule of public appearances reflects the lack of attention New York television and radio stations pay to New Jersey events. "The problem in our state is the inability to communicate," he comments. "If you want to try to punch through with a message, you've literally got to go out and do it yourself."
Mr. Florio does not easily engage in small talk. "I'm comfortable with silence," he says. "I'm not bothered by lulls in the conversation." In private encounters he is intense, formal and in control. His friends attribute that to his politeness; his critics say he is aloof and even arrogant.
He seems most comfortable when the topic is substantive, like health care or the environment. Even when confronted with a direct question about his personal life, he often finds ways to turn the conversation in another direction. Asked about his grandchildren, he replies that Matthew is 4 and Chelsea is 3 -- and then abruptly begins a detailed explanation of how his administration is improving the state's economy.
As Trenton comes in view, the Governor considers another question: growing up in Brooklyn, did he ever consider a career other than politics? "I always wanted to be a New York City cop," he replies. "My ethic was that you had made it if you got a city job. A city job was forever."
10:11 A.M.: When the limousine pulls up to the side entrance to the State House, Mr. Florio is quickly out the door and on his way. He is an athlete, a former amateur boxer, a jogger, and he strides rapidly through a winding series of hallways to his office.
The Governor's office is surprisingly small -- 10 feet by 15 feet. He works there in shirtsleeves, sipping coffee brought by his administrative assistant, Tina Lado. On the wall is a photograph of Woodrow Wilson when he was Governor of New Jersey and used the same leather-covered desk where Mr. Florio is seated.
"Here, look at this," Mr. Florio says, passing along a letter from Kiwi International Airlines. "They're thanking us for what our guaranteed loan programs have done to help them expand their business. That's what economic development is all about."
10:33 A.M.: The Governor sets out double time on the one-block walk to Thomas A. Edison State College, where he is to speak before a special meeting of the State League of Municipalities. Somehow, the state troopers manage to keep up.
The speech echoes the theme of his earlier talk (the 1990 tax increase is paying off) but is tailored slightly for his audience of 100 municipal officials with references to his programs to help the cities.
"You're not just talking to the people who are there," Mr. Florio says later. "You're talking to people who are going to be talking to other people."
On his way out, the Governor is set upon by a group of reporters and photographers and asked for his reaction to the news that both Republican candidates for Governor had once hired illegal aliens. He declines to comment -- except to say that neither he nor any of his Cabinet members has ever hired illegal aliens.
11:15 A.M.: Back in his office, Mr. Florio convenes the daily meeting of what he calls his "core group," which includes Joseph C. Salema, the chief of staff; Brenda Bacon, the chief of management and planning; M. Robert DeCotis, the chief counsel, and Jon Shure, the director of communications.
The sessions are held in the office next to his -- a huge paneled room that was once used as the Governor's office. Visitors are not welcome.
Mr. Florio's aides say he is a reasonable, polite boss, though he has a short fuse in one regard. "If there's one thing that makes this man go off in a second," Ms. Lado says, "it's not returning a phone call or a letter."
11:55 A.M.: A Sikorsky S-76B helicopter, piloted by two state troopers, rises from the heliport a few hundred yards from the State House. The Governor is on his way to Parsippany to deliver the keynote address to the annual luncheon meeting of the Morris County Chamber of Commerce.
Wearing silver-framed bifocals and moving his lips slightly, Mr. Florio spends the 20-minute ride editing his speech, which is printed in extra- large type on 50 pages. A car driven by a state trooper awaits him at the Morristown Airport, and when he arrives at the Parsippany Hilton, he is immediately ushered to the dais.
The Governor does not like to eat in front of a crowd, he says, and does not touch the food in front of him. On most days, he grabs a bite at a local diner or in the car; on this day, he has no lunch at all.
During his speech, he hardly looks at the manuscript over which he has labored so hard. He knows the speech by heart: New Jersey's move toward economic recovery is largely the result of tough decisions made early in his administration.
Later he comments: "We've been saying the same thing for the past three years. We were out there talking with nobody listening. But people are listening now."
1:45 P.M.: Newark is the next stop, and on the way, word comes over the car phone that Christine Todd Whitman has just officially announced her candidacy for governor and pledged to roll back all the tax increases Mr. Florio has imposed.
"That's great," Mr. Florio says, deadpan. He would like to know, he adds, what programs Ms. Whitman plans to cut.
"The $1.5 billion in added school assistance came out of what we've done," Mr. Florio says. "If you want to be out there saying you're going to de-fund the school financing system, that's fine. Go do it."
2:06 P.M.: The Governor arrives at N.J. Transit's Broad Street Station, 21 minutes behind the written schedule for the day. He is a stickler for staying on schedule, his aides say.
At the Newark station, Mr. Florio boards a special train that will take him and about 100 officials and reporters to a site deep in the Kearny Meadowlands. The occasion: groundbreaking ceremonies for the long-awaited "Kearny Connection," a $60 million link that will enable residents of North Jersey to commute directly into New York's Penn Station.
Reporters and television crews follow the Governor into a special car stocked with coffee, cake and cookies.
"There are a few things I am an expert on," he says. "Cheesecake, ice cream, pizza and chocolate chip cookies. Now you know why I jog."
For this speech, Mr. Florio blends transit facts, figures and anecdotes with the theme of his earlier talks. A crowd shivers in the cold as Mr. Florio; Thomas M. Downs, the Transportation Commissioner, and Shirley A. DeLibero, N.J. Transit's executive director, wield ceremonial gold-painted shovels.
Later, back in the car and headed for the Newark Fire Dock heliport, Mr. Florio talks about his uneasy relationship with news photographers, who often, he says, end up catching him in unflattering poses.
He offers an incident with a photographer on the Kearny Connection train as an example.
"I knew what he was waiting for," Mr. Florio says. "He was waiting for me to eat the chocolate chip cookie. We were waiting each other out. Finally I decided, 'The hell with it, I'm eating the chocolate chip cookie.' So he got his picture."
3:10 P.M.: From a State Police helicopter, Mr. Florio looks out over the city of Newark.
"See that open land there," he says, pointing to blocks of empty lots in the center of the state's biggest city. "All that land could be developed if we create an economic environment that is attractive to developers."
4 P.M.: Normally, by this time of the day, Mr. Florio has returned to Princeton for his three-mile jog. "My staff always knows when I just come back from running," he says. "I pick up the phone and call them with all these great ideas. They say, 'Oh-oh, you've been running again.' "
But on this day, the Governor is scheduled for a different exercise, a meeting with the Republican legislative leadership.
Members of Mr. Florio's core group have assembled in the large office next to the Governor's and are waiting for the arrival of the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, Republican of Scotch Plains, and the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, Republican of Independence.
The Governor works in his own office and joins the group a minute or two before the legislators arrive from their offices down the hall.
Visitors are not welcome at the meeting, but later Mr. Florio says the session was called to "determine areas of agreement and narrow down areas of disagreement" between the administration and the Republican-dominated Legislature over the state budget.
By all accounts, the Governor has little taste for the politicking side of politics, the give and take of elective office or electioneering. "The thing he loves is government," Ms. Lado, his assistant, says. "Politics and elections are just something he has to go through."
5:35 P.M.: Back in the limousine, Mr. Florio is on the last lap of his official day, headed home to Princeton for a live broadcast of his monthly call-in radio show.
He talks about the perception among some reporters that "the real Jim Florio" is lurking somewhere inside Jim Florio the Governor.
"Maybe they're looking too hard," he says. "Maybe what they're looking for has been there in front of them all along."
When he is asked if he really cares that much about whether people like him, he answers quickly and decisively: "No. It's not something I worry about."
What plans does Mr. Florio have for his life after he leaves the Governor's mansion? "I'd think I'd like to teach at a college," he says, adding that he might also like to work for a law firm that specializes in environmental legislation.
He has no interest, he says, in returning to Washington as a Congressman: "I turn on C-Span and see all these folks down there in Congress flailing around and not getting a whole lot done."
How has his life been changed by his 1988 marriage to the former Lucinda Coleman? For the first time this day, his face softens and relaxes as he says, softly: "A great deal," and then, in almost a whisper, "A great deal."
6 P.M.: After arriving at Drumthwacket, the Governor changes into a sweater and jeans in preparation for his radio show. When a photographer asks permission to take pictures during the broadcast, Mrs. Florio is hesitant because the second-floor study where it takes place is in the family's private quarters and off limits to the press. But she finally agrees to the request.
After the broadcast is over and the photographer has left, Mrs. Florio says, "I just wanted to have one place in the whole world that was private."
Mr. Florio: "And now I've gone and broken the rules."
Mrs. Florio: "As a matter of fact, I was thinking of setting up the radio station downstairs next month, if that's O.K. with you."
Mr. Florio, with a laugh: "We'll talk about it."
Then the Governor and his wife walk up the stairs and into that one place in their world that is private.

HEADLINE: Rent Control: A 'Misnomer'

 BODY:
This is in response to a recentarticle, "Battle Lines Drawn for Major Struggle Over Rent Control."
First of all, rent control is a misnomer since it implies that rents are fixed. They are not -- they go up every year, usually on a par with inflation, and often beyond it. In Cliffside Park they go up beyond what banks pay, so that landlords are making a profit over ordinary interest. 
 In addition, landlords can get hardship increases in this town merely by proving they need one, but since that involves opening their books, no landlord applies for it. If you ask landlords, as I have, what they consider a fair profit, their answer is, "What the market will bear." Translate that to "Whatever I can get," and you have the basis for their complaints. Rent leveling forces them to charge a semi-reasonable amount.
I say semi-reasonable because you have to look at the tenants' side of things. To use the analogy in the article, when a supermarket raises its prices beyond what a shopper can pay, that shopper can always go to another store. But where can a tenant go? There are no affordable new housing units being built for someone making $15,000 to $20,000 a year, and even $30,000 is a tight squeeze.
The result is that tenants with apartments that they can afford stay where they are and hope their rent will not go up past what they can manage. In a climate of declining interest rates and high unemployment, that extra $20 or $30 or $40 a month for their annual increase becomes harder to manage every year. New subsidies for older citizens are as nonexistent as new affordable units.
As for vacancy decontrol, what happens is a revolving apartment door. A tenant moves in, finds the rent too high and (1) either sneaks out in the middle of the night, leaving the landlord with a vacant unit and lost rent till he finds a new tenant, or (2) takes in a roommate (or two or three transients), thus violating whatever occupancy laws may exist. The result in either case is a destabilization of the neighborhood and a lack of community feeling that is sensed by everyone, including homeowners.
As for repairs, why make them when tenants can be forced to make their own or go without? One tenant spent three years trying to get a flaking ceiling repaired under a legal system that is almost totally unresponsive to tenant needs. The problem was not the cost involved, which was minimal, but simply the landlord's unwillingness to make any repairs at all.
Now we come to homeowners. Homeowners benefit from a stable population, something they don't get if rents go sky-high. Tax shifts onto homeowners do not happen as a result of rent leveling, certainly not in this town, where tax increases can be passed on to tenants in the form of surcharges and hardship increases (which, as explained, are not even requested). Often, homeowners are landlords too, owning two-family houses with one unit rented, and they can simply raise the rent to cover their tax increases.
One last point: After World War II, the Government lost no time in providing housing for two million returning servicemen and their families. Today, we have over two million families living in the street. Could the difference be that the first two million were battle-trained, combat-hardened veterans, many with arms, while today's homeless are often women and children, the elderly, the disabled and the disadvantaged?
 
MIRIAM OFFENBERG
Vice President
Cliffside Park Tenants' Association
Cliffside Park

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
How John Bull at Home Becomes John Bear Abroad

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
WITH the British Government pushing down interest rates to end the country's stubborn recession, stock prices have begun to soar. Or have they?
It all depends on how you measure them. In pounds, the bull market is certainly on. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index ended this week 24 percent higher than at the end of last August, shortly before the Government's economic policy changed. Last week, the Footsie, as it is affectionately called, rose 2 percent. 
 Unfortunately for foreign holders of British stocks, those gains never happened, for the British pound has ticked down with every increase in the stock market, reflecting overseas reaction to those same lower interest rates. The pound has fallen to $1.45 from its peak of $2 in early September.
As a result, an American who bought the Footsie stocks last August now shows a 10 percent loss in dollars, including a small decline last week. From this side of the Atlantic, it looks like a bear market.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Gently Presiding Over The GATT's Final Round

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay

 BODY:
IN 1986, at this country's posh beach resort, Punta del Este, the world's trading partners began discussions on how to liberalize international trade and fight protectionism. Under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, it became known as the Uruguay Round.
Now after seven arduous years, the talks, known by the acronym GATT, appear close to an end, and it is perhaps fitting that Uruguay's Foreign Minister, Sergio Abreu Bonilla, has been chosen as president of the round to bring the negotiations to a close. 
 But Mr. Abreu will not enjoy a few months of genteel discussions and celebration. With France and the United States at bitter odds over agricultural issues, he has the formidable task of trying to nudge both sides into an agreement.
And since Uruguay, a tiny country of three million, is not a heavyweight in world trade, it will be difficult to make his voice heard amid the rows of the giants of the industrialized world.
But ever the diplomat, polished from having represented his country in numerous Latin American trade talks and with two master's degrees from the University of Southern California, Mr. Abreu has a clear message of gentle persuasion.
"What we are trying to do is close the round in the fastest timetable possible, with the most minimum number of changes in the final act," Mr. Abreu said. "We don't want to reopen all the negotiations and have countries rethink their positions. Our worry is how to create the conditions in which the Uruguay round can be closed."
Later this month, Mr. Abreu starts a kind of diplomatic quest, first traveling to Europe for talks with GATT's director, Arthur Dunkel, then on to Washington for talks with Mickey Kantor, the new United States trade representative named by President Clinton.
Mr. Abreu acknowledges that he cannot push anyone. Rather, he says, he is there "to assist in any way, to help out."
What concerns him most is the possibility that the Clinton Adminstration will want to review the agreement and will miss an opportunity to get quick approval in Congress.
Under what is called the fast-track legislation, if the agreement is presented to Congress before March 2, it cannot make modifications. It must either pass it or reject it, with the latter being highly unlikely.
But after that date, things get much more difficult.
In late January, Mr. Dunkel said he saw no way of completing the talks by that deadline, but Mr. Abreu held out hope.
"The conditions are there for the close of the Uruguay round," he said, adding that failure could "lead to greater protectionism by the various economic blocs."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A G.M. Loss Could Spur Health Reform

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
GENERAL MOTORS will report the largest annual loss in the history of corporate America this week -- about $23 billion, or around $3,000 for each car and truck G.M. sold last year.
When G.M. signaled that loss last week, it drew a big yawn on Wall Street. That is because most of the loss -- $22.2 billion -- comes from a new accounting rule, the kind of thing that causes eyes to glaze over. Much more attention was paid to the fall in interest rates around the world, a fact that caused stock indexes to spurt to records. 
 But the sheer magnitude of that figure should cause a lot of people to sit back in amazement. It is based on estimates of what G.M. will have to pay in the future for health care costs for retired workers. Like most companies, G.M. has accounted for such payments only when it spent the cash, about $1 billion last year. But it never bothered to estimate the total liability until the accounting regulators ruled that such costs must be deducted from income while the workers were still performing services, not after they retired.
Estimating such figures is a work of art, with assumptions piled on assumptions. The key question is how rapidly health care costs will rise. Compared with other companies, G.M. is guessing health costs will rise a bit more slowly. Had it been less optimistic, the bill could easily be a few billion higher.
Even so, G.M. is assuming that by the turn of the century health care will be consuming 18 percent of the national income, up from about 14 percent now.
Such huge numbers provide further evidence that something must be done about the cost of health care, which is why the economy's long-term vitality may depend more on Hillary Rodham Clinton's work than on the success of the rest of the Clinton Administration.
In the meantime, companies are trying to cut benefits. Last fall, G.M. began requiring retired managers to pay part of their health expenses, but the company cannot force retired union workers to do the same.
There is a silver lining for the stock market in all this, contrary to much of what has been written. We now know that for many companies, especially ones with aging work forces, real profits have been much lower than reported ones for many years. Now that the Financial Accounting Standards Board has forced more reality into the statements, investors can have greater faith in the numbers that are reported in the future, and companies will have a better understanding of their costs. That should justify higher price-earnings multiples in the stock market, even as it results in lower reported earnings. G.M. estimates that for the next several years, its annual earnings will be cut $1.4 billion as a result of the new accounting rule.
And perhaps it is not too Pollyannish to hope that disclosures such as G.M.'s will spark national action to hold down health costs. That, in turn, would be wonderful news for American competitiveness and for corporate profits.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
In Mexico, It's All a Matter of Trade

BYLINE: By Tim Golden

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
FOR Mexico's stock exchange to suffer, it has begun to seem, investors merely need feel uneasy about the fate of the North American Free Trade Agreement. They need not have anything especially substantive to make them feel that way.
After climbing 43 percent over the previous four months, values on the Bolsa de Valores, as the exchange is known, began falling again on Tuesday, Jan. 26. By last Wednesday, the market index had dropped more than 11 percent, and analysts were putting a good part of the blame on doubts about the future of the agreement. 
 At no point during the seven days of trading did anything happen clearly to change the prospects for Congressional passage of the trade pact. The agreement -- which is almost certain to be ratified by Canada and Mexico -- was not even a particular subject of debate on Capitol Hill.
And when the market rallied strongly on Thursday, its index jumping 3.2 percent on the last day of trading before a long holiday weekend, there was no sign that the trade accord had anything to do with the bounce. Mostly, investors were grabbing at short-term bargains, analysts said.
A handful of other forces were clearly at work in the market's sharp correction: rising interest rates that siphoned money from equity investments and deepened concerns about overall economic performance; a surfeit of Mexican equities on international markets, and worries about the profitability of big Mexican companies as they prepared to issue quarterly earnings reports.
But the episode underscored how even after President Clinton embraced the trade agreement, its tortuous legislative course in Washington continues to shape day-to-day perceptions of Mexican economic well-being.
"One of the underlying elements of the Mexico story is Nafta," Timothy Heyman, the director of Baring Securities' Mexico City office, said. "And if doubts are cast on its passage, you have problems."
He added: "The doubts don't necessarily have to be well-founded."
When the Mexican exchange plunged from its 1992 high of 1,907.36 points on June 1, investors' fears were centered on the independent candidacy of H. Ross Perot, who had criticized the agreement. Later, as the Bolsa index continued to slide to a low for the year of 1,252.10 on Sept. 25, blame was directed at Mr. Clinton for his then-tepid support of the accord.
Mr. Clinton's endorsement of the trade pact on Oct. 4 is credited by many analysts with having helped turn the market's fortunes around. Within barely two months, the index rose from 1,389.72 to 1,742.55.
The latest unease, analysts said, seemed to stem almost as much from the Clinton Administration's fumbling in trying to secure a nominee for the post of Attorney General or a place for gays in the military as from its Jan. 27 announcement of punitive tariffs on steel imports from Mexico and 18 other countries.
Other developments contributed to the concern, analysts said. Senator Max Baucus of Montana, a Democrat prominent on trade issues, called on Jan. 29 for a cross-border tax on trade between Mexico and the United States. On Feb. 2, the United States imposed further duties on Mexican steel wire rope.
Still, Senator Baucus had issued the same call before. The trade agreement was never expected to do away with disputes over unfair trade. Nor did Clinton Administration officials indicate that their support for the agreement had seriously weakened.
Yet in several ways, market analysts noted, the vagaries of the trade agreement do cut to more fundamental economic concerns.
Without the new capital flows that Mexican officials expect from the accord, the widening current-account deficit -- it is projected for about $20 billion for 1992 -- would look even worse. With real interest rates close to 10 percent and rising again, many investors see the trade agreement as essential to quickening the economy's sluggish growth.
"The agreement will draw direct and portfolio investment into Mexico by companies that consider it too risky without Nafta," said Mickey M. Schleien, a research analyst specializing in Latin America at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. "But because the prices already reflect the assumption that the agreement will be passed, any questions about a significant delay or a cancellation will cause prices to trend back down toward the levels they would be at if Nafta had never been considered."
Although the market's latest troubles did not coincide with pressure on the peso, some economists still contend that the rising interest rates and widening trade deficit will eventually force a devaluation. Some analysts say the Government's determination to force inflation down to single digits has also left the markets feeling a lack of liquidity.
There was also reason to wonder about the appetite for Mexican stocks. Grupo Carso, the conglomerate that controls the national telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico, managed to place $369 million of new equity in late January at only a slight discount. But the issue, which came only days after the sale of more than $300 million in the phone company's stock by an American mutual-fund manager, was only the first significant placement since a glut of new stocks helped provoke the market's fall last year.
Along with recent issues of Government and private debt, said Roberto R. Barrera, the director of analysis at the Mexico City brokerage InverMexico, "It's enough to give anyone indigestion."
