SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2427 words

HEADLINE: Some Dos and Don'ts for a Clinton Public-Works Policy

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
TWO years ago, the Harvard professor who is President Clinton's top economic adviser, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, was calling for a Marshall Plan's worth of government investment in worker training and infrastructure -- $2 trillion in the 1990's to fire up the nation's productivity growth and get the economy moving again.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton promised to funnel $20 billion a year into the nation's infrastructure, everything from roads and bridges to water treatment plants, recycling plants, high-speed trains and an electronic "superhighway" to convey huge amounts of data. 
 Since the election, fiscal reality and a perkier economy have scaled back the Clinton public works plan. The talk from the White House these days is that the Administration may devote a third of its economic stimulus plan to infrastructure -- perhaps $5 billion in 1993. With 435 congressional districts, that's like divvying up a sixpack among a college full of fraternities.
Expect much gnashing and moaning at construction firms, mayor's mansions and Wall Street bond houses. But in many quarters you're more likely to hear sighs of relief that Washington won't after all be throwing a lot of money at public works projects.
Mr. Reich and other Democratic proponents of big increases in such spending argue that the economic payback to public investment on, say, better transportation and communications systems far outstrips the returns to business investment. They say infrastructure spending would pay for itself in a matter of months. They also argue that the nation's infrastructure was woefully neglected during the Reagan-Bush years.
"Public investment is the best way to do fiscal stimulus and it's important to do for its own sake," said Robert Kuttner, a widely published columnist who has long advocated a bigger Government role in the economy as a way of reviving the Democratic Party. "It bridges over the failure of the private sector to invest adequately. It doesn't leak out to imports. It's a way of subsidizing high tech. And it makes up for the shortfall in public investment."
But many infrastructure experts in government, the Federal Reserve and academia disagree. Claims of a huge shortfall in infrastructure spending are wildly exaggerated, they say, and infrastructure projects aren't a painless productivity palliative anyway.
"I can't imagine them putting in $20 billion," said Rudolph Penner, director of economic studies at KPMG Peat Marwick in Washington and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office. He said that if the Clinton team consulted government experts on the subject, "they'll quickly see that would really be a waste of money."
What America urgently needs, these experts say, is to better manage an existing infrastructure valued by the Commerce Department at roughly $2.3 trillion. "We've got to make more efficient use of what we have," said Clifford Winston, a transportation specialist at the Brookings Institution, "and be very wary of putting money into anything new."
Ed Hudgins, an economist at the Joint Economic Committee, , agrees. "We've had little vision," he said. "That's why we've spent an inordinate amount on public infrastructure and why our cities are still crowded and we feel that we haven't gotten our money's worth."
Bottom line: Even though Washington won't be spending the bucks some were hoping for, the Clinton Administration still needs a better infrastructure policy than past administrations have been able to come up with. What follows is a list of dos and don'ts from experts skeptical of plans for large new Federal programs advanced by Mr. Reich and some other Clinton advisers.
 
Don't Raise Spending a Lot
 There is little evidence that a big rise in public infrastructure spending would produce bigger economic and social benefits than other public or private investments, such as vaccination programs or business spending on research and development.
The economist whose studies are most often cited by advocates of a lot more spending is David Alan Aschauer, at Bates College in Maine, who concluded that infrastructure spending packs three to five times the productivity punch of private business investment. Few economists find his claim credible. States with more infrastructure haven't grown faster than states with less, and Hong Kong, which is known for its growth, stinted on public works while Singapore, whose productivity has stagnated for two decades, was lavish.
"That doesn't mean building the Erie Canal or O'Hare airport or the Federal highway system wasn't a good idea," said Robert Schwab at the University of Maryland. "But with a huge stock of infrastructure, the payoff from expanding it isn't huge."
Spending on infrastructure, more than two-thirds of it paid for by state and local taxpayers, is already at a record level. The United States has been spending close to $150 billion a year on construction and maintenance -- twice as much, after adjusting for inflation, as the nation spent in the 1960's. Spending amounts to 2.6 percent of G.D.P., compared with the all-time high of 3.2 percent around 1960.
While Federal spending was flat during most of the 1980's, spending at the state and local level has risen by more than a third in the past decade. "There's been a substantial turnaround since the early 1980's," said George Peterson, a specialist on state and local finance at the Urban Institute.
Since 1990, Federal spending has risen 14 percent. And now the highway bill passed last year is funneling an extra $30 billion a year over the next five years to spruce up roads and bridges. "Spending is probably adequate to maintain the system at current quality," said Mr. Winston of Brookings.
Mr. Clinton's supporters cite the drop in infrastructure financing as a share of G.D.P. since the 1960's and the fact that Japan and Germany spend a larger percentage. But the drop in the United States reflects the completion of 40,000 miles of interstate highways and thousands of schools for the baby boomers.
"Take out highways and schools and there's no slowdown," said Jack Tatom, an economist at the St. Louis Federal Reserve. The amount of infrastructure per capita, he points out, is higher than it was in the 1960's.
Anyway, international comparisons aren't necessarily a good guide to how much Washington should be shelling out. In infrastructure per capita, the United States is way ahead of Japan, where sewers and seats on commuter trains are in short supply. And a lot of what counts as public works in Germany would in the United States go under the heading of business investment, by A.T.& T. and Con Edison.
 
Don't Give the Money To Everyone
 Infrastructure needs vary from place to place. On average, the West is wonderfully endowed, while the older cities of the Midwest and Northeast are coping with 60-year-old bridges and century-old water mains.
"There may be a case for spending more money in New York City, but Syracuse doesn't need more infrastructure," said Douglas Holtz-Eakin, an economist at Syracuse University. "Many people associate New York City with the typical city in the Northeast and that's misled us into thinking that there's a general infrastructure crisis."
The trouble is that Washington tends to view public works projects in terms of political payola rather than public payoff. Example: the highway bill passed last year includes 500 "demonstration projects" -- one in almost every congressional district -- that will cost taxpayers $6.5 billion. "Our system has a political imperative to spread the money around to almost every congressional district," Mr. Penner said. "There's no way in our political system to say 'Let's do the best 310 projects'."
 
Don't Rely on Public Works As a Jobs Program
 The United States Conference of Mayors says it has $27 billion worth of projects approved and needing only financing. The implication is that such programs will create lots of jobs right away. But if the Carter economic stimulus package -- $15 billion a year in 1977 and 1978 -- is any guide, infrastructure dollars don't pour into the economy. According to the C.B.O., 2 percent to 20 percent of money authorized for infrastructure is spent in the first year, and spending is usually stretched over four or more years.
"Never, ever think of infrastructure programs as a short-run stimulus program," Mr. Penner said. "It simply takes so long to get the money out. That was always true, but it's especially true now that we have all sorts of things encumbering projects -- environmental impact statements, minority set-asides and other things that we didn't have before."
 
Don't Go for the Glitz
 The projects that make infrastructure seem sexy are large, like high-speed trains and a national "superhighway" for data, especially in the midst of a military slowdown that is throwing thousands of engineers out of work. "We should go for things like information highways and high-speed rail that have the potential of a commercial payoff and technological spinoff," Mr. Kuttner said.
But projects like bullet trains are precisely the ones about which many people have the most doubts. Recent history, here and abroad, is full of costly bloopers, from the Concorde to the Miami subway system. Enormously expensive projects like the data superhighway could be carried out by private enterprise, and more efficiently at that. And some, like bullet trains, probably should remain on the drawing board.
"Do we really need high-speed trains?" said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "There are several hundred jets collecting dust in the Mojave Desert because airlines don't have enough business to use them right now. Besides, if fiber-optic networks are successful, we won't need them to get to there from here. Instead of commuting by high-speed trains, we'll telecommute."
 
Do Focus on Maintenance
 There's solid evidence of a high payback for filling potholes and other mundane repairs -- in short, keeping the existing system running smoothly, therefore reducing wear and tear on vehicles and disruption to users. A C.B.O. study concluded that spending on such mundane work would produce by far the highest return to society of any kind of infrastructure spending; for each dollar invested, the annual payback would be 40 cents for some years.
 
Do Remove Impediments To Privatization
 Private involvement in the nation's infrastructure is no panacea, the experts say, but it could help by allowing private investment to help pay for construction and maintenance, and it could improve operating efficiency.
One priority, Mr. Hudgins said, is Federal guidelines that would allow for leasing or even selling airports. Some financially strapped cities -- Baltimore and Indianapolis -- are already looking into that possibility.
 
Do Charge Users the Full Cost of Infrastructure
 The problem that drives most Americans crazy is traffic snarls. Think of roads as a resource like oil or water. If they're free or heavily subsidized, people use more than they're willing to pay for, which is often the same thing as too much. That in turn exaggerates the need for yet more construction.
Right now, gasoline taxes discourage driving, but not in relation to the amount of congestion and wear and tear the driver causes. Mr. Winston and other transportation experts say one of the best ways to reduce automobile congestion is to charge a toll on the busiest roads that's highest in peak periods; the best way to address wear and tear is to charge heavier trucks more for use of a road. What makes this conceivable is that there's new technology -- involving sensors on the backs of license plates -- that eliminated the need for toll booths. Low-income drivers could get rebates just as has been suggested for the equally regressive gasoline tax.
Congestion pricing would be easiest to introduce at airports: make landing fees the highest at peak hours. Right now the most common method of assessing landing fees is by aircraft weight.
The net benefit of charging cars and planes for causing congestion is $15 billion, Mr. Winston said. And it doesn't involve any increase in capital spending.
 
Do Rely on State and Local Governments
 The lion's share of public infrastructure spending is done by state and local governments -- and most economists say that's the way it should be. Taxpayers get more for their money because they choose projects of greatest value to them.
The worst examples of excesses with Federal money involve urban mass transit. Cost-benefit studies, and experience, show that in all but the most densely populated cities, like New York, bus fleets are vastly cheaper and more efficient than rail systems. Yet Washington paid up to three quarters of the construction costs of rail systems in a dozen cities -- Miami and Buffalo among them -- that now operate at only a small fraction of their capacity.
What's more, any digging done on Federal projects is apt to be twice as expensive as it needs to be, said Stephen Moore at the Cato Institute, a conservative think tank in Washington. The 1933 Davis Bacon Act, for example, requires that workers on Federal construction projects be paid prevailing union wages. The law keeps contractors from competing on cost and inflates costs by a quarter, Mr. Moore said. If this and a slew of other regulations were scrapped, he claims, taxpayers could get twice as much construction for every tax dollar as now. Indeed, President Bush signed a waiver of Davis Bacon in the last days of his administration. Mr. Reich has announced that President Clinton has reversed the waiver.
 
Do Upgrade Existing Roads and Airports
 Taxpayers would get off more lightly if the Government insisted on stiffer standards in road construction, said Mr. Winston of Brookings, who calls current standards penny-wise and pound-foolish. Specifically, paving roads thicker would make them more durable, less easily damaged by truck traffic -- a principal source of wear and tear -- and cheaper to maintain. "That means that spending on roads should be reduced in the long run, not increased," said Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
The C.B.O. also found high returns from adding runways to congested airports. Mr. Winston said that if roads were paved thicker and more runways were built at existing airports -- at a cost to the Government of an extra $2 billion a year -- the total benefit to the nation would be $25 billion a year.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 31 - February 5

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Data, Data Everywhere -- but Not Many Jobs in Sight 

The latest employment numbers merely restated the theme that has run through all the economic chatter lately: As all the business cycles and indicators and sales data strut around the stage, job growth sits obstinately in the wings. In this very odd recovery, an awful lot of people will simply not get paychecks. Unemployment was indeed down in January, to 7.1 percent from 7.3 percent, but only because the number of people in the labor force fell. "Better, but still too high" was President Clinton's assessment of the rate, giving a strong sign that he will push ahead with his plan to spend some money to create jobs -- a plan he will announce on Feb. 17.
 
While the national job numbers were at least mixed, in the New York area they were unambiguously bad. New York City's rate, unadjusted for seasonal variations, was a dismal 13.4 percent, the highest in at least 25 years. In New York State, the rate stayed at a high 8.5 percent.

A Recovery That Will Stay Put
 
Yes, in the past year or so the economic rebounds seemed to flit away as soon as they were spotted. But this time -- jobs emphatically aside -- most signs point to a true recovery. All the data on recent performance smell like spring -- solid numbers on manufacturing, durable goods, home sales. And, most to the point, the Government's computer-powered crystal ball tells of truly bright days ahead: the index of leading indicators soared 1.9 percent in December, its third straight rise and the rosiest forecast in nearly 10 years. The economy "is beyond the recovery stage," said John R. Williams, a Bankers Trust economist.
 
The Other Side of the Sword
 
Another number came in surprisingly strong last week, but it harbored bad news, too. The 4 percent quarterly productivity rise was the highest since the early 70's, suggesting a mighty recovery. But look closely: High productivity means companies turn out goods with fewer workers; and those standing outside the gates can't buy a sandwich with statistics. And people with jobs aren't reaping the benefits, either; productivity gains haven't been passed on in higher wages. It is a double-edged sword. If the gains persist, though, jobs could follow.
 
Investors Hear the Music
 
Wall Street saw no shades of gray. "The best of all worlds," one money manager called it. "Interest rates down, business cycles recovering, inflation not a problem." Investors saw that same happy mix, sending stock prices roaring to record levels on Thursday and again on Friday. Everything seemed to fall in place: the reports on retail sales, factory orders, the rate cuts in Germany and Japan. The market's reasoning: with rates low, companies can more easily raise money to expand. Other stock indexes had already hit records. Last week, the Dow industrials, having been weighed down by the likes of G.M. and I.B.M., finally made their move, ending fully 4 percent higher for the week, at 3,442.14.
 
Now What, Mr. Clinton?
 
So with this embarrassment of rich numbers, where does a new President steer the ship? Still, still, toward job growth. A lot of numbers have been tossed around -- all the way from $15 billion to $60 billion -- as the exact amount needed. Alan Greenspan had given his much-needed blessing to $20 billion, but as more specifics fell into place, the figure crept up. Last week, President Clinton lobbed another number into the ring, telling governors and Congress he wants $31 billion, divided between tax breaks and spending to create jobs.
 
Jobs and the Trade Pact
 
One front of the job battle came into better focus. Unions and members of Congress predicted huge job losses from the North American Free Trade Agreement, while the Bush Administration cited the economic gains. But no Federal agency had done a full study of the economic impact until last week, when an International Trade Commission report contended that the pact would help overall American economic output and employment slightly. Some have argued for extensive renegotiation of the pact, but this independent evaluation gives them little ammunition.
 
The Family, Stupid
 
The battle lines on the family-leave bill have long been clear: George Bush said businesses would be hurt, while Democrats gave more weight to a worker's right to 12 weeks' unpaid leave to care for an infant or ill relative. Mr. Bush vetoed the bill twice. But the Democrats moved quickly to put their stamp on such matters, as Congress passed the bill easily and President Clinton signed it. The Republicans grumbled, though; Senator Bob Dole talked of "tens of thousands" of job losses.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japan Finally Cuts Rates . . .
 
Perhaps he couldn't quite say the words "weak economy." Instead, "a severe adjustment phase" is what Yasushi Mieno, the Bank of Japan's governor, called it. So severe, in fact, that last week the central bank finally yielded to world pressure and lowered its discount rate, to 2.5 percent from 3.25 percent, to try to give things a shove. The last time the rate was that low was in the late 80's, when Japan's economy was the wonder of the world. Pressure for a rate cut has risen with the arrival of the Clinton team, which is viewed as being tough on trade, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen welcomed the move.
 
 . . . And Germany Budges, Too
 
In Germany, the interest-rate pressures have a special cast, because of problems created by German unity and the strains as Europe tries for monetary union (page 13). The Bundesbank has kept rates high, fearing inflation, but last week the central bank lowered its Lombard rate by half a point, to 9 percent, in a surprise attempt to help the economy and silence critics. The action is also seen as a signal to trade unions to limit demands for pay raises.
 
Russia Battles Its Inflation
 
Inflation of 2 percent isn't bad -- unless, as in Russia, it's 2 percent a day. Boris Yeltsin knows things are bad, and in a speech on his 62d birthday on Monday -- in which he likened the nation's troubles to the bleakest days of the fight against the Nazis -- Russia's President called for national resolve. More specifically, Russia sharply raised prices for natural gas and phone calls but also nearly doubled minimum pensions. Meanwhile, the International Monetary Fund faulted Russia for letting inflation get out of control, saying it threatened the nation's fledgling democracy.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
At Chrysler, Contagious Success
 
How the fallen have become mighty again. A year ago, Chrysler was deep in Detroit's dumps, its shares selling for a feeble $12.50. But it's been an uphill ride ever since, as successful new models and strong profits have helped triple the stock's price. So Chrysler saw a chance to tuck away some cash, and ended with even more than it had hoped for. In the second-largest stock sale ever (second only to G.M., of course), it took in over $2 billion last week. The selling price, $38.75, was $2.50 above the target. The stock ended the week at $40.75. Half the proceeds will go straight to its underfunded pension fund. Standard & Poor's, liking what it saw, quickly raised Chrysler's debt rating.
 
G.M. Takes Some Big Lumps
 
But as Chrysler cruises, General Motors keeps hitting potholes. First it swallowed, in one accounting gulp, future retiree health costs. The charge against earnings was a whopper: $20.8 billion. G.M.'s expected '92 deficit of more than $23 billion wipes away a record set by I.B.M. just the week before. To top it off, S.&P. cut G.M.'s debt rating.
 
Even as the dismal numbers mounted, the auto maker's good name got a beating when a Georgia court held it responsible for a teen-ager's death in a G.M. pickup, saying the company had knowingly failed to fix a defective fuel-tank design. The huge award, over $100 million, may well be lowered, but the problem could haunt G.M.: many lawsuits are pending, and the Government may order a recall of 4.7 million pickups.
 
Good News for All: Sales Surge
 
So some in Detroit are up, and some are down, but a rising tide could lift them all. Last week auto makers reported a surge in sales to the best level in two years.
 
Leslie Fay's Loose-Fitting Data
 
"Something doesn't add up here," one Leslie Fay executive said. No, indeed. For reasons unknown, the people adding up numbers for the big apparel maker did some creative accounting, apparently inflating the value of inventories while lowering reported costs. The controller, Donald F. Kenia, came forward when the false data no longer fit under the rug, and was suspended. That left the directors' audit committee to untangle the mess, and new data could wipe out last year's profits. The stock lost more than a third of its value, and investors, having no intention of just licking their wounds, filed lawsuits.
 
Post's Savior May Not Add Up
 
It seemed at first that The New York Post had a solid savior and would survive intact, but the plot thickened as the week wore on. Doubts were raised about the net worth of the buyer, Steven Hoffenberg, because of what were called dubious accounting methods. Then word of other buyers arose, some perhaps in partnership with Mr. Hoffenberg. In the meantime, The Post's lifeblood started to drip away, as top editors and writers were lured to The Daily News.
 
American Express Tries Again
 
At American Express, chairmanship has its privileges, but they don't necessarily include keeping the job. Even after James D. Robinson 3d persuaded the board to keep him on, investors rebelled -- and were heard. So again the company stood behind a chairman for its new era; this time it was Richard M. Furlaud, a director who had backed Mr. Robinson. With Harvey Golub installed as chief executive, Mr. Furlaud presumably joins the ranks of chairmen who kibitz from the sidelines.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 25; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 829 words

HEADLINE: At Work;
The Family Leave Bargain

SERIES: Second of three articles on recent research in work-family issues.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
HERE are two facts of life: Babies are here to stay and so are women in the work force. Women now make up 46 percent of the American labor force. For the rest of the 1990's, some studies project, two out of three new workers will be female. By 2000, half the work force will be women, mostly of childbearing age. And four out of five women in the work force will probably have children during their working lives.
So managers may want to pull up their socks and read a second chapter in "Parental Leave and Productivity," a study released recently by the Families and Work Institute in New York. Like the institute's research on supervisors' attitudes toward leave reported on here last week, "The True Cost of Parental Leave" may offer some surprises to anyone who thinks family leaves are terminally disruptive and expensive. The message is particularly apt now that President Clinton has signed the family leave law. 
 The authors, Rebecca Marra and Judith Lindner, make their point pithily: Leaves don't cost as much as you think. They argue that managers who think leaves are too costly haven't considered the expense of the alternatives.
Using data gathered from supervisors at a high-tech company with generous leave policies, Ms. Marra and Ms. Lindner developed a "cost model" to help compare strategies for coping with a leave. Replacing a worker permanently, the most common managerial reaction to an employee's extended absence, is not necessarily the most effective. "Companies mostly don't think about how expensive it is to lose a person and to have all the additional costs of hiring and training," Ms. Lindner said. She and Ms. Marra found that providing liberal leave policies and covering the absence internally was statistically, at least, more cost-effective.
The result comes with several caveats and potential emendations. The model tries to account for many variables, among them type and length of leave; amount of planning time; the employee's job, age and performance; the size of the immediate work group and the supervisor's attitudes toward leave.
Variables, by definition, mean that conclusions can't be true for all places and all times. But the authors found that the cost of a leave "supported," as the authors say, by rerouting or reassigning work or simply letting it go, was on average 32 percent of a worker's annual salary -- 39 percent for management, 28 percent for nonmanagement. Replacing workers, according to data collected for an earlier study at the same company, was 150 percent of a manager's salary and 75 percent of a nonmanager's.
The researchers segmented the data to find out where most of the costs were -- or were not -- falling. The total cost of managing 70 percent of the leaves was 30 percent or less of the employee's annual salary. In 9 of 10 leaves, the total cost was less than 70 percent of a worker's annual salary, which, in the words of the report, means that "in almost all of the parental leaves studied, the total cost was lower than the average cost of replacing a nonmanagement employee."
As other researchers have found, planning is the key to making a leave go smoothly. The institute has said that employers, on average, have about five months' notice of a maternity leave. Ms. Marra and Ms. Lindner found little evidence to support the popular notion that free-ranging pregnancy hormones lower productivity and raise absentee rates. Often, au contraire.
This is not to say that leaves cause no blips. Managerial employees clearly cost more than nonmanagers. Small units are inconvenienced more than large. Pregnancies with complications can be costly. When women unexpectedly fail to return to work or leave shortly after returning, the company pays for the leave and the cost of the replacement.
AND the availability of leaves depends to some extent on the health of the company and of the economy. In the strip-mined employment environment of the 90's, companies may have less flexibility. "If a company has no fat whatsoever, if it's really trimmed down," Ms. Marra said, it can't just slide someone over from another assignment. "Maybe not everything gets done, but most things get done."
Small companies, recession or not, may never have as many options as large corporations. "But there may be some options they haven't thought of," Ms. Marra said.
Ms. Lindner said former employees or retirees might agree to work temporarily. "It's not good news, but a recession means that you may have a pool of people you may be able to hire back temporarily," she said.
Although it is probably fair to say that the two authors are philosophically committed to encouraging family-friendly corporate policies, their research is not meant to whitewash the difficulties. Their model, properly modified to the circumstances of a particular company, offers the possibility of a realistic prediction of leave costs. If it debunks a myth or two in the process, so much the better.

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
She Puts Up the Money for the Software Dreams

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
ANN WINBLAD, daughter of a high school football coach in rural Minnesota, recalls that her first toy was a stopwatch. It apparently set her up for a career marked by rapid achievement and precise timing. She became a computer programmer. In 1976, she started a software company, Open Systems, then sold it several years later "for a pile of money." She moved to California; worked as a consultant for Microsoft, Apple and I.B.M.; wrote a book on object-oriented programming, and co-founded Hummer Winblad Venture Partners in Emeryville, Calif.
With her partner, John Hummer, a former professional basketball player ("which makes our average height six feet," the diminutive Ms. Winblad notes), she is one of the leading venture capitalists in the computer software industry. 
 Question: What do you look for in a potential investment?
Answer: Just a few things. Who's running the company? Can they attract excellence? If you look at a company like Microsoft, one of the reasons they've been successful is they've been rigorous in their recruiting. They're very selective.
Second, we have to find market space where there's room, where there aren't significant competitors. Timing is everything, not just in life but in the software businesses as well. For example, Powersoft, one of our investments, has grown from zero to just over $20 million in just a year. Timing played a big part in their entry in the client-server environment.
Q: And strategy.
A: Building a software company is very much like playing the game of Risk. Your goal is to capture continents. You have to choose which one of your opponents you're going to use as a strategic partner, at least for a while.
Q: Alliances do seem to shift, don't they?
A: Right. You need to place your army, you need to claim your market space right away. You have to have a strategy and you have to keep an eye on not only your own strategy but also your partner's or your competitors' strategies.
We have to look for people who think like that. We're going to enter in the game of Risk with them, and they're actually going to be playing it. We're going to hand them the money to buy the board, and maybe finance their armies, but we're going to have to let them alone to play. Hopefully they won't get stuck in Australia and New Zealand, and they'll capture Asia.
I just learned how to play the game a few years ago and I often use it as a discussion point in asking people how they think. It takes more than cleverness to be a C.E.O. You have to be tough, you have to be smart, you have to think strategically, and you really have to understand the product space you're trying to claim. Positioning is key.
 
 
 
ANN L. WINBLAD
 Born: Nov. 1, 1950; Red Wing, Minn.
 
 Education: Bachelor's in mathematics and business, master's in international economics and education, College of St. Thomas, St. Paul.
 
 Drives: Mercedes 560 convertible, Jeep Cherokee
 
 Frequent-flier miles: "I've taken every vacation in the last four years without buying a ticket."
 
 Ideal escape: Safari
 
 Current reading: "Genius," by James Gleick
 
 Hobbies: Sports fan, reading, cycling
 
 PC: Macintosh

HEADLINE: STAMPS;
Common-Sense Advice For Novice Collectors

BYLINE: By Barth Healey

 BODY:
THE aggressive marketing by the United States Postal Service is evidently luring new collectors, but letters from readers indicate that many do not have a clue about how to develop their new hobby beyond buying stamps as they are issued.
A good way to start the transformation from accumulator to collector is with a new paperbound book from Dell, "Stamp Collecting: The Complete, Easy Guide to the World's Most Popular Hobby." (The immodesty of the title belies the stereotype of the deferential collector who studies philatelic minutiae in isolation.) 
 The author is Charles F. Adams, who answers the question, What is a stamp collection? most sensibly: "It's whatever you want it to be." The book is full of other common-sense advice, including a section on stamp albums that rightly warns of the frustrations that printed albums often cause because they seem to demand that a new collector acquire certain stamps to fill certain blank spaces.
Both new and experienced collectors can also use the APS Stamp Identifier, a slim booklet published by the American Philatelic Society with 45 pages of key words that appear on stamps. A new collector will recognize "Italia" as Italy but might stumble over "Pacchi Postali (with star and crescent)" as a key to a stamp from the former Italian colony of Somaliland. Also helpful are transliterations of Arabic, Chinese, Greek, Hebrew and Cyrillic alphabets.
Both books are available from the American Philatelic Society, P.O. Box 8000-N, State College, Pa. 16803. Mr. Adams's guide is $3.75; the identifier is $2.50, both postpaid.
 
From the United Nations

Continuing its emphasis on social issues, the United Nations put out a set of six stamps on Friday on the theme "Aging: Dignity and Participation." Last year was the 10th anniversary of the adoption of a United Nations convention on aging that calls for economic security and a chance for the elderly to participate fully in society.
Two stamps (valued at 29 cents and 52 cents) were issued in New York, two (50 centimes and 1.6 francs) in Geneva and two (5.5 schillings and 7 schillings) in Vienna.
Covers canceled on the first day of issue are available from the World Federation of United Nations Associations. The covers have a cachet showing the center panel of a quilt designed by Dink Siegel and sewn by Doreen Beck. The quilt, titled "Fantasy," is one of many original designs they have collaborated on.
The federation is also offering an 8 1/2-inch-by-11-inch print of the panel, in an edition of 500 signed copies. This print, like the dozens prepared by the federation over the years, raises money to promote United Nations activities. Each print is $70, postpaid, from the World Federation of United Nations Associations, Room DC1-1177, United Nations, N.Y. 10017.
The United Nations Postal Administration has also reorganized its marketing, focusing on a new publication, a 24-page booklet that describes new stamps and older ones that can still be bought by mail at face value. The booklet, to be published every two months, is available free from the U.N.P.A., Box 5900, Grand Central Station, New York 10163-9992.

HEADLINE: Don't Chip at Deficit With Social Security

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan is right to oppose the proposal for eliminating this year's Social Security cost of living adjustment as a component of the deficit-reducing package (front page, Jan. 31). 
 The proposal implies a regressive inflation tax on the elderly. Indeed, eliminating inflation adjustments in general is capricious, inequitable and affords a further dangerous invitation to use inflation to reduce the real value of Government debt. If Social Security recipients are to be singled out for sacrifice, this is the least equitable way. If it has to be done, far better to include more Social Security benefits of the well-to-do elderly in the income tax base.
Social Security should be seen as a contributory national insurance system and as such should be separated from the general budget. From time to time, adjustments must be made (as was the case in the 1980's) to keep the system self-sustaining, actuarially sound without burden on the general budget and to maintain equity between generations.
But to chip away at the system for the sake of budget deficit reduction will ultimately destroy confidence in and weaken the system. Its integrity should not be threatened by making it a vehicle for deficit reduction.
It is quite amazing how the Income tax is rarely mentioned as the best and most ready means of implementing President Clinton's aim of "shared sacrifice." Like no other tax, it spreads the burden of revenue increase in an equitable manner, whether by income class, region of the country or age group.
What should be the politically most acceptable tax has become the politically least acceptable because of an ideological distaste for even moderate progressivity over the upper income range.
 
PEGGY B. MUSGRAVE
Professor of Economics
University of California
Santa Cruz, Calif., Feb. 1, 1993

HEADLINE: Car Import Duty Can Only Hurt U.S. Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Before President Clinton backs the punitive duties on imported cars that American car manufacturers propose (front page, Jan. 26), he will presumably evaluate their impact on the American cost of living, job creation and the interest rate the Government has to pay to sell bonds -- the last an important part of the Federal budget. On all three counts, the news will be bad. 
 Americans still have the world's highest per capita income, adjusted for cost of living, well ahead of the Japanese and other, less open economies. But that relatively low cost of living depends on our open economy. Import duties raise the cost of living by raising the price of both imported and competing domestic goods.
If American car manufacturers have import duties, they can maximize profits by selling fewer and more expensive cars. American consumers are already paying $1 billion a year because of "voluntary" auto import restraints. The new duties would drive these costs up severalfold, to several hundred dollars a car or more for all cars.
Nor will the duties save jobs, unless only jobs at American car manufacturing plants are counted. Elsewhere, jobs will be lost. They will be lost in all the industries that depend on car sales, because the volume of cars sold will be lower. They will also be lost because American capital will be channeled into the less efficient American automobile industry, instead of more efficent, more rapidly growing industries, such as the high-tech industries where United States performance recently has been superior to that of other countries.
Last, the slowing of imports will raise the cost of financing the national debt, as well as all debts. All the dollars that foreign exporters make here and that are not spent on American goods and services -- in other words, the trade deficit dollars -- must find their way into the American capital market.
Thus the trade deficit has had the impact of channeling money into United States real estate, bonds and other assets. With less foreign money in the American market, demand for United States bonds will slacken. The price of bonds will go down, which is tantamount to the interest rate's going up. Just the opposite is needed to help balance the budget.
The auto industry proposals will not serve the American public, neither consumers, nor workers (except in the industry's own plants), nor taxpayers.
 
MICHAEL MAY
La Jolla, Calif., Jan. 26, 1993
 
The writer is research professor of engineering-economic systems at Stanford University, on leave at the University of California at San Diego.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1827 words

HEADLINE: A TOUGH SELL;
Better Days Muffle Clinton's Call for Sacrifice

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To economists, it makes no sense whatsoever. But in a perverse way, the rather good economic news these days may make it harder politically for President Clinton to ask Americans to tighten their belts for the sake of future prosperity.
Before the election, when the economy seemed dead in the water, when the unemployment rate was peaking, when Ross Perot was barking about how the economy was perched on the edge of a cliff, Mr. Clinton had no trouble campaigning for a fundamental change in direction. 
 But now, with the recession clearly over despite lingering joblessness, with businesses expanding and consumers' confidence jumping, with the outlook rosier than anyone could have foreseen a few months ago, the sense of urgency about changing course may be dissipating.
Mr. Clinton appears to be determined to get a handle on the budget deficit whatever the political cost, and his advisers have suggested how painful his long-term program might be: an energy tax that would strike at the pocketbooks of all Americans, especially the middle class, and new limits on retirement payments under Social Security.
Economists have no doubt that medicine this strong is needed to get control of the deficit. But it seems incomprehensible to some politicians that Mr. Clinton would entertain higher taxes on the middle class or go after the benefits of the elderly after he specifically promised in his campaign not to. That seems particularly true when times do not seem so bad.
The Government reported last week that the unemployment rate in January had reached its lowest level in a year -- 7.1 percent -- and that the main gauge for forecasting economic conditions six to nine months from now, the index of leading economic indicators, had registered its biggest monthly gain in 10 years in December. The economy in the last three months of 1992 grew more than in any calendar quarter since the end of the Reagan years.
Throughout the week, the President tried to focus attention on the economic and social policies that dominated the campaign last year. But practical politics kept colliding with economic reality.
"Since the election," Mr. Clinton told the staff of the Office of Management and Budget at a pep rally Wednesday, "we've learned even more about the difficulty of the budget." The nature of that difficulty, although he did not say so directly, is that the deficit cannot be brought under control as easily as Mr. Clinton had suggested during his campaign -- primarily by raising the taxes of the wealthy and improving the management of Government programs. In fact, to accomplish his goals, ordinary people must pay higher taxes, and popular programs must be cut.
The budget picture led to other clashes of economics and politics. Mr. Clinton told a conference of governors here that he was still serious about his promise to "end welfare as we know it," but behind the scenes, his staff acknowledged that truly changing welfare policy would be more expensive, more difficult technically and more divisive politically than the President let on.
 
Glad Tidings, Mostly
 On Capitol Hill, as Hillary Rodham Clinton was meeting with lawmakers about legislation to overhaul the medical-care system, Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, was warning others that the kind of health measures the Administration had been talking about would not save money in the short run.
And the President's advisers said his campaign promise to allow college students to work off their student loans by doing community service work would be fulfilled at first basically by a pilot project. Anything more would be too costly.
Mr. Clinton, who takes pride in his knowledge of economics and mastery of politics, assumed the same stance last week that he had during the campaign and the transition. He eagerly offered the good news about the tax cuts and new spending for public works and job training he hopes to put into effect this year to give the economy a quick stimulus. He talked about sacrifice generally, saying the pain of lowering the deficit must be borne evenly, but never mentioning the price to any particular person or group of people.
 
Fear as Motivator
 To most economists, emphasizing the stimulus and playing down deficit reduction is misguided. They see the budget deficit, now about $300 billion, as a crippling condition that left unattended will rob America's next generation of its birthright. By all Keynesian logic, they say, the time to attack the deficit is when times are good -- when tax increases and spending cuts can be weathered without sending the economy into a tailspin. They feel the positive economic news should strengthen the hand of the President, who has promised to try to cut the deficit almost in half by the end of his term.
Politicians see this through a different lens. When the economic picture is bleak, they say, their constituents are ready to do whatever it takes to turn matters around. But when people are back on their feet, it becomes harder to convince them of the need for new unpleasantness, be it higher taxes or lower benefits or cutbacks in favorite programs.
"Tough choices are better politics when the fear is urgent and not just abstract," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat.
James M. Ruvolo, a member of the Democratic National Committee and a former party chairman in Ohio, said Mr. Clinton could "no longer take it for granted that people know things are tough."
Economists and politicians also have different perspectives on the significance of the President's economic stimulus proposal, which could raise the deficit by as much as $30 billion this year before the deficit reduction package would take hold.
Some economists think a stimulus is unnecessary with the economy quite strong already and worry it would make the eventual reduction of the deficit all the more difficult. Others argue that a brief increase in deficit spending this year would give the economy the running start it needs to withstand austerity in the years ahead. But nearly all economists agree that the small stimulus being contemplated is not crucial one way or the other. A $30 billion stimulus in a $6 trillion economy is, after all, of the same magnitude as a $250 bonus for someone with a yearly salary of $50,000.
To politicians, though, it is not trivial at all. To them, stimulating the economy now is essential for two reasons: First, Mr. Clinton promised to do it, and unlike, say, a middle-class tax-cut, this is an easy promise to keep; second, the President can reward important Democratic constituents like mayors and governors by delivering public works projects to their communities and tax cuts to local manufacturers.
The saving grace for Mr. Clinton in reconciling the economic and political viewpoints may be that the jobs picture remains poor, despite the other positive economic data. High unemployment normally lingers after a recession is over. But this time, the economy stopped shrinking in March 1991, almost two years ago. The unemployment rate last month was still over 7 percent, and the number of private payroll jobs rose by only 106,000. That is twice last year's average monthly rate, but far below the normal rate of job growth at this stage of an economic recovery.
Adding to the psychology of the matter, almost every morning's paper brings news of another blue-chip company -- Sears, I.B.M., General Motors -- that is laying off tens of thousands of workers.
Economists may disregard the significance of campaign promises and favors for constituents. Politicians may care little about the new figures on durable goods or housing starts. But the importance of jobs -- more jobs, better jobs -- is something they both understand.
Mr. Clinton is advertising his stimulus program as primarily a way to create new jobs quickly. If he can sell painful deficit reduction measures as the price for guaranteeing jobs in the next century, economists and politicians alike may buy the pitch. And so may the American public.
 
WEEK THREE
Getting Organized, Or Not
 Government did march on last week, sometimes along the same lines that Bill Clinton had drawn in his campaign. Following are a few of the things, in addition to the economic plan, that preoccupied the Administration.
 
AWKWARD TRANSITION
Once more, President Clinton had to say, "I was greatly impressed with her as a lawyer and . . . I wish her well." He was talking about Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood of Manhattan, who was almost but not quite nominated to be Attorney General. In 1986, Judge Wood hired a baby sitter with an expired entry visa and, while no one said any law was broken -- the prohibition on hiring illegal aliens was not yet in effect -- she stepped aside under White House pressure with a reference to "the current political environment."
 
TRANSITION, CONT.
Another New Yorker, Andrew M. Cuomo, was appointed an assistant secretary at the Department of Housing and Urban Development; Mr. Cuomo, who builds housing for the homeless, was on the Clinton transition team.
R. James Woolsey was confirmed as Director of Central Intelligence.
 
BILLS TO SIGN
The President signed a bill, his first, and the first in what Democrats all around said would be a wave of legislation making up for the last 12 years. It was the long-in-coming, previously vetoed family leave act, guaranteeing workers up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for a newborn or a sick child, spouse or parent. Congress, having passed the measure twice before, did it again by votes of 265 to 163 in the House and 71 to 27 in the Senate. The issue of homosexuals in the military complicated things only briefly, when the Senate appended a statement on the matter.
 
BUDGETS TO CUT
Defense Secretary Les Aspin asked the military to sacrifice, directing the Pentagon to cut $14 billion in next year's spending plan. It was the first step in fulfilling Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to cut $60 billion more than Mr. Bush would by 1997. The Administration said it was also considering scaling back the space station and superconducting super collider.
 
FIGHTS TO SETTLE
The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, infuriated senior aides by overruling their decision to put off disciplining agents who broke bureau rules. Most had made personal use of official vehicles, which brings a 30-day suspension; Mr. Sessions, who did the same thing, was ordered to take lessons in proper use of his car. Administration officials, meanwhile, cannot help until they have an Attorney General.
 
NOT JUST VISITING
Hillary Rodham Clinton, in charge of coordinating the Administration's plans on health care, took her concerns to Capitol Hill, by herself. She met with the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, and with Senators Bob Dole, the minority leader, and John H. Chafee.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1733 words

HEADLINE: Clinton's Social Security Test: Selling Sacrifice to the Elderly

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The new ethos of Washington is supposed to be "shared sacrifice," but constituent groups are already mounting pre-emptive defenses. Probably none will be as formidable as Social Security recipients.
Selling sacrifice to the elderly, and the politicians who represent them, may be the first crucial test of President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan. 
 What was widely seen as an Administration trial balloon -- a proposal for a one-year freeze in Social Security cost-of-living increases -- has landed with a thud on Capitol Hill. President Clinton was bluntly told by Democratic senators that such a measure would exact an enormous political cost, perhaps even Democratic control of the Senate, Democrats on Capitol Hill say. In the House, early partisan skirmishing saw Republicans rising happily to the defense of a program that they were often accused of trying to plunder during the Reagan-Bush years.
"Social Security is unequivocally the one contract the country is overwhelmingly in favor of," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip. "I'm going to do everything I can to keep the Democrats from tampering with it." Recalling the elections of the 1980's when Democrats campaigned on the simple slogan, "Save Social Security, Vote Democratic," Mr. Gingrich added, "Tip O'Neill must think these folks have lost their minds."
 
Turning Up the Pressure
 The groups that lobby for retirees in Washington are talking of jammed switchboards, mass mailings, "800" number hotlines, and of sacrifice unfairly apportioned. "These entitlement programs like Social Security did not cause the deficit and therefore should not be used to resolve it," said Martha McSteen, a former Social Security commissioner who now heads the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare.
Despite Ms. McSteen's remarks, retirement benefits account for about a fourth of the Federal budget, and many in the Administration and Congress agree that cutting the deficit will be impossible if those benefits are left untouched.
The American Association of Retired Persons, which was holding its annual legislative meeting in Washington this week, sought and heard reassurances from an array of Congressional and Administration leaders that their concerns were understood. "I am a dues-paying, discount-seeking member of the A.A.R.P.," declared Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Subcommittee on Aging of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. "You didn't create the deficit, and I don't know why they look at you all the time to correct the deficit."
 
Who Will be Unscathed?
 But even as the retirees' lobby kicks into gear, and a freeze in benefits seems less likely, there is also a widespread recognition that it will be hard for any big group to emerge unscathed from the coming round of cuts and taxes. This is particularly true for the elderly, whose programs accounted for 28.3 percent of all Federal outlays in 1990, according to the House Ways and Means Committee. By contrast, programs benefiting children accounted for 5.2 percent, according to the House panel.
As a result, opponents of a benefits freeze are looking on another Administration proposal as a fallback position: raising the amount of Social Security benefits subject to taxation for higher-income retirees. "That's a perfectly legitimate subject to talk about," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a furious opponent of a benefits freeze, said in an interview on Friday. Some on Capitol Hiil even saw the mention of a possible freeze in cost-of-living adjustments as an early softening-up strategy to make the tax increase more attractive.
An analysis released this weekend by Families USA, a Washington advocacy group, said that nearly half of the money raised from a freeze would come from beneficiaries with incomes below $20,000 and an additional 33 percent from beneficiaries with incomes of $20,000 to $40,000. "Cutting the Social Security COLA socks it to the poorest of our grandparents," said Ron Pollack, executive director of the lobbying group.
 
Tax Increase Is Proposed
 The other proposal being circulated would raise taxes on benefits: Under current law, 50 percent of Social Security benefits are subject to income tax for retired individuals whose annual income exceeds $25,000 and for couples whose income exceeds $32,000. Raising that percentage to 85 is one possibility under discussion.
The analysis from Families USA said that 84 percent of the revenues raised from that proposal would come from beneficiaries with incomes over $40,000 a year. "It's a way of asking sacrifice from those who can afford it," Mr. Pollack said.
Still, no one underestimates the difficulty in making any adjustments affecting the Social Security program, which is known on Capitol Hill as the "third rail" of American politics, ready to deliver a lethal shock to the politician who touches it. It is one of the great success stories of American Government, a program credited with largely eliminating poverty among the elderly. It is also seen as an almost sacred covenant between the populace and the Government because, as a former Social Security Commissioner, Robert Ball, put it, "You get the benefits because of the work you do."
 
Political 'Holy Writ'
 Added to the popularity of the program, which crosses generational lines, is the unusual political clout of its beneficiaries. "It's sort of holy writ in politics that seniors carry political weight that far exceeds their numbers," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. "They pay more attention, they're more involved, and they're more likely to vote."
Twenty-one percent of the voters last November were 60 and older. Americans 65 and older are also more likely to consider themselves Democrats than other age groups.
Not surprisingly, Democrats often use Social Security as their magic bullet in Congressional elections, and the issue has become fiercely partisan. For example, in 1985 Senate Republicans, who were then in the majority, were hammered for advocating reductions in cost-of-living increases to cut the deficit. The Social Security issue in general was an important factor in their loss of Senate control the following year, as it had been in the Republicans' loss of 26 House seats in 1982.
In last year's Presidential campaign, Ross Perot's brisk call for deficit reduction ran into some highly skeptical questioning on the very issue of Social Security benefits for upper-income Americans. And former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, whose economic plan suggested that limiting social security benefits might be necessary because of the deficit, was attacked for that position in leaflets and television commercials across South Florida, where there are many retiree communities.
The attacks came from the Clinton campaign.
 
New Climate in Capital
 Despite all the reflexive politics as usual, senior citizen lobbyists are keenly aware that the climate is different in Washington these days. The deficit is getting a level of public and political attention that it has rarely received. As cuts are contemplated, some analysts argue that the Government has long short-changed its children and continues to do so at its peril; "generational inequities" are part of the quiet debate in policy circles here.
At the same time, there is still some private resentment among lawmakers about the health insurance program meant to protect older Americans from the high costs of catastrophic illnesses. It foundered in 1988, when retirees revolted over a surtax imposed on the most affluent 40 percent to pay for it.
Advocates for the elderly have a big stake in working with the Administration and the Democratic leadership on the new national health care plan.
In the end, many lawmakers say, the challenge for Mr. Clinton will be making every group feel that the sacrifice is really "shared." Representative Bob Wise, Democrat of West Virginia, said, "You've got to see everybody getting a nick taken out of them; everybody's going to have to be able to look at their neighbor and say, he got his hit too."
 
 
 
SOCIAL SECURITY'S BENEFITS AND BOOMERANGS: A CHRONOLOGY
1977: In the first big attempt to deal with potential insolvency in the Social Security program, Congress approves a bill intended to yield $227 billion over 10 years by increasing the payroll tax rate and sharply raising the level of wages that can be taxed.
1981: After the 1977 plan fails to shore up the system, Ronald Reagan's Administration proposes to trim Social Security by reducing benefits for early retirement, delaying the cost-of-living allowance and reducing benefit growth for future retirees. The proposals cause such an uproar that the Administration retreats and appoints a bipartisan study commission.
1982: President Reagan embraces a Senate Republican budget plan calling for $40 billion in unspecified Social Security savings over three years. That plan, too, quickly dies, but the issue rages through the fall elections.
1983: After almost two years of bitter political debate and inaction, Congress acts on the recommendations of the bipartisan commission and agrees to make fundamental changes in Social Security. The package raises the retirement age from 65 to 67 by the year 2027, delays cost-of-living increases for six months and increases payroll taxes for employers and employees.
1985: The Senate's majority Republicans agree with the White House to a broad deficit-reduction plan that includes freezing Social Security benefits for one year. The Senate adopts the proposal, 50 to 49. Two months later, President Reagan backs away after Democrats agree to higher military spending.
1988: Congress approves the Catastrophic Coverage Act intended to protect Medicare beneficiaries from financial ruin because of the high cost of acute illness. To finance it, beneficiaries are required to pay a flat monthly premium, and the wealthiest 40 percent a surtax on their income tax. Angered at having to pay for benefits many already receive as retirees, these beneficiaries inundate Congress with protests. Congress later votes to repeal the act.
January 1993: White House officials say President Clinton is considering a plan to cut back Social Security benefits.

HEADLINE: Looking for an Attorney General: The Search;
In Looking for Attorney General, Clinton Now Wants a Sure Thing

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Amid finger-pointing over their second failed effort at choosing an Attorney General, White House officials said today that they hoped to announce a new nominee quickly, possibly in the next two days.
President Clinton is now seeking an easily confirmable nominee, the officials said, and will not insist that the job go to a woman. 
 They said Mr. Clinton wanted to move fast, both for political reasons and for the practical concern that there is a leadership vacuum at the Justice Department at a critical time. Judicial nominations are at a standstill, major crime legislation is being drafted in Congress and the Federal law-enforcement budget is under attack by some Administration officials who want to cut spending.
 
Back for the Third Time
 Still stunned by the forced withdrawal of Judge Kimba M. Wood, who had employed an illegal alien as a baby sitter, although before it was illegal to do so, officials regrouped at the White House today to review their list of candidates for the third time. They were back where they were two weeks ago, when Zoe Baird, Mr. Clinton's first choice, was ordered to withdraw after it was disclosed that she had employed two illegal aliens for household work at a time when that had become against the law.
Seeking to publicly distance himself from the episode, Mr. Clinton did not mention Judge Wood in a radio address this morning.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said in an interview that there was nothing wrong with the selection process. "It's bad luck and it's unfortunate that it's almost impossible in a competitive environment to proceed with the process in absolute privacy," he said. "But the search and research process did its job."
The President "has not made a decision," Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "and is still considering several people and is going to announce his decision relatively soon."
 
Looking at Former Governor
 White House officials said former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia, a friend of Mr. Clinton when the two were members of the Democratic Leadership Council, was still in the running. One advantage of choosing him, they said, was that he had been among the finalists for United States Trade Representative and had already gone through initial background checks.
The officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, also said they had not ruled out Judge Patricia M. Wald of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. She had been Mr. Clinton's first choice for Attorney General but said she was not interested.
Others likely to be considered include Drew S. Days 3d, a law professor at Yale University; Diana Murphy, a Federal judge in Minneapolis, and Jamie S. Gorelick, president of the District of Columbia Bar Association.
 
A Candidate Is Culled
 Charles F. C. Ruff, a Washington lawyer who had once been viewed as a strong alternative, has been ruled out, officials said, because of questions involving his hiring of a maid. Mr. Ruff confirmed in an interview today that he had employed a woman once a week for the last eight or nine years but had not paid her Social Security taxes until the issue came up in Ms. Baird's confirmation hearings.
Asked if his actions were improper, Mr. Ruff, who said he has since paid about $3,300 in back taxes, replied, "That's for others to judge, I'm afraid."
White House officials said they were discouraged that the turn of events with the Attorney General search had put a pall over what had been a largely successful week for Mr. Clinton.
"The frustrating thing was that our legs were really getting underneath us," said one official closely involved in the selection process. "There was a sense we had a great week: the family leave bill, the economy was back in focus, the gays thing was behind us, and then this. To have the week end like this was just a bummer."
